webTitle: Best in hospital with pneumonia

fields.headline: Best in hospital with pneumonia
fields.trailText: George Best is in a Belfast hospital with pneumonia, though he was said yesterday afternoon by his father to be "improving". He may be detained for a week.
fields.body:
George Best is in a Belfast hospital with pneumonia, though he was said yesterday afternoon by his father to be "improving". He may be detained for a week.

Best, 54, was admitted to the Belfast City Hospital on Friday night after experiencing breathing difficulties. A hospital spokeswoman said yesterday that Best had requested no information be released about his condition.

But his father, Dickie, confirmed Best was suffering from pneumonia and that he had seen an improvement since Friday night. Last March Best was taken to hospital with liver problems and doctors advised him to stay off alcohol for ever.

Joe Royle has turned to a trio of foreign players in his attempt to keep Manchester City in the Premiership. He has signed the striker Egil Ostenstad on loan from Blackburn, while taking another Norwegian, Runar Berg, and the German Thomas Strunz on trial.

Ostenstad is on loan until the end of the season with a view to a permanent move. He is set to be in City's squad for Saturday's match with Tottenham.

Strunz, a German international, is available on a free transfer from Bayern Munich and Berg would cost around £500,000 from Venezia. Both are midfielders.

Blackburn have taken Eyal Berkovic on loan from Celtic for the rest of the season with Graeme Souness announcing the deal marks the end of his recruitment this campaign.

The midfielder will join Blackburn permanently only if they are promoted this season, in which case they will have to pay Celtic around £3.5m.

His agent Pinhas Zehavi claimed several Premiership clubs were interested in Berkovic but that he had chosen Blackburn because of his friendship with Souness.

webTitle: Barak concedes defeat

fields.headline: Barak concedes defeat
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak has congratulated Ariel Sharon on his election victory after exit polls gave him 59.5% of the votre compared to Barak's 40.4%.
fields.body:
Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak, who had staked his leadership on a failed bid to make peace with the Palestinians, has conceded defeat after exit polls projected an overwhelming win for hawkish challenger Ariel Sharon.

Barak said he had called Sharon to congratulate him, and a Sharon aide, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Sharon had proposed a government that would include Barak's Labor Party.

"We lost the battle but we will win the war," he told supporters.

At Sharon headquarters, jubilation broke out when the exit polls were announced by Israel's two main TV channels moments after the polls closed.

They projected that Sharon won 59.5 percent of the vote to Barak's 40.5 percent. The first official returns - about 4 percent of the vote, drawn from areas where Barak is strong - showed Sharon leading by a smaller margin: 52.2 percent to Barak's 47.7 percent, election officials reported.

Sharon's supporters at his campaign headquarters whistled, clapped and blew horns, waving blue-and-white banners as they awaited his arrival.

"The end of Oslo!" some shouted, referring to the interim peace accord that Sharon had always opposed.

Barak supporters were plunged into gloom. "It's a disaster for Israeli democracy and the Israeli people, because they totally want something Sharon is unable to deliver," said parliament member Yael Dayan.

At Barak headquarters, a few downcast young campaigners softly sang a line from the national anthem: "We have not yet given up hope."

In his speech to supporters, Barak himself sounded strong and upbeat even as he conceded defeat.

"The road we chose is the one and only true path," he said as backers, some teary-eyed, slowly waved blue-and-white Israeli flags. "The true path requires courage... and it is possible that the public is not fully ready for the painful truth. The truth will prevail."

In appearances earlier in the day, Sharon said he hoped to form an alliance with Barak's party. But Barak associates have so far rebuffed those advances.

The election was widely seen as a referendum on Mideast peacemaking, with the positions of the two candidates differing starkly.

The 72-year-old Sharon says he will not cede the Palestinians more territory or a foothold in Jerusalem. Barak had offered Palestinians a state encompassing most of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, together with a share of the contested city.

Palestinians had said beforehand they would work with whomever Israel elected, and repeated that after the exit polls were released.

"We respect the Israeli people's choice and we hope the peace process will continue," Nabil Abourdeneh, a top aide to Yasser Arafat, quoted the Palestinian leader as saying. However, Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat warned that Sharon's hardline views were a "recipe for war." For many Israelis, neither candidate was a satisfactory choice - and the depth of that frustration was driven home by what election officials called a historically low turnout, 62 percent. Traditionally, Israel's voting average is close to 80 percent, among the democratic world's highest.

Israeli Arabs, who account for 12.5 percent of the electorate and were a key source of support for Barak in 1999 elections, stayed home in droves. Furious at Barak over the fatal shooting of 13 Israeli Arabs by police during riots in October, most boycotted the vote.

Barak, 58, was forced into early elections after 19 turbulent months at the helm of an ever-fraying governing coalition. He had hoped to the end for a turnabout. "We're busy winning!" he told supporters in Tel Aviv as evening fell.

Israel clamped an election-day closure on the West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinians have already been under tight travel restrictions since the start of ferocious clashes that are now in their fifth month.

Palestinians declared a "day of rage" to coincide with the Israeli voting. Dozens of Palestinians were hurt in clashes with Israeli soldiers in the West Bank, Palestinians said.

For many Israelis, the driving force behind the choice was a sense of insecurity spawned by months of fighting. Although the great majority of the nearly 400 people killed have been Palestinians, Israelis have been badly rattled by bombings, drive-by shootings, abductions and ambushes that are seen as making increasing inroads into daily life.

And many Israelis simply could not stomach the fact that the outbreak of violence came on the heels of the most sweeping concessions offered the Palestinians by any Israeli leader: a state in 95 percent of the West Bank and virtually all of Gaza, and control of Arab neighborhoods of Jerusalem, claimed by both sides as their capital.

During the brief campaign - begun after Barak resigned eight weeks ago - the prime minister warned again and again that Sharon could plunge Israel into all-out war with the Palestinians, or even ignite a regional conflagration.

Sharon countered by saying that calm must be restored before any meaningful dialogue could occur, and that Barak's proffered concessions on territory and Jerusalem went too far.

For the first time in Israel's history, voters were choosing only a prime minister. No lawmakers' seats were at stake, so Tuesday's winner inherits the same sharply divided Knesset, or parliament.

Many analysts predicted it would be just as difficult for Sharon to form a stable government as it has been for Barak - and that his term in office could be even shorter.

In the West Bank town of Ramallah, demonstrators burned pictures of both Israeli candidates, but the harshest words were reserved for Sharon. One of the protesters, a 61-year-old Palestinian woman named Masada Mousa, asked: "Do you think any Palestinian expects the murderer Sharon to achieve peace?"

webTitle: Exit polls predict Sharon landslide

fields.headline: Exit polls predict Sharon landslide
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: Exit polls commissioned by Israel's two main TV channels both projected a Sharon win by an overwhelming margin of 59.5 percent  to 40.5 percent - about the same margin predicted in public opinion polls in the days and weeks before the vote.
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon has secured a projected landslide win over Ehud Barak, the prime minister whose peace hopes were dashed by some of the worst Israeli-Palestinian bloodletting in decades.

Exit polls commissioned by Israel's two main TV channels both projected a Sharon win by an overwhelming margin of 59.5 percent to 40.5 percent - about the same margin predicted in public opinion polls in the days and weeks before the vote.

Jubilation broke out at Sharon's headquarters in Tel Aviv, with supporters jumping and dancing with joy, waving Israeli flags as they awaited his triumphant arrival.

"The end of Oslo!" some shouted, referring to the interim peace accord that Sharon had always opposed.

Barak supporters were plunged into gloom. "It's a disaster for Israeli democracy and the Israeli people, because they totally want something Sharon is unable to deliver," said parliament member Yael Dayan.

At Barak headquarters, a few downcast young campaigners softly sang a line from the national anthem: "We have not yet given up hope."

Charting a new road map for Mideast peacemaking, Israelis appeared to have picked Sharon - a veteran hawk who refuses to cede the Palestinians more territory or a foothold in Jerusalem - over Barak, who offered Palestinians a state encompassing most of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, together with a share of the contested city.

Sharon says he does want to negotiate peace - but only after calm has been restored. For many Israelis, neither candidate was a satisfactory choice - and the depth of that frustration was driven home by what election officials called a historically low turnout, just over 60 percent.

Traditionally, Israel's voting average is close to 80 percent, among the democratic world's highest. Israeli Arabs, who were a key source of support for Barak in 1999 elections, stayed home in droves, dealing a final blow to the prime minister's already slim chances for pulling out a last-minute victory.

The 72-year-old Sharon, whose admirers regard him as a war hero and whose detractors fear him as a reckless military adventurist, had been overwhelmingly favored in pre-election opinion polls.

But Barak, forced into early elections after 19 turbulent months at the helm of an ever-fraying governing coalition, had hoped to the end for a turnabout.

"We're busy winning!" he told supporters in Tel Aviv as night fell.

Israel clamped an election-day closure on the West Bank and Gaza Strip, where Palestinians have already been under tight travel restrictions since the start of ferocious clashes that are now in their fifth month.

Palestinians declared a "day of rage" to coincide with the Israeli voting, but the violence - by recent standards - was relatively muted. At least 43 Palestinians were hurt in clashes with Israeli troops in the West Bank.

For many Israelis, the driving force behind the choice was a sense of insecurity spawned by months of fighting. Although the great majority of the nearly 400 people killed have been Palestinians, Israelis have been badly rattled by bombings, drive-by shootings, abductions and ambushes that are seen as making increasing inroads into daily life.

And many Israelis simply could not stomach the fact that the outbreak of violence came on the heels of the most sweeping concessions offered the Palestinians by any Israeli leader: a state in 95 percent of the West Bank and virtually all of Gaza, and control of Arab neighborhoods of Jerusalem, claimed by both sides as their capital.

In the course of the short campaign - triggered when Barak resigned eight weeks ago - the prime minister warned again and again that Sharon could plunge Israel into all-out war with the Palestinians, or even ignite a regional conflagration.

But Sharon countered by saying that calm must be restored before any meaningful dialogue can occur, and that Barak's proffered concessions on territory and Jerusalem went too far.

"To those who want security for the citizens of Israel - I will bring it," he told supporters Tuesday in the northern town of Kiryat Shemona, on the Lebanese border.

For the first time in Israel's history, voters were choosing only a prime minister, not a parliament. Because no lawmakers' seats were at stake, the winner in Tuesday's ballot inherits the same sharply divided Knesset, or parliament.

Many analysts predicted it would be just as difficult for Sharon to form a stable government as it has been for Barak - and that his term in office could be even shorter.

Sharon has said - and repeated Tuesday - that he wanted a broad-based coalition that could embrace Barak's Labor Party. It was not clear whether such an alliance could be forged, since Barak's and Sharon's positions on the Palestinians are so far apart.

Officially, Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority says it will work with any Israeli prime minister. But some of his top associates expressed deep misgivings.

"There's a lot of anger and bad memories among our people about Sharon," said top Palestinian negotiator Nabil Shaath.

An Israeli commission found Sharon indirectly responsible for the massacre of hundreds of Palestinian refugees in Beirut in 1982.

In the West Bank town of Ramallah, demonstrators burned pictures of both Israeli candidates, but the harshest words were reserved for Sharon. One of the protesters, a 61-year-old Palestinian woman named Masada Mousa, asked: "Do you think any Palestinian expects the murderer Sharon to achieve peace?"

webTitle: Full text of Jack Straw's speech

fields.headline: Full text of Jack Straw's speech
fields.trailText: An Effective Protection Regime for the Twenty-first Century
fields.body:
An Effective Protection Regime for the Twenty-first Century

Speech to IPPR, 6 February 2001

By the Home Secretary, Rt Hon Jack Straw MP

1.Ten days ago, I sat in Westminster Central Hall with the Prime Minister, the Prince of Wales and hundreds of others to mark the first UK Holocaust Memorial Day. On the fifty-sixth anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, it gave us cause to remember Europe's efforts in the war's aftermath to make sure that such suffering never took place again.

2.Those post-war efforts culminated in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, including a right to seek political asylum. The 1951 UN Convention on Refugees gave that right legal statement.

3.In this, the Convention's fiftieth anniversary year, we celebrate the right to asylum. The UK has a proud history of offering shelter to those fleeing persecution. We, the whole of the EU, USA and Canada, and many other countries around the world, are committed to maintaining that tradition and to meeting our obligations under the Convention.

4.Yet the Convention is no longer working as its framers intended.

5.The environment in which it is applied today is one that has changed almost out of all recognition from that of 1951. Numbers of asylum seekers have vastly increased.

6.As a result, the current system is failing many refugees, while at the same time putting huge pressure on receiving nations - not just Western states, but also developing countries which host large numbers of the world's displaced persons.

7.The time has therefore come for the Convention's signatories to re-examine its operation, with a view to making it work as it was intended - to relieve the suffering of genuine refugees.

The problem

8.The Convention was designed for an era when international flows of people were on a much smaller scale than they are today. Intercontinental travel was rare, difficult and expensive.

9.Fifty years on, the world has been transformed. New technology, global communications and cheap international travel have all contributed to a world where rapid, long-distance migration is a realistic option - and a widespread aspiration.

10.This is creating new pressures on every part of our immigration system - not least that part which deals with claims for asylum. In particular, thousands of would-be migrants are taking advantage of one aspect of the Convention - namely, that it places an obligation on States to consider any application for asylum made on their territory, however ill-founded.

11.The statistics speak for themselves. Whilst the potential for large-scale economic migration has expanded, so too the number of people affected by political upheaval has risen. Civil war and internal oppression continue to make conditions difficult in many countries. As a consequence, the number of displaced persons has increased massively.

12. Up until 1988, the UK received around 4,000 asylum applications a year. With the collapse of the Berlin Wall, and the Iron Curtain, the imploding of the economies of Eastern Europe, and civil and cross border wars in the Balkans, Iraq and Iran, Afghanistan, the Horn of Africa, and elsewhere, numbers rose ten fold in the space of three years. However, investment in staff and IT in the Home Office lagged badly behind this surge for a decade. In 2000, 76,000 applications were made and the majority of initial decisions taken during the year resulted in refusals of both asylum and exceptional leave. About 80% of appeals are unsuccessful. Other EU countries have also seen large increases in asylum applicants, many of whom do not qualify for any form of protection. Despite our increases, we remain 7th in the per capita league table.

13. And, since the Convention places no obligation on states to facilitate access to their territory for those in need of protection, many well founded refugees as well as those with no serious claim resort to people-smuggling and other methods of illegal entry in order to access the protection that they need.

14. Taken together, these two trends - of increasing economic migration, and increasing numbers of displaced persons - mean that we are faced with a situation where too much effort and resources are being expended on dealing with unfounded claims for asylum, and not enough on helping those in need of protection.

A way forward?

15. So how can we make the international protection regime work better?

16. First, let me repeat that the UK - and all other signatory States - must meet their basic obligations under the 1951 Convention. That obviously includes giving sanctuary to Convention refugees who arrive at our shores.

17. But our obligations go beyond that.

18. Refugees have a right to expect that their claims will be assessed quickly and fairly; and that they will be integrated into our society.

19. But refugees and the public also have a right to expect that there will be a quick and effective process in place for identifying those who make unfounded claims for asylum.

20. We have achieved a good deal in the last 12 months in striving to reach these goals. The backlog is down. Decisions are up. Applications are being processed more swiftly. We are taking positive action to help recognised refugees feel that they belong in their new home. All of us I hope recognise and appreciate the contribution which many refugees are making to our society, through their work and their culture.

21. We have worked hard to improve on our domestic processes over the last three and a half years. But we have also helped to lead a much more active European Union wide agenda, for what is a shared European problem. At the European Union Heads of State meeting in Tampere in 1999, the Member States committed themselves to building a Common European Asylum System.

22. The UK is at the forefront in driving forward European action in this area. Later this week, Barbara Roche and I will be in Stockholm for the informal meeting of EU justice and home affairs ministers. We will be focussing on asylum and on combating people smuggling and trafficking. I will use the meeting to call for real results by the end of this year on some of the key measures which will set up a Common European Asylum System - on asylum procedures, reception conditions for asylum seekers, and the replacement of the Dublin Convention.

Our EU partners are fully signed up to working with us to combat trafficking through the Western Balkans. We expect most of them to attend a planning meeting we are hosting in London next Monday.

24. And on Friday, the Prime Minister, the Foreign Secretary and I will be meeting our French opposite numbers in Cahors in France at the Franco-British Summit. We will use this meeting to press the case for enhanced co-operation between us to combat the problem of illegal immigration from France to the UK, including problems associated with the Eurostar service.

25. All this shows how we are working actively with our European partners to find solutions to the challenges we face.

28. It seems to me that the international community must, collectively, do at least three things better than it is doing now:

29. First, we must help the countries concerned to make conditions in the regions of origin better;

30. Second, we must make it easier for genuine refugees to access the protection regimes of Europe and other Western States, for example by making their journeys less hazardous;

31. Third, we must ensure that those who are not refugees are dissuaded from seeking to benefit unjustly from the terms of the 1951 Convention.

Conditions in regions of origin

34. Most refugees want nothing more than to return safely to their own country. They have the best chance of doing that if they are able to stay in safety and dignity in a place as close as possible to home, until such time as it is safe to go back.

Those in particularly need were given temporary protection in the UK and other EU member states as apart of the Kosovo Humanitarian Evacuation Programme. Co-ordinated joint action between EU Member States, UNHCR and other agencies meant that many evacuees did not have to flee hundreds of miles to find safety. They were able to return home when it was safe for them to do so and did not have to get embroiled with the criminal traffickers.

But those same countries give only $1 billion a year to UNHCR, the main provider of protection to the millions of displaced persons in the regions of origin.

37. Money is not a panacea, and I am not saying that more money spent in these areas would provide a miracle cure. But I am saying that the balance of effort is wrong.

38. The international community now needs to get together and consider what might be done to redress this imbalance. This is not something the UK can do alone. It is not even something which the EU can do by itself. Instead it requires both the funders and the funded to come together to discuss a way forward.

39. Action in the regions of origin will reduce the pressure on refugees to travel further afield in search of protection.

40. But I do not pretend that all such movement can be brought to an end. There remains the question of how refugees can reach safety in the developed world if help cannot be provided more locally.

Resettlement programme?

41. Some may say that the increased use of visas and the imposition of penalties on carriers is the main barrier preventing refugees from reaching safety, and that the answer is therefore to end these policies. I disagree.

42. Remove measures such as these and we risk an unacceptable rise in uncontrolled economic migration of people seeking to gain entry by making unfounded asylum claims. That would put intolerable pressure on our assessment processes and risk bringing the Convention into dispute.

43. Neither governments nor their publics within Europe and beyond would find this acceptable. We are all committed to the Convention and all wish to see it operate effectively. At the same time, we have a duty to operate immigration policies for the benefit of our communities.

44. So we need other ideas - ideas which enable us to consider asylum claims in the region of origin.

45. One option would be for the EU to set up a resettlement programme, under which an agreed number of refugees - and possibly others in need of protection - would be identified in their own regions and brought to the EU for resettlement. The European Commission has stated, in its November paper on a common EU asylum system, that it will be carrying out feasibility studies on such a programme.

46. I can see potential advantages in such a scheme. The Humanitarian Evacuation Programme from Kosovo I referred to earlier showed how a proactive and co-ordinated EU response could help address a serious protection crisis. That Programme provided temporary protection and gives some useful pointers as to how other programmes for resettlement could contribute to a more orderly and effective international protection system.

47. Equally, there are serious issues to consider such as the cost and scale of any programme, how those selected for resettlement would be allocated to individual Member States, and what the criteria for selection would be. In assessing this, the Commission can draw on the experiences of countries such as the USA, Canada and Australia. The UK will play a constructive part in the Commission's work.

48. It will also be necessary for the EU to fit any procedures for assessing asylum claims overseas into the wider picture. We need to ensure that such external procedures are matched by domestic EU procedures which deal with unfounded asylum claims more speedily than is the case at present. We would also want to see more applications lodged from overseas leading to fewer claims being made within the EU.

49. The aim of my speech in Lisbon was to highlight the inconsistencies and illogicalities in the current global system for the protection of refugees. The Commission Communication on Asylum rightly seeks to look at the asylum system as a whole. The UK will want to play a full part in the developing debate on all these ideas but it is clear that completing the reform of the domestic system will provide the essential platform from which more radical longer term ideas can be considered. Any moves towards the implementation of ideas for processing of claims overseas or substantial resettlement programmes will have to be in parallel with driving down the numbers of unfounded applications.

More effective domestic procedures for weak claims

50. This leads onto my third area: devising better ways of dealing with those who are not in need of protection but who seek to shelter under the umbrella of the Convention.

51. In so doing, these individuals do great damage to asylum systems. They overload the elaborate procedures we have for assessing asylum claims. They cause vast quantities of money to be expended on assessing unfounded claims which might be better spent in the regions of origin. And they can turn the public against genuine refugees.

52. There are two main ways of deterring misuse of this kind. The first is to process claims quickly. There is a range of measures which states can implement domestically to address this. However, there are collective measures which I believe could help.

53. For example, an EU or internationally-agreed list of safe countries or groups from which asylum applications would be ruled inadmissible or considered under a greatly accelerated process. More generally, the EU's development of common asylum policies should reduce the attractions of so-called "asylum shopping".

54. The second aspect of deterring unfounded claims is the prompt return of those found not to need protection. The integrity of any asylum process will be undermined if those who make unfounded claims are able to stay.

55. I therefore make no apology in highlighting this as a fundamental issue for any protection regime. Everyone who is concerned about the need for international protection should be in favour of an effective system for returning those who do not have such a need. One aspect of this is that countries must document and accept back their nationals who do not qualify for protection elsewhere. We are already working with our European partners to conclude Community readmission agreements with third countries.

56. EU States have their particular set of interests on protection issues. Other countries, many of whom provide shelter for the millions of displaced people, have their own set of interests, which might not all be the same as ours. But nor need they be incompatible - all countries have their part to play in meeting the burden of supporting refugees.

57. We need to get together so that we can understand each other's perspectives, and move on from there to identifying collective actions which will deliver the effective protection system we all want. UNHCR's global consultations provide us with an excellent opportunity for such a debate.

Conclusion

58. Most of us can agree that the international protection regime is not operating as well as it should. We need some radical thinking if we are to ensure that the principles of the 1951 Convention are to be applied effectively in the modern age.

59. With the EU looking to move towards a common asylum system, and with UNHCR holding its global consultations exercise, now is the time to have that debate and to find solutions.

60. Asylum is an international issue which requires an international response. And the UK is dedicated to playing its full part in trying to develop a better system of protection.

webTitle: Straw proposes asylum blacklist

fields.headline: Straw proposes asylum blacklist
fields.standfirst: Home secretary wants Geneva convention rewritten
fields.trailText: A list of countries and groups from which asylum applications would be "ruled inadmissible" should be drawn up to combat Europe's huge influx of refugees, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said today.
fields.body:
A list of countries and groups from which asylum applications would be "ruled inadmissible" should be drawn up to combat Europe's huge influx of refugees, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said today.

Giving a key speech on the future of asylum policy, Mr Straw said that certain refugees could either be pushed through a quicker asylum process to save money or excluded from applying altogether, provided the international community could agree to rewrite the 1951 UN convention of refugees.

Mr Straw said: "An EU or internationally agreed list of safe countries or groups from which asylum applications would be ruled inadmissible or considered under a greatly accelerated process ought to be on the agenda."

He set out the blueprint of an asylum system where people must apply for refugee status while they are still abroad, rather than after travelling to the UK.

Such a set-up could counter the problems of illegal immigration and people trafficking, but will cause an outcry from human rights groups who fearthat genuine refugees fleeing persecution could be denied their only chance of safety.

The proposals in Mr Straw's speech were immediately condemned as "dangerous" by some audience members at a left-wing think-tank conference on the future of asylum.

The home secretary added: "The UK will want to play a full part in the developing debate on all these ideas, but it is clear that completing the reform of the domestic system will provide the essential platform from which more radical longer-term ideas can be considered.

"Any moves towards the implementation of ideas for processing of claims overseas or substantial resettlement programmes will have to be in parallel with driving down the numbers of unfounded applications."

The toughening stance on asylum - part of a multi-pronged attack on the issue by the government this week - signals the important role the issue will play in the forthcoming general election.

Asylum applications reached an all-time high of more than 76,000 last year.

Mr Straw called for a wide-ranging revamp of the convention, which governs countries' responsibilities to asylum seekers.

He said: "Would-be migrants are taking advantage of one aspect of the convention - namely that it places an obligation on states to consider any application for asylum made on their territory, however ill-founded."

He continued: "The UK has a proud history of offering shelter to those fleeing persecution. Yet the convention is no longer working as its framers intended."

Addressing the conference called Modernising Asylum organised by the Institute for Public Policy Research at Lincoln's Inn Fields, central London, Mr Straw also backed the idea of a resettlement programme for refugees who would be identified in their own regions before being brought back to the EU and divided among member states by a quota system.

Elaborating on how the list of "safe countries" would be devised, he said it would be broken into three categories.

The first would include countries like the US or Canada, from where "no applications for asylum should be entertained", while the final category would feature oppressive states where asylum seekers would be considered automatically.

In the middle would be a group of countries - which he did not define but said would include China - where, "by agreed criteria, the presumption is that the application would be unfounded" if it was made in the receiving state.

Sarah Spencer, of the IPPR, said: "This proposal alarms me the most and I think it could be very dangerous.

"The volatility of a political situation on the ground can change so quickly, an EU list of so-called safe countries would always be out of date.

The chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality, Gurbux Singh, said: "I did not get the impression that the issues had been fully thought through and there were some real question marks about the practicality of what he was proposing.

"For example, I do not know whether the proposal to make assessments of asylum seekers in their own countries is actually workable."

webTitle: Mr Bean turned into cartoon

fields.headline: Mr Bean turned into cartoon
fields.trailText: 6.30pm: Rowan Atkinson's Mr Bean is to be launched as an animated cartoon series, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Rowan Atkinson's Mr Bean is to be launched as an animated cartoon series.

The comedian will be voicing the 26-part cartoon series. Richard Curtis, Mr Bean co-creator and writer of Notting Hill and the Vicar of Dibley, is also closely involved in the new project.

The star of the live-action series is being filmed for each new 30-minute show so the animators can replicate Atkinson's unique movements for the cartoon Mr Bean.

As with the original series, the animated version will have little dialogue.

Mr Bean will be joined by in the cartoon by faithful sidekick Teddy, evil landlady Mrs Wicket and her horrible one-eyed cat Scrapper.

"While the new series will remain entirely faithful to the original feel of Mr Bean, in animation we can do all sorts of things that I'm physically restricted from in live action," said Atkinson.

"It'll be Bean, but more so - visiting places we have never been able to reach before."

Claudia Lloyd is series-producing the show for Tiger Aspect Productions, with original Mr Bean lead writer Robin Driscoll heading the writing team on the animated version.

webTitle: Leader: London jams, but no one blames Ken

fields.headline: Where was Ken?
fields.standfirst:
London jams, but no one blames him

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: London jams, but no one blames him.
fields.body:
Londoners will not expect too much sympathy from their fellow Britons as they complain of their "day of commuter hell" yesterday. After a long winter of floods and railway chaos, many Britons will feel citizens of the capital have got off pretty lightly with a mere 12 hours of standstill on the underground. All the same, when London grinds to a halt the economy of the entire country is affected, so the frustrations of the capital are not completely parochial.

Who will those frustrations be directed towards? Who will drivers stuck on the M25 and commuters sardined into buses blame for their ordeal? And who will they curse when the rail unions strike again, on February 12 and 19?

The most obvious target might seem to be the unions themselves. But many passengers dislike the planned partial privatisation of the tube just as much as the protesters: few will damn the strikers when they share their grievance.

Perhaps Ken Livingstone will be next in line for blame: in any American city, it is the mayor who is first to feel the heat. But here too the usual rule does not quite apply. For most Londoners currently see the mayor as a champion on the same side as both commuters and the unions - pitted against a government bent on privatisation. For the moment that leaves Ken safe from attack. Few Londoners yesterday even demanded he work to ease the road congestion that inevitably comes when the tube shuts down - understanding, perhaps, that the mayor has all too little power to do anything.

That leaves the government. Despite John Prescott's admirable shift towards compromise on privatisation last week, it is Labour's policy which is still seen as the threat to the tube. As long as that continues, Mr Livingstone will be able to cast himself as solution rather than problem. But that cannot last forever: eventually Londoners will hold Ken responsible for what happens in the city - and blame him when things go wrong.

webTitle: Tories offer savings tax lure to voters

fields.headline: Tories offer savings tax lure to voters
fields.standfirst:
Pre-election battle stepped up as Hague widens plan to include middle income groups

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The Conservatives stepped up the pressure on Gordon Brown to woo the "grey power" electorate in next month's budget when they announced plans to scrap all income tax on the savings and dividends of 20m mainly older voters.
fields.body:
The Conservatives stepped up the pressure on Gordon Brown to woo the "grey power" electorate in next month's budget when they announced plans to scrap all income tax on the savings and dividends of 20m mainly older voters.

Labour immediately claimed the Tory plans will give only around £100 a year to most people affected, but will disproportionately benefit the better off, giving an average £1,500 to the top 10%, those with the biggest savings.

William Hague and Michael Portillo joined forces to unveil the £3bn proposal which went further than expected in exempting not just pensioners' savings and dividends but all such savings for lower and middle income groups.

It would leave only higher rate taxpayers - with incomes above £32,785 where the higher rate band currently starts - paying income tax on savings. The £2.3bn cost (plus £680m to abolish dividend taxes) will be found from £8bn savings on public spending, Mr Portillo said.

Though the Tory proposal would retain the 40% tax rate on savings, the effect of abolishing both the 22% standard rate of tax and the 10% starter rate for all savers would unavoidably mean larger net benefits to those with a high proportion of savings income.

They are typically self-employed people who have retired on capital assets rather than a conventional occupational pension.

Around 16m of the likely beneficiaries of the Tory scheme are non-pensioners, mostly on modest incomes. Around 4.7m are retired, mainly the better off.

The move, which the Conservative leader billed as a blow for "individual independence, institutional freedom and social responsibility", was endorsed as feasible by analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS). The plans reflect both Tory concern to win back older voters - who tend to vote in above-average numbers - and to encourage savings which have slipped by two-thirds as a share of national income since 1997.

The Tory plan would also end what Mr Portillo denounced as "one of the greatest injustices of the tax system" - that people who have saved out of taxed income are then taxed a second time on the income generated by their savings which have also been subjected to corporation tax.

Under the Tory scheme, a pensioner on the basic rate of tax with £10,000 invested in an ordinary building society account would benefit by £120 in the first year, rising to £740 if they kept their money in for five years. For someone with £20,000 in the bank, the gains would be £240 and £1,481 respectively.

webTitle: Move A-levels to spring, MPs urge

fields.headline: Move A-levels to spring, MPs urge
fields.standfirst:
Plan aims to improve access to Oxbridge for state pupils

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Universities should select students after their A-level and Scottish higher results have been published in an attempt to improve the chances of state school pupils getting into top institutions, MPs will say this week.
fields.body:
Universities should select students after their A-level and Scottish higher results have been published in an attempt to improve the chances of state school pupils getting into top institutions, MPs will say this week.

In a long-awaited report on widening access to university, to be released on Thursday, the Commons education select committee will argue for A-levels and highers to be taken in the spring. Students would then be selected in the summer, once their results were known.

Labour MPs supporting the majority report - a Liberal Democrat and two Tory members refused to sign up - believe that the move would help state school students to get into Oxford and Cambridge.

They were persuaded by evidence that the current system gave too much power to admissions tutors to award places to students who failed narrowly to reach their required grades. One Oxford don called it a "black art".

The MPs' report also calls for extra financial incentives to encourage universities to take on students from poor areas. The Higher Education Funding Council for England (HEFCE) gives institutions extra money from a £24m fund if they take on students from a postcode covering an area where university participation rates are lower than average. This premium of between £70 and £210 works out at roughly 5% extra per student. MPs want this increased to 20% - and eventually to 50%.

The proposals are likely to infuriate Oxbridge and lead to MPs being accused of unfair "positive discrimination".

The report recommends getting rid of the separate application form which applicants to Oxford and Cambridge are required to fill in.

"Why should we signal in the 21st century that these universities should be different?" one source supportive of the committee report said.

The report warns Oxbridge: "The college system should not be used as an excuse for inaction."

Some MPs believe collegiate independence has enabled the universities to shirk their responsibilities to encourage more applications from state schools. The universities flatly reject the claim.

The select committee began its controversial inquiry in the wake of the Laura Spence affair, when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, strongly criticised Magdalen College, Oxford, for refusing to select the state school student.

Miss Spence was rejected before she got the results of her A-levels in which she was awarded five As.

Barry Sheerman, chairman of the select committee, angered opposition MPs by refusing to allow specific reference to the Spence case. The majority report does not criticise Mr Brown - one of the main reasons why the two Tory members of the committee, Nick St Aubyn and Stephen O'Brien, have opposed it.

Last week Oxford University released figures showing it had accepted 42.2% of applicants from state schools and 41.7% of those from private schools.

Liberal Democrat Evan Harris, whose Oxford West and Abingdon seat includes the university, claimed this showed that it was leading the way on university access.

But the select committee has taken more account of figures produced by the millionaire philanthropist Peter Lampl that showed that more than 1,000 students from poorer areas were not winning the places at top universities to which their grades entitled them.

Mr Lampl, now an unpaid adviser to the HEFCE, supports delaying applications until results are known - as do the Local Government Association and the teaching unions.

The committee heard from Gerard McCrum, a former don at Hertford College, Oxford, who said that many students who narrowly missed the grades they were required to achieve were often given places anyway.

"If someone has not missed their target by too much they will say, 'Don't worry about that, you can come up anyway...' It is a black art."

Dr McCrum told the committee: "The head of college and the admissions tutor usually do it themselves.

"It all has to be done very quickly within hours in the middle of the long vacation so the people who are there - and it is usually the admissions tutor and the head of the college - usually decide that."

webTitle: Students condemn Warwick's plans for mandatory fees for computers

fields.headline: Students condemn Warwick's plans for mandatory fees for computers
fields.trailText: Student leaders have condemned plans by the University of Warwick to charge students mandatory fees for computers. Students starting degrees courses after 2003 could pay as much as £1,250 for leasing a computer for three years of undergraduate study.
fields.body:
Student leaders have condemned plans by the University of Warwick to charge students mandatory fees for computers. Students starting degrees courses after 2003 could pay as much as £1,250 for leasing a computer for three years of undergraduate study.

The Warwick Students' Union and the National Union of Students are preparing to campaign against the proposals which they say will see top-up fees being introduced by the 'back door'.

The proposal comes in a report just released by the university that sets out its 'e-strategy' for the coming years. The report summarises the findings of a working group chaired by Sir Brian Follett, the university's vice-chancellor.

Student leaders say this move that will significantly increase the debt burden of students and further reduce access to the university for the less well off, which has already been restricted since the introduction of tuition fees.

The NUS president, Owain James said: "The NUS is vigorously opposed to Warwick University's introduction of top-up fees by the back door. Clear evidence shows that not only is the existing system forcing thousands of students into great financial hardship and debt but is also deterring many people from even entering higher education. If Warwick are allowed to do this, with no doubt other universities following suit, then the current crisis in higher education can only intensify."

Meanwhile, the University of Warwick issued a statement saying that its new 'e-strategy' will ensure that all future students have access to laptop computing. The university says that there will be unmetered connection to the internet and intranet from all campus student bedrooms by 2001-2002.

The university is constructing a 'student portal' that will be the gateway to the university's web resources and services, through which students will register for courses and accommodation, and use electronic library resources.

"Warwick believes that it could, and should, ensure that 100% of its students should have access to a laptop and there should be no digital divide," the statement said.

The university added that students who cannot afford to the computers will be given "the assistance they need to have access to their own laptop".

webTitle: Bitter divisions over university access report

fields.headline: Bitter divisions over university access report
fields.trailText: The House of Commons education committee's inquiry into university access has sparked a bitter political row in Westminster.
fields.body:
The House of Commons education committee's inquiry into university access has sparked a bitter political row in Westminster.

The committee's main proposal is that universities should select students after their A-level and Scottish higher results have been published, so that state school pupils have a higher chance of getting into 'top' academic institutions.

But both the Conservative and Liberal Democrat MPs on the committee are holding separate confidential briefings tomorrow to unveil their own reports - before the committee's official report is published on Thursday.

While MPs on cross party committees usually vote to support a report's recommendations at the end of an inquiry, it is unusual for two alternative reports to appear. Tensions between the MPs have been growing as the expected general election draws closer.

Tory MPs Nick St Aubyn and Stephen O'Brien are enraged that the committee refused to condemn the comments made by the Chancellor Gordon Brown about Oxford University after it rejected the state pupil Laura Spence last year.

Brown sparked controversy when he accused the university of elitism. During one of the public hearings last year St Aubyn and Barry Sheerman, the Labour chair of the committee, rowed over whether Spence should be mentioned by name during the inquiry.

Liberal Democrat MP Evan Harris, meanwhile, has fallen out with the Labour committee members over their refusal to question the government's policy of charging fees and scrapping maintenance grants.

Labour MPs made up the majority of the committee's members.

"There is a fear from some members of the committee to criticise the government," said Dr Harris. "What's the point of a committee if it doesn't question the government? They are failing to discharge the function of a select committee."

Many universities meanwhile are likely to be disappointed with the committee's main recommendations which focus almost exclusively on efforts to enrol more highly qualified state school pupils into academic elite institutions. Many believe that the bigger social problem facing universities is to widen access for people who, up to now, have had no chance of getting on degree courses at all.

webTitle: Deciding where to study for an MBA

fields.headline: Pick a winner
fields.standfirst: Don't let course rankings blind you to what suits your needs best, advises Francis Beckett
fields.trailText: Don't let course rankings blind you to what suits your needs best, advises Francis Beckett
fields.body:
Deciding where to study for an MBA is not easy, and the wrong decision can cost you heavily. "There are now 1,500 credible business schools running MBA programmes worldwide, and probably as many more that are not credible," the Association of MBAs director general, Mike Jones, told the association's recent annual general meeting.

There are some obvious considerations. You need to avoid the cowboys, for a start. These include the South America-based "University of England and Wales" and the "University of Warwickshire," now closed, whose logo closely resembled that of Warwick University.

You need to be cautious about those that may not be cowboys but do not have the sort of reputation that reassures employers. The MBA, probably more than any other qualification, varies massively in its usefulness on the job market according to where you get it.

You could make sure you choose a course accredited by the Association of MBAs, but that still leaves 60-plus courses worldwide, 30-plus in the UK. So which one? You could look at the league tables. Business Week and US News and World Report produce internationally respected league tables, and in Britain the Financial Times ranking is probably the best known. But none can claim to be the last word, and they have recently come under heavy fire from business school academics. Each of them depends on a particular set of criteria, and another equally justifiable set of criteria will produce radically different results.

The position of a school in the Financial Times tables is determined by its performance in three broad areas: career progression from the MBA, measured by such factors as salary and international mobility; diversity of experience, judged by such factors as the percentage of international and women students; and research qualities.

This year's Financial Times rankings, published last month, revealed that, worldwide, Harvard Business School has been pushed into second place by Wharton, University of Pennsylvania; and Insead in France has pushed London Business School into second place in Europe. In Britain, London Business School is well ahead of the pack, with Oxford's Said Business School in second place.

But inside the business school world, the ranking produced by the academic management magazine Long Range Planning is causing at least as many ripples as the Financial Times. It's based on the business schools' published research, because the magazine's editor Professor Charles Baden-Fuller of City University Business School, believes: "The mission of business schools is not only to train managers and educate students, but is also to develop the ideas, theories and evidence that will reshape management practice in the future."

In contrast to the Financial Times, the magazine's list concludes that, in Europe, London Business School is top, still just ahead of Insead. Next comes Tel Aviv, in front of a clutch of UK schools: Warwick, Manchester and Cambridge's Judge Institute. About half of the top 45 schools were British, which is not surprising since Britain awards 10,000 MBAs a year, twice the number that the whole of the rest of Europe awards.

But Long Range Planning's criteria, too, have come under fire from other academics. Professor Bruce Lloyd, professor of strategic management at South Bank University, writes in the coming issue of Ambassador, the magazine of the Association of MBAs: "How far can the process of evaluation and assessment be left in the hands of academics . . . ? How far is publication in relatively obscure academic journals any measure of relevance to 'reshaping management practice in the future'? . . . How often do we read at the end of a detailed research paper that the analysis does not really give us any useful answers, but the case for doing further research is overwhelming?"

So how does the potential student make a choice, when the experts do not agree? Questions of time and cost will constrain the choice a little. A full-time London Business School MBA takes two years, whereas everywhere else in Britain the MBA takes one year - if you cannot afford two years off work and very high fees, you can forget about London Business School. If you need to work throughout and have limited money to spare, you will need to study part-time, or perhaps by distance learning: the market leaders in distance learning are the Open University Business School and Henley Management College.

If you are clear about which management discipline you wish to specialise in, Long Range Planning has produced separate rankings for three separate disciplines: finance, marketing and general management. If you wish to specialise in marketing, you might do best to go abroad, because in that subject, Insead comes top, and there are three Dutch business schools in the top seven, and only one (London Business School) from Britain.

In finance and in general management, London Business School comes top. Insead comes second in general management, but in finance it is beaten into sixth place by Tel Aviv, London School of Economics, Erasmus in the Netherlands, and City University Business School in London.

You need a business school that is well regarded. But rather than go for the top of the league tables, it is at least as important to look for the business school that suits you, with the specialisms you want, and with an atmosphere you like.

You could make sure you choose a course accredited by the Association of MBAs, but that still leaves 60-plus courses worldwide, 30-plus in the UK. So which one? You could look at the league tables. Business Week and US News and World Report produce internationally respected league tables, and in Britain the Financial Times ranking is probably the best known. But none can claim to be the last word, and they have recently come under heavy fire from business school academics. Each of them depends on a particular set of criteria, and another equally justifiable set of criteria will produce radically different results. The position of a school in the Financial Times tables is determined by its performance in three broad areas: career progression from the MBA, measured by such factors as salary and international mobility; diversity of experience, judged by such factors as the percentage of international and women students; and research qualities. This year's Financial Times rankings, published last month, revealed that, worldwide, Harvard Business School has been pushed into second place by Wharton, University of Pennsylvania; and Insead in France has pushed London Business School into second place in Europe. In Britain, London Business School is well ahead of the pack, with Oxford's Said Business School in second place. But inside the business school world, the ranking produced by the academic management magazine Long Range Planning is causing at least as many ripples as the Financial Times. It's based on the business schools' published research, because the magazine's editor Professor Charles Baden-Fuller of City University Business School, believes: "The mission of business schools is not only to train managers and educate students, but is also to develop the ideas, theories and evidence that will reshape management practice in the future." In contrast to the Financial Times, the magazine's list concludes that, in Europe, London Business School is top, still just ahead of Insead. Next comes Tel Aviv, in front of a clutch of UK schools: Warwick, Manchester and Cambridge's Judge Institute. About half of the top 45 schools were British, which is not surprising since Britain awards 10,000 MBAs a year, twice the number that the whole of the rest of Europe awards. But Long Range Planning's criteria, too, have come under fire from other academics. Professor Bruce Lloyd, professor of strategic management at South Bank University, writes in the coming issue of Ambassador, the magazine of the Association of MBAs: "How far can the process of evaluation and assessment be left in the hands of academics . . . ? How far is publication in relatively obscure academic journals any measure of relevance to 'reshaping management practice in the future'? . . . How often do we read at the end of a detailed research paper that the analysis does not really give us any useful answers, but the case for doing further research is overwhelming?" So how does the potential student make a choice, when the experts do not agree? Questions of time and cost will constrain the choice a little. A full-time London Business School MBA takes two years, whereas everywhere else in Britain the MBA takes one year - if you cannot afford two years off work and very high fees, you can forget about London Business School. If you need to work throughout and have limited money to spare, you will need to study part-time, or perhaps by distance learning: the market leaders in distance learning are the Open University Business School and Henley Management College. If you are clear about which management discipline you wish to specialise in, Long Range Planning has produced separate rankings for three separate disciplines: finance, marketing and general management. If you wish to specialise in marketing, you might do best to go abroad, because in that subject, Insead comes top, and there are three Dutch business schools in the top seven, and only one (London Business School) from Britain. In finance and in general management, London Business School comes top. Insead comes second in general management, but in finance it is beaten into sixth place by Tel Aviv, London School of Economics, Erasmus in the Netherlands, and City University Business School in London. You need a business school that is well regarded. But rather than go for the top of the league tables, it is at least as important to look for the business school that suits you, with the specialisms you want, and with an atmosphere you like.

webTitle: Higher browsing

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: meh
fields.body:
The third degree

 Baywatch hunk David Hasselhoff has withdrawnfrom the race to become student rector of Dundee University because he couldn't promise to attend more than once a year. Maybe it was the lack of warm beaches, or the criticism of Ross Kemp (EastEnders' Grant Mitchell) by Glasgow students for not fulfilling his duties - or did someone tell him that a previous Dundee rector Peter Ustinov once received a letter form an anxious parent addressed to "The Grand Rectum of Dundee"?

 Given that vice-chancellors often complain that managing academics is like herding cats, it's about time the "largely unexplored world of cat behaviour" should be investigated. Thanks to £250,000 from the charity Cats Protection, Rachel Casey yesterday took up a lectureship in feline behaviour and welfare at Southampton University with feline stress high on her agenda. Her credits include BBC1's Barking Mad, and Channel 4's Pet Rescue.

 The Commons education committee's inquiry into student drop-outs is a prime example of the problems . Last week, the number of witnesses in the room (five) outnumbered the MPs asking questions for almost the entire session. The rump of the committee was sceptical of the DfEE's triumphant spin on the news that student debt had trebled - "don't say debt, it's income" - and of the reasons why ministers waited until the report's plain-speaking author Claire Callender was out of the country before publishing it.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us at: donald.macleod@theguardian.com or lee.elliot-major@ theguardian.com

'Glass door' access

MPs are expected to call on universities to adopt more professional and transparent approaches to widening participation, when the House of Commons education employment committee publishes its report on university access this Thursday. But the MPs' inquiry into whether academic institutions are doing enough to open their doors to students from poorer backgrounds has been plagued by political differences. Tory MP Nick St Aubyn wanted the main report to criticise the chancellor, Gordon Brown, for his attack on Oxford University over its rejection of the state school sixth-former Laura Spence. Liberal Democrat MP Evan Harris, meanwhile, argued for more attention in the report on the government's introduction of maintenance grants. But they have agreed with the Labour MPs on the committee's 28 recommendations for universities and government.

Research news

Funding assured for 3as and 3bs

Medium-rated research departments in English universities will definitely receive grants after the next research assessment exercise even though the results are not yet known, funding chiefs announced last week. In an unprecedented step, the Higher Education Funding Council for England has said that departments rated 3a and 3b in the next assessment will receive block grants. It is the first time the council has committed itself to fund such departments before the results of the assessment are revealed. The council says that the level of grants to departments with lower ratings of 3a and 3b - which have some research of national reputation - will be decided after the RAE results are known at the end of the year.

Universe

Too dear and picky

Academic mothers who want to attend the annual meeting of the National Women's Studies Association say they are being shut out by a lack of adequate childcare and that the organisation should be setting an example. Association officers say they offer the best childcare they can find each year, but that the mothers are too picky and the arrangements they want too expensive.

Loans for Oz postgrads

Graduate students in Australia will become eligible for the same kind of loans as undergraduates as part of a A$3bn package to increase enrolments and improve research. Prime Minister John Howard said there would be loans for 250,000 graduate students, and 21,000 new undergraduate places would be created over the next five years.

webTitle: Hitting back at last week's attack on teaching quality assessments

fields.headline: Belief system
fields.standfirst: John Randall hits back at last week's attack on teaching quality assessments
fields.trailText: John Randall hits back at last week's attack on teaching quality assessments
fields.body:
Get your notepads out, and listen to our words of wisdom, said the financial wizards of Warwick. "But I've got an under-performing endowment policy and an Equitable Life pension" said one who listened. "Why should I believe an economist?"

Why indeed! Sadly, last week's broadside from the protesting professors serves only to show that economists can be as economical with the actualité as any politician. It's easy to set up a caricature and knock it down, to ignore inconvenient facts, and to clothe rhetoric in emotional language. But it is not best academic practice.

First, the caricature: £200,000 worth of staff time was claimed to have been expended. But on what? On demonstrating that the curriculum, teaching, learning and assessment were fit for their purpose. Any university that cares about its academic standards uses staff time constantly to monitor these things for itself, and should have little difficulty in satisfying Quality Assurance Agency reviewers that all is well. Surely we are not asked to believe that Warwick only worries about them when QAA comes visiting?

Then the facts ignored. "Nobody explains" that universities are judged against their own objectives, claimed the article. Oh yes we do! In Guardian Higher and the Sunday Times in 1999, in a paper sent to all universities, and in our evidence to the Education Select Committee, to name but a few.

The rhetoric of slander may spice up a story, but it misleads. A review is not an accusation of failure, but an opportunity to demonstrate success.

On one thing I can agree. The process of review they experienced is far from perfect. It is a process the QAA inherited from its predecessors. Because we know its limitations, we have been working with the academic community to design a better process, which is operating in Scotland now, and will be used throughout the UK from later this year. It will be less intrusive, and will not require a mountain of paper. It is based on clear standards, to aid comparability. A Warwick economist is amongst those who drafted the standard for economics.

What will not change is the need for independent verification of claims to provide a high quality service. As students and parents are asked to pay directly for higher education, they will want to know they are getting value for their money. The higher the fees, the greater will be the demand for impartial evidence of high standards.

The public is sceptical, and understandably so, about professional services of all kinds. They have been let down by medical experts, financial experts and safety experts. Working together, all of us in higher education must ensure they are not let down by academic experts. That means we must strive constantly to enhance the quality of provision and the standards of academic awards. Dissemination of good practice, through the review process, is an important part of this.

Enhancement alone is not enough. The Bristol surgeons, many financial advisers and the Railtrack safety engineers lost public confidence. Their professional reputations, and the standing of their institutions suffered. The Warwick professors are wrong to dismiss the promotion of public confidence as an expensive public relations exercise. Universities must maintain high standards, and the public must be confident they are doing so. Those who spend the public's money must retain the public's confidence. Write that down in your notebook, professor.

John Randall is chief executive at the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education

webTitle: Who is to blame when students drop out?

fields.headline: The feet that vote
fields.standfirst: When students drop out, it's usual to blame their personalities. So what about poor teaching or lousy living arrangements?  Tony Mooney asks
fields.trailText: When students drop out, it's usual to blame their personalities. So what about poor teaching or lousy living arrangements? Tony Mooney asks
fields.body:
Sam Yauner is part of a £200m-a-year problem. The 21-year-old dropped out of Sheffield Hallam University after one year and is now working happily in a pub chain.

Jolie Compton lasted four weeks before she had had enough of her anthropology course at Brunel.

Their reasons make uncomfortable reading for universities and for the members of the Commons select committee on education who are investigating keeping students in the sector. Why do more than one in six undergraduates give up courses early?

The committee heard that the cost to the taxpayer is an estimated £200m and there is also a human cost. Some studies suggest that 80% of dropouts occur in the first year, with 30% of all withdrawals in the first term. This is the time of year when university administrators will be wringing their hands wondering what they can do to stop the haemorrhage of students, and funds, from their institutions.

For years academic researchers have worked on the assumption that dropping out of college was analogous to suicide - students were more likely to withdraw if they failed to integrate into the university's social and academic worlds. But no one asked students themselves how they reached their decisions.

There has also been a tendency to blame the students, rather than challenge university practices or the growing lack of personal contact between students and their teachers.

Looking back, Sam feels that he became part of the stampede to get degrees without much thought. "I went to a private school and I never felt that I had any option but university. There was no pressure from my parents but there was pressure from the school. But I did feel that after my parents had spent such a lot of money on me I ought to repay them by getting a degree." Turned down for drama courses, he took a gap year teaching in South Africa and gained a place at Sheffield Hallam in international business studies and French.

On the social side things went well for Sam in Sheffield. He made a lot of good friends at the university and thought that the city was an exciting place to study. The turn-off was the quality of the teaching he received.

"After the small classes of private school I was not prepared for the lecture halls with about 200 other students in them," he reflects. "It was far too impersonal. Although we were in small groups of about 20 for seminars I had been so bored with the lectures that I couldn't be bothered to turn up for many of them. I thought of leaving during the year but soldiered on."

Sam thinks that he failed two out of the four units at the end of his first year. After a couple of catering jobs in Sheffield he now has a "brilliant" job in London at the Pitcher and Piano chain of bars. After six weeks as a barman he has been accepted for management training and has no thought of ever going back to university. "I get more satisfaction out of putting a smile on customers' faces than I ever would have getting 70% in an essay."

Jolie, who got good A-levels (AAC grades), also did a gap year, but the place she thought she had to study anthropology at her first-choice university did not materialise because of bureaucratic mistakes. She went to Brunel through clearing. "Anthropology was taught on the Uxbridge campus but I was given a room in a hall of residence on the Runnymede campus some 15 miles away. The people on this campus were mainly art and design students. There were only about 30 students studying at Uxbridge and only three studied anthropology."

According to Jolie the first week was a joke. She had to pay £60 to participate in freshers' week. This included a meal a day (if the food had not already been eaten), a small room with a "nightclub" in it and organised treasure hunts. The Runnymede had no cash point, no shop, one tiny bar.

A big disadvantage was transport. "The transport to Uxbridge was free but there were only three buses, at 8.00am, 11.00am and 1.00pm. So if you missed a bus you could end up paying £25 on a taxi to get to your lectures. There was only one bus back to Runnymede and this was at 6.00pm, so there was little chance of socialising on the site at which we were taught and where our friends were."

After persuading a doctor to write her a note outlining why she should be on the Uxbridge site, Jolie moved into a flat ten days after starting. Friendships had already formed and Jolie felt an outsider from the start. The breaking point came when she found that she was expected to do a four-year sandwich course, with her second year in industry. With her first year to be devoted to general social-science studies, Jolie felt that a two-year study of anthropology was not what she had been looking for and she left after about four weeks.

Jolie went back to study and is now in the second year of an anthropology course at Sussex, but has a huge debt because she is supporting herself. Yet she has had lucrative job offers through her contacts in Japan to become involved in IT recruitment.

Too much academic research on student dropouts in the past 25 years has focused on a model developed in the mid-1970s by Vincent Tinto of the Teachers College at Columbia University. His model is still dominant and suggests that student decisions to persist or drop out are influenced by their ability to integrate into a university's social and academic worlds: the more their involvement in these areas, the more likely they are to stay.

Ability and family background were seen as big factors, and personality differences were identified between persisters and dropouts. It would appear dropouts are more impulsive, lack deep emotional commitment to education and are unable to benefit from past experiences. And dropouts tend to be more unstable and anxious, overactive and restless. Tinto said social integration and participation in extracurricular activities were directly related to staying on. But recent research by academics at Nottingham Trent, Ulster and Paisley universities says "Tinto's model makes assumptions about how students reach dropout decisions, without ever consulting any students as to whether these assumptions hold true."

A key critic of the Tinto model is Mantz Yorke, professor of education at Liverpool John Moores University, author of a book on non-completion, who gave evidence to the select committee. Policy makers needed to take account of the 37% who said that financial problems were a moderate or considerable influence on their withdrawal, he said. These problems seem to be affecting working-class dropouts more than others.

Yorke thinks universities "should resist the temptation to blame the victim for poor performance." He told the select committee that universities needed to improve support for new students, especially those from families with little knowledge of higher education. It is quite possible, he says in his book, that "some changes will be found necessary in the chosen approach to teaching and learning, and that some way will need to be found to retain a component of personal contact between staff and students. The rethink of teaching and learning may well lead to radical rather than incremental change."

Leaving Early: undergraduate non-completion in HE, by Mantz Yorke, is published by Falmer Press.
