webTitle: A new book about the Irving trial is set to reignite the row about what history is

fields.headline: Facts to fight over
fields.standfirst: A new book about the Irving trial is set to reignite the row about what history is. Historians  Richard Evans and  Alun Munslow lock horns
fields.trailText: A new book about the Irving trial is set to reignite the row about what history is. Historians Richard Evans and Alun Munslow lock horns
fields.body:
The past 15 years or so have seen a sustained assault on the discipline of history. It has been mounted by poststructuralists who take their cue from linguistic theories that proclaim there is no consistent or logical relationship between language and the concepts to which it refers. Language, to quote one of them, is "an infinite play of significations". Moreover, we can only apprehend the world through language. Thus, in effect, nothing exists outside language.

Taken together these two theories imply that knowledge is created, not discovered. Every time we read a text, we reinvent it. Nobody who writes a text has a hope of controlling the ways in which it is read. Meaning is put into it by the reader, not by the writer.

In the face of such theories, the commonsense reaction is to kick a chair, or indeed kick a poststructuralist, and take the physical sensation as proof that something exists outside language. But - whatever the merits of this procedure - you can't do it in history, which no longer exists in a physical sense at all. What happened has to be reconstructed from the remains it has left behind, and most of these are texts of one kind or another.

A string of writers on the study of history has concluded that we can never know anything for sure about the past. The meaning of the historical documents we all rely on cannot be fixed by their authors.

Historians reinvent documents every time they read them. So we can't penetrate the veil of the document to any past reality behind it.

In the second half of the 1990s, the flaws in the poststructuralist position became apparent. I identified some in my book In Defence of History, published in 1997; others, such as Raymond Tallis, identified the theoretical illogicalities behind them. The self-contradictory nature of the poststructuralists' position became apparent when they launched a series of fierce attacks on my book. Many accused me of misreading or distorting what they had said. But how could such an accusation hold water if meaning was put into a text only by its reader and not by its writer?

In the end, poststructuralists appeared to believe in their ability to write texts in such a way as to impose strict limits on their interpretation. Moreover, they must also have believed that what they were saying was true, or why would they have said it? Yet their theories denied the existence of any kind of truth at all.

Language does bear some relation, however complex and mediated, to what it refers to - that, surely, was why it was invented. You can interpret texts in different ways, but the number of ways is restricted by the words that are in them. This point emerged with clarity in last year's libel action by David Irving against American historian Deborah Lipstadt, who had accused him of falsifying and distorting the historical record.

The High Court's judgment, delivered last April, found that Irving had indeed done this. He had added words to documents when he quoted them in his books. He had taken out sentences and paragraphs from sources he cited. He had transposed sentences in other sources so as to change their meaning. He had presented mistranslations of the original German in order to support his arguments. He had used at least one source he knew to be a forgery. He had failed to take a sufficiently critical attitude to some evidence and adopted an implausibly over-sceptical attitude to other evidence.

The High Court judgment was careful to point out that historians disagree widely on many matters of interpretation of issues such as the Holocaust. What was at issue was historians' ability to reconstruct past events, not the interpretations they put on them.

The task of reconstruction is difficult, and can only ever be carried out partially. We are dealing with matters of probability. In the case of the gas chambers at Auschwitz, whose existence Irving denied, the probability is overwhelming; in other matters less so. Historians have always admitted that we can only see the past "through a glass, darkly".

Most poststructuralists appear to think of themselves as on the left. But as the Irving case showed, the belief that all representations of the past are equally valid and equally unprovable does not just subvert comfortable "bourgeois" certainties. It can also disarm any attempt to criticise as untruthful the misrepresentation of past reality in the service of racist and anti-semitic ideology.

Richard J Evans is professor of modern history at Cambridge University. His book, In Defence of History, has been reissued by Granta with a lengthy, new afterword replying to his critics. His new book, Telling Lies About Hitler: History, the Holocaust and the David Irving Trial, will be published by Heinemann in March.

Over the years the practice of history has witnessed a good many shifts and turns. Since the 1960s, for example, the discipline has experienced a social science turn, a cliometric or statistics turn, a women's history turn, a cultural history turn and so on. These are not fads. Each has developed and still remains a vibrant way in which historians elect to study and write about change over time.

But, in this "history of history" one thing has apparently not changed. That is its epistemology. In other words, despite all these methodological developments and thematic innovations, the basic way historians "know" has remained fixed.

Despite the use of statistics and the new themes (society, women, gender, culture) there remain two immovable points in the historian's universe: empiricism and analysis. By empiricism is meant knowledge gained through the senses as we observe and experience life.

In the case of historians the assumption is that the reality of the past can be discovered through the observation of its traces - the evidence. By analysis is meant inference - the reasoned drawing of conclusions. As the product of the Enlightenment, the empirical-analytical model has become the epistemology for doing history.

However, since the 1960s, doubts about the empirical-analytical paradigm as the privileged route to knowing have emerged. This has not happened in history alone but in all the arts, humanities, social sciences and even the physical and life sciences. How can we be sure that the data and inference really do get us close to true meaning? How can we trust our sources - not because they are false or forgeries or missing, but because of the larger claims empiricism makes about our powers to find and represent their meaning accurately?

It is no abstract philosophical point: where does meaning come from in history? Is it the past itself or the historian as s/he narrates it, or both? This is the essence of the postmodern challenge, the turn toward the narrative-linguistic.

The narrative-linguistic turn in history continues to deploy the empirical-analytical model. But it does so self-consciously and in ways which, without denying the reality of the past or brushing aside the desire to get at meaning, extends the knowing process to include its representation, and the cognitive form we give to the past within our texts. The narrative-linguistic turn recognises that history, a literary activity, is self-consciously (and self-evidently) authored.

Postmodern historians thus ask many fresh questions. Is there only one story to the past, or several, and is it the past or the historian who provides them? Is history what happened or what historians tell us happened? If the latter, we must understand the telling process which is so essential to knowing. All these questions have to be addressed when we do history: to ignore them is to do only half the job.

The emphasis now is less on history as a process of objective discovery and report and instead more on more of an acceptance of its unavoidably fictive nature - that is, its literary constructedness.

By this I mean recognising the assumptions that underpin authorial activity in creating the text and which are already (in a pre-empirical sense) and necessarily brought to the historical field, often determining the selection of evidence and its most likely meaning. None of this is to deny the reality of the past or to become amoral or relativist or to slip into the denial of the data. It is, rather, to recognise that history is a complex linguistic process, and that the truth of the past cannot be revealed by the analysis of its traces alone.

In other words, the postmodern challenge extends the remit of history to include the historian's pre-narrative and pre-figurative assumptions and how we weave those assumptions into forms or strategies of narrative explanation.

In a very real sense the postmodern challenge forces us to face up to the highly complex question of how we can know truthful things about the past and what we, as moral beings, do as a result.

Alun Munslow is professor of history and historical theory at Staffordshire University and is UK editor of Rethinking History: The Journal of Theory and Practice.

webTitle: The implications for medical students of the Alder Hey hospital inquiry

fields.headline: Moral boost
fields.standfirst: Medical students have always studied bodies - living and dead. But the Alder Hey hospital inquiry highlights yet again that the ethical and physical must be learnt hand-in-hand.  Donald MacLeod reports from Newcastle's acclaimed medical school
fields.trailText: Medical students have always studied bodies - living and dead. But the Alder Hey hospital inquiry highlights yet again that the ethical and physical must be learnt hand-in-hand. Donald MacLeod reports from Newcastle's acclaimed medical school
fields.body:
Work hard, play hard and don't cry - that has long been the unofficial motto for medical schools. Young med students are exposed to gruesome, undignified sights and need to grow some defences. But are they toughened up too much in the process?

After the Alder Hey scandal a torrent of media criticism has blamed doctors' arrogance and insensitivity. The episode, coming after the inquiry into child deaths at Bristol Royal Infirmary, raises the question whether it is doctors' training that turns sensitive teenagers into unfeeling professionals, more concerned with research than the feelings of the bereaved.

Preparing to deal with a working life full of disease and death obviously requires a bit of toughening up. But few patients or relatives are in a mood to appreciate the crude - and cruel - black humour that many in the medical profession develop as a defence.

Labelling a comatose patient "NFN" (Normal For Norfolk) is not to everybody's taste. Less forgivable still was the nine-week-old foetus found at Liverpool University's Institute of Child Health with an entry "Inflated monster. Humpty Dumpty."

John Spencer, who oversees personal and professional development at Newcastle University's highly rated medical course, believes it is vital for students to reflect on their attitudes and reactions to what they encounter, as well as learning to diagnose diseases.

UK medical schools have been undergoing radical change, part involving a new stress on communication skills and ethical issues like confidentiality and obtaining informed consent. There is a lot less cutting up dead bodies, a lot more empathising.

But it will take a long time for changes to feed into busy hospitals when the current crop of students are practising and reaching senior positions, concedes Spencer: "I qualified 27 years ago and I had not one minute of formal teaching about communication or ethics." Nowadays, he says, informed consent is dealt with in a more sensitive way. "It's not bawled out from the bottom of the bed in an open ward." Consent is also sought by a senior doctor or a GP rather than a junior doctor.

But in the wake of Alder Hey, he adds, "it is going to be quite a challenge if we are required to be very explicit for a post-mortem examina tion. That is going to put people off."

For Spencer, the key issue at Alder Hey is that parents were not asked. He believes that people are willing to cooperate if they are treated in an adult way. "We involve patients in medical teaching. Students come and interview or examine them. The great majority are willing but they do like to be asked." When it comes to the living, one label for the warmer approach to patient consultations is ICE - ideas, concerns and expectations. Trainee doctors are now taught to ask patients what they think is wrong, their fears (could it be a brain tumour?) and what they expect to happen.

Spencer says the feedback from consultants is that recent graduates are vastly better at communicating and relating to patients than the previous generation.

But he admits that the hidden curriculum - what students pick up when they come into contact with practising doctors and consultants - is a tougher problem to crack than including a bit of empathy in the formal curriculum. "If what they see is doctors doing it differently and getting away with it, maybe they will think all this stuff we are teaching them is not important - you can get to the top of the profession and still be a bastard."

He adds: "We are always struggling to reconcile the harsh realities of busy practice, which is not just physically and intellectually demanding but emotionally demanding. We are trying to inculcate patient-centred methods of clinical practice and build in empathy from the start."

That involves taking the doctor's emotions seriously as well as the patient's or the relative's - something Spencer feels the profession has been bad at. He says students must be given a chance to talk and reflect about the things that have distressed them - the dying baby in intensive care, the Aids patient in the VD clinic.

"We do a lot about breaking bad news and talking to people who are dying and desperately ill, but there are deeply rooted problems. Doctors like to cure and heal and when you can't there is a tremendous feeling of failure. You are also confronting your own mortality - we try to get students to talk about that," said Spencer.

As host to the national learning and teaching centre for medicine, Newcastle promotes good practice around the country.

Kate Duffield, a fourth year Newcastle medic who chairs the BMA's medical students committee, thinks the new approach is working and students want more focus on ethics. "By far the majority of students go into medicine to help people. They are distressed by the recent events and don't want to be tarred with the same brush."

Of the qualified doctors she has seen in action, some communicate better than others, but Duffield insists that for every bad example she could point to an inspiring one.

The empathy that medical schools are now seeking to promote was conspicuously missing at Alder Hey and the result could be serious damage to medical research and teaching as relatives become less willing to consent to postmortem examinations and the retention of organs.

Jim Lowe, of Nottingham University medical school, warns that research is already being hampered because coroners and family doctors are becoming more reluctant to agree to the removal and retention of organs at postmortem. He dated a loss of confidence in the postmortem to the Bristol Royal Infirmary inquiry, when it was revealed children's hearts had not been returned for bur ial. Hospitals and medical schools are now anxious to win over a disgusted public. Philip Love, vice-chancellor of Liverpool University, which is closely tied to Alder Hey, issued an apology to relatives while trying to distance the university from the "quite appalling activities" attributed to pathologist Professor Dick van Velzen, who was on his academic staff.

Liverpool's collection had been used for detailed anatomical analyses of the development of the jaw and abnormalities such as cleft palate. "The true value of research collections may only be realised over a number of years. Such research collections are an essential basis of much research designed, following ethical approval, to improve human health or longevity of life," says Love.

Research can and is often done on very small amounts of tissue but when it comes to the more emotive issue of retaining a heart or a brain doctors have belatedly realised they have to make a case to relatives. Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children, which has about 2,000 hearts and 370 brains for teaching and research, said specific consent for hearts was introduced in 1992 and for brains in 1997.

Last week a statement from the hospital said: "We must emphasise that organs were and are retained only for decent motives - the better training of surgeons, and research into fatal and disabling diseases. For example, death rates from some congenital heart conditions have been dramatically reduced as a result of research done in the past 30 years."

Professor Tony Risdon, head of the histopathology department at Great Ormond Street, said advances in the way brains are "fixed" in formalin meant they could often be examined and then returned for burial. "We certainly treat the bodies with the respect they deserve."

But the need to gain full consent has drastically reduced the number of postmortems apart from those ordered by a coroner. The heart collection - only six have been retained since 1992 - shows examples of congenital deformities. This is invaluable, insists the hospital.

"It allows a surgeon to examine real, solid, three-dimensional examples of the particular problem on which he has to operate."

webTitle: Britain's shortage of skilled social scientists

fields.headline: Don't count on us
fields.standfirst: Oh dear, says Lee Elliot Major. Many of Britain's social scientists can't do their sums
fields.trailText: Oh dear, says Lee Elliot Major. Many of Britain's social scientists can't do their sums
fields.body:
Universities are failing to produce social scientists who can work well with numbers and statistics, a leading academic has warned.

In an unprecedented outburst, Dr Gordon Marshall, chief executive of the Economic and Social Research Council, says that the UK research community is facing a skills shortage crisis.

"It's clear that British universities and colleges are not producing quantitatively competent social scientists in sufficient numbers," says Marshall in the council's newsletter last week. The council may create a cadre of special research centres teaching scientists the latest numerical and statistical techniques.

The shortage of skilled number-crunchers is affecting disciplines across the social science spectrum, including criminology, sociology, economics, political science, social policy studies, social geography, education and management studies. Increasingly few graduates, meanwhile, are taking up studies in applied or theoretical social statistics. In terms of analytical brainpower, the UK is slipping behind its international competitors, particularly Scandinavia, the Netherlands, Germany, the central European states and the US.

It has always been a suspicion harboured by physical and biological scientists that social scientists are no good at numbers. The "hard" sciences were supposedly governed by the strictest statistical standards, while the "soft" sciences relied on the vagaries of qualitative studies and anectdotal evidence.

There is also growing demand for social scientists with statistical and computer-modelling skills. Whitehall departments, from the office of national statistics and the social exclusion unit to the Treasury and Home Office, are crying out for such talent as they try to develop govern ment policies grounded on sound evidence. (The cabinet minister for science, Stephen Byers, is not known for his mathematical acumen - he was famously unable to multiply 8 by 7 while explaining numeracy teaching when he was a junior education minister.)

Ironically, the largest and richest datasets ever produced from social surveys are now available to academics. Research centres are forever searching for staff with statistical skills. Research projects are delayed. In subjects such as economics, academics able to analyse data are tempted away by more lucrative careers elsewhere.

"The growing shortage of quantitative expertise among young - and many established - researchers seems a problem with a complex aetiology," says Marshall, "and one therefore, for which there is no obvious single solution. Reversing the trend will almost certainly require a long-term joint effort by educational institutions, teaching professionals and funding agencies."

Some argue that the education system is failing to teach mathematical skills appropriately. The content of the curriculum and "informal cultures" of primary and secondary schools are blamed, as are modular courses at university, which allow students to choose easier options.

The council plans a full frontal assault on the problem. A systematic investigation will quantify the skills deficit in various disciplines and identify likely causes. Guidelines for postgraduate training will demand that young researchers have substantial experience of a range of statistical techniques. A scheme for "cadet social scientists" is proposed which would provide training for graduates already working in government departments and agencies. There are calls to create research centres dedicated to quantitative skills training.

Marshall says the council must act now: "Failure to do so is likely to result in Britain falling further behind the rest of Europe, both in the provision of talented quantitative social researchers, and the ability to design public policy on a reliable evidence base."

Andrew Oswald, professor of economics at Warwick University, who recently co-authored a report on the demise of economics as a UK academic discipline, agrees that failure to act will mean countless opportunities lost

"Compared to the US, Britain is light years behind in its training of quantitative social scientists," he says. "Fast computers and huge random-sample surveys provide us with incredibly exciting opportunities for understanding the patterns insociety. In the future, it will be more important to have good social scientists than good natural scientists. Quantitative sociology is in principle the most exciting subject in the universe. fields.bodyText: Universities are failing to produce social scientists who can work well with numbers and statistics, a leading academic has warned. In an unprecedented outburst, Dr Gordon Marshall, chief executive of the Economic and Social Research Council, says that the UK research community is facing a skills shortage crisis. "It's clear that British universities and colleges are not producing quantitatively competent social scientists in sufficient numbers," says Marshall in the council's newsletter last week. The council may create a cadre of special research centres teaching scientists the latest numerical and statistical techniques. The shortage of skilled number-crunchers is affecting disciplines across the social science spectrum, including criminology, sociology, economics, political science, social policy studies, social geography, education and management studies. Increasingly few graduates, meanwhile, are taking up studies in applied or theoretical social statistics. In terms of analytical brainpower, the UK is slipping behind its international competitors, particularly Scandinavia, the Netherlands, Germany, the central European states and the US. It has always been a suspicion harboured by physical and biological scientists that social scientists are no good at numbers. The "hard" sciences were supposedly governed by the strictest statistical standards, while the "soft" sciences relied on the vagaries of qualitative studies and anectdotal evidence. There is also growing demand for social scientists with statistical and computer-modelling skills. Whitehall departments, from the office of national statistics and the social exclusion unit to the Treasury and Home Office, are crying out for such talent as they try to develop govern ment policies grounded on sound evidence. (The cabinet minister for science, Stephen Byers, is not known for his mathematical acumen - he was famously unable to multiply 8 by 7 while explaining numeracy teaching when he was a junior education minister.) Ironically, the largest and richest datasets ever produced from social surveys are now available to academics. Research centres are forever searching for staff with statistical skills. Research projects are delayed. In subjects such as economics, academics able to analyse data are tempted away by more lucrative careers elsewhere. "The growing shortage of quantitative expertise among young - and many established - researchers seems a problem with a complex aetiology," says Marshall, "and one therefore, for which there is no obvious single solution. Reversing the trend will almost certainly require a long-term joint effort by educational institutions, teaching professionals and funding agencies." Some argue that the education system is failing to teach mathematical skills appropriately. The content of the curriculum and "informal cultures" of primary and secondary schools are blamed, as are modular courses at university, which allow students to choose easier options. The council plans a full frontal assault on the problem. A systematic investigation will quantify the skills deficit in various disciplines and identify likely causes. Guidelines for postgraduate training will demand that young researchers have substantial experience of a range of statistical techniques. A scheme for "cadet social scientists" is proposed which would provide training for graduates already working in government departments and agencies. There are calls to create research centres dedicated to quantitative skills training. Marshall says the council must act now: "Failure to do so is likely to result in Britain falling further behind the rest of Europe, both in the provision of talented quantitative social researchers, and the ability to design public policy on a reliable evidence base." Andrew Oswald, professor of economics at Warwick University, who recently co-authored a report on the demise of economics as a UK academic discipline, agrees that failure to act will mean countless opportunities lost "Compared to the US, Britain is light years behind in its training of quantitative social scientists," he says. "Fast computers and huge random-sample surveys provide us with incredibly exciting opportunities for understanding the patterns insociety. In the future, it will be more important to have good social scientists than good natural scientists. Quantitative sociology is in principle the most exciting subject in the universe. People matter more than things."

webTitle: Internet link combats classroom shortage

fields.headline: Internet link combats classroom shortage
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Birmingham city council has drawn up plans for its pupils to receive lessons via internet video links as a way of coping with the teacher shortage.
fields.body:
Birmingham city council has drawn up plans for its pupils to receive lessons via internet video links as a way of coping with the teacher shortage.

The council hopes that existing hi-tech video conference equipment can be used to allow more than one class to be taught at a time.

The council stressed yesterday that that none of its schools was operating on a reduced working week, but timetables were being squeezed, and local agencies for temporary staff were clearly stretched.

It aims to ensure that no children have to be sent home, as has happened at three schools in other midlands authorities.

The authority is to issue guidance to schools, including instructions on setting up internet links between two classrooms fitted with cameras and microphones, so one teacher can cover both.

"This is not a question of replacing teachers," a council spokeswoman said. "It is a matter of using existing technology to maximum advantage."

She said the new technology was particularly appropriate for teaching languages and for activities such as debates.

The council is also urging former teachers to rejoin the profession.

The government yesterday announced the next step towards the classroom of the future, naming 12 local education authorities in England that have been awarded £10m to deliver education using state-of-the-art facilities in more than 30 pilot schemes.

In Cornwall, for example, a space-age mission control centre is being built in partnership with the National Space and Science Centre. Students will be able to learn how to fly a space mission using remote control, video conferencing and remote sensing.

Local authorities were invited to put forward their ideas after a discussion paper on the classroom of the future was published last June.

They were asked to take account of future developments in education, such as longer working days, and the huge projected increase in internet use.

webTitle: On the Web: Spanish | Florence Nightingale

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.trailText: Spanish | Florence Nightingale
fields.body:
Spanish

Sí España
www.DocuWeb.ca/SiSpain

Suitable for: teachers & KS5 pupils

An award-winning interactive information service from various Spanish embassies and the Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs. A very ambitious site that will eventually be available in four languages; it is still very much under construction.

Learn Spanish
www.assk.com/spanish/sp-menu.htm

Suitable for: KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

Detailed language-learning from the basics upwards at this colourful website. For someone who already speaks Spanish, there are some useful revision aids. But it's not user-friendly - you'd need a lot of patience to navigate with any ease.

Quia
www.quia.com/index.html

Suitable for: KS3 pupils & teachers

An excellent US site recommended by Edexcel exam board. Interactive exercises designed by teachers in many languages provide templates for designing your own exercises. For beginners.

BBC Online
www.bbc.co.uk/education/gcsebitesize/spanish/index.shtml

Suitable for: KS4 pupils & teachers

The best revision site around, offering revision help for GCSEs, Standard Grades or National Tests. Coverage of topic areas and exam techniques is especially good. A must.

An online tutorial
www.studyspanish.com/index.htm

Suitable for: KS3/4/5 pupils

This clearly laid-out site has extensive material on all aspects of Spanish. The site is supplemented by some good links to support sites and materials. Highly recommended.

Newspapers
www.elmundo.es
www.elpais.es
www.marca.es

Suitable for: KS5 pupils & teachers

Online newspapers are always recommended, especially at A-level, although there are areas here suitable for GCSE students.

Vocabulary Builder
home.earthlink.net/~mikcar

Suitable for: KS3 pupils

A colourful way to acquire new vocab, although pronunciation is with a South American accent that could confuse beginners.

Compiled by Emily Brearley and John Witney

Florence Nightingale

The Florence Nightingale Foundation
www.florence-nightingale-foundation.org.uk

Suitable for: Teachers

Select "History" for basic details and then select the link to the Florence Nightingale Museum, which has a detailed, illustrated account of her life including details of the Crimean War and the nursing school.

Avenging Angel
www.florence-nightingale-avenging-angel.co.uk

Suitable for: KS2 pupils & teachers

A useful site based on a book of the same title. Select "Florence's Statistics" to see a pie chart which Florence drew up to indicate the main causes of death in the military hospital (she is credited with inventing the pie chart).

Country Joe McDonald
www.countryjoe.com/nightingale

Suitable for: KS2 pupils & teachers

This unlikely source - Country Joe McDonald's tribute to Florence Nightingale - is one of the best sites on the subject, with well illustrated chronological details of Nightingale's life. See also links to more details of the Crimean war including a good map of where the Crimea is.

Spartacus
www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/Renightingale.htm

Suitable for: KS2 pupils & teachers

Includes a photograph and a good biography. The presentation is clear although there is a lot of text. Has many links to other sites, including those detailing the various diseases Nightingale would have treated.

Chronic Immunological and Neurological Diseases
www.geocities.com/CapitolHill/4277/nightingale.html

Suitable for: KS2

This site is not very extensive but includes a biography, which is fairly easy to read.

Agnes Scott College
www.scottlan.edu/lriddle/women/nitegale.htm

Suitable for: teachers

Includes a biography that both includes the better known aspects of Nightingale's life and also stresses her many other skills such as linguistics and maths. The information here would make useful background research for an assembly.

Compiled by Jim Merrett

webTitle: Book reviews

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Lindsey Fraser looks at If I Didn't Have Elbows, by Sandi Toksvig, and Duel, by David Grossman
fields.body:
If I Didn't Have Elbows, by Sandi Toksvig, illustrated by David Melling
(Zero to Ten, £4.99)

Age 6-10yrs

Subtitled "The Alternative Body Book", this colourful, witty and direct book looks at how all our internal organs are interdependent. Each double-page spread gives at least one result of not having a heart, lungs, blood or skin, and augments the information by looking at the way in which we and other species use those organs and functions. As a means of arousing a child's curiosity, the approach is imaginative, and there is potential for creative writing inspired by the various questions and scenarios posed by the book.

Duel, by David Grossman, translated by Betsy Rosenburg
(Bloomsbury, £4.99)

Age 11-15yrs

The Marsh Award was established to raise the profile of books written in languages other than English. We are poor at exploring such literature, although it is heartening to find Egmont and Orchard publishing strongly in this area. Duel, this year's winner, is short, touching and often comic. It has a distinctive accent, but this is a distinctive book. David, volunteering in an old people's home, finds himself in the midst of a long-standing row between two old men. This is a poignant reminder that strong feelings aren't the preserve of the young. Given years to stew, they emerge as unadulterated fury.

webTitle: School report: Millennium Wheel

fields.headline: School report
fields.standfirst: Millennium Wheel
fields.trailText: Millennium Wheel
fields.body:
Millennium Wheel Kit
(www.theconsortium.co.uk tel: 01225 771320)

Price £40 + Vat

Age/ability range 11+ yrs

The manufacturer says: "A topical and enjoyable vehicle for the development of both technological skills in the areas of mechanisms and structures and the key skills of problem solving, team-working and communication."

Paula Beasley, acting headteacher, Sts Joseph & Teresa Catholic School, Wells, Somerset, says:

"The product came as a kit with clear instructions. The idea was to build structures by inserting paper into pieces of dowelling. The great thing about it was that the children learnt how strong paper could be when linked to triangular shapes. The process helped to enhance their thinking and key skills.

"We used the kit with a mixed age group (years 4, 5 & 6) and this worked well, with the older ones helping the younger ones. The children made sections of the wheel in groups then came together to create the final structures, which were two 1.5m millennium wheels. They were very keen and enthusiastic for the entire length of the session (about three and a half hours).

"The wheel is on display and the children will be doing some writing around it. It will also feed into our rolling design and technology programme on making bridges."

Curriculum links

fields.headline: CD-rom reviews
fields.trailText: Clicker 4 | Macbeth
fields.body:
Clicker 4
(Crick Software, £90 + Vat (single user). Tel: 01604 671691, www.cricksoft.com)

Age 5-11

All literacy and special needs teachers should explore this program, with its structured environment allowing students to discuss texts and language. Children write into grids, and the completed sentence is then read back to them. Pictures and graphics can be imported into any grid. With planning, Clicker 4 can offer enhanced learning experiences both during the Literacy Hour and other writing exercises. Helpful links to the Crick website at www.clickergrids.com let teachers download many more resources. Easy to use and popular among pupils.

Macbeth
(BBC Shakespeare, £88.12 inc VAT, tel: 01937 541001)

Age 10+

The first part - the play - is presented interactively, allowing speedy cross-referencing. "Hotspots" are used to explain difficult language. The second part gives a life of Shakespeare, which helps students to see the play in context. Information is clearly categorised, which enables students to find what they want quickly. It is easy to use, has useful support materials and the spoken text helps introduce the play to special needs students. Although a little more video footage would be welcome, students and teachers alike have had real success with this program.

You can read full evaluations of these programs at www.teem.org.uk

webTitle: Teachers will refuse to pay subs to regulatory council, unions predict

fields.headline: Teachers will refuse to pay subs to regulatory council, unions predict
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Union leaders in England predicted last night that thousands of teachers would refuse to pay their subscription to the General Teaching Council, their new professional body.
fields.body:
Union leaders in England predicted last night that thousands of teachers would refuse to pay their subscription to the General Teaching Council, their new professional body.

Amid an escalating row between the unions and the council before a key meeting next Tuesday, general secretaries of the three main unions said they had been inundated with protests at the fee.

Under legislation, the GTC can make the fee compulsory when it is introduced in October. Ultimately it could deregister any teacher who refused to pay.

A spokeswoman for the council, chaired by the Labour peer and former film producer Lord Puttnam, said the fee would not be compulsory to start with. But unions believe that eventually the GTC will require it to be deducted from pay packets.

The council has been set up to promote and regulate the profession. All teachers in state schools will have to register, and they can be taken off for professional misconduct. The council will also advise the education secretary on teaching standards and development.

Talks are under way about the level of the fee, to be set at Tuesday's meeting. It is likely to be more than the £20 first predicted. One well-placed senior source said it would be about £26, but there are rumours - discounted by key figures at the council - that it will be £30.

Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said "thousands" of teachers would refuse to pay - a view taken by other unions. "People are suddenly waking up to the fact that they are having to pay for something that has yet to establish its credentials.

"There will be a considerable suspicion that teachers are being asked to pay for the running costs of what is a quango rather than a properly independent body."

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said that members were asked to accept a "pig in a poke". The NUT believes compulsory payment is still on the GTC agenda, and is arranging a meeting with other TUC teacher unions.

"What we want is for teachers to be able to make a decision about whether they want the GTC," Mr McAvoy said.

The 64-member council is made up of 25 elected teacher members, nine members appointed by the main teacher unions, 17 appointed by other representative bodies such as local councils, and 13 chosen by the education secretary.

At the root of the protest is an increasingly bitter private spat between union chiefs and the GTC leadership, headed by Lord Puttnam and Carol Adams, the chief executive.

The unions, although supportive on issues such as professional development, believe the council is trying to move into areas such as pay and conditions that are rightfully theirs. Senior council figures believe the union leaders have given their public support to having the council but are privately determined to see it fail.

"What they'll do is try to bleed it to death," one source said. "They are horrified that in three or four years the GTC will emerge as the group that does speak for all teachers."

Council sources also believe the protest is more to do with internal union politics than rank and file discontent.

The unions retort that they are responding to their members' views. They are angry that the GTC plans to "communicate the commitment and concerns of teachers", which they say is their role.

"The GTC is not supposed to be serving the individual interest," said Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers. "Claiming to be 'the voice of the profession' is ambitious, perhaps even arrogant, given the divergent views on many issues central to education which have raged for years."

Union leaders concede that work done in the council's early months on promoting professional development has been impressive.

A GTC spokeswoman said she was confident most teachers would agree to pay the fee. "We are happy that, by the power of argument and the benefits that will accrue to the profession, people will see it as in the best interests to ensure its independence.

"We will also be developing individual services for members, particularly in relation to our website, which we are investing in considerably."

webTitle: If you ask me...

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: Leading experts advise on your problems
fields.body:
If my child doesn't get a place in one of the good local primary schools, should I (a) move house; (b) accept a place at the 'bad' school but keep her on the waiting list for the 'good' one; (c) keep her in nursery until she's five in the hope that a place comes up later on?

I really sympathise, but I certainly wouldn't advise moving home: it's a very drastic decision, and there's no guarantee you'll get the school of your choice anyway. Keeping your daughter at nursery sounds like a good idea, but you've got to take into account the fact that your child's peer group will move out of nursery, and she'll find herself surrounded by younger children whom she doesn't know. What I'd advise is to look round as many schools as you can - in neighbouring boroughs as well - and apply to as many as possi ble. Then you'll hopefully get at least one offer you feel happy with, and you can always remain on the waiting list at your preferred school.

Valerie Taylor-Walker,
Admissions officer, Beatrix Potter School, an over-subscribed primary

Moving might be a solution - but it is quite drastic, and also if you wait until the stage you suggest, it will almost certainly be difficult to find a place when you move (because they'll have allocated all their places by then).

Putting her in one school with a view to moving her might work, but be aware that in the first year or two of primary, turnover isn't great.

Leaving your child in nursery might work, but you risk her losing out on a reception year, which is an important foundation stage. Your child isn't legally obliged to be in full-time education until the term after she's five, so that does give you some leeway - and you could always choose to home educate her after that.

Margaret McGowan
The Advisory Centre for Education

My first thought would be to question how you know this school really is dreadful. One thing you can look to, when they come out, is the added-value league tables - this will give you a far better indication than the existing tables as to whether the school is worth considering. If you do find yourself in the situation you envisage, my advice would be to keep your child in nursery. In general a nursery school will cater better for a child of this age group than a reception class, and you'll get more time to explore other options.

John Coe
The National Association of Primary Education

Coming next

For about two years I have missed a lot of school because of depression. Since I don't think I'm ready, I have decided not to do my GCSEs this year. I've found out that if I want to sit exams later I need to register with an examination centre, but I don't know how to get in touch with one. Can you offer any advice?

Do you have a problem with your childs education? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. Please send in your "problem" marked "If you ask me" to Guardian Education, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or fax them to 020 7239 9933 or e-mail to education.letters@theguardian.com

webTitle: the motives behind the government's 'money and morals' course

fields.headline: What can a minister teach a teenager about honesty?
fields.standfirst: Next month, the government will launch a 'money and morals' course for schoolchildren.  Maureen Freely questions its motives
fields.trailText: Next month, the government will launch a 'money and morals' course for schoolchildren. Maureen Freely questions its motives
fields.body:
He doesn't want to preach. He can't preach, because if he did, who would listen? But you'd have to admit Blunkett's job would be so much easier if only he could. The problem he is trying to tackle - well, nip in the bud, really, before it poisons us all - is an epidemic of dishonesty. Apparently, he has reason to believe that today's young people are having a very hard time telling the difference between right and wrong. Even worse, they seem to think you have to lie to get ahead!

Not to worry, though. The education department is determined to reach these poor benighted souls before it's too late. From September, children in state schools will be having instruction in citizenship, and one of the key modules will focus on ethics and integrity in the world of work.

Due to that annoying no-preaching rule, honesty instructors will be aiming to get their teaching points across through lively discussion. According to the Jewish Association of Business Ethics, which designed the course, this sort of instruction is better anyway, as it allows children to exercise and perhaps even strengthen their moral judgement. So, rather than tell children that it's wrong to engage in industrial spying or lie on their CVs, teachers will present them with imaginary dilemmas. A business associate offers you a week in Paris, courtesy of the Ritz. Is this a bribe or an act of kindness? A man is accused of using his influence to help an associate. He tells Mr Clean, his boss, that he did no such thing. But many of his colleagues are not convinced. Should he keep his job?

Excellent questions. If Aitken and Mandelson had been forced to study "money and morals" as schoolboys, who knows how different the world would be today? But - given that they are not the only people my age who've ever been economical with the truth - you have to ask who is going to teach this subject. And you have to wonder what conclusions the children will be taking away with them, if and when their instructors are not saints but venal types like you and me.

When I tested the idea out on a few teenagers from 14 to 17, their first response was, "Oh God, not another one. Don't we get enough lectures already?" When I told them that, this time at least, things were meant to be different, one said, "Well, they're lying. And I wouldn't say that was a very good start."

To prove the point, she described her citizenship module in PDM. "That's short for Personal Decision Making. Or pants, because it's totally useless. In PDM, they tell you that you can have your opinion, but if it's not the 'right' opinion, the teacher gives you a special look and says, 'Hmmm. Yes. That's an interesting perspective. But I don't agree with it.' Or even worse, she says, 'Hmmm. Yes. That's an interesting perspective. Does anyone else in the room agree with it?' Of course they can tell that she wants them to say she's right, and I'm wrong. So that's what they say."

According to Stephen Zimmerman, one of the architects of the scheme, children today "see many more moral grey areas than previous generations did." When I repeated his remark to my sample teenagers, they were insulted. "That's ridiculous," one said. "Of course young people know the difference between right and wrong, and they care a lot about it, too. You learn it by osmosis, from the people around you. Maybe not politicians, but the majority of people are moral. They get upset when they see something is wrong. Like that little girl Anna. We all knew that was wrong. We didn't need to have a teacher tell us, for God's sake!"

The wrong that bothers them most right now is this constant lecturing from teachers who don't practise what they teach. "We have this teacher we call Mr Scary," one told me. "He's always lecturing us about honesty and integrity. But then he uses spies to find out if we go out of bounds. And the computer engineer - he tells us not to swear, but then you see him when he's trying to repair something and he's swearing and actually using the F-word in front of us. If we were in a lesson and said that, oh my God, it would be the end of the world. But the worst one is our EFL teacher. That's short for Education for Life. Well! Let's sit back and see how long her life is going to last! She tells us not to smoke, and then you see her with all the other teachers, smoking in the bike shed."

"It's not like they got where they are by being honest all the time," one of the boys added. "Nobody can succeed in life unless they cheat a little bit. There are things like that in the news all the time. X bribes somebody not to tell something. You hear that and then you go to school and they tell you not to do it."

"Yeah, who do they think they are?" another girl fumed. "It really annoys me when they reveal some govern ment secret they've been holding for ages. Like beef is poisonous so don't eat it because people are dying of BSE and you say like, why couldn't you tell us ages ago?"

"And war," said another, "It simply makes no sense at all."

"And like, they tell us to be caring and stuff," said a third. "And then you go home and watch the news and the government is saying, yes we care about the third world debt, but those countries should still pay us back because we're the rich ones. It's the same with animal testing. How would they feel if someone five times bigger than you stuck a needle in you and then jammed you into a cage?"

She paused here to sigh, and then said, "That's what I feel like sometimes, in school. Just because they're bigger than us, we have to play along with them. It's such a farce. When they teach us honesty, I hope I have the courage to skive, or at least say what I think."

The others thought this would be disastrous, not to mention naive. "Sometimes, if you want them to like you, you have to tell a few lies."

But I don't agree with it.' Or even worse, she says, 'Hmmm. Yes. That's an interesting perspective. Does anyone else in the room agree with it?' Of course they can tell that she wants them to say she's right, and I'm wrong. So that's what they say." According to Stephen Zimmerman, one of the architects of the scheme, children today "see many more moral grey areas than previous generations did." When I repeated his remark to my sample teenagers, they were insulted. "That's ridiculous," one said. "Of course young people know the difference between right and wrong, and they care a lot about it, too. You learn it by osmosis, from the people around you. Maybe not politicians, but the majority of people are moral. They get upset when they see something is wrong. Like that little girl Anna. We all knew that was wrong. We didn't need to have a teacher tell us, for God's sake!" The wrong that bothers them most right now is this constant lecturing from teachers who don't practise what they teach. "We have this teacher we call Mr Scary," one told me. "He's always lecturing us about honesty and integrity. But then he uses spies to find out if we go out of bounds. And the computer engineer - he tells us not to swear, but then you see him when he's trying to repair something and he's swearing and actually using the F-word in front of us. If we were in a lesson and said that, oh my God, it would be the end of the world. But the worst one is our EFL teacher. That's short for Education for Life. Well! Let's sit back and see how long her life is going to last! She tells us not to smoke, and then you see her with all the other teachers, smoking in the bike shed." "It's not like they got where they are by being honest all the time," one of the boys added. "Nobody can succeed in life unless they cheat a little bit. There are things like that in the news all the time. X bribes somebody not to tell something. You hear that and then you go to school and they tell you not to do it." "Yeah, who do they think they are?" another girl fumed. "It really annoys me when they reveal some govern ment secret they've been holding for ages. Like beef is poisonous so don't eat it because people are dying of BSE and you say like, why couldn't you tell us ages ago?" "And war," said another, "It simply makes no sense at all." "And like, they tell us to be caring and stuff," said a third. "And then you go home and watch the news and the government is saying, yes we care about the third world debt, but those countries should still pay us back because we're the rich ones. It's the same with animal testing. How would they feel if someone five times bigger than you stuck a needle in you and then jammed you into a cage?" She paused here to sigh, and then said, "That's what I feel like sometimes, in school. Just because they're bigger than us, we have to play along with them. It's such a farce. When they teach us honesty, I hope I have the courage to skive, or at least say what I think." The others thought this would be disastrous, not to mention naive. "Sometimes, if you want them to like you, you have to tell a few lies."

webTitle: What the schools think of Ofsted's performance over the past year

fields.headline: Watching the detectives
fields.standfirst: Today Ofsted publishes its annual report on schools. But what do the schools think of Ofsted's performance over the past year?  Diane Taylor asks two headteachers for their verdict
fields.trailText: Today Ofsted publishes its annual report on schools. But what do the schools think of Ofsted's performance over the past year? Diane Taylor asks two headteachers for their verdict
fields.body:
Tetherdown Primary School, North London

Tetherdown consistently achieves good exam results and is over-subscribed. But mention "Ofsted inspection" to the school's headteacher, Evelyn Pittman, and you'll have her quaking in her boots.

"Teaching is a very intimate process," she explains, "and it can be hard to be observed. On weekdays during term-time primary teachers see the children in their class for more hours a day than their parents do. It's like a family."

Tetherdown received one of Ofsted's new two-day inspections for schools deemed to be performing well last September, just 15 months after Pittman had undergone a full Ofsted inspection at her previous school where she was acting head. Although the two-day inspection is less stressful for teachers than a full five-day one, she says, the burden on the head is the same.

"If the head does not have a clear and realistic view of the school and of how to address any weaknesses the whole thing goes down the pan.

"I was lucky both times with the team of inspectors the schools had; they were excoriatingly thorough but there was no other agenda and the inspections were clear and fair.

"The first report highlighted a couple of problems the school had but was very positive for me. They felt I had done very well as acting head at addressing those problems.

"The second inspection report commended the school and focused on a couple of areas we were already addressing, such as assessments. But it was harder to get a handle on than the first; the guidance about what to expect was vaguer about what was required."

The prospect of an inspection does provide a deadline for the school to get things done, and while the inspectors are on site everyone performs to the very best of their ability, but Pittman says it is impossible to suddenly paper over the cracks of a problem school with industrial quantities of educational Polyfilla and hope the inspectors won't notice. "That sort of poor leadership just gets found out," she says. When the inspectors finally left, the staff felt a sense of collective euphoria, but this high was closely followed by what Pittman calls POTS - Post-Ofsted Traumatic Syndrome.

"It's very stressful to go through all that and after the initial euphoria I hit rock bottom for a week or two. Other heads I've spoken to who also had good reports felt exactly the same. I keep saying I'll get out of teaching before the next one comes around, but who knows?

"On balance I would say that Ofsteds are a bit of a sledgehammer to crack a nut if a school is already genuinely self-evaluating.

"I think that the important thing for a school to do is to take charge of their own Ofsted. In the end Ofsted is what you make of it."

The verdict

Behaviour of the inspectors: Knowledgeable, shrewd, rigorous.

Quality of the written report: A fairly accurate picture, but raised no new, major issues.

Higher Side Community Comprehensive, Knowsley

"It's very stressful," says Chris Wilkinson, headteacher of Higher Side, which was inspected last February. "And it doesn't help schools with their overall development. The process is judgmental rather than developmental." While Wilkinson says that the process isn't all bad - his school's last two Ofsted reports have been good and have included constructive suggestions - he believes that there must be a better way of ensuring that schools run well and can keep on improving.

"The way schools are inspected at the moment is both cumbersome and very expensive. While it's nice to bask in the glory when you get a positive report, it doesn't actually help the school that much. The inspectors come, they inspect and then they go. Schools have that empty feeling of being left on their own. To be inspected and to be judged isn't really what schools need. Staff always look ill in the build-up to Ofsted."

Wilkinson suggests that an alternative model would be that used by Investors in People initiatives where people and organisations are assessed and supported on an ongoing basis. He believes that it is important for schools to receive support in the post-Ofsted period when they are implementing changes to the school as flagged up by the inspectors.

There are techniques that schools can use to make an Ofsted inspection a more positive experience than it might otherwise be, he says. "The trick is to work with the inspectors and use the process and the report as a tool for the school. And it's also important as a head to make sure that your staff don't peak too soon because the waiting part is often the worst."

Inspectors don't really see the school functioning as it normally does, believes Wilkinson. "It takes the first half of the week for everyone's nerves to settle down. And the absence of one or two key people at a crucial time can make an organisation very vulnerable."

But one group who seem to positively enjoy the experience are the pupils, says Wilkinson. "It's always amazed me how relaxed the children are," he says. "They like to show the inspectors what they can do, they tell the truth about the school and you see them having some quite animated conversations with the inspectors."

The verdict

Behaviour of the inspectors: Professional. We were lucky with the ones we got.

Quality of the written repor:t Constructive. Thorough.

webTitle: So you want to learn...embalming

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: ...embalming
fields.trailText: ...embalming
fields.body:
Malcolm? Yes, sweetums.

Look, we've been going out for six years. Six delicious years!

Thankyou, toadface . . . but you still won't tell me what you actually do . I don't want to bore you, sweetums.

Nonsense, I want to know. No, really, it's very dull.

Tell me or I'll never speak to you again. Oh, all right. I'm . . .

Yes? I'm an . . . embalmer .

How lovely! Do you know what an embalmer does?

It's something to do with interior design? Not exactly. I prepare dead bodies.

Oh! Um, how do you mean prepare? I prevent deterioration of the body and remove any distressing signs of death, minimising health risks to those who come into contact with the body.

Right. I see. The preservation process involves the injection of fluids into the body and washing it with germicidal soap, cutting the hair, shaving the men, applying cosmetics and, for the severely injured, using reconstructive materials such as wax and plaster of Paris.

Where do you do this, Malcolm? In a funeral director's operating room.

Heavy work, is it? You spend a lot of time leaning over, lifting, bending and manipulating bodies.

But you have help? Not necessarily. Embalming can be a solitary activity. In fact, if you don't combine it with funeral directing then you may not spend a great deal of time interacting with the living.

Doesn't sound like everybody's cup of tea. No. The squeamish need not apply. But embalmers should be sensitive to other people's feelings. They also need an eye for detail. An interest in anatomy would be an advantage, too.

How do you get in? I mean, to the job. You need to register with a tutor accredited by the British Institute of Embalmers (BIE). The training is modular, with a foundation module followed by five practical and theoretical modules set by the National Examinations Board of Embalmers (NEBE). Training is mainly on the job, with part-time tuition. Late entry is common and is easier than going in as a school leaver. New entrants may start as drivers or pallbearers. NVQs are available as recognition of your abilities.

And then what? Many embalmers are self-employed, working for several funeral directors. There tends to be low staff turnover and work may be hard to find. Vacancies are advertised in The Embalmer, published by the BIE.

webTitle: Furthermore

fields.headline: Education bored
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones wakes up to some shocking news on her bedroom wireless
fields.trailText: Janet Jones wakes up to some shocking news on her bedroom wireless
fields.body:
If you are reading this, there is a chance that you also listen to BBC Radio 4.

So you may have heard what I heard the other morning: further education got a mention on the Today show! It was at a prime-time spot, too. The time that everybody wants - immediately after the news on the hour. Prime ministers get out of the shower for the right moment on the Today show. There came those words "further education". They were loud and clear across the Jones bedroom from the radio's vantage point on top of the chest of drawers. Mr Jones did not hear them - he is tuned to other things. But I heard them and moved from part-listening to total-listening as fast as possible. After some time the interview sprang into hearing and thence into sense. You know those moments - when the brain does a spin and a twirl and gathers itself together and pounces. Something to do with Pavlov's dog and conditioning. My head even lifted itself off the pillow to try and support these early morning athletics.

"What?" I said to myself, Mr Jones being busy with his other things.

Further education? In the headlines? It was like seeing someone you know in the wrong place: the doctor buying aspirins in the chemist's or the chemist waiting in the surgery to consult the doctor.

Perhaps my college had been consumed by a local earthquake. Or an explosion. Or a fire. Or come under attack from a group of disaffected students. (Or staff.) Perhaps some of the staff had been arrested under suspicion of a spectacular scam - though it's hard to imagine what scam you could achieve in further education that would reach two minutes past the hour on the Today show. Mass murder?

Further education does not belong in the headlines. When did you last see or hear it there? What is it about further education that makes it so uncompelling and uncool? The name does not help: "further" suggests it is a very long way away but without the appeal of Mars or the moon. While "education" is a word that institutions usually try to avoid: School? Yes. University? Yes. Polytechnic? Yes. College? Yes. Nursery? OK. Even "learning". But "education"? Not as a name.

Another reason - though let's not get too serious - is that most of the participants in further education do not talk about further education at all. We talk about college. A sector that is not known by its name is in an odd position.

So why was further education getting a mention by its unknown name? I was agog.

The answer proved my point. Further education was being cited as the least exciting, least interesting, least attractive subject for a speech. The politician was explaining that if he had mentioned further education nobody would have heard him and he would not have been on the Today programme.

As it was, he had mentioned foxhunting and everybody wanted to talk to him. Later in the day, when we were in college and fleeing a brandished knife, I felt those foxes deserved their place in the nation's consciousness - and wished the deepest shadows of further education were as tame as the public perceive them to be.

webTitle: Colleges need more money to restore lecturers' pay

fields.headline: Give us more cash
fields.standfirst: Colleges still need a great deal more money to restore lecturers' pay, reports Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Colleges still need a great deal more money to restore lecturers' pay, reports Peter Kingston
fields.body:
College principals are demanding up to £200m more from government to ensure that they can bring lecturing staff pay back up to school teacher salary levels.

The call was made loud and clear to Baroness Blackstone, the education minister, and senior civil servants attending an Association of Colleges conference on pay, that the £150m government has offered for the next two years will not be enough to restore parity.

"We want a massive increase for year three," the AoC's chief executive David Gibson said after the meeting on Friday.

Three days earlier the lecturers' union Natfhe issued the employers with a pay claim for an immediate £3,000 flat-rate rise for all further education lecturers and managers, payable from this August "as a first step in a staged award".

In a letter to the association, Natfhe's general secretary Paul Mackney is also calling for "improvement over no more than four years to restore pay relativity with school teachers".

The Association of Colleges is well aware that if no deal is brokered with Natfhe by the end of the month, the union will ballot members to support a programme of industrial action beginning with a one-day strike on May 1 and probably escalating after that. Instructions have already gone out to branches from the union's Britannia Street headquarters in London's King's Cross to check membership lists.

The leadership is anxious to forestall the type of legal challenge which London Underground successfully mounted against the Rail, Maritime and Transport union last week.

At the association's conference, 330 principals and human resources managers were consulted for their views on its pay proposals. The association has proposed that staff "engaged with teaching and learning" should have access over the next two years, according to each college's priorities, within the agreed guidelines, to about £800-£1,000"

A further £800-£1,000 would reward teams or individuals demonstrating "commitment to raising standards and supporting others". In addition, an advanced lecturer paygrade would "recognise advanced practioners".

"The principals and heads of human resources departments were of a single view that their staff were essential to their success," David Gibson reported afterwards.

"They were committed to keeping staff and they believed that staff should have a significantly greater amount of money in salary.

"Our research shows that the average lecturer gets £22,000-£24,000. We think that is totally insufficient for good, committed, successful staff."

Since 1993 lecturers' pay had fallen between 10% and 35% behind their equivalents' salaries in school, he said.

The hard sticking point with the union is on performance-related pay. Natfhe has made clear it will not accept any whiff of it.

But Gibson said that part of the conference was taken up in trying to establish criteria for measuring the effect that staff have on widening participation, performance and student achievement.

He said anxiety was widespread at the conference that the £50m announced by ministers for September to March next year and the £100m earmarked to improve pay above the normal increase in the year following was going to fall far short of restoring parity.

"Some of the principals have only just started to do the reckoning and they are alarmed," Gibson said.

They told Blackstone and DfEE officials that between £150m and £200m would be needed in year three, and that it should be available to all sectors of staff.

Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, is due to announce the year three sum in March.

webTitle: Why Levi's don't want their jeans to be sold at Tescos

fields.headline: Jean genius
fields.standfirst: Tesco's staff training is second to none, but can they sell Levi's? By John Crace
fields.trailText: Tesco's staff training is second to none, but can they sell Levi's? By John Crace
fields.body:
When is a blue not a blue? When it's a Levi's blue. The clothing manufacturer, Levi Strauss, is currently involved in a lengthy court case at the European Court of Justice in Brussels to prevent Tesco from selling its jeans. The problem, Levi insists, is not that the supermarket undercuts the normal high street retail price by up to £20, but that Tesco's staff aren't trained to sell their products properly. So what training do sales assistants need to sell jeans, and how does it differ from normal retail training?

"Staff have to explain how one blue is different from another blue," said Mark Elliott, a Levi Strauss & Co's spokesman. "These things are important to jeans aficionados. Customers need advice on what's on offer and the difference between loose and baggy, straight and slim. We're not saying you need a university degree to sell jeans but if a person is cutting bacon and filling shelves one minute, it's not possible for them to sell jeans as well."

This will come as something of a surprise to anyone who has ever bought a pair of jeans from a clothes shop, where the prime qualification for a sales assistant often seems to be terminal and monosyllabic cool, and the specialist knowledge is limited to differentiating between flares and straight leg, zip or button fly, and waist size.

Mark Elliott's remarks may also come as a surprise to some of his own sales staff. A phone call to one of Levi's central London stores last week produced the following response. "We look to recruit people with some sales experience," said a member of staff, "but we do offer our own training in product knowledge and operating the till." So, is this product knowledge particularly demanding? "To be honest, no. We have about four or five concepts which shouldn't take anyone very long to get to grips with."

While each retail organisation may offer its own staff training, there is a national qualification - the Retail Operations NVQ level 2 - for sales assistants. The qualification, which is divided into 25 modules - varying from health and safety to display and product information - of which candidates are assessed on at least eight, is usually completed within six months. Staff are normally given two months to become acquainted with the products and then assessed in store over the next four.

"The NVQ level 2 is generic across the sector," says Margaret Barkway, City & Guilds chief verifier for distributive industries, "and is used in all types of retail environment. The specialised knowledge for someone selling jeans would centre around fit, fabric, leg-length and what age groups the particular styles are aimed at. It's hardly rocket science, but it is detailed."

A lecturer in retail at a further education college in the south of England, who prefers to remain anonymous, acknowledges that retail staff training does raise various issues. "For the NVQ level 2, staff are generally trained on the specific goods which they are selling by their line managers," she says, "and one could argue that if Tesco managers haven't themselves been trained on a particular product range then they won't have the necessary experience to train their staff. Levi is likely to have based their argument on issues such as displaying stock to attract customer interest and meeting customers needs for information and advice, as Tesco staff may not have the same levels of knowledge on product information and labelling as specialist clothing retailers and therefore may not be able to ask customers the right questions to ensure they go away with exactly what they want."

However, she concedes "When it comes to jeans, most people have a fair idea of what brand, style, fit and size they are looking for," she says, "so the role of the sales assistant may be less important than in other sectors."

For its part, Tesco is sure that it is more than capable of flogging Levi's. The company boasts a great record on staff training and has instituted its own gold, silver and bronze awards that it regards as an improvement on the NVQ level 2. It clearly regards Levi's court action as a smoke screen for price protection. "We don't think five minutes more training than our staff get justifies an extra £20 on the price and neither do our customers," said Simon Soffe, a Tesco spokesman.

webTitle: College Days: Petra Boynton

fields.headline: College Days
fields.standfirst: Petra Boynton
fields.trailText: Petra Boynton
fields.body:
Born April 24, 1970

Occupation Research fellow in psychology, University College London specialising in health, sex and gender. Only academic to have done research about the Daily Sport. Was Cosmopolitan magazine's woman of achievement 2000.

College Basingstoke College of Technology (BCOT) 1986-1988

Studied A-levels in English language & literature, psychology and sociology, GCSE Maths, O- and A-level in child psychology.

Her psychology tutor said "She was hardworking and extremely lively."

She says "I was asked to leave school at 16 and told I wasn't going anywhere. It was the college that got me to university and made all the difference to my life."
