webTitle: Rostrum

fields.headline: Adult matters
fields.standfirst: At last, studying for pleasure seems to be back on the agenda, says Alan Tuckett
fields.trailText: At last, studying for pleasure seems to be back on the agenda, says Alan Tuckett
fields.body:
Not all promises are broken. When David Blunkett met the newly appointed Fryer committee, not long after the last general election, he discussed the things he would like to be judged by at the end of the parliament. He made clear that he intended to make a difference to adult education - not just the kind of adult studies that lead to a qualification, or to promotion at work, but the kind that people do for pleasure, to add dignity and stimulus to life. In short, he was talking about the kind of adult education for which the local education authorities were responsible.

He said, memorably, that it takes a long time to turn round an oil tanker. You need patience, but above all you need a sense of where you want to go. It was a welcome message.

And, after a long wait, it seems to me that we now have the tanker pointing in the right direction, with three related government announcements on a single day last week. The first promised a 9% increase in local authority-secured adult education in 2002/3, building on an increase of more than 5% in the year about to start.

Second, the first ever national capital building programme for local authority adult education has been established for 2002/3. The £16m on offer won't build people's palaces of culture in every local community, but it is an important first step. It recognises that adults benefit from learning accommodation suited to their own needs. The third sum available this year makes up the losses in this year's standard spending allowance for those authorities that lost out in the transfer of local authority adult education budgets to the new Learning and Skills Council.

At first sight this may look like modest growth, but it comes at the end of a bleak decade for community-based adult learning. In the run-up to the 1992 Further and Higher Education Act Sheila Lawlor, the Tory pamphleteer, argued that all money spent by local authorities on adult education was money stolen from schools, and should be outlawed; except in areas of disadvantage, where any spending should be met by social services. Otherwise, she argued, if people want opportunities they can go to the market for them. These ideas survived into a white paper, but were seen off by an alliance led by the National Federation of Women's Institutes.

Nevertheless, budgets for uncertificated adult education were remorselessly squeezed through the 1990s, as local authorities found it harder to balance the books, and devolve budgets to the schools. Many tutors accelerated the flight away from learning for pleasure by changing modest French conversation classes to credit-bearing qualifications courses, which attracted better funding. The result was that participation among people over 60 plummeted by 40% between 1990 and 1994. It looked as though public funding for such work was on the way out.

Despite David Blunkett's enthusiasm, anxieties continued in the debates leading to the Learning and Skills Act. Would adult education be swallowed up by reconfigured Training and Enterprise Councils? Would local authorities take their bats home once "their" budgets were transferred to the new Learning and Skills Council? How would voluntary sector providers fit in? A step at a time, the questions are being answered. There is a two-year transitional guarantee for local authority providers to maintain provision. The Learning and Skills Council has been given a strong priority to expand adult community learning, particularly in the poorest communities. And now there is firm cash to back the expansion - for basic skills, for credit-bearing courses, for new forms of higher education, for further education, which is mainly for adults, and for the modest evening class.

So is everything in the garden rosy? Not quite. The new law still gives young learners entitlements, and adults get what is left over. Fine, whilst we have the current ministers. But how will adults fare under a different, perhaps less enlightened and inspiring secretary of state?

Alan Tuckett is director of the National Institution of Adult Continuing Education

webTitle: The real-life popstars college

fields.headline: Pop starts
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston  visits the college where Nasty Nigel is a hero
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston visits the college where Nasty Nigel is a hero
fields.body:
The lecture hall is packed with students staring at a large screen. The best bloodsport on telly is playing. Like the rest of the nation these students are hooked on Popstars, ITV's update of the Circus Maximus.

But it is not for pleasure that they are watching Nigel Lythgoe, LWT's Caesar of light entertainment, and his two co-judges give the thumbs down to hordes of aspiring Britneys and Robbies.

It is part of their education. They are watching the video clips to learn. These youngsters, mostly aged 16 to 18, are at the Academy of Contemporary Music (ACM), which bills itself Europe's leading school for rock and pop musicians.

Like the hopefuls in Popstars, many of them will soon be going in for auditions. Many have been blooded by the process already.

They are focusing on the juiciest clips from the series to date, including Lythgoe's franker comments on some of the dire performances, which have inevitably earned him a "Nasty Nigel" tag in the tabloids.

"I put it down to their ears. They must be hearing something different from us," he says after a song has been murdered for the umpteenth time.

One bruised hopeful fatuously reported Lythgoe to the Broadcasting Standards Council for mocking his performance of Robbie Williams' hit Angels. But such whining is the last thing the students are being told they should do.

"Nigel is a hero," is the message they are getting from their lecturer, Bruce Dickinson.

"Your friends in the music industry are the people who tell you the truth, not the people who tell you you're brilliant and going to be a star."

A failed audition like a bad gig must be learned from, he says.

"Rejections at auditions are hugely positive experiences."

So, what are the lessons from the rejections on Popstars?

"Not enough preparation in many cases.

"Flawed attitudes in others."

The students watch one young woman arguing with the judges. She is insisting on singing the "bridge" passage from a number. They want her to sing something else.

"Most of the time you've got to work out what the people holding the audition want," Dickinson says. "It's not what you want."

Teaching rock and pop is a growth industry, says Phil Brookes, 31, MD and co-founder of the academy.

The further education sector has a long and honourable history of teaching performing art, but there hasn't been much that has focused exclusively on the needs of future pop and rock musicians, he says.

He says that the academy scores because all its teachers are seasoned pop and rock professionals and because it has very good contacts in the industry.

"We are always looking at what skills the industry requires."

The academy began in the finest tradition of rock ventures.

"I started it seven years ago in my mum's garage in Guildford," Brookes says.

He was a guitar tutor who realised that there was nothing structured for kids learning the instrument with a view to a pop career.

"We started with guitar, drums and vocal part-time course. There were 40 students."

A year later full-time courses validated by Edexel were launched. The student roll soared to 120. In 1998 the fledgling academy moved into premises in the centre of Guildford and added a music production course.

Then came the big break. The academy set up home next door in a handsome building, which in 1901 housed Dennis Brothers, Europe's first custom-built car industry.

Its 22 studios and theatre were officially opened last year by the heritage secretary Chris Smith.

There are now 420 full-time students and twice as many part-timers. A tenth of the students come from the EU, notably Germany and Italy. A further 5% come from other coun tries overseas.

The ACM, a company limited by guarantee, is affiliated to Guildford College. It offers a level three diploma and a level four higher diploma. From next year it will also run a degree in contemporary music, a BA for pop singers validated by Middlesex university.

Another new venture it is launching in September is the Pop Academy, aimed at 12-year-olds. In an industry seemingly getting younger by the minute, that is the age for catching tomorrow's pop stars.

For four hours on Saturday mornings these teenies will be taught voice, choreography, video performance and . . . image.

The academy is not as rigidly selective as some performing arts institutions, but does not run an absolutely open door. There were 600 applicants for the full-time places this year. Everybody is auditioned.

"If you came here wanting a guitar place and you couldn't play the guitar, we wouldn't be able to offer you a place," explains Ian Edwards, who teaches guitar.

About 80% of the students on the guitar and drums courses are male. The majority on the vocal courses is female. In every case the aim over the year is to produce well-rounded professionals who will slot into the pop and rock industry.

"We don't tell people they'll be the next Ronan Keating," says Edwards. "But Ronan Keating has sound and lighting engineers, a record company, a publishing company - all these areas are legitimate jobs for our students."

Every Thursday, all students must attend three lectures on various aspects of the business of pop music.

In its short existence the academy has groomed some promising performers. A recent student landed three world tours on guitar with Boyzone.

Lucy Randell, 18, who completed her course in the summer, is in the final four candidates to perform Britain's entry in the Eurovision song contest with a song called Just Another Rainbow.

She switched to the academy three months into a Btec in performing arts at Barking College. "I didn't really click at that."

Like other students she wanted a course focused on pop.

Bruce Dickinson reckons that parents these days are more prepared to countenance pop and rock training as a viable career path for their children.

"We've now got a generation of young people whose parents have got Never Mind The Bollocks by the Sex Pistols in their collections.

"They don't think their kids are aliens for thinking seriously of pop music education."

There is one problem.

"One of the functions of pop music is to piss off your parents.

"That's difficult for these youngsters with parents listening to the Sex Pistols."

webTitle: Libyans target embassy in Lockerbie protest

fields.headline: Libyans target embassy in Lockerbie protest
fields.trailText: More than 4,000 angry Libyans protested outside the British embassy and the UN building in Tripoli today, as they continued to press for the conviction of the Lockerbie bomber to be overturned.
fields.body:
More than 4,000 angry Libyans protested outside the British embassy and the UN building in Tripoli today, as they continued to press for the conviction of the Lockerbie bomber to be overturned.

The demonstrators clashed with police and carried coffins bearing the phrases "these are the victims of the American raid" and "American civilisation means killing children", referring to the 1986 US airstrikes on Libya that killed 37 people, including the adopted daughter of the country's leader Muammar Gadafy.

The Foreign Office confirmed that there was a demonstration outside the building in Tripoli, but a spokeswoman declined to comment on reports that Libyan riot police beat protesters and sprayed tear gas at the crowd who were trying to break into the building.

She said: "At no time was the embassy breached. Staff safety is our first priority and we made clear to the authorities the need to ensure the security of our diplomatic premises was maintained."

The Foreign Office now plans to revise its advice on travel to Libya, although no specific changes were revealed.

Today's protest was the latest demonstration of the public outrage that followed the conviction of Abdel Baset al-Megrahi on Wednesday for the bombing Pan Am Flight 103.

The Libyan intelligence agent was jailed for life for murdering the 270 people who died when the New York-bound airliner exploded over the Scottish town in 1988.

His co-accused, Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, was cleared of the atrocity and returned home to Libya to a hero's welcome from Colonel Gadafy.

Since then, Col Gadafy and Mr Fhimah have been insisting that Megrahi is innocent, while his countrymen have taken to the streets to protest against his conviction.

Last week, Col Gadafy promised that he would come forward with new evidence yesterday, which, he said, would leave the three judges who unanimously convicted Megrahi with three options - to resign, admit the truth or commit suicide.

But Col Gadafy's rambling speech in Tripoli yesterday produced no new evidence. Instead, he hit out at the judges, Britain and the United States, and he accused British police of planting evidence to secure the conviction.

In a speech lasting more than two hours, he described Megrahi, who was ordered to spend a minimum of 20 years in a Scottish prison, as "a kidnapped hostage", adding:"Keeping him is a terrorist act."

The Foreign Office now plans to revise its advice on travel to Libya, although no specific changes were revealed. Today's protest was the latest demonstration of the public outrage that followed the conviction of Abdel Baset al-Megrahi on Wednesday for the bombing Pan Am Flight 103. The Libyan intelligence agent was jailed for life for murdering the 270 people who died when the New York-bound airliner exploded over the Scottish town in 1988. His co-accused, Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, was cleared of the atrocity and returned home to Libya to a hero's welcome from Colonel Gadafy. Since then, Col Gadafy and Mr Fhimah have been insisting that Megrahi is innocent, while his countrymen have taken to the streets to protest against his conviction. Last week, Col Gadafy promised that he would come forward with new evidence yesterday, which, he said, would leave the three judges who unanimously convicted Megrahi with three options - to resign, admit the truth or commit suicide. But Col Gadafy's rambling speech in Tripoli yesterday produced no new evidence. Instead, he hit out at the judges, Britain and the United States, and he accused British police of planting evidence to secure the conviction. In a speech lasting more than two hours, he described Megrahi, who was ordered to spend a minimum of 20 years in a Scottish prison, as "a kidnapped hostage", adding:"Keeping him is a terrorist act." webTitle: Brown aims children's credit at 4m families to cut poverty

fields.headline: Brown aims children's credit at 4m families to cut poverty
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday intensified the pre-election battle over tax by promising that 4m families in Britain will be better off by £442 a year under Labour thanks to the children's tax credit, which comes into effect in April.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday intensified the pre-election battle over tax by promising that 4m families in Britain will be better off by £442 a year under Labour thanks to the children's tax credit, which comes into effect in April.

Speaking at the launch of an advertising campaign for the credit, the chancellor made a pitch for middle Britain voters when he said that a family on average earnings of £25,000 would receive the equivalent of 2.5p off the basic rate of tax.

The £4.7m TV advertising campaign is designed to raise awareness of the children's tax credit which will benefit 5m families where the main earner brings home up to £40,000. The credit is targeted at the less well off, so that 4m families earning £32,000 or less will receive the full credit of £442 a year. With child benefit payments of £15.50 a week for the first child, this will work out at £1,248 a year.

Mr Brown said that he was determined to overhaul the tax and benefit system inherited from the Tories which neglected the needs of families and children. "We seek to ensure that the tax system actually acknowledges the costs of bringing up children and the tax and benefit system reflects those costs better," the chancellor said. "Under our policy, every family with children should have more support and in this way we improve family prosperity all round and also reduce child poverty."

Under Labour, the number of children living below the poverty line has fallen from 4m to 3m, but Mr Brown believes that further fiscal action is needed to take a further 1m out of poverty in the next parliament. But the chancellor made clear that he would not introduce "indiscriminate" tax cuts in next month's pre-election budget. "We will do nothing that puts economic stability and the improvements we are investing in for our public services at risk," he said.

Mr Brown coupled his tax cuts for families with a warning that the government expected parents to accept their responsibilities. At the same press conference, the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, said that new rules this week would allow the child support agency to crack down on a minority of parents.

Courts will also be able to confiscate driving licences from men who refuse to pay maintenance for their children. "We have to ensure that those absent parents who evade their responsibilities do their best for their children," Mr Darling said.

webTitle: Tories plan tax cut to woo grey vote

fields.headline: Tories plan tax cut to woo grey vote
fields.trailText: The Conservatives stepped up the pressure on Gordon Brown to                                                    woo the "grey power" electorate in next month's Budget when                                                    they announced plans to scrap all income tax on the savings                                                    and dividends of 20m mainly older voters.
fields.body:
The Conservatives stepped up the pressure on Gordon Brown to woo the "grey power" electorate in next month's Budget when they announced plans to scrap all income tax on the savings and dividends of 20m mainly older voters.

Labour immediately claimed the Tory plans would give only around £100 a year to most people affected, but would disproportionately benefit the better off, giving an average £1,500 to the top 10%, those with the biggest savings.

William Hague and Michael Portillo joined forces to unveil the £3bn proposal, which went further than expected in exempting not just pensioners' savings and dividends but all such savings for lower and middle income groups.

It would leave only higher rate taxpayers - with incomes above £32,785- paying income tax on savings. The £2.3bn cost (plus £680m to abolish dividend taxes) would be found from £8bn savings on public spending, Mr Portillo said.

Though the Tory proposal would retain the 40% tax rate on savings, the effect of abolishing both the 22% standard rate of tax and the 10% starter rate for all savers would unavoidably mean larger net benefits to those with a high proportion of savings income.

They are typically self-employed people who have retired on capital assets rather than a conventional occupational pension. Around 16m of the likely beneficiaries of the Tory scheme are non-pensioners, mostly on modest incomes. Around 4.7m are re tired, mainly the better off.

The move, which the Conservative leader billed as a blow for "individual independence, institutional freedom and social responsibility", was endorsed as feasible by analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies, who have been critical of both sides' figures during pre-election skirmishes. The plans reflect Tory attempts to win back older voters - who tend to vote in above-average numbers - and to encourage savings which have slipped by two-thirds as a share of national income since 1997.

The Tory plan would also end what Mr Portillo denounced as "one of the greatest injustices of the tax system" - that people who have saved out of taxed income are then taxed a second time on the income generated by their savings, which have also been subjected to corporation tax.

The proposal would create a tax revolution in "a Britain where the overwhelming majority of people who have already paid tax on the income they earn, do not then have to pay tax again when they save that income and earn interest on it", Mr Hague said.

Under the Tory scheme, a pensioner on the basic rate of tax with £10,000 invested in an ordinary building society account would benefit by £120 in the first year, rising to £740 if they kept their money in for five years. For someone with £20,000 in the bank, the gains would be £240 and £1,481 respectively.

webTitle: Disney suffers online losses

fields.headline: Disney suffers online losses
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Walt Disney is counting the cost of its failed internet ventures after posting a dramatic fall in earnings, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The Walt Disney Company is counting the cost of its failed online ventures after posting a dramatic reduction in earnings.

The world's second largest media company was hit by a £173m loss from its stake in the Disney Internet Group, reducing its first quarter net income to £43m, against £244m for the same period last year.

Disney last month said it would close its loss-making Go.com internet portal and would focus its resources on the ABC.com and ESPN.com sites.

The shake-out will lead to 400 job losses and will cost a massive £550m in restructuring charges, which will decimate the next set of earnings figures.

"I am pleased with the strength of our results in the first quarter. Looking forward, we believe that our recent move to focus on our core internet holdings will help maintain the growth of Disney's bottom line," said Michael Eisner, chief executive of Disney.

Disney is a genuine multimedia player, owning the ABC television network, the ESPN cable company, the Touchstone film studio and several theme parks.

webTitle: Credits roll on Tom and Nicole blockbuster

fields.headline: Credits roll on Tom and Nicole blockbuster
fields.standfirst:
The Cruise-Kidman romance was the Hollywood couple's most polished product, says Guardian Unlimited Film editor Xan Brooks

Guardian Unlimited Film
fields.trailText: The Cruise-Kidman romance was the Hollywood couple's most polished product, says Guardian Unlimited Film editor Xan Brooks.
fields.body:
On hearing the news that the notoriously dull, taciturn President Calvin Coolidge had died, Dorothy Parker casually remarked: "How can they tell?"

On opening today's papers one could be forgiven for thinking the same thing. Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman, we are told, are no more, kaput, history. How can they tell?

Seldom has a major celebrity relationship - played out on screen and before the world's press - provided so few dramatic fireworks. Never has one winked out with such quiet, unprompted finality.

Cruise and Kidman met on the set of the tedious car-racing drama Days of Thunder and wed on Christmas Eve 1990. At the time he was one of Hollywood's most bankable stars and she a young Australian hopeful yet to enjoy a major commercial hit in her own right.

Ten years later, (a few decent Kidman roles aside) not much has changed. Instead of A Star is Born, the Cruise-Kidman saga has given us an essay in corporate consolidation.

Instead of a turbulent soap-opera (à la Bogart and Bacall, or Burton and Taylor) we had this squeaky-clean account of two clean-cut, toothsome types who liked go-kart racing, outdoor hiking and going to bed early.

Nothing wrong with that, of course. Not every Hollywood couple has to peddle their wares as a kind of media floor-show (stand up Angelina Jolie and Billy Bob Thornton) or yo-yoing series of break-ups and make-ups (Ben Affleck and Gwyneth Paltrow).

Yet could it be that Cruise and Kidman are just a little more professional, a tad more classy even, in ordering their material?

For the past 10 years they have conspired to have it both ways. On the one hand, they got frisky on screen (in the turgid Eyes Wide Shut and the flat-out stupid Far and Away) and cooed to the press about how picture-perfect their marriage is. On the other, they reached for the lawyers as soon as anyone questioned the official line (and rumours concerning the true state of their union were as common as LA waiters with a showbiz agent).

Let's not be too cynical here: of course they loved each other, of course they were the real deal. Yet this, for better or worse, is Hollywood.

As well as being a genuine relationship, Cruise and Kidman was both a business merger and a piece of media theatre so rigorously policed, so impeccably stage-managed that all the drama was weeded out.

They met in the public eye, loved in the public eye and then terminated their arrangement, with nobody any the wiser. In this way Cruise and Kidman played the media game and won: they kept the real story hidden, let nothing slip except airbrushed grins and lovey-dovey platitudes. Tom and Nicole, we hardly knew you.

webTitle: Tony the Tiger, Bob the Builder, and Secret Squirrel

fields.headline: Tony the Tiger, Bob the Builder, and Secret Squirrel
fields.trailText: TO HULL AND BACK
fields.body:
TO HULL AND BACK

At 6.30 this morning, two white vans with Mul-T-Lock emblazoned on their flanks pulled up outside Hull City's Boothferry Park ground. Doing, we presume, what Mul-T-Lock does best, the van drivers then shut up the ground with padlocks, preventing anyone from getting in until the landlord, former Davis Cup captain David Lloyd, gets the £45,000 he's owed in rent. This would be a bit of a bind, even if Hull weren't 24 hours away from facing a winding-up order for £230,000 of unpaid taxes. Which, of course, they are.

Hull's current chairman is a Mr Nick Buchanan, and he was not impressed by this morning's activities. "I think someone is running to a personal agenda here and I don't think they realise they are not hurting Nick Buchanan," said Nick Buchanan. "They are hurting Hull City FC." However, debate rages (does it ever do anything else?) as to who exactly is hurting the club. After all, in his two years in charge of Hull, Mr Buchanan has presided over an increase in the club's debt from £100,000 to £1.5m, despite the club turning an operating profit in the year 1998-99, and despite healthy average crowds of around 6,000.

While the fraud squad conducts an inquiry into off-the-field activities at the club, rumours abound as to where the money's gone. Buchanan claims it's all down to a "top-heavy" wage structure. Most fans, meanwhile, prefer to blame Mr Buchanan and former vice-chairman Stephen Hinchliffe (who, after resigning his post at the club, turned out to be banned by the DTI from holding a company directorship). When he can't afford to pay his VAT or his rent, they wonder, how can Mr Buchanan afford to run up a club tab of £5,000 at Mr Chu's Chinese restaurant? We phoned Boothferry Park for comment, but there was nobody in the office.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BLAB DE BILDE

Bob the Builder, cartoon star and cash cow of popular north London gadabout Neil Morrissey, is famous for preaching the virtues of "working together" to "get the job done". But his irritating little brother, Sheffield Wednesday striker Gilles, takes a more self-centred approach. Unhappy with "deplorable" First Division football, the fist-happy Belgian wants to leave struggling Wednesday immediately, and finds it unacceptable that the club are holding out for some of the £3m they wasted on an international striker who has managed one lower-league goal all season.

"I reached an agreement with Las Palmas but Wednesday wanted too much money," whined poor helpless little Gilles, who once attacked Alost defender Krist Porte with his fist, smashing his nose and eye socket into variously sized bits. "They are destroying me," Mr the Builder grizzled on. "I am not surprised we're bottom. All the players who have left have been replaced by reserves. As a result I can't motivate myself. If they hold me to my contract, I don't know whether I could cope with that."

The Fiver can only imagine how hard it must be to pick up a fat cheque every week for not being able to hit a cow door from ten yards with an arse banjo. However, club chairman Howard Culley doesn't sympathise. "The comments beggar belief," spluttered Culley this afternoon. "We had interest from both Aston Villa and Las Palmas - and it is nothing to do with the club's financial demands that they fell through. We want him to be a success and to prejudice that just wouldn't be sensible." And as if to prove Wednesday's commitment to their Belgian star's career, Culley then pointed to the latest league tables. Well, it's so much easier to score goals in the Second, isn't it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Because of all the financial interests at stake, the sport is turning into a mafia. Like all soccer lovers, it makes me sorry" - Manchester United godfather Eric Cantona stuffs two cotton-wool balls in each cheek and explains why he has turned his back on football.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE DIARY OF ARSENAL'S GEORGE GRAHAM: SECRET AGENT

5am: Awoke from bad dream which involved a ball hitting the back of a net. Twitched uncontrollably.

8.30am: Finally recovered from spasm. Inserted secret transmitter into ear, which allows subliminal pro-Arsenal messages to be received in AM or FM frequencies.

9am: On way to work, noticed thousands of Spurs fans sobbing into their papers. Heh! Realised they'd been reading my Sun interview, where I tell Pat Sheehan: "I won't walk away from Tottenham." Cackle loudly at my warped genius.

12pm: Training. Berated team for making last Saturday's 0-0 draw against Charlton too exciting. Thought about the practicalities of introducing a 9-1-0 formation, until HQ warned me it might blow my cover. Consider appointing Stefan Freund club captain instead.

12.01pm: Given the Heinlich manoeuvre by office staff after suffering laughing fit.

2pm: Phoned Norris McWhirter to ask whether a fifth consecutive 0-0 draw would make the Guinness Book of Records. Got over disappointing news by shouting at Ian Walker during a crisis meeting at the club's Chigwell training ground. He's now thinking of leaving. Not for Highbury, I hope.

4pm: Prepared supporters for inevitable defeat against Charlton in FA Cup tomorrow. "There are other clubs as big as Tottenham who can't win the championship, can't qualify for [Big Cup] and who are not in either cup," I smiled, while cleverly blaming my long injury list for Spurs' poor run of form.

5pm: Noticed that everybody's morale is at rock bottom. Left the ground contemplating a job well done.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Everton have confirmed reports that they will be taking Argentinian defender Pablo Paz on trial, with a view to a permanent move. "He is still coming over for a few days training, where we will have a look at him and see where we go from there," said manager Walter Smith.

Sol Campbell tops Bayern Munich's summer shopping list, according to reports in Germany.

Bayer Leverkusen are tracking Arsenal goalkeeper Alex Manninger.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Fifa and Uefa have repeated their demand that players should only be allowed to move once a year if the EU decide to scrap the current transfer system. At a joint meeting today, Fifa head Sepp Blatter and Uefa president Lennart Johansson also agreed to present a united front at meetings with the EU commission on February 14 and 16.

Paul Taylor, the referee accused of making insulting remarks towards Notts County's Sean Farrell, has been "completely exonerated" by the FA, according to Premier League referees' spokesman Keith Cooper. Cooper's comments followed a four-hour FA hearing today, which found the misconduct charge against Taylor had been "not proven".

Bayern Munich president Franz Beckenbauer has called for a smaller Big Cup with only one group stage instead of two. "Thirteen games instead of 17 would be enough," said Beckenbauer. "After the first group stage we should go straight into the knockout phase with the round of eight."

Leicester City have paid Altrincham £50,000 for winger Kevin Ellison.

Burnley have made an enquiry about Coventry striker John Aloisi. Manager Stan Ternent told Burnley's official website: "If we can afford him then I will speak to the player to see if he fancies the move. He will definitely strengthen the squad."

Jaap Stam could sign a new contract at Manchester United within the next few weeks, according to his agent Ton van Dalen.

St Mirren have signed French striker Moussa Dagnogo in time for tonight's CIS Insurance Cup semi-final against Kilmarnock.

The following matches have been called off due to bad weather: Northampton Town v Swansea, Rochdale v Brighton, Cheltenham v York, Shrewsbury v Kidderminster, Aberdeen v Dundee United, Queen of the South v Airdrie, Dunfermline v St Johnstone, and Falkirk v Dundee.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Scottish and Grampian: Live Scotsport Special - St Mirren v Kilmarnock (7.30pm) "Allo, guv'nor! Look, sorry to be a right royal pain in the proverbial, but you don't mind if me and me mate Bill shift this piano through your TV & Radio section, do you? It'd take us hours to carry it all the way round and you don't? Brilliant. Listen, don't mind us, we'll be done in two ticks."

ITV all regions: Football Extra (2.55am) [lift, grunt, heave]

Channel 4: Football Italia (1.45am) "OK, Bill as you are as you are woah! down a bit woah! down a bit down a bit that's it OK as you are as you are "

Channel 5: Brazilian International Football (2.30am) [carry, hump, move]

Argentine Football (4am) [slip, clang]

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm) "Yaroo! You've dropped it on me flaming foot, you great fat useless bugger!"

"Don't you call me a great fat useless bugger! If you're going to be like that, you can shift it yerself!"

"Hey where are you going?!? Come back come back!!!"

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2am) [heave, pant, gasp]

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) [the piano does not move]

Talksport: Football First (7pm) "Erm you don't mind if I leave this here for a couple of days, do you?"

Most fans, meanwhile, prefer to blame Mr Buchanan and former vice-chairman Stephen Hinchliffe (who, after resigning his post at the club, turned out to be banned by the DTI from holding a company directorship). When he can't afford to pay his VAT or his rent, they wonder, how can Mr Buchanan afford to run up a club tab of £5,000 at Mr Chu's Chinese restaurant? We phoned Boothferry Park for comment, but there was nobody in the office. * * * * * * * * * * * * * BLAB DE BILDE Bob the Builder, cartoon star and cash cow of popular north London gadabout Neil Morrissey, is famous for preaching the virtues of "working together" to "get the job done". But his irritating little brother, Sheffield Wednesday striker Gilles, takes a more self-centred approach. Unhappy with "deplorable" First Division football, the fist-happy Belgian wants to leave struggling Wednesday immediately, and finds it unacceptable that the club are holding out for some of the £3m they wasted on an international striker who has managed one lower-league goal all season. "I reached an agreement with Las Palmas but Wednesday wanted too much money," whined poor helpless little Gilles, who once attacked Alost defender Krist Porte with his fist, smashing his nose and eye socket into variously sized bits. "They are destroying me," Mr the Builder grizzled on. "I am not surprised we're bottom. All the players who have left have been replaced by reserves. As a result I can't motivate myself. If they hold me to my contract, I don't know whether I could cope with that." The Fiver can only imagine how hard it must be to pick up a fat cheque every week for not being able to hit a cow door from ten yards with an arse banjo. However, club chairman Howard Culley doesn't sympathise. "The comments beggar belief," spluttered Culley this afternoon. "We had interest from both Aston Villa and Las Palmas - and it is nothing to do with the club's financial demands that they fell through. We want him to be a success and to prejudice that just wouldn't be sensible." And as if to prove Wednesday's commitment to their Belgian star's career, Culley then pointed to the latest league tables. Well, it's so much easier to score goals in the Second, isn't it? * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "Because of all the financial interests at stake, the sport is turning into a mafia. Like all soccer lovers, it makes me sorry" - Manchester United godfather Eric Cantona stuffs two cotton-wool balls in each cheek and explains why he has turned his back on football. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE DIARY OF ARSENAL'S GEORGE GRAHAM: SECRET AGENT 5am: Awoke from bad dream which involved a ball hitting the back of a net. Twitched uncontrollably. 8.30am: Finally recovered from spasm. Inserted secret transmitter into ear, which allows subliminal pro-Arsenal messages to be received in AM or FM frequencies. 9am: On way to work, noticed thousands of Spurs fans sobbing into their papers. Heh! Realised they'd been reading my Sun interview, where I tell Pat Sheehan: "I won't walk away from Tottenham." Cackle loudly at my warped genius. 12pm: Training. Berated team for making last Saturday's 0-0 draw against Charlton too exciting. Thought about the practicalities of introducing a 9-1-0 formation, until HQ warned me it might blow my cover. Consider appointing Stefan Freund club captain instead. 12.01pm: Given the Heinlich manoeuvre by office staff after suffering laughing fit. 2pm: Phoned Norris McWhirter to ask whether a fifth consecutive 0-0 draw would make the Guinness Book of Records. Got over disappointing news by shouting at Ian Walker during a crisis meeting at the club's Chigwell training ground. He's now thinking of leaving. Not for Highbury, I hope. 4pm: Prepared supporters for inevitable defeat against Charlton in FA Cup tomorrow. "There are other clubs as big as Tottenham who can't win the championship, can't qualify for [Big Cup] and who are not in either cup," I smiled, while cleverly blaming my long injury list for Spurs' poor run of form. 5pm: Noticed that everybody's morale is at rock bottom. Left the ground contemplating a job well done. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Everton have confirmed reports that they will be taking Argentinian defender Pablo Paz on trial, with a view to a permanent move. "He is still coming over for a few days training, where we will have a look at him and see where we go from there," said manager Walter Smith. Bayer Leverkusen are tracking Arsenal goalkeeper Alex Manninger. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Fifa and Uefa have repeated their demand that players should only be allowed to move once a year if the EU decide to scrap the current transfer system. At a joint meeting today, Fifa head Sepp Blatter and Uefa president Lennart Johansson also agreed to present a united front at meetings with the EU commission on February 14 and 16. Paul Taylor, the referee accused of making insulting remarks towards Notts County's Sean Farrell, has been "completely exonerated" by the FA, according to Premier League referees' spokesman Keith Cooper. Cooper's comments followed a four-hour FA hearing today, which found the misconduct charge against Taylor had been "not proven". Bayern Munich president Franz Beckenbauer has called for a smaller Big Cup with only one group stage instead of two. "Thirteen games instead of 17 would be enough," said Beckenbauer. "After the first group stage we should go straight into the knockout phase with the round of eight." Leicester City have paid Altrincham £50,000 for winger Kevin Ellison. Burnley have made an enquiry about Coventry striker John Aloisi. Manager Stan Ternent told Burnley's official website: "If we can afford him then I will speak to the player to see if he fancies the move. He will definitely strengthen the squad." Jaap Stam could sign a new contract at Manchester United within the next few weeks, according to his agent Ton van Dalen. St Mirren have signed French striker Moussa Dagnogo in time for tonight's CIS Insurance Cup semi-final against Kilmarnock. The following matches have been called off due to bad weather: Northampton Town v Swansea, Rochdale v Brighton, Cheltenham v York, Shrewsbury v Kidderminster, Aberdeen v Dundee United, Queen of the South v Airdrie, Dunfermline v St Johnstone, and Falkirk v Dundee. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Scottish and Grampian: Live Scotsport Special - St Mirren v Kilmarnock (7.30pm) "Allo, guv'nor! Look, sorry to be a right royal pain in the proverbial, but you don't mind if me and me mate Bill shift this piano through your TV & Radio section, do you? It'd take us hours to carry it all the way round and you don't? Brilliant. Listen, don't mind us, we'll be done in two ticks." ITV all regions: Football Extra (2.55am) [lift, grunt, heave] Channel 4: Football Italia (1.45am) "OK, Bill as you are as you are woah! down a bit woah! down a bit down a bit that's it OK as you are as you are " Channel 5: Brazilian International Football (2.30am) [carry, hump, move] Argentine Football (4am) [slip, clang] Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11pm) "Yaroo! You've dropped it on me flaming foot, you great fat useless bugger!" "Don't you call me a great fat useless bugger! If you're going to be like that, you can shift it yerself!" "Hey where are you going?!? Come back come back!!!" You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2am) [heave, pant, gasp] Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) [the piano does not move] Talksport: Football First (7pm) "Erm you don't mind if I leave this here for a couple of days, do you?"

webTitle: Woolies bans girls' mag

fields.headline: Woolies bans new girls' mag
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: Woolworths has banned controversial girls' magazine Mad About Boys, claiming it is 'a step too far', reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Woolworths has banned Mad About Boys, the controversial magazine aimed at girls as young as 10, claiming the magazine is "a step too far".

And the retailer has had to contact 800 stores to recall issues.

A spokeswoman said that Woolworths, which considers itself a "family" retailer, found the magazine, which launched last week, "very alarming".

"Trying to get young people to look like Kate Moss is one thing, but with younger children, it's damaging to make them that conscious of their appearance," she said.

But the magazine's publisher, John O'Sullivan, is furious with the spin the retailer is putting on its decision.

"I'm disappointed that Woolworths feel this way, but this is nothing to do with the content - the fact is they never had shelf space for it in the first place," he said.

He added that the magazine could benefit from the negative media attention.

"We're a small company and this was a quiet little launch and it's gone ballistic," he said.

Children's charity Kidscape yesterday called on newsagents and retailers to boycott the magazine, claiming it would have a negative impact on children's body image and could encourage paedophiles.

Kidscape, whose patrons include Katie Boyle and Phil Collins, said the magazine "drove a horse and cart" through legislation designed to protect children.

Director Michelle Elliott said: "I would encourage newsagents to use their common sense and not to carry this magazine.

"This is encouraging children to be sexual, to worry about their bodies and to have themselves made up and ready for boys considerably older than them."

Mad About Boys, which is targeted at girls between 10 and 12, features pin-up boys as old as 17 and offers tips on hair and beauty.

Ms Elliott objected to girls of that age being encouraged to think of themselves as "sexy".

webTitle: Children's safety 'bought at a price'

fields.headline: Children's safety 'bought at a price'
fields.standfirst: Success in cutting fatal accidents and abuse achieved by restricting freedom to explore
fields.trailText: Despite concerns about attacks on children, like the killing of Anna Climbie and the abduction and murder of Sarah Payne, the United Kingdom has one of the world's lowest rates of child deaths caused by accident and abuse.
fields.body:
Despite concerns about attacks on children, like the killing of Anna Climbie and the abduction and murder of Sarah Payne, the United Kingdom has one of the world's lowest rates of child deaths caused by accident and abuse.

A UN report published today says such events are rarer than in many other industrialised countries.

But the authors of the first league table of children's deaths by injury in the world's 26 richest countries said that, in some cases, the success of reducing numbers being killed in road accidents, drownings, fires, falls and deliberate injury, might be bought at a price.

On the whole children were no longer being allowed to explore their boundaries and develop their own sense of risk and danger, said the report. The authors, a Florence-based research centre for Unicef, examined the deaths of children aged one to 14.

This revealed that the UK's injury death record, 6.1 per 100,000 children in the age group each year, was better than in any other country except Sweden. The figure is a quarter of that in Korea and less than half that in the United States.

Although the likelihood of children dying from injury had been falling steadily since the 1970s, 20,000 would still die in this group of wealthy nations over the next year. Nearly half that total could be saved if all countries could match Sweden where the death rate was just over five per 100,000 for the years 1991 to 1995.

The report said that although the UK fared well in general, children with parents in unskilled manual jobs were three or four times more likely to die than those whose parents were in skilled non-manual work. The UK also had a bad record on deaths from fires, and boys were more than half as likely to die from injury as girls.

Britain's death rate from intentional injury of 0.8 per 100,000, compared with 2.74 in the US, and 1.58 in France.

In most industrialised nations "parents are increasingly worried about the threats to children, whether from traffic accidents or predatory paedophiles," said the report. "In response to high profile media treatment of selected cases, and more generalised warning from public organisations that have to compete for public attention and public funds, it is natural for parents to increase the level of protection."

It added: "In practice this has meant that millions of parents now drive or accompany their children on journeys, prevent them from playing outside or exploring independently, and feel that every activity has to be supervised."

The report referred to one study in the UK which suggested the proportion of children aged seven and eight who travelled to school without adult supervision fell from 80% to 10% between 1970 and 1990.

Public messages on ensuring the safety of children, said the report, should help parents keep a sense of proportion but there was no point in telling them to change their behaviour because the risks to their children were small.

"The appropriate response to this is not to tell parents that the roads are much safer. It is to make those roads safer so that parents' own assessments of the danger changes."

webTitle: Rise in waiting lists

fields.headline: Rise in waiting lists
fields.trailText: Waiting lists for NHS hospital treatment increased by more than 13,000 patients in December despite unprecedented government planning to deal with winter pressures, official figures showed today.
fields.body:
Waiting lists for NHS hospital treatment increased by more than 13,000 patients in December despite unprecedented government planning to deal with winter pressures, official figures showed today.

The number of people waiting for in-patient hospital treatment in England rose by 13,200 to stand at 1,034,400 in the final month of 2000, the Department of Health said.

But there was some good news for the government, with a dramatic fall in the number of people waiting for an out-patient appointment.

The Tories have claimed that the government's obsession with reducing in-patient numbers has driven more people on to the so-called "waiting list for the waiting list".

Ministers described the increase as expected and said the winter planning had kept the rise to a "minimum".

And numbers still remain in line with the government pledge of keeping waiting lists to 100,000 below the 1997 figure they inherited from the Tories.

Health minister John Denham said: "Waiting lists always go up in winter, but this year better planning and more investment have kept increases to a minimum.

"The small rise in the NHS waiting list was expected, and will probably have risen again during January."

Unprecedented planning and investment went into avoiding another winter crisis in the health service after the crippling problems of the previous year.

Every NHS trust was ordered to come up with a plan for easing pressures on hospitals during the winter months.

But in December, 10 patients had still been waiting longer than the maximum 18-month target set by the government. And 48,400 had waited more than a year - a rise of more than 600 on the previous month.

Ministers have pledged that by 2005, no patient will wait longer than six months, with an eventual three-month maximum by 2008.

Labour pledged in its last election manifesto to reduce waiting lists by 100,000 from the figure it inherited from the Conservatives - a target achieved amid much fanfare last year.

Despite the December rise, waiting numbers are still 23,623 below that, with ministers hoping that expected rises for January will not jeopardise their success.

But many hospitals might have cancelled routine elective surgery to deal with winter problems, meaning waiting lists could increase in the coming months.

The shadow health secretary, Dr Liam Fox, said: "This is yet further evidence, if any were needed, that Alan Milburn is incapable of managing even his own flawed policy with any competence."

"We now have first-class staff in a second-class service run by third-rate ministers."

Meanwhile, the number of people waiting more than 13 weeks for an out-patient's appointment - what the Conservatives have called the waiting list for the waiting list - fell by more than 30,000 in the three months to December from 435,768 to 399,137.

This fall will be seen as a victory by ministers who have repeatedly faced criticism that the waiting list initiative has distorted clinical priorities and not changed the number of patients actually waiting for treatment.

webTitle: TV ratings: February 5

fields.headline: EastEnders scores high ratings for BBC1
fields.trailText: 4.30pm TV overnights: EastEnders and The Weakest Link helped BBC1 to an early evening ratings lead last night, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The killer combination of nasty Nick Cotton in EastEnders and evil Anne Robinson in The Weakest Link helped BBC1 to an early evening ratings lead last night.

Nearly 14m viewers tuned in to watch nasty Nick's revenge attack on Mark Fowler at 8pm, according to unofficial overnight figures.

Of these, 8.3m stayed tuned for The Weakest Link to give BBC1 an average of 43% of the viewers between 8 and 9pm.

However, during the last 10 minutes of the 40-minute programme viewers began to switch over to ITV, providing proof if any were needed that Who Wants to be a Millionaire? is still the king of the quiz shows.

Chris Tarrant's comparatively jovial charms helped to pull in 11.4m viewers to the show, giving ITV a comfortable lead over BBC1 between 9 and 10pm.

The performance of BBC1's much-promoted police drama Second Sight continued to be solid rather than spectacular with an average viewing figure of 5.6m for its 50-minute slot.

Elsewhere, Channel 5 got its best viewing figures of the day with its 10pm broadcast of Goodfellas.

The Robert de Niro blockbuster pulled in 1.7m viewers to give Channel 5 a 15% share of the viewing after 10pm - a higher share than both Channel 4 and BBC2.

Romantic comedy classic When Harry Met Sally, shown for the umpteenth time on Channel 4, nevertheless attracted 2m viewers to give the channel a 14% share.

webTitle: Westferry row heads for courts

fields.headline: Desmond and Hollinger at loggerheads over Westferry price
fields.trailText:
4.45pm update: The stand-off between Richard Desmond and Hollinger over the Westferry printing plant is heading for the courts, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 6: Desmond hits hurdle in Westferry sale

Feb 6: Express to sell Westferry stake
fields.body:
The stand-off between Express owner Richard Desmond and Daily Telegraph publisher Hollinger over the Westferry printing plant is heading for the courtroom as both parties struggle to agree a price.

Sources at Northern & Shell revealed that Hollinger has already made an offer for the plant and arbitrators could be called in.

Hollinger wants to buy Mr Desmond's 50% stake in the lucrative plant, but it has balked at the £80m fee demanded by the OK! publisher's advisers.

But insiders at the Express reveal that the £80m-plus valuation was based on a complex financial arrangement agreed by Hollinger and previous Express owner Lord Hollick.

The valuation was set down in a pre-determined formula that was agreed between Hollick and Hollinger. And that valuation was north of £80m," said one source close to the negotiations.

Mr Desmond has taken advice from his solicitors who say the valuation is legally correct.

If the price cannot be determined through arbitration, then the sale will have to be settled in court.

It is understood that Hollinger, which already owns 50% of Westferry, made an offer to Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell company before Christmas last year.

Another offer was made last month which the Express proprietor rejected.

Although both sides are keen to resolve the deadlock outside of the courtroom, Mr Desmond is said to be relaxed.

"He is no hurry and will take his time," said a source.

However, Hollinger vice-chairman Dan Colson has already said that his company is in no hurry to sell the stake and it will take its time before completing a deal.

webTitle: Train theft of MoD laptop with fighter secrets alarmed Pentagon

fields.headline: Train theft of MoD laptop with fighter secrets alarmed Pentagon
fields.standfirst: Read the document
fields.trailText: Worried American officials complained about British security when a laptop was stolen containing secrets of the biggest military procurement project ever launched, a ministerial letter obtained by the Guardian has disclosed.
fields.body:
Worried American officials complained about British security when a laptop was stolen containing secrets of the biggest military procurement project ever launched, a ministerial letter obtained by the Guardian has disclosed.

Officials from both countries went through every line of the computers' files once it was recovered. It held details of progress on the development of the United States' supersonic joint strike fighter.

The huge project to produce a new generation of fighter aircraft is expected to create at least 5,000 British jobs. Last month Britain and the US signed a top-level agreement setting out the UK's involvement in the next phase.

A petty thief stole the laptop from a British military officer at Paddington station in London last May. It had been left on the luggage rack on a train. The officer did not realise it had gone until the train reached Heathrow.

The computer is believed to have passed through several hands before it was returned to the Ministry of Defence. The thief was caught and later convicted.

In a letter on June 12 last year Baroness Symons, minister for defence procurement, promised her counterpart in the Pentagon that she had "made sure that your concerns on the joint strike fighter laptop incident are acted upon".

A Pentagon source said: "We had no idea who had had it."

An MoD spokesman said that initially the Americans had been worried, but they were reassured that nothing held on the laptop compromised the military and commercial secrecy surrounding the fighter plane.

The spokesman added that security procedures had since been reviewed. For example, officials had been told to ensure their laptops were less conspicuous when on public transport.

The ministry admitted last year that 59 of its laptops had been stolen since 1997, while eight others had been lost.

Baroness Symons met senior Pentagon politicians in Washington to discuss the joint strike fighter and other equipment issues last May.

Documents released under the US freedom of information act indicate that because of the close relationship between the two countries British firms have won a greater slice, at least 15%, of the lucrative contracts to develop the hi-tech plane than might have been expected.

The government has so far contributed nearly £2bn towards the project, around 10%. Pentagon officials commented that the UK was "a valued partner in the joint strike fighter program as well as a valued ally in coalition operations".

The US military plans to buy 3,000 of the planes, and Britain plans to have 150, which will replace Royal Navy and RAF Harrier jump jets.

The huge project to produce a new generation of fighter aircraft is expected to create at least 5,000 British jobs. Last month Britain and the US signed a top-level agreement setting out the UK's involvement in the next phase. A petty thief stole the laptop from a British military officer at Paddington station in London last May. It had been left on the luggage rack on a train. The officer did not realise it had gone until the train reached Heathrow. The computer is believed to have passed through several hands before it was returned to the Ministry of Defence. The thief was caught and later convicted. In a letter on June 12 last year Baroness Symons, minister for defence procurement, promised her counterpart in the Pentagon that she had "made sure that your concerns on the joint strike fighter laptop incident are acted upon". A Pentagon source said: "We had no idea who had had it." An MoD spokesman said that initially the Americans had been worried, but they were reassured that nothing held on the laptop compromised the military and commercial secrecy surrounding the fighter plane. The spokesman added that security procedures had since been reviewed. For example, officials had been told to ensure their laptops were less conspicuous when on public transport. The ministry admitted last year that 59 of its laptops had been stolen since 1997, while eight others had been lost. Baroness Symons met senior Pentagon politicians in Washington to discuss the joint strike fighter and other equipment issues last May. Documents released under the US freedom of information act indicate that because of the close relationship between the two countries British firms have won a greater slice, at least 15%, of the lucrative contracts to develop the hi-tech plane than might have been expected. The government has so far contributed nearly £2bn towards the project, around 10%. Pentagon officials commented that the UK was "a valued partner in the joint strike fighter program as well as a valued ally in coalition operations". The US military plans to buy 3,000 of the planes, and Britain plans to have 150, which will replace Royal Navy and RAF Harrier jump jets.

webTitle: Straw proposes asylum blacklist

fields.headline: Straw proposes asylum blacklist
fields.standfirst:
Home secretary wants Geneva convention rewritten

Full text of Straw's speech
fields.trailText: A list of countries and groups from which asylum applications would be "ruled inadmissible" should be drawn up to combat Europe's huge influx of refugees, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said today.
fields.body:
A list of countries and groups from which asylum applications would be "ruled inadmissible" should be drawn up to combat Europe's huge influx of refugees, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said today.

Giving a key speech on the future of asylum policy, Mr Straw said that certain refugees could either be pushed through a quicker asylum process to save money or excluded from applying altogether, provided the international community could agree to rewrite the 1951 UN convention of refugees.

Mr Straw said: "An EU or internationally agreed list of safe countries or groups from which asylum applications would be ruled inadmissible or considered under a greatly accelerated process ought to be on the agenda."

He set out the blueprint of an asylum system where people must apply for refugee status while they are still abroad, rather than after travelling to the UK.

Such a set-up could counter the problems of illegal immigration and people trafficking, but will cause an outcry from human rights groups who fearthat genuine refugees fleeing persecution could be denied their only chance of safety.

The proposals in Mr Straw's speech were immediately condemned as "dangerous" by some audience members at a left-wing think-tank conference on the future of asylum.

The home secretary added: "The UK will want to play a full part in the developing debate on all these ideas, but it is clear that completing the reform of the domestic system will provide the essential platform from which more radical longer-term ideas can be considered.

"Any moves towards the implementation of ideas for processing of claims overseas or substantial resettlement programmes will have to be in parallel with driving down the numbers of unfounded applications."

The toughening stance on asylum - part of a multi-pronged attack on the issue by the government this week - signals the important role the issue will play in the forthcoming general election.

Asylum applications reached an all-time high of more than 76,000 last year.

Mr Straw called for a wide-ranging revamp of the convention, which governs countries' responsibilities to asylum seekers.

He said: "Would-be migrants are taking advantage of one aspect of the convention - namely that it places an obligation on states to consider any application for asylum made on their territory, however ill-founded."

He continued: "The UK has a proud history of offering shelter to those fleeing persecution. Yet the convention is no longer working as its framers intended."

Addressing the conference called Modernising Asylum organised by the Institute for Public Policy Research at Lincoln's Inn Fields, central London, Mr Straw also backed the idea of a resettlement programme for refugees who would be identified in their own regions before being brought back to the EU and divided among member states by a quota system.

Elaborating on how the list of "safe countries" would be devised, he said it would be broken into three categories.

The first would include countries like the US or Canada, from where "no applications for asylum should be entertained", while the final category would feature oppressive states where asylum seekers would be considered automatically.

In the middle would be a group of countries - which he did not define but said would include China - where, "by agreed criteria, the presumption is that the application would be unfounded" if it was made in the receiving state.

Sarah Spencer, of the IPPR, said: "This proposal alarms me the most and I think it could be very dangerous.

"The volatility of a political situation on the ground can change so quickly, an EU list of so-called safe countries would always be out of date.

The chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality, Gurbux Singh, said: "I did not get the impression that the issues had been fully thought through and there were some real question marks about the practicality of what he was proposing.

"For example, I do not know whether the proposal to make assessments of asylum seekers in their own countries is actually workable."

webTitle: Universities face million pound penalties

fields.headline: Universities face million pound penalties
fields.trailText: Some universities are set to fork out millions of pounds in penalties for not recruiting as many students as planned last year.
fields.body:
Some universities are set to fork out millions of pounds in penalties for not recruiting as many students as planned last year.

The failure to meet student recruitment targets suggests that the government's drive to expand universities could fall flat on its face, as demand for HND and degree courses falls.

The Higher Education Funding Council for England today announced that academic institutions that have failed to deliver the expected number of additional full-time students for 2000-01 will suffer financial penalties.

For many new universities, which have witnessed sharp falls in recruitment, this will mean the loss of millions of pounds.

Institutions though will be able to recover funds by enrolling additional students in 2001-02.

The move by the funding council comes following a decision to allow institutions much more flexibility in the numbers of students they can recruit. Institutions are bound by strict quotas of student enrolments, but last year the council said that they could recruit 4% over their core numbers. Some popular universities recruited more students, but at the expense of other institutions.

The government aims to eventually have 50% of all people under 30 with some experience of higher education, and hopes to expand two year university courses in particular. But universities report that demand for so called sub-degree courses is failing to keep up with the extra places on offer.

Institutions will receive their individual grant letters on Wednesday 28 February.

webTitle: How to find out what the public really thinks

fields.headline: How to find out what the public really thinks
fields.standfirst: Local authorities should reject tick box questionnaires and instigate qualitative research to enable effective public consultation, says Ben Page of opinion researchers MORI
fields.trailText: Local authorities should reject tick box questionnaires and instigate qualitative research to enable effective public consultation, claims Ben Page of opinion researchers MORI.
fields.body:
How do you consult people over something which most of them know very little about, which they are not very interested in and which is also quite complicated?

That is the challenge that new political structures - mayors and Westminster-style cabinets - pose for councils. The government is requiring authorities to consult widely over which option they should choose.

Ministers have not been prescriptive, and are requiring only that consultations use a variety of methods, be fair and unbiased, cover all the options for restructuring and reach everyone in the community. The official consultation guidance recommends - but does not require - a lot more. While this lack of prescription is encouraging, it certainly allows diversity to flower in all its glory.

The need to consult over the choice of specific political management arrangements is all very well, but to make this worthwhile, authorities ought to forget the new political models and first ask: "What would the ideal council for this area be like? How would it work and make decisions? How would it involve local people? What would its key features be?"

To understand this you need to reject tick box questionnaires and start with qualitative research.

Focus groups - eight to 10 people who are selected to be a reasonably homogenous group and who meet for up to two hours - are one option. A deliberative workshop - 30 people who spend a day discussing the issues - is another.

At least half the population have never heard of any of the proposals, and even fewer have any detailed understanding of how their council makes decisions at the moment.

This means that qualitative research needs time to allow an understanding of where people are coming from and what they see as the issues that need to be addressed. Only then should you introduce the models and start discussing the pros and cons of each.

Once this process has been completed with groups from across the authority, so that you have an idea of what the key aspects are locally, then it may be worth trying to get a measure of which option has the strongest support - if any.

Many authorities are relying on self-completion questionnaires. The problem is that many people do not fill them in, and that those who do tend to be older, and more middle class, under-representing the views of younger, more working-class people.

In particular, people who respond to questionnaires in council magazines tend to be older, and will tend to favour the model closest to the existing arrangements - leader and cabinet, which most councils also favour.

Because of this, authorities who want to do more than pay lip service to the idea of consultation do need to consider a carefully structured survey of the public - ideally face to face to allow visual prompts and descriptions to be used. Relying on telephone surveys in our experience means there is less time to explain the different options, meaning people tend to choose on the basis of features they are already most familiar with - usually meaning that they select a mayoral model.

However the survey is conducted, it is important to ask not just which option people favour, but also the extent of awareness of the options and interest in different forms of participation - eg local forums for neighbourhoods, local referenda and so on.

Some of MORI's (Market & Opinion Research International) findings suggest that in the absence of knowledge, and without strong feelings, many will opt for what they are told local politicians have already weighed up. Face to face surveys will not give an informed view, but then the public itself is not informed.

A well-designed survey ought to be able to demonstrate that the voters are basically confused, or to at least highlight the key outputs they want from any new system.

The one thing that the public says consistently is that they want politicians to spend less time in meetings and more time in the community. Which of the new political models will actually deliver that? Time will tell.

 Ben Page is director of government research at MORI.

webTitle: Man charged with Sarah Payne murder

fields.headline: Man charged with Sarah Payne murder
fields.trailText: A 42-year-old man was this afternoon charged with the murder and kidnapping of schoolgirl Sarah Payne.
fields.body:
A 42-year-old man was this afternoon charged with the murder and kidnapping of schoolgirl Sarah Payne.

Roy Whiting, a divorced father of one from Littlehampton, West Sussex, was arrested this morning and taken from a location in Kent to Bognor police station for questioning about the murder.

Detective Superintendent Peter Kennett, who led the hunt for Sarah's killer, announced the charges six hours later and said Mr Whiting due to appear before magistrates at Chichester tomorrow morning.

Mr Whiting's arrest follows a Crimewatch appeal last month which prompted 300 people to phone in with information. The appeal asked for information about a distinctive curtain, although the police refused to say what part, if any, the curtain played in the inquiry. The owners of the curtain were traced as a result of the Crimewatch appeal.

Sarah, from Hersham, Surrey, disappeared from a field near her grandparents' home in Kingston Gorse, near Littlehampton, on July 1 last year. She had been playing with her brothers Lee, 13, Luke 11, and six-year-old sister Charlotte after a day on the beach.

Her partially buried body was found 16 days later just off the A29 near Pulborough. Police believe she had been strangled or suffocated.

When Sarah was reported missing, a massive police operation was launched - at its peak up to 2,000 people a day were contacting detectives. Detectives took more than 33,000 calls in the month following her disappearance.

The murder also sparked a national campaign for tougher laws against paedophiles, including a national, publicly available register of those convicted of sex offences against children.

webTitle: Absent Bin Laden dominates US trial

fields.headline: Absent Bin Laden dominates US trial
fields.standfirst: Four accused of bombing embassies and killing 224
fields.trailText: The name of the elusive Osama bin Laden dominated the proceedings of America's biggest trial yesterday, in which four men are accused of a conspiracy that culminated in the bombing of two US embassies in Africa and 224 deaths.
fields.body:
The name of the elusive Osama bin Laden dominated the proceedings of America's biggest trial yesterday, in which four men are accused of a conspiracy that culminated in the bombing of two US embassies in Africa and 224 deaths.

"The story that's about to unfold is long, complicated and challenging," the assistant US attorney Paul Butler told the jury as he opened the case for the prosecution.

"But at the core the charges are simple. They are that all four defendants entered into an illegal agreement with Bin Laden to kill Americans anywhere in the world. Each helped the best they could, and 224 men, women and children lost their lives."

The four men, two of whom face the death penalty if convicted of direct involvement in the bombings of the embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam in August 1998, were led into court with their hands cuffed behind their backs and their feet shackled.

Outside, a fork-lift truck rearranged blocks of concrete in front of metal barriers at the entrance to the the old federal courthouse in Manhattan. Two hydraulically operated steel barricades were placed across a road running alongside, designed to halt a truck travelling at 50mph. Cameras with night vision and capable of reading a newspaper a block away monitored the area.

Inside courtroom 318, where the trial of those accused of the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Centre was also held, sniffer dogs searched for explosives. Those attending the trial had to pass two sets of metal detectors.

"The bombings were neither the beginning nor the end of a terrorist plot to kill Americans," Mr Butler said."In the blink of an eye everything changed. What [the bombings] did to human beings that day defies description. Words and numbers cannot describe the horror."

Mohammed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, a 24-year-old Saudi Arabian, is accused of being in the vehicle that carried the Nairobi bomb, and 27-year-old Khalfan Khamis Mohammed, from Tanzania, is accused of being in the truck that contained the explosives in Dar es Salaam.

The other two, said to have been involved in the wider conspiracy, face life in jail if convicted. They are Wadih el-Hage, a 40-year-old American citizen born in the Lebanon and said to have been Mr Bin Laden's personal secretary, and MohamedSaddiq Odeh, a Jordanian, 35, who is accused of running a fishing business to support the group in Kenya. They plead not guilty.

The prosecution is expected to use contested confessions, and computer and telephone records in the course of the trial, which could last up to a year. Whittling down the jury to 12 members and six alternates from a pool of 1,300 took a month in itself.

In all, 22 men have been charged with involvement in the conspiracy to kill Americans: the four on trial in Manhattan, another who will face the court later, one who has pleaded guilty and is expected to be a star witness for the prosecution, three who are fighting extradition from the United Kingdom, and 13 who remain at large, including Mr Bin Laden. He is believed to be in Afghanistan.

Ali Mohammed, a naturalised American from Egypt who has admitted taking part in the plot, told an earlier hearing that he had been sent by Mr Bin Laden to scout the US embassy in Nairobi. "Bin Laden looked at the picture of the embassy and pointed to where a truck could go as a suicide bomber," he said.

Another man who will testify against the four is known only as CS-1. The man, believed to be a convicted terrorist, says he worked for Mr Bin Laden until five years ago.

Robert Precht, who was a lawyer for one of the defendants in the World Trade Centre trial, said outside the court yesterday: "In this trial the mastermind [of the plot] has already been manufactured by the extensive press coverage, the attacks by politicians on Bin Laden, and even the public statements and military actions of former President [Bill] Clinton.

"To the extent that Bin Laden has become a focal point, he becomes a ready-made mastermind for the defence," he said.

In the dock: the accused

Khalfan Khamis Mohammed
Age 27, from Tanzania

Sometimes called "KK", he is accused of riding in the bomb-laden truck to the embassy in Tanzania. He was detained in South Africa in October 1999, and faces the death penalty. He allegedly rented a house as the bomb factory.

Wahid el-Hage
Age 40, from Texas

Born in Lebanon, said to be Osama bin Laden's former secretary. Raised a Roman Catholic, he converted to Islam. In the late 70s he attended the University of South-western Louisiana. In 1992 he went to work for Bin Laden in Sudan and Kenya. The father of seven, he was back in Texas by 199. He now says he is a college freshman living in the 70s and can't remember his family.

Mohamed Saddiq Odeh
Age 35, from Jordan

Arrested days after the Nairobi bombing when he tried to enter Pakistan. Alleged to have said he went to Kenya for five days before the attacks and met an explosives expert who led the Kenyan terrorism cell. Prosecutors say he stayed with other group members at the Hilltop Hotel in Kenya, before travelling on August 5 to meet Osama bin Laden. They said he told them that all the plotters except one had left Kenya a day before the attack, shaving their beards to avoid suspicion. He has a wife and child in Jordan.

Mohammed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali
Age 24, from Saudi Arabia

Arrested five days after the bombing in Nairobi, he was interviewed extensively by the FBI. Prosecutors say he denied having a role but changed his story, saying he rode in the truck and threw a stun grenade at guards. Allegedly he discarded two keys to the padlock of the vehicle at a hospital. He says his confession was coerced. If convicted he could be executed.
