The man, believed to be a convicted terrorist, says he worked for Mr Bin Laden until five years ago. Robert Precht, who was a lawyer for one of the defendants in the World Trade Centre trial, said outside the court yesterday: "In this trial the mastermind [of the plot] has already been manufactured by the extensive press coverage, the attacks by politicians on Bin Laden, and even the public statements and military actions of former President [Bill] Clinton. "To the extent that Bin Laden has become a focal point, he becomes a ready-made mastermind for the defence," he said. In the dock: the accused Khalfan Khamis Mohammed Age 27, from Tanzania Sometimes called "KK", he is accused of riding in the bomb-laden truck to the embassy in Tanzania. He was detained in South Africa in October 1999, and faces the death penalty. He allegedly rented a house as the bomb factory. Wahid el-Hage Age 40, from Texas Born in Lebanon, said to be Osama bin Laden's former secretary. Raised a Roman Catholic, he converted to Islam. In the late 70s he attended the University of South-western Louisiana. In 1992 he went to work for Bin Laden in Sudan and Kenya. The father of seven, he was back in Texas by 199. He now says he is a college freshman living in the 70s and can't remember his family. Mohamed Saddiq Odeh Age 35, from Jordan Arrested days after the Nairobi bombing when he tried to enter Pakistan. Alleged to have said he went to Kenya for five days before the attacks and met an explosives expert who led the Kenyan terrorism cell. Prosecutors say he stayed with other group members at the Hilltop Hotel in Kenya, before travelling on August 5 to meet Osama bin Laden. They said he told them that all the plotters except one had left Kenya a day before the attack, shaving their beards to avoid suspicion. He has a wife and child in Jordan. Mohammed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali Age 24, from Saudi Arabia Arrested five days after the bombing in Nairobi, he was interviewed extensively by the FBI. Prosecutors say he denied having a role but changed his story, saying he rode in the truck and threw a stun grenade at guards. Allegedly he discarded two keys to the padlock of the vehicle at a hospital. He says his confession was coerced. If convicted he could be executed.

webTitle: Blackhurst back at the Indie

fields.headline: Blackhurst returns to the Independent
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
4pm: The former Express deputy editor has rejoined his old paper as an investigative political writer, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: Express Takeover
fields.body:
Former Express deputy editor Chris Blackhurst has resurfaced at his old paper, the Independent, just two weeks after leaving the Express with Rosie Boycott.

Mr Blackhurst said he was "delighted to be going back to what I enjoy, which is writing and getting stories - especially in the run-up to a general election".

He has been signed on a three-month writing contract and will focus on political investigations.

Mr Blackhurst confirmed the appointment but was unwilling to provide further information about his role.

Mr Blackhurst was Ms Boycott's deputy while at the Independent and was brought with her to the Express when she took the editorship in 1999.

His new Independent job marks a return to political journalism for Mr Blackhurst.

He was Westminster correspondent on the Independent on Sunday and then on the Independent.

Mr Blackhurst was appointed deputy editor of the Independent on Sunday by Ms Boycott when she joined in 1996.

He then became deputy at the Independent when Ms Boycott was made editor.

While at the Independent, Mr Blackhurst broke the story of John Birt's tax arrangements and paymaster-general Geoffrey Robinson's offshore trust.

webTitle: Bishop tells Bloody Sunday inquiry of dying youth

fields.headline: Bishop tells Bloody Sunday inquiry of dying youth
fields.standfirst: Special report: Bloody Sunday
fields.trailText: The former Bishop of Derry, Dr Edward Daly, today told the Bloody Sunday inquiry how he helped carry a dying teenager through the streets of Bogside after the boy was shot by British paratrooper.
fields.body:
The former Bishop of Derry, Dr Edward Daly, today told the Bloody Sunday inquiry how he helped carry a dying teenager through the streets of Bogside after the boy was shot by British paratrooper.

Recalling his role in events after paratroopers opened fire on a protest march on January 30, l972, Dr Daly said he had helped lead a teenager to safety by waving a white, bloodstained handkerchief.

Footage of Dr Daly, now 67, crouched and leading a way to safety amid army gunfire, was beamed around the world and came to epitomise the horror of events in the city that day. The young man being carried, Jack Duddy, 17, was the first of 13 Catholic men and youths to be shot dead by British troops.

Dressed in a black clerical suit, Dr Daly took the stand at the inquiry and said he had urged his Catholic parishioners not to get involved in confrontation on the day of Bloody Sunday. He told today's hearing that, just hours before the march, he had appealed to his congregation at the city's St Eugene's Cathedral.

He said: "I clearly remember speaking at the end of mass, saying there was activity and not to get involved and to go home quietly." He retired as Bishop of Derry in 1993 after suffering a stroke and, as he prepared to give evidence at the hearing in Derry's Guildhall today, he was told by tribunal chairman, Lord Saville of Newdigate, to feel free to take breaks when needed.

Dr Daly had warned in his written statement to the inquiry that he had suffered some memory problems and confusion, although the principal events were still "fairly clear" in his mind.

His voice occasionally cracked with emotion when he recalled: "I was not sure if Jackie Duddy was dead or not. We just decided it was imperative to get him to hospital. I don't know when Jackie Duddy died."

Once Duddy's body was removed, the bishop then tended to other dead and wounded in the Bogside, but was unsure how many.

He said: "When I went down there I thought the whole action had been confined to the square. I was just aghast when I went down there and saw what happened."

Later asked if he had any sense of danger before the march, he replied: "No. Speaking for myself. My plans for that evening were to rehearse a play we were producing. I did not anticipate I would be late for the rehearsal."

webTitle: Councils must have a central role in care trusts

fields.headline: Councils must have a central role in care trusts
fields.trailText: Comment: With the creation of care trusts some social services will effectively be run by the NHS. But if the reforms are to work councils should be given a meaningful role in holding the health service to account, writes Nick Harvey
fields.body:
One of the less remarked-on provisions of the health and social care bill making its way through parliament is its creation of care trusts.

These new bodies will combine aspects of social services, currently provided by local authorities, with health services, provided in the NHS by primary care trusts (PCTs).

Few would oppose closer working arrangements between health and social services. At times, their contradictory working practices and separate funding streams frequently rub against each other.

At its worst this causes arguments between the two, resulting in patients being left in hospital too long because neither service will take responsibility for their care after being discharged.

Care trusts will be NHS bodies growing out of existing PCTs. Though dressed up as a gradual evolution, the government's approach is to uproot social services, wrest them from councils and plonk them in the NHS.

This will have operational advantages, but raises questions. Local government, for all its shortcomings, has at least some accountability to local communities. The NHS has virtually none. The democratic deficit is a weakness of the NHS and if a major service is to move across then this must be addressed now.

Another impact of the change is the surreptitious nationalisation of social services. The shape of local care varies greatly according to local needs and priorities. Coming under the NHS won't make services entirely homogenous, but the prevalence of central dictat from Whitehall is one of the least appealing features of the NHS. Over time this would make a difference.

Providing social care from within the NHS will also shift from a person-centred service to a patient-centred service. Local government's involvement in housing, transport, recreation, education, the economy and the environment brings a wider perspective than the NHS offers.

Finally, finance. Bringing the two services together with one budget would work much better if the government had followed the recommendation of its own royal commission and made all care - whether nursing or personal care - free.

It is absurd to bring the two systems together as one body with one budget while perpetuating means testing for personal care but not nursing care.

Bureaucracy will have to be sustained, and confusion over what legislation governs an individual's care will be rife. What a missed opportunity to simplify everything and end injustice in one go.

But if the government is set on these reforms, what could improve them? A meaningful role for local authorities must be key.

First, responsibility for public health should be transferred from health authorities to councils, which already run many services that impact upon health. Then give them more power to define what local communities want from their care services, through the health improvement programmes.

Give councils real scrutiny clout - as they seem to be inheriting from the community health councils (CHCs) - and have them staff and support the patient forums that will represent patients and inspect services. Have them commission the patient advisers to help with individual complaints.

Together this would give councils a critical mass of health activity, thereby maintaining some democratic leverage over local health services and keeping together most of the CHC functions many of us fear becoming disparate.

It's not perfect, but it would be significantly better than what is planned.

&#149 Nick Harvey is health spokesman for the Liberal Democrats.

webTitle: BBC arts chief defends Omnibus switch

fields.headline: BBC arts chief defends Omnibus switch
fields.standfirst: Catch up on BBC stories here
fields.trailText:
4.15pm update: BBC arts chief Roly Keating has defended documentary strand Omnibus's move from BBC1 to BBC2. By Jason Deans
Feb 6: BBC2 slot for Omnibus
Catch up on BBC stories here
fields.body:
BBC controller of arts commissioning Roly Keating has defended the move of Omnibus from BBC1 to BBC2, saying the documentary strand will be able to tackle a wider range of subjects.

He also denied that the shift to BBC2 signalled a further marginalisation of BBC arts programming.

"I would say we are putting arts closer to the centre of the BBC's activities than it has been for several years," Mr Keating said.

"There will be more investment and more output that will be better scheduled and promoted more heavily.

"It means Omnibus can tackle a richer range of subjects than has been possible on BBC1."

Mr Keating said this week's BBC1 Omnibus on Nancy Mitford, accompanying the new BBC1 adaptation of her comic novels, was a good example of the kind of documentary that would continue to go out on the mass audience channel.

By contrast, upcoming BBC2 editions of Omnibus will cover subjects including Italian painter Botticelli.

In the next run of the documentary strand, two episodes would go out on BBC1 and six on BBC2, Mr Keating said.

"I don't know what the exact split will be in future - my view is you've got to be pragmatic."

Mr Keating said the new Saturday night arts slot between 7 and 9pm "was the best place to get viewers coming to these kind of programmes".

He added: "We're going from an intermittent 90-minute slot on Sunday to a 40-week a year commitment to two hours on Saturday."

The move follows criticism that heavyweight programmes such as Panorama and arts shows were being pushed out of primetime on BBC1 to enable the station compete better with ITV.

Last year culture secretary Chris Smith expressed concern at plans to switch current affairs and arts programmes such as Panorama and Omnibus from BBC1 to other channels.

He was also alarmed at plans by the BBC to "undermine the rich mix" of shows on BBC1 by switching some of its long-running programmes to BBC2.

webTitle: Comment: Straw's asylum revolution

fields.headline: Straw's asylum revolution
fields.standfirst:
Jack Straw's plan to revolutionise the way we treat asylum seekers may restrict their right to sanctuary, writes home affairs editor Alan Travis

Straw in bid to toughen asylum rules
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Comment: Jack Straw's plan to revolutionise the way we treat asylum seekers may restrict their right to sanctuary, writes home affairs editor Alan Travis.
fields.body:
The plan by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to revise the way the west treats the world's asylum seekers has come a long way since he first floated the idea in Lisbon last June.

Germany, France and Italy within Europe and Australia and Canada outside are all believed to be expressing strong interest, turning it from the pet idea of one British minister into a serious project on the world stage.

The proposal that Mr Straw will outline today at a seminar at the Institute of Public Policy Research in London would not close the European door to the world's asylum seekers, but it would radically change the way they are treated.

He hopes to end the criminal trade which forces asylum seekers to travel halfway across the world - often in the back of a lorry or in a dangerously overcrowded ship - to Europe to claim refugee status.

He wants to do this by ensuring that asylum claims are decided not in the final destination country of the migrant, but in the nearest safe haven to the country from which they are fleeing. The plan replicates the United Nations' emergency humanitarian evacuation programme from Kosovo two years ago.

The UN decided in the Balkans who should qualify and then the European Union decided amongst themselves how to share the burden with a quota system for each country. In the case of Kosovo, Britain took 4,000 refugees and their dependants. The advantage was that more than half honoured their promise to return home.

In the same way, Mr Straw would have a list of safe countries to which asylum seekers could flee and where their applications would be decided before they were dispersed around the world on a quota system.

For example, Afghans fleeing the Taliban regime would apply in neighbouring Pakistan for UN refugee status and, if accepted, would then come to Europe. One advantage for Britain would be that the iniquitous voucher and dispersal system could be abolished.

But critics of Mr Straw's plan to revise the way the 1951 UN convention on refugees worry that it would diminish the right of individuals to claim asylum.

They also say there may be a danger - as with famine relief - that the number of refugees helped would become dependant on the politics of the last humanitarian disaster to hold the attention of European television viewers.

webTitle: After the purge

fields.headline: After the purge
fields.standfirst: In the wake of Sarah Payne's death, the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth caught the national mood of fear and loathing. As residents routed out suspected paedophiles, innocents were terrorised and riots split the community. But what happened next? Seven months on,  Dave Hill  pays a visit
fields.trailText: In the wake of Sarah Payne's death, the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth caught the national mood of fear and loathing. As residents routed out suspected paedophiles, innocents were terrorised and riots split the community. But what happened next? Seven months on, Dave Hill pays a visit
fields.body:
It wasn't until he switched on Newsnight that Father Gary Waddington realised he had trouble brewing in his own backyard. Driving home after dining out with friends, he'd seen the burning car surrounded by onlookers, fire fighters and police, but could never have imagined what the scene signified. "I just thought there'd been an accident," he says. "Then I realised I was seeing exactly the same thing on my television screen, with Jeremy Paxman explaining what was really going on - almost literally on my doorstep."

From Father Gary's garden gate you get a view of where the paedophile-purgers of the Paulsgrove estate got into their stride. A municipal green slopes down from the front of St Michael and All Angels church until it meets Allaway Avenue, with its promenade of shops and the local housing office of Portsmouth city council. Facing this stands the second-floor flat where Victor Burnett, 55, used to live, and which he had vacated only hours before a group of his neighbours wanted him out.

There'd been mutterings about Burnett since he'd moved in two years ago. But after he became one of the convicted child sex offenders "named and shamed" by the News of the World following the death of Sarah Payne, and after further coverage in the local press, the mutterings turned into howls of hate. Placards were brandished, missiles thrown and a police officer injured. At one point a woman, thought to have been Burnett's sister, came on the scene. Her car was turned over and torched.

On the same day, August 3, that the News of the World bowed to pressure to stop naming and shaming, the paedophile story got fresh legs. Paulsgrove was the place where it ran. Seven months later it is still running. It took a week for Paulsgrove's dispensers of unofficial justice to extend it to a dozen or so other residents of their own or the adjoining Wymering estate, and, in the process, get the media goggling, the politicians flapping and parents everywhere worrying about predatory "perverts" lurking down their way.

By contrast, the forces of conventional authority have had a lengthier task. The wheels of law and order are still turning. Fifty people were arrested during the period of the protests, 39 of whom were charged. Most of these have come before magistrates in recent weeks: the minor cases have been dealt with, the more serious will go to crown court later in the year. Meanwhile, at ground level, fears have had to be stilled and scars healed.

"It could have happened anywhere," Father Gary says as he takes me on a tour through Paulsgrove. It's not urban unrest country. Paulsgrove does not bloom with affluence, but nor does it reek of decay. Sixty per cent of its properties are owner-occupied and early residents, called "Grovers", maintain a pioneering spirit. Theirs, though, was not the sort of solidarity paraded by the "perv-hunters".

Councillor David Horne, a resident of Paulsgrove for 36 years, describes how "the whole estate was touched by it. If they didn't see it for themselves, they saw it on the news every night. There were lots of terrified people asking each other 'are they going to come down my street next?' Most people look on the protesters with nothing but contempt. You could say the community has united against them. Most of all, they would just like to forget."

The council remains engaged in social fabric surgery. Rob Hutchinson, director of Portsmouth social services, says: "We've got into a closer dialogue with the community; a respectable community which is articulating itself in a way that it hasn't done before. The established local groups like the tenants associations, and more recently the protesters, have been contributing in a responsible and sensible way."

But getting to this stage has not been easy. The problem was establishing a dialogue with the protest organisers - Residents Against Paedophiles, as they are known - with their mobile-phone networks, business cards and mob which trailed in their wake. And once the protests were called off came the long slog of reconstruction. A "Keep Safe" programme has been running in the schools, and last month a Paulsgrove primary hosted the launch of council-funded child protection awareness sessions.

Hutchinson and others have also offered reassurance that the system designed to protect the public against paedophiles works. He stresses that following previous expressions of concern, Burnett had been the subject of two public protection conferences involving social services, probation staff and the police - the standard procedure. The conclusion of both assessments was that, despite his previous record, there was no evidence that Burnett was going back to his old ways. As for the others who attracted Rap's attentions, the authorities are certain that none posed a threat. Up to 20 people were screened by social services, the probation service and the police. Of these, some had no criminal record, no charges pending, nor even any previously recorded allegation of criminal activity. Others did have convictions, of which some were for sexual offences. But these were not against young children and, in one case, had been committed many years ago with no subsequent reoffending.

In short, all the protesters' targets subsequent to Burnett were victims of rumour, gossip and, in some cases, sheer spite. Nor were those besieged and terrorised inside their homes the only victims, according to Superintendent Bob Golding who was in charge of policing: "There are the children who witnessed the demos or took part; some of them were only four or five years old. Then there were others in the area, intimidated by what was happening and too scared to speak out."

The legacy of bloodlust may be hardest to erase. Most of those who had their collars felt were just boy rowdies, out for fun. But it's the images of women and their children marching through the night that stick most in the mind: infants toting cardboard coffins, mothers chanting hate. It may have been triggered by a combination of local circumstances and national news events. But Paulsgrove still came to represent with terrible vividness a mood of fear and loathing in the national psyche.

If the leading lights of Rap are anything to go by, that mood may rise again. Among the most vocal was Katrina Kessell, 33-year-old lone mother of five, and a victim of sexual abuse as a child. She regrets the violence, but not being fined £60 last Monday for, as she puts it, "shouting me mouth off in the street".

She sticks by her assertion that only the undeserving got the doorstep treatment: "We checked them all out properly, we had people down the library looking back through the newspapers." She says the longer-term benefits are clear. By Kessell's reckoning, all but two paedophiles now remain to pose a threat to children, and they at least, she says, are being "properly monitored" by the police: "It's a lot better round here now they've gone."

Moreover, she explains, seeing off the paedo-menace has yielded other improvements: the child protection sessions are part of a council drive to assuage community fears that has been careful to take grass-roots sentiment on board. Plus, she says, there's been a healthy growth of public spirit: "A lot of us are closer than we were. Looking out for our kids has helped bring people together."

Father Gary recalls that "the more obvious it became that completely innocent citizens were being driven from their homes, the more people started to think about the problem of paedophiles a bit more deeply. They began to ask well, if we don't have these people here, where else will they go? Or, just because we haven't got them living in our streets, does that mean they stop being a danger to our children?" But as Father Gary also said: "It was a pretty frightening way to start up a debate."
fields.bodyText: It wasn't until he switched on Newsnight that Father Gary Waddington realised he had trouble brewing in his own backyard. Driving home after dining out with friends, he'd seen the burning car surrounded by onlookers, fire fighters and police, but could never have imagined what the scene signified. "I just thought there'd been an accident," he says. "Then I realised I was seeing exactly the same thing on my television screen, with Jeremy Paxman explaining what was really going on - almost literally on my doorstep." From Father Gary's garden gate you get a view of where the paedophile-purgers of the Paulsgrove estate got into their stride. A municipal green slopes down from the front of St Michael and All Angels church until it meets Allaway Avenue, with its promenade of shops and the local housing office of Portsmouth city council. Facing this stands the second-floor flat where Victor Burnett, 55, used to live, and which he had vacated only hours before a group of his neighbours wanted him out. There'd been mutterings about Burnett since he'd moved in two years ago. But after he became one of the convicted child sex offenders "named and shamed" by the News of the World following the death of Sarah Payne, and after further coverage in the local press, the mutterings turned into howls of hate. Placards were brandished, missiles thrown and a police officer injured. At one point a woman, thought to have been Burnett's sister, came on the scene. Her car was turned over and torched. On the same day, August 3, that the News of the World bowed to pressure to stop naming and shaming, the paedophile story got fresh legs. Paulsgrove was the place where it ran. Seven months later it is still running. Fifty people were arrested during the period of the protests, 39 of whom were charged. Most of these have come before magistrates in recent weeks: the minor cases have been dealt with, the more serious will go to crown court later in the year. It's not urban unrest country. Paulsgrove does not bloom with affluence, but nor does it reek of decay. Sixty per cent of its properties are owner-occupied and early residents, called "Grovers", maintain a pioneering spirit. Theirs, though, was not the sort of solidarity paraded by the "perv-hunters". The problem was establishing a dialogue with the protest organisers - Residents Against Paedophiles, as they are known - with their mobile-phone networks, business cards and mob which trailed in their wake. A "Keep Safe" programme has been running in the schools, and last month a Paulsgrove primary hosted the launch of council-funded child protection awareness sessions. webTitle: Alzheimer's Society ad campaign

fields.headline: Alzheimer's Society to advertise for first time
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: The charity hopes to run a three-year campaign to raise awareness of the illness, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Alzheimer's Society is plotting its first advertising campaign in an effort to raise public awareness of the illness.

The charity, which is planning a three-year advertising drive, is seeing pitches from a number of ad agencies this week.

It hopes to make an appointment later this month.

The charity has an annual marketing budget of approximately £250,000.

"There has been an increase in media interest in dementia and it has become less of a taboo subject," said a spokeswoman for the Alzheimer's Society.

"However, there are still major gaps in people's knowledge about who is afflicted and how the disease can affect people."

The Alzheimer's Society is funded by charitable donations and receives a small government subsidy.

The charity funds research into Alzheimer's disease and works to raise awareness of the condition.

fields.trailText: An Effective Protection Regime for the Twenty-first Century
fields.body:
An Effective Protection Regime for the Twenty-first Century

Speech to IPPR, 6 February 2001

By the Home Secretary, Rt Hon Jack Straw MP

1.Ten days ago, I sat in Westminster Central Hall with the Prime Minister, the Prince of Wales and hundreds of others to mark the first UK Holocaust Memorial Day. On the fifty-sixth anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, it gave us cause to remember Europe's efforts in the war's aftermath to make sure that such suffering never took place again.

2.Those post-war efforts culminated in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, including a right to seek political asylum. The 1951 UN Convention on Refugees gave that right legal statement.

3.In this, the Convention's fiftieth anniversary year, we celebrate the right to asylum. The UK has a proud history of offering shelter to those fleeing persecution. We, the whole of the EU, USA and Canada, and many other countries around the world, are committed to maintaining that tradition and to meeting our obligations under the Convention.

4.Yet the Convention is no longer working as its framers intended.

5.The environment in which it is applied today is one that has changed almost out of all recognition from that of 1951. Numbers of asylum seekers have vastly increased.

6.As a result, the current system is failing many refugees, while at the same time putting huge pressure on receiving nations - not just Western states, but also developing countries which host large numbers of the world's displaced persons.

7.The time has therefore come for the Convention's signatories to re-examine its operation, with a view to making it work as it was intended - to relieve the suffering of genuine refugees.

The problem

8.The Convention was designed for an era when international flows of people were on a much smaller scale than they are today. Intercontinental travel was rare, difficult and expensive.

9.Fifty years on, the world has been transformed. New technology, global communications and cheap international travel have all contributed to a world where rapid, long-distance migration is a realistic option - and a widespread aspiration.

10.This is creating new pressures on every part of our immigration system - not least that part which deals with claims for asylum. In particular, thousands of would-be migrants are taking advantage of one aspect of the Convention - namely, that it places an obligation on States to consider any application for asylum made on their territory, however ill-founded.

11.The statistics speak for themselves. Whilst the potential for large-scale economic migration has expanded, so too the number of people affected by political upheaval has risen. Civil war and internal oppression continue to make conditions difficult in many countries. As a consequence, the number of displaced persons has increased massively.

12. Up until 1988, the UK received around 4,000 asylum applications a year. With the collapse of the Berlin Wall, and the Iron Curtain, the imploding of the economies of Eastern Europe, and civil and cross border wars in the Balkans, Iraq and Iran, Afghanistan, the Horn of Africa, and elsewhere, numbers rose ten fold in the space of three years. However, investment in staff and IT in the Home Office lagged badly behind this surge for a decade. In 2000, 76,000 applications were made and the majority of initial decisions taken during the year resulted in refusals of both asylum and exceptional leave. About 80% of appeals are unsuccessful. Other EU countries have also seen large increases in asylum applicants, many of whom do not qualify for any form of protection. Despite our increases, we remain 7th in the per capita league table.

13. And, since the Convention places no obligation on states to facilitate access to their territory for those in need of protection, many well founded refugees as well as those with no serious claim resort to people-smuggling and other methods of illegal entry in order to access the protection that they need.

14. Taken together, these two trends - of increasing economic migration, and increasing numbers of displaced persons - mean that we are faced with a situation where too much effort and resources are being expended on dealing with unfounded claims for asylum, and not enough on helping those in need of protection.

A way forward?

15. So how can we make the international protection regime work better?

16. First, let me repeat that the UK - and all other signatory States - must meet their basic obligations under the 1951 Convention. That obviously includes giving sanctuary to Convention refugees who arrive at our shores.

17. But our obligations go beyond that.

18. Refugees have a right to expect that their claims will be assessed quickly and fairly; and that they will be integrated into our society.

19. But refugees and the public also have a right to expect that there will be a quick and effective process in place for identifying those who make unfounded claims for asylum.

20. We have achieved a good deal in the last 12 months in striving to reach these goals. The backlog is down. Decisions are up. Applications are being processed more swiftly. We are taking positive action to help recognised refugees feel that they belong in their new home. All of us I hope recognise and appreciate the contribution which many refugees are making to our society, through their work and their culture.

21. We have worked hard to improve on our domestic processes over the last three and a half years. But we have also helped to lead a much more active European Union wide agenda, for what is a shared European problem. At the European Union Heads of State meeting in Tampere in 1999, the Member States committed themselves to building a Common European Asylum System.

22. The UK is at the forefront in driving forward European action in this area. Later this week, Barbara Roche and I will be in Stockholm for the informal meeting of EU justice and home affairs ministers. We will be focussing on asylum and on combating people smuggling and trafficking. I will use the meeting to call for real results by the end of this year on some of the key measures which will set up a Common European Asylum System - on asylum procedures, reception conditions for asylum seekers, and the replacement of the Dublin Convention.

23. We will also emphasise the importance of tackling people smuggling and trafficking particularly through the Western Balkans. The Prime Minister and the Italian Prime Minister (Amato) wrote jointly in the Observer and Corriera della Sera this weekend of the need for strong action against traffickers. Our EU partners are fully signed up to working with us to combat trafficking through the Western Balkans. We expect most of them to attend a planning meeting we are hosting in London next Monday.

24. And on Friday, the Prime Minister, the Foreign Secretary and I will be meeting our French opposite numbers in Cahors in France at the Franco-British Summit. We will use this meeting to press the case for enhanced co-operation between us to combat the problem of illegal immigration from France to the UK, including problems associated with the Eurostar service.

25. All this shows how we are working actively with our European partners to find solutions to the challenges we face.

26. Important however as our domestic procedures are and important as consistent standards in EU Member States are, they are not enough by themselves to resolve the difficulties we face. To do that we need to take a step back and look at the wider picture.

27. That is what I began to do in my speech in Lisbon last June, when I set out some ideas for creating a more rational and effective protection regime. Today I want to develop my thinking a little further.

28. It seems to me that the international community must, collectively, do at least three things better than it is doing now:

29. First, we must help the countries concerned to make conditions in the regions of origin better;

30. Second, we must make it easier for genuine refugees to access the protection regimes of Europe and other Western States, for example by making their journeys less hazardous;

31. Third, we must ensure that those who are not refugees are dissuaded from seeking to benefit unjustly from the terms of the 1951 Convention.

32. Let me take each of these briefly in turn.

Conditions in regions of origin

33. The great majority of the world's refugees are forced to live in areas neighbouring their homeland. It follows that the main focus of the international community's protection efforts should be on these areas.

34. Most refugees want nothing more than to return safely to their own country. They have the best chance of doing that if they are able to stay in safety and dignity in a place as close as possible to home, until such time as it is safe to go back.

35. This was the principle behind the concerted EU effort to help refugees from the Kosovan conflict. The overwhelming majority of displaced people were looked after across the border in neighbouring Macedonia. Those in particularly need were given temporary protection in the UK and other EU member states as apart of the Kosovo Humanitarian Evacuation Programme. Co-ordinated joint action between EU Member States, UNHCR and other agencies meant that many evacuees did not have to flee hundreds of miles to find safety. They were able to return home when it was safe for them to do so and did not have to get embroiled with the criminal traffickers.

36. Yet current spending patterns do not seem to reflect the priority of protection in the regions. On one estimate, about $10 billion is spent annually by developed countries in assessing claims for refugee status, most of which are rejected. But those same countries give only $1 billion a year to UNHCR, the main provider of protection to the millions of displaced persons in the regions of origin.

37. Money is not a panacea, and I am not saying that more money spent in these areas would provide a miracle cure. But I am saying that the balance of effort is wrong.

38. The international community now needs to get together and consider what might be done to redress this imbalance. This is not something the UK can do alone. It is not even something which the EU can do by itself. Instead it requires both the funders and the funded to come together to discuss a way forward.

39. Action in the regions of origin will reduce the pressure on refugees to travel further afield in search of protection.

40. But I do not pretend that all such movement can be brought to an end. There remains the question of how refugees can reach safety in the developed world if help cannot be provided more locally.

Resettlement programme?

41. Some may say that the increased use of visas and the imposition of penalties on carriers is the main barrier preventing refugees from reaching safety, and that the answer is therefore to end these policies. I disagree.

42. Remove measures such as these and we risk an unacceptable rise in uncontrolled economic migration of people seeking to gain entry by making unfounded asylum claims. That would put intolerable pressure on our assessment processes and risk bringing the Convention into dispute.

43. Neither governments nor their publics within Europe and beyond would find this acceptable. We are all committed to the Convention and all wish to see it operate effectively. At the same time, we have a duty to operate immigration policies for the benefit of our communities.

44. So we need other ideas - ideas which enable us to consider asylum claims in the region of origin.

45. One option would be for the EU to set up a resettlement programme, under which an agreed number of refugees - and possibly others in need of protection - would be identified in their own regions and brought to the EU for resettlement. The European Commission has stated, in its November paper on a common EU asylum system, that it will be carrying out feasibility studies on such a programme.

46. I can see potential advantages in such a scheme. The Humanitarian Evacuation Programme from Kosovo I referred to earlier showed how a proactive and co-ordinated EU response could help address a serious protection crisis. That Programme provided temporary protection and gives some useful pointers as to how other programmes for resettlement could contribute to a more orderly and effective international protection system.

47. Equally, there are serious issues to consider such as the cost and scale of any programme, how those selected for resettlement would be allocated to individual Member States, and what the criteria for selection would be. In assessing this, the Commission can draw on the experiences of countries such as the USA, Canada and Australia. The UK will play a constructive part in the Commission's work.

48. It will also be necessary for the EU to fit any procedures for assessing asylum claims overseas into the wider picture. We need to ensure that such external procedures are matched by domestic EU procedures which deal with unfounded asylum claims more speedily than is the case at present. We would also want to see more applications lodged from overseas leading to fewer claims being made within the EU.

49. The aim of my speech in Lisbon was to highlight the inconsistencies and illogicalities in the current global system for the protection of refugees. The Commission Communication on Asylum rightly seeks to look at the asylum system as a whole. The UK will want to play a full part in the developing debate on all these ideas but it is clear that completing the reform of the domestic system will provide the essential platform from which more radical longer term ideas can be considered. Any moves towards the implementation of ideas for processing of claims overseas or substantial resettlement programmes will have to be in parallel with driving down the numbers of unfounded applications.

More effective domestic procedures for weak claims

50. This leads onto my third area: devising better ways of dealing with those who are not in need of protection but who seek to shelter under the umbrella of the Convention.

51. In so doing, these individuals do great damage to asylum systems. They overload the elaborate procedures we have for assessing asylum claims. They cause vast quantities of money to be expended on assessing unfounded claims which might be better spent in the regions of origin. And they can turn the public against genuine refugees.

52. There are two main ways of deterring misuse of this kind. The first is to process claims quickly. There is a range of measures which states can implement domestically to address this. However, there are collective measures which I believe could help.

53. For example, an EU or internationally-agreed list of safe countries or groups from which asylum applications would be ruled inadmissible or considered under a greatly accelerated process. More generally, the EU's development of common asylum policies should reduce the attractions of so-called "asylum shopping".

54. The second aspect of deterring unfounded claims is the prompt return of those found not to need protection. The integrity of any asylum process will be undermined if those who make unfounded claims are able to stay.

55. I therefore make no apology in highlighting this as a fundamental issue for any protection regime. Everyone who is concerned about the need for international protection should be in favour of an effective system for returning those who do not have such a need. One aspect of this is that countries must document and accept back their nationals who do not qualify for protection elsewhere. We are already working with our European partners to conclude Community readmission agreements with third countries.

56. EU States have their particular set of interests on protection issues. Other countries, many of whom provide shelter for the millions of displaced people, have their own set of interests, which might not all be the same as ours. But nor need they be incompatible - all countries have their part to play in meeting the burden of supporting refugees.

57. We need to get together so that we can understand each other's perspectives, and move on from there to identifying collective actions which will deliver the effective protection system we all want. UNHCR's global consultations provide us with an excellent opportunity for such a debate.

Conclusion

58. Most of us can agree that the international protection regime is not operating as well as it should. We need some radical thinking if we are to ensure that the principles of the 1951 Convention are to be applied effectively in the modern age.

59. With the EU looking to move towards a common asylum system, and with UNHCR holding its global consultations exercise, now is the time to have that debate and to find solutions.

60. Asylum is an international issue which requires an international response. And the UK is dedicated to playing its full part in trying to develop a better system of protection.

I will use the meeting to call for real results by the end of this year on some of the key measures which will set up a Common European Asylum System - on asylum procedures, reception conditions for asylum seekers, and the replacement of the Dublin Convention. 23. We will also emphasise the importance of tackling people smuggling and trafficking particularly through the Western Balkans. The Prime Minister and the Italian Prime Minister (Amato) wrote jointly in the Observer and Corriera della Sera this weekend of the need for strong action against traffickers. Our EU partners are fully signed up to working with us to combat trafficking through the Western Balkans. We expect most of them to attend a planning meeting we are hosting in London next Monday. 24. And on Friday, the Prime Minister, the Foreign Secretary and I will be meeting our French opposite numbers in Cahors in France at the Franco-British Summit. We will use this meeting to press the case for enhanced co-operation between us to combat the problem of illegal immigration from France to the UK, including problems associated with the Eurostar service. 25. All this shows how we are working actively with our European partners to find solutions to the challenges we face. 26. Important however as our domestic procedures are and important as consistent standards in EU Member States are, they are not enough by themselves to resolve the difficulties we face. To do that we need to take a step back and look at the wider picture. 27. That is what I began to do in my speech in Lisbon last June, when I set out some ideas for creating a more rational and effective protection regime. Today I want to develop my thinking a little further. 28. It seems to me that the international community must, collectively, do at least three things better than it is doing now: 29. First, we must help the countries concerned to make conditions in the regions of origin better; 30. Second, we must make it easier for genuine refugees to access the protection regimes of Europe and other Western States, for example by making their journeys less hazardous; 31. Third, we must ensure that those who are not refugees are dissuaded from seeking to benefit unjustly from the terms of the 1951 Convention. 32. Let me take each of these briefly in turn. Conditions in regions of origin 33. The great majority of the world's refugees are forced to live in areas neighbouring their homeland. It follows that the main focus of the international community's protection efforts should be on these areas. 34. Most refugees want nothing more than to return safely to their own country. They have the best chance of doing that if they are able to stay in safety and dignity in a place as close as possible to home, until such time as it is safe to go back. 35. This was the principle behind the concerted EU effort to help refugees from the Kosovan conflict. The overwhelming majority of displaced people were looked after across the border in neighbouring Macedonia. Those in particularly need were given temporary protection in the UK and other EU member states as apart of the Kosovo Humanitarian Evacuation Programme. Co-ordinated joint action between EU Member States, UNHCR and other agencies meant that many evacuees did not have to flee hundreds of miles to find safety. They were able to return home when it was safe for them to do so and did not have to get embroiled with the criminal traffickers. 36. Yet current spending patterns do not seem to reflect the priority of protection in the regions. On one estimate, about $10 billion is spent annually by developed countries in assessing claims for refugee status, most of which are rejected. But those same countries give only $1 billion a year to UNHCR, the main provider of protection to the millions of displaced persons in the regions of origin. 37. Money is not a panacea, and I am not saying that more money spent in these areas would provide a miracle cure. But I am saying that the balance of effort is wrong. 38. The international community now needs to get together and consider what might be done to redress this imbalance. This is not something the UK can do alone. It is not even something which the EU can do by itself. Instead it requires both the funders and the funded to come together to discuss a way forward. 39. Action in the regions of origin will reduce the pressure on refugees to travel further afield in search of protection. 40. But I do not pretend that all such movement can be brought to an end. There remains the question of how refugees can reach safety in the developed world if help cannot be provided more locally. Resettlement programme? 41. Some may say that the increased use of visas and the imposition of penalties on carriers is the main barrier preventing refugees from reaching safety, and that the answer is therefore to end these policies. I disagree. 42. Remove measures such as these and we risk an unacceptable rise in uncontrolled economic migration of people seeking to gain entry by making unfounded asylum claims. That would put intolerable pressure on our assessment processes and risk bringing the Convention into dispute. 43. Neither governments nor their publics within Europe and beyond would find this acceptable. We are all committed to the Convention and all wish to see it operate effectively. At the same time, we have a duty to operate immigration policies for the benefit of our communities. 44. So we need other ideas - ideas which enable us to consider asylum claims in the region of origin. 45. One option would be for the EU to set up a resettlement programme, under which an agreed number of refugees - and possibly others in need of protection - would be identified in their own regions and brought to the EU for resettlement. The European Commission has stated, in its November paper on a common EU asylum system, that it will be carrying out feasibility studies on such a programme. 46. I can see potential advantages in such a scheme. The Humanitarian Evacuation Programme from Kosovo I referred to earlier showed how a proactive and co-ordinated EU response could help address a serious protection crisis. That Programme provided temporary protection and gives some useful pointers as to how other programmes for resettlement could contribute to a more orderly and effective international protection system. 47. Equally, there are serious issues to consider such as the cost and scale of any programme, how those selected for resettlement would be allocated to individual Member States, and what the criteria for selection would be. In assessing this, the Commission can draw on the experiences of countries such as the USA, Canada and Australia. The UK will play a constructive part in the Commission's work. 48. It will also be necessary for the EU to fit any procedures for assessing asylum claims overseas into the wider picture. We need to ensure that such external procedures are matched by domestic EU procedures which deal with unfounded asylum claims more speedily than is the case at present. We would also want to see more applications lodged from overseas leading to fewer claims being made within the EU. 49. The aim of my speech in Lisbon was to highlight the inconsistencies and illogicalities in the current global system for the protection of refugees. The Commission Communication on Asylum rightly seeks to look at the asylum system as a whole. The UK will want to play a full part in the developing debate on all these ideas but it is clear that completing the reform of the domestic system will provide the essential platform from which more radical longer term ideas can be considered. Any moves towards the implementation of ideas for processing of claims overseas or substantial resettlement programmes will have to be in parallel with driving down the numbers of unfounded applications. More effective domestic procedures for weak claims 50. This leads onto my third area: devising better ways of dealing with those who are not in need of protection but who seek to shelter under the umbrella of the Convention. 51. In so doing, these individuals do great damage to asylum systems. They overload the elaborate procedures we have for assessing asylum claims. They cause vast quantities of money to be expended on assessing unfounded claims which might be better spent in the regions of origin. And they can turn the public against genuine refugees. 52. There are two main ways of deterring misuse of this kind. The first is to process claims quickly. There is a range of measures which states can implement domestically to address this. However, there are collective measures which I believe could help. 53. For example, an EU or internationally-agreed list of safe countries or groups from which asylum applications would be ruled inadmissible or considered under a greatly accelerated process. More generally, the EU's development of common asylum policies should reduce the attractions of so-called "asylum shopping". 54. The second aspect of deterring unfounded claims is the prompt return of those found not to need protection. The integrity of any asylum process will be undermined if those who make unfounded claims are able to stay. 55. I therefore make no apology in highlighting this as a fundamental issue for any protection regime. Everyone who is concerned about the need for international protection should be in favour of an effective system for returning those who do not have such a need. One aspect of this is that countries must document and accept back their nationals who do not qualify for protection elsewhere. We are already working with our European partners to conclude Community readmission agreements with third countries. 56. EU States have their particular set of interests on protection issues. Other countries, many of whom provide shelter for the millions of displaced people, have their own set of interests, which might not all be the same as ours. But nor need they be incompatible - all countries have their part to play in meeting the burden of supporting refugees. 57. We need to get together so that we can understand each other's perspectives, and move on from there to identifying collective actions which will deliver the effective protection system we all want. UNHCR's global consultations provide us with an excellent opportunity for such a debate. Conclusion 58. Most of us can agree that the international protection regime is not operating as well as it should. We need some radical thinking if we are to ensure that the principles of the 1951 Convention are to be applied effectively in the modern age. 59. With the EU looking to move towards a common asylum system, and with UNHCR holding its global consultations exercise, now is the time to have that debate and to find solutions. 60. Asylum is an international issue which requires an international response. And the UK is dedicated to playing its full part in trying to develop a better system of protection. webTitle: MacLaurin in buyout of events arm

fields.headline: PR firm agrees buyout of events arm
fields.trailText:
3.45m: MacLaurin has agreed to a management buyout of its video and events division in a £300,000 deal, writes Julia Day.
Feb 5: MacLaurin rebrands
fields.body:
PR company MacLaurin has agreed to a management buyout of its video and events division, MCM Productions, in a deal believed to be worth £300,000.

The news follows the rebranding of MacLaurin with a new logo.

MCM Productions was set up in 1996 by MacLaurin director Neil Crespin to support the company's PR clients, but went on to establish its own client base including Dixons, Subaru World Rally Team, the Guardian and Fila UK.

The division, which has its own on and offline edit facility and TV production crew, generated revenues of £1m last year.

Events and productions MCM worked on last year include the Benetton formula one car launch in Barcelona, a five-month-long roadshow for the cable TV company Telewest and the launch of the Science Museum's Wellcome Wing, which was attended by the Queen.

MCM will retain its headquarters alongside MacLaurin in Bergham Mews, west London.

"This is a major opportunity to own a highly creative video production and event management business," said Mr Crespin.

"The company has established an excellent reputation over the past four years and we intend to aggressively develop this going forward."

webTitle: Emap plans Heat TV series

fields.headline: Emap plans Heat spin-off TV series
fields.trailText:
3.15pm: Emap Elan is to launch a TV series based on Heat magazine, writes Jessica Hodgson.
3pm: Red goes online
fields.body:
It made a massive impact when it launched and then struggled to keep up with the cut-throat world of showbusiness news.

However, Heat magazine is now fighting fit and planning to launch a TV spin-off.

Emap Elan is working on programme plans that could bring "several hours a week" of Heat magazine onto a digital TV channel.

Emap Elan publishes most of Emap's men's and women's magazines.

It is hatching plans to put many more of its best-known titles - including Elle, FHM, Arena and the Face - on television and is talking to broadcasters and independent production companies.

David Hepworth, editorial director of special projects, and designer Neil Stephenson are overseeing the Heat project.

It is to be produced by television independent the Picture Production Company.

And Emap has appointed Empire publishing director Steve Buckley to explore the idea of putting many of the magazines on TV in masthead-programming deals.

"The brief is to pursue opportunities for programmes for all Emap Elan's magazine brands," said Mr Buckley.

However, he was cagey about specific plans.

Mr Buckley said first off the mark would be the Empire awards, which would be produced by the Picture Production Company and screened on FilmFour on February 21.

But the company is also involved in planning programmes based on Heat.

The developments at Emap Elan mirror similar plans under way at Emap Performance, which has already created 24-hour TV channels based on Q and Smash Hits.

The strategy marks a return to masthead-programming for Emap's consumer magazine brands.

Two years ago, Emap experimented with a masthead show based on FHM, which was abandoned.

webTitle: The Israeli election

fields.headline: The Israeli election
fields.standfirst:
Israel is voting for a new prime minister. Richard Moriarty explains why so much rests on this election

Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel is voting for a new prime minister. We explain why so much rests on this election.
fields.body:
Israelis have gone to the polls today after Ehud Barak's government, elected just 21 months ago, lost majority support in the Knesset, Israel's parliament.

Why did Barak lose support?
Presiding over a coalition government, support for Barak was always whimiscal. Elected on a peace platform, he carried out his manifesto pledge to withdraw Israeli troops from Lebanon within his first year of office and also pursued peace with Syria. But support for his government was damaged when his attempts at a peace deal with the Palestinians failed.

So what went wrong?
Barak lost support from the Knesset because Jewish Israelis were angered by his pursuit of peace in spite of the increasingly violent intifada. Arab Israelis were also angered by his use of troops to quell the uprising - a decision later condemned by the United Nations. Additionally, his offer to share sovereignty of Jerusalem with the Palestinians annoyed Israeli rightwingers, and ended in failure when it was rejected by Yasser Arafat. Despite winning a confidence vote in the Knesset, Barak called a new election to renew his mandate for peace.

Who's going to win?
Barak is expected to be on the end of the heaviest political defeat in Israel's history as Ariel Sharon, leader of the hard right Likud party, and champion of Jewish settlements, is 22 points ahead in the polls. Arab Israelis, who would usually support Barak, are boycotting the election in protest at the killing of 13 young, unarmed Arab Israeli demonstrators by police last year.

What are the differences in manifestos?
Both Barak and Sharon are fighting the election on security issues. Barak told voters that they should choose between "Barak or war", while at the start of his campaign, Sharon pledged: "Only I can bring you peace and security and protect Jerusalem. Because I know the Arabs and the Arabs know me."

Where does Sharon's core support come from?
The religious right backs his Likud party, but Sharon is also expected to receive massive support from the 1m Russian immigrants who now live in Israel. They form 18% of the electorate and their importance has been shown by Sharon's attempts at speeches in Russian. They have also been targeted by TV adverts in Russian. It was this section of the electorate that was credited with bringing Barak to power in 1999, but they have now turned their backs on him. A Russian was the first Israeli citizen killed by the intifada.

Will a Sharon victory help revive the peace process?
Probably not. Sharon is hated by the Palestinians due to his past exploits in the army and as defence secretary. In 1953, he led a massacre on Qibya, a Palestinian village, which left 69 villagers dead. Under his command, Israeli troops crossed into Lebanon in 1982 and this led to the massacre of more than 1,000 Palestinian refugees living in Beirut by pro-Israeli Lebanese militia. An Israeli report later found Sharon indirectly responsible for the massacre and recommended that he never be allowed to hold the position of defence secretary again. Nabil Shaath, a Palestinian cabinet minister and senior peace negiotiator, said: "It does not look like he is the man who would push the peace process forward. He might - and in fact he looks like the man who is going to - destabilise our area." The isolationist policy of the new US government also means prospects for peace are bleak.

What effect will it really have?
Little effect is expected in the Knesset, as a coalition government will still be required. But in such a volatile political situation, the prime minister's actions can have a serious effect on the region. For example, Sharon's visit to the al-Asqa mosque in East Jerusalem sparked the four-month long intifada that has claimed hundreds of lives. Sharon insists that all of Jerusalem must remain in Israeli hands and that Palestinians must not be given more than the 42% of the West Bank they already have. This could mean the intifada being prolonged - especially as candidates hoping to replace Arafat vie for position.

What about Yasser Arafat?
Arafat is struggling to keep control of the Palestinian Fatah party due to his age. During the intifada, new leaders have appeared, although Arafat continues to be an important figurehead. If and when Sharon replaces Barak, Arafat will probably have lost his best chance of winning a peace deal and a Palestinian homeland.

webTitle: Red goes online

fields.headline: Red goes online
fields.trailText: 3pm: Emap's Red has upped the ante in the online women's magazine market with the launch of its first website, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Red, the magazine for thirtysomethings, has upped the ante in the online women's magazine market with the launch of its first website.

Hoping to make its mark on the internet, RedDirect.co.uk will go head-to-head with allabouteve.co.uk, the website for rival magazine Eve that was launched last summer.

While RedDirect.co.uk has some catching up to do, it has the marketing muscle of Emap behind it, and can use Emap Digital's first women's website, NewWoman.co.uk, to help build up an online following.

New media director Carmel Hayes said the strategy was to launch a series of magazine brand-oriented websites from its stable of women's titles.

Emap launched its first website for women four years ago using the New Woman brand, and is now looking at ways to target different female demographics.

NewWoman.co.uk, for example, focuses on "Diet Coke break" women aged 25 to 35 years olds.

RedDirect.co.uk is to be built into a flagship Emap Digital brand aimed at fashionable and high-spending 30 to 40-year-old women.

Other Emap Elan magazines, such as Elle, Elle Decoration, Top Sante, more!, J17 and Bliss, are expected to be extended go online in the next year.

"We want to create a new online communities on the back of the ready-made communities the magazines offers," said Ms Hayes, adding that Emap had decided not to follow its competitors in developing a generic women's portal.

"It's not about trying to be all things to all women, it's about understanding what your audiences wants. Our audience trust the Red brand and its recommendations - they don't have time to search for the best health product, book or dress."

Red boasts a readership of 600,000.

A shopping section, Red Direct Home Shopping, will offer four product categories: jewellery, fashion and accessories, gifts and kids.

Red was launched in January 1998 on the back of a £2.5m marketing campaign. It has recently had a change of editor after Sally Brompton left after nine months, and deputy editor Trish Halpin stepped up to take the reins.

webTitle: Wakeham declares power of press watchdog

fields.headline: Wakeham declares power of press watchdog
fields.trailText:
12.15pm: The chairman of the Press Complaints Commission today claimed it had changed the publishing culture, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 5: A decade of diplomacy
Jan 26: Prince invited to PCC party
fields.body:
Lord Wakeham, the chairman of the Press Complaints Commission, today claimed the regulator had "changed the entire culture of British newspapers and magazines".

In a report marking the body's 10th anniversary, Lord Wakeham said: "Ten years ago, I doubt there were very many editors who stopped themselves to ask 'Can we get away with it?' - because they knew they could.

"Today, the application and observance of the code are very much a part of the culture of every newsroom and editorial office."

The code of practice was tightened after the death of Princess Diana three-and-a- half years ago.

Guidelines on long-lens photography banned the paparazzi from private property, including restaurants and churches.

New controls on doorstepping were also introduced, stopping hordes of journalists (and particularly TV cameras) camping at private addresses in the hope of getting an interview.

Lord Wakeham said in his report that "huge advances" had been made in the protection of privacy.

He claimed the PCC had proved "self regulation is a key manifestation of freedom of expression" and put paid to clamours for statutory regulation of the press.

He added: "There are no serious commentators now who believe statutory controls are either desirable or practical."

Lord Wakeham contrasted the perception of the press and regulation today with the controversial situation at the beginning of the 1990s.

At that time, David Mellor claimed the popular press were "drinking in the last chance saloon".

Mr Mellor, then the "minister of fun" at the Department of Heritage, made the remarks following a report in 1993 carried out by Sir David Calcutt.

He threatened to introduce a statutory body if press self-regulation did not lead to a marked improvement in standards of accuracy and privacy.

Lord Wakeham's remarks come the day before the PCC throws a party for newspaper executives and hundreds of celebrities the press has clashed with over the last 10 years.

webTitle: Council 'good practice' winners unveiled

fields.headline: Council 'good practice' winners unveiled
fields.trailText: The government has unveiled its annual "beacon" list identifying the most innovative local authorities, shrugging off Tory criticisms that the scheme is costly and bureaucratic.
fields.body:
The government has unveiled its annual "beacon" list identifying the most innovative local authorities, shrugging off Tory criticisms that the scheme is costly and bureaucratic.

Local government minister Hilary Armstrong announced that 43 beacon awards would go to 39 councils, and more than doubled the funding available to them, bringing it to a total of £1.7m.

The initiative is designed to help councils learn from each other's experiences and expertise. It identifies the authorities providing the best services, and invites other councils to learn from them. Around 95% of authorities in England and Wales have already visited a beacon learning event.

But Conservative local government spokesman Nigel Waterson has attacked the scheme for being expensive and time consuming. He said: "Local residents know better than ministers whether their council is performing well and delivering the services they need."

Although the government has upped the financial support for successful councils, ministers have admitted that the process of becoming a beacon and of spreading good practice through roadshows and open days leaves some authorities out of pocket.

Ministers have also admitted that they have no timetable for introducing the promised phase two of the beacon scheme, in which winning authorities would act as test beds for new spending freedoms and flexibilities, such as the ability to raise extra money through the local business rate.

Beacon supporters, however, maintain that winning councils are already reaping rewards. Cynthia Griffin, director of best practice at the local government Improvement and Development Agency, said: "It's much easier to broker in resources if you're seen as successful It is hard work, but they get an awful lot out of it and so does everyone else."

Ms Armstrong said councils were learning how to make efficiency savings by following the example of other authorities. "Councils like the scheme the way it is," she commented.

The government looks likely to act on complaints from district councils that they were excluded by this year's award categories, which included town centre regeneration and reducing vehicle crime.

Beacon council advisory panel chairman Lord Filkin said: "The panel has already responded to requests for more service areas that can be addressed by shire district councils. We have recommended a good selection to ministers, who will shortly be announcing the new themes."

webTitle: Blunkett to encourage elderly and unemployed to volunteer

fields.headline: Blunkett to encourage elderly and unemployed to volunteer
fields.trailText: Older people and the unemployed are to be encouraged to get involved in community-based voluntary work, under plans to be announced by the government tomorrow. Nicola Hill reports
fields.body:
Older people and the unemployed are to be encouraged to get involved in community-based voluntary work, under plans to be announced by the government tomorrow.

The employment and education secretary, David Blunkett, is to announce the initiative in a keynote speech on volunteering at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations conference tomorrow in London.

The plans will encourage older people to give time to the community and make it easier for unemployed people to volunteer.

Mr Blunkett today pledged an extra £1m to the Community Champions fund, which encourages local people to contribute to their community.

The fund is now in its second year and has so far helped more than 700 individuals and community groups to set up projects.

The Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) has also secured a further £1m a year from the Home Office Active Community fund allowing the programme to extend for a further three years.

The DfEE works in partnership with individual leaders in the voluntary and community sector to galvanise local people into becoming more involved in community and regeneration activity.

Today Mr Blunkett presented awards to 29 groups and individuals that have participated in the Community Champions fund. Winners include a Manchester sports programme that is working to cut crime and a project bringing IT to a rural community in Cornwall.

Mr Blunkett said: "We need local people to get fully involved in driving change forward, if we are to see real improvements in our deprived communities. These 29 Community Champions are doing just that. Their dedication and enthusiasm means that money spent on an area is spent on what local people need."

He added that the extra money for the fund meant it could offer a greater focus on groups, such as older volunteers and people with disabilities and those from ethnic communities.

webTitle: More children behaving badly

fields.headline: More children behaving badly
fields.standfirst:
As the annual Ofsted report notes rising levels of bad behaviour in schools, higher education editor Donald MacLeod sees problems ahead

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: As the annual Ofsted report notes rising levels of bad behaviour in schools, higher education editor Donald MacLeod sees problems ahead.
fields.body:
Boredom is at the root of bad behaviour, suggests the new chief inspector Mike Tomlinson. Inspectors found much to praise in schools in England, he notes in the Ofsted annual report issued today, but bad behaviour in one in 12 schools - higher than in previous years - was a cause for concern.

It obviously threatens progress for the minority causing the trouble, as well as for their unfortunate classmates whose lessons are disrupted. As teachers will tell you, it is not so much the full-scale shouting incident or violence, but the drip-drip of petty disruption that is so wearing for them and damaging to learning.

It is a largely a secondary school problem, and Mr Tomlinson said that schools were not taking enough notice of what pupils had achieved at primary.

"As a consequence, challenge is not as high as it might be and then motivation dips," he said.

That is one factor. Liaison between secondary and primary schools still leaves a lot to be desired. But more worrying is the "success" of Ofsted and the government in turning primary schools into more regimented institutions which constantly test their pupils.

This has improved their maths scores but done nothing for the motivation of some of the children who are being drilled to pass - or fail.

The literacy and numeracy hours are squeezing out other subjects like design and technology or geography, laments Mr Tomlinson's own report.

But it is utterly predictable that, if primary teachers and headteachers are judged on tests in English, maths and science, then they are going to teach to the tests.

Eleven year-olds used to be keen and willing when they arrived at secondary school - now, in too many cases, they are already bored and ripe for mischief.

A better balance needs to be found in English primary schools between the basics and breadth and enjoyment.

Mr Tomlinson might be the man to encourage this and undo some of the Gradgrind damage done by his predecessor Chris Woodhead.

But the fundamental problems of bad behaviour in the classroom can only be tackled by getting more good teachers into the profession. The premature retirement of swathes of experienced teachers in their 50s in the interests of efficiency has left schools without the old hands whose practical knowledge of keeping discipline was irreplaceable.

The next wave of teachers in their 40s is about to go.

The teacher shortage is going to get worse - thank goodness. It will help to concentrate the minds of politicians and voters, and go a little way to restoring the standing of the profession.

Teachers used to be mentioned in the same breath as lawyers and doctors; now they are classed with nurses and police constables. And we all know what difficulties they have with behaviour.
