webTitle: Disillusioned Israelis go to polls

fields.headline: Disillusioned Israelis go to polls
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Voters in Israel are casting ballots today in a prime ministerial election that could shut down the already troubled Middle East peace process.
fields.body:
Voters in Israel are casting ballots today in a prime ministerial election that could shut down the already troubled Middle East peace process.

The hardline rightwing candidate, Ariel Sharon, is widely expected to win today's election, a prospect that has caused outrage among Palestinians.

Casting his ballot at a Jerusalem school this morning, a tense-looking Mr Sharon said that a vote for him was a vote for an undivided Jerusalem under Israeli sovereignty.

In an unprecedented attempt to reach a peace deal with the Palestinians, Mr Barak proposed sharing sovereignty in Jerusalem with Palestinians and handing over up to 95% of the West Bank and Gaza. His offer fell short of Palestinian demands and increased frustration at the peacemaking deadlock.

Mr Barak resigned in December, two and a half years before the end of his term. He said he would seek a mandate for peace negotiations.

It was a visit four months ago by Mr Sharon - the architect of Israel's 1982 Lebanon invasion and a champion of Jewish settlements visit - to a bitterly contested Jerusalem site holy to Jews and Muslims that sparked the current wave of violence.

Now Palestinians are watching with trepidation as the election unfolds. Senior Palestinian peace negotiator Nabil Shaath said a Mr Sharon premiership might plunge the Middle East into turmoil. "It does not look like he is the man who would push the peace process forward ... He looks like the man who is going to, destabilise our area."

But others, including Ahmed Abdel-Rahman, secretary-general of the Palestinian authority, said Mr Sharon might modify his stance once in power.

If opinion polls are right, Mr Barak is destined to suffer the most resounding election defeat in Israel's history, only 21 months after winning its biggest victory. The 58-year-old former army chief, whose daring commando missions made him Israel's most decorated soldier, broke taboos on peacemaking during his short time in power and reshaped his country's political debate.

Mr Barak ended Israel's 22-year occupation of south Lebanon last May, bringing the troops home within a year of taking office. But his popularity slumped after he failed to deliver peace with Syria or the Palestinians.

"Barak promised. Barak disappointed. Barak must be replaced," ran the slogans of Mr Sharon's campaign.

When Mr Barak won the last election in May 1999, defeating Likud prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu by 56% to 44%, he promised to be "prime minister of everyone," pursuing peace while healing rifts between left and right, religious and secular.

But Mr Barak has failed to heal the divisions among Israelis. He has managed to disappoint Israeli Arabs, Russian immigrants and swing voters, all large constituencies that helped bring him to power.

Israeli Arabs, whose 12.3% of the electorate backed Barak overwhelmingly in 1999, vowed to abstain this time in protest at the police killing of 13 of their number at the start of the uprising and Mr Barak's perceived neglect of their needs.

webTitle: Banned sect leader fosters culture of confusion

fields.headline: Banned sect leader fosters culture of confusion
fields.standfirst: As the bitter struggle between the banned Falun Gong and the  Chinese government reaches a new pitch, John Gittings examines the nature of the movement and the background of its shadowy  "master"
fields.trailText: John Gittings in Shanghai examines the Falun Gong and the background of its shadowy "master".
fields.body:
The struggle between the Chinese government and the banned Falun Gong (FLG) sect may seem far removed from the cosmopolitan city of Shanghai. Yet it continues to be waged in the residential areas away from the downtown shopping malls and high-rise office blocks. Every city district has been holding meetings to convince ordinary citizens that the FLG is an "evil cult" and that the attempted suicides in Tiananmen Square last month are the final proof. In at least one district, the meeting was designed for the "family members" of FLG adherents - an indication that they still exist in sufficient numbers to be taken seriously. A mobile library has been cruising around local housing estates with a display of "anti-heresy" books. After a year and a half, the crackdown ordered personally by President Jiang Zemin still seems far from succeeding.

The outside world is still a long way from forming a balanced view of this movement. The task has been immensely complicated by Beijing's punitive reaction, which violates the ordinary human rights of thousands of Chinese. We do not have to believe every report of deaths and torture in prisons: the rough handling of FLG protesters in Tiananmen Square gives a good guide to the authorities' ruthlessness.

Yet while the sight of rank and file FLG members quietly risking their lives is impressive, it also raises questions about why they are doing so. These have been sharpened by the suicide attempt, in which one of the group actually died. (While FLG spokespeople insist that the incident was a frame-up, it is extremely hard to see how this could have been staged.) The most serious questions concern the role of the movement's master, Li Hongzhi, and the pronouncements he has issued from the safety of his US exile.

Some analysts point to the increasingly apocalyptic tone of the master's messages, which may have encouraged his followers to go to such extreme lengths. For several years he has talked in vague terms about a coming "catastrophe" which will eliminate the "bad people" while allowing those who have followed his path to achieve salvation. Last year Mr Li went further, claiming that a dire prophecy by the 16th century French soothsayer Nostradamus referred to the current situation in China. He said that a reference in the prophecy to the Roman god Mars really indicated Marx -- or the Chinese Communist party.

In several messages last autumn, Mr Li denounced those of his followers who were forced to recant their faith, saying that they were serving the evil purposes of the regime. There seems no doubt that many practitioners headed for Tiananmen Square to face the regime's wrath, believing this was what the master required them to do.

This was made very clear in an article, supposedly written by an anonymous practitioner, which the FLG circulated in December. The writer urged his fellow practitioners "not to cover up yourself with excuses anymore. Teacher (the master) and yourself know your thoughts the best. The only thing left is whether or not you are willing to step forward and/or are capable of doing so."

In a New Year's Day message, Mr Li carried his exhortation a stage further, arguing that "forbearance" had its limits when faced with evil. "If the evil has already reached the point where it is unsaveable and unkeepable, then various measures at different levels can be used to stop it and eradicate it." Although vaguely worded, the message appears to have been interpreted by some followers as an instruction to abandon non-violence. Ten days later another message was posted to correct the misunderstanding.

Falun Gong spokespeople have stressed that Mr Li continues to preach non-violence and that suicide is specifically excluded. But they also offer conflicting interpretations of his new year message: in one version, he was simply saying it was time "to step forward and inform the public of the truth". In another interpretation, he was predicting that the "evil forces" opposed to the FLG would meet disaster by supernatural means.

Some experts who have studied the FLG closely feel that the net effect of Mr Li's exhortations has been to ratchet up the psychological pressure on his supporters to take extreme measures, including the suicide attempts.

Other observers reject this view, arguing that FLG statements have also urged moderation. One from the master in August explicitly told followers that getting themselves jailed was not the only way of achieving merit, reportedly prompting some adherents to avoid active protest.

At the very least the master has caused considerable confusion among his followers, in circumstances that for them (but not for him) may mean the difference between life and death.

Sharper questions are also being asked about the master's past, his spiritual claims, his sources of income, and his motives for taking on the Chinese government. Although some of these were raised when he first emerged into the limelight, attention since then has focused understandably upon Beijing's savage treatment of his followers. Most western media have refrained from describing the Falun Gong as a cult, perhaps partly because the word was appropriated by Beijing.

One of the few analysts to take a more critical look, the well-known Chinese intellectual Dai Qing, made a prescient forecast last year in a postscript to a speech she had given at Harvard.

"As long as the Communist party unreasonably insists that it is the only organisation to be respected, and FLG followers blindly worship and unconditionally follow their master", she wrote, "many frightful scenarios can still occur."

Ms Dai describes Mr Li as "capable yet immoral, ambitious yet irresponsible". She points out the obvious fact that until April 1999, when Mr Li arranged a provocative demonstration in Beijing (and immediately left the country for the US), his followers were left alone to practise their beliefs.

Ms Dai concludes that the unequal struggle between the FLG and Beijing has become the largest conflict in China's transition towards modernity - and that the behaviour of both sides is still rooted in the past.

In another interpretation, he was predicting that the "evil forces" opposed to the FLG would meet disaster by supernatural means. Some experts who have studied the FLG closely feel that the net effect of Mr Li's exhortations has been to ratchet up the psychological pressure on his supporters to take extreme measures, including the suicide attempts. Other observers reject this view, arguing that FLG statements have also urged moderation. One from the master in August explicitly told followers that getting themselves jailed was not the only way of achieving merit, reportedly prompting some adherents to avoid active protest. At the very least the master has caused considerable confusion among his followers, in circumstances that for them (but not for him) may mean the difference between life and death. Sharper questions are also being asked about the master's past, his spiritual claims, his sources of income, and his motives for taking on the Chinese government. Although some of these were raised when he first emerged into the limelight, attention since then has focused understandably upon Beijing's savage treatment of his followers. Most western media have refrained from describing the Falun Gong as a cult, perhaps partly because the word was appropriated by Beijing. One of the few analysts to take a more critical look, the well-known Chinese intellectual Dai Qing, made a prescient forecast last year in a postscript to a speech she had given at Harvard. "As long as the Communist party unreasonably insists that it is the only organisation to be respected, and FLG followers blindly worship and unconditionally follow their master", she wrote, "many frightful scenarios can still occur." Ms Dai describes Mr Li as "capable yet immoral, ambitious yet irresponsible". She points out the obvious fact that until April 1999, when Mr Li arranged a provocative demonstration in Beijing (and immediately left the country for the US), his followers were left alone to practise their beliefs. Ms Dai concludes that the unequal struggle between the FLG and Beijing has become the largest conflict in China's transition towards modernity - and that the behaviour of both sides is still rooted in the past. webTitle: Thunderbirds in road tax ad

fields.headline: Thunderbirds' Lady Penelope clamps down on road tax evasion
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The DVLA has recruited Thunderbirds' Lady Penelope in a new campaign against road tax evasion, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Driver & Vehicle Licensing Agency has recruited the services of Thunderbirds' Lady Penelope for an ad campaign against road tax evasion.

In the TV and cinema ad, which breaks today, Lady Penelope is called away from a leisurely shopping trip to an important assignment on Tracy Island.

But her plans for a swift getaway are foiled when she returns to her Rolls to find it has been clamped. The hapless Parker has forgotten to renew her tax disc.

In a fit of pique, Lady Penelope whips out a pair of scissors and Parker slumps to the floor, his strings cut.

"Unpaid car tax costs the government around £183m each year and we intend to clamp down hard on this," said Lynne Hopkins, campaign manager at the DVLA.

"The ad shows that owners of unlicensed vehicles face being wheelclamped. Last year, over 600,000 motorists were successfully penalised for not having a valid tax disc."

The TV campaign is supported by a series of print and poster ads featuring other famous fictional vehicles with wheel clamps.

webTitle: iVillage buys rival Women.com

fields.headline: iVillage buys rival Women.com
fields.trailText: 11.45am: America's largest website for women has been snapped up by iVillage for £20.7m, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Its advice on how to make love like a movie star and its fascinating tips on dating, babies and shopping kept 8m women hooked every month.

But today, America's largest website for women has succumbed to the economies of the dot.com sector, admitting it needed a partner to survive.

Women.com has been snapped up by arch-rival iVillage for £20.7m.

The deal comes amid growing awareness that the web cannot sustain large numbers of niche websites that depend on the dwindling pot of ad revenue for their livelihood.

And it will send alarm bells ringing in the UK, where Femail.co.uk, Handbag.com and BeMe.com were inspired by the huge success of Women.com.

iVillage and Women.com have competed head-to-head in the US market for the past few years, despite a 15% overlap in users.

According to internet measurement stats from Media Metrix, Women.com had the upper hand in December with more than 8.4m unique visitors, compared with iVillage's 6.7m.

However, Women.com has suffered from growing losses in the past year.

The website was forced to lay off a quarter of its workforce and face the prospect of being delisted from the Nasdaq stock market.

iVillage and Women.com recently attempted to move into the UK market.

iVillage's entry was facilitated by a £12.4m investment from Tesco.

However, it has had a limited impact in the UK and has yet to be boosted by the full marketing muscle of Tesco.

UK.women.com, a joint venture between the National Magazine Company and Women.com, has been planned for years.

However, despite appointing launch staff and announcing definite plans, the project was shelved.

The most likely consequence in the UK of iVillage buying Women.com is for iVillage.co.uk and UK.women.com to merge.

The combined operation would probably take the iVillage.co.uk branding.

The acquisition will be financed by a mix of cash and shares.

The move will leave Hearst, the US publisher that set up Women.com, with less than 30% of iVillage.

webTitle: Westferry printing plant sale

fields.headline: Desmond hits hurdle in Westferry sale
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
12.45pm update: Richard Desmond has been knocked back in his attempts to rush the sale of Westferry printing plant, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 6: Desmond to sell stake in Westferry printing plant
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Express owner Richard Desmond has been knocked back in his attempts to rush the sale of his stake in the Westferry printing plant.

Dan Colson, vice-chairman of Hollinger, which owns the Daily Telegraph and is the prospective buyer of the 50% holding, said the company "will not be forced" into a quick deal.

"We don't see any great urgency, and if it takes months then so be it. We will not be forced into doing a less attractive deal just to rush through a quick sale," he said.

Mr Colson added that he had no plans to meet executives from Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell company today, and he is set on a price for the stake.

Mr Desmond acquired the Westferry interest as part of the £125m deal that gave him ownership of the Express newspapers last year.

"We have served notice of our intention to buy them out. We have our views as to what the plant is worth," said Mr Colson.

Hollinger owns the remaining 50% of the highly profitable printing plant, which prints the southern editions of the Guardian, the Financial Times, the Daily Express and the Daily Telegraph.

The sale of the stake will have to be in accordance with a complex co-ownership agreement signed by both parties.

However, insiders at Hollinger have poured scorn on the £80m price tag mooted by Northern & Shell and branded the Express owner as "no bunch of Mother Teresas".

And sources close to Mr Desmond have also conceded that they were aiming too high. However, they believe they can extract up to £60m from the Telegraph.

"The £80m figure is completely spurious. It bears no resemblance to the number that would have come out of the agreement. The price would be a fraction of that," said one source.

Mr Desmond would benefit from a quick sale of the Westferry holding, as he borrowed £97m to pay for the Express titles, and up to 200 staff are set to go in a cost-cutting spree at Ludgate House.

webTitle: Election day: what the Israeli papers say

fields.headline: Election day: what the Israeli papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText:
6 February: The Israeli media get used to the idea of Ariel Sharon as prime minister after today's vote.
Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.body:
The Israeli media assume, like the rest of the world, that Ariel Sharon will win today's election by a landslide.

There are widespread predictions that the turnout will be the lowest in Israel's electoral history - a factor deplored by the Tel Aviv daily Ha'aretz. It points out in its leading article today that the country is about to choose its fifth prime minister in less than nine nine years, and that the public is sick of politics: "The rapid successions of authority, the election promises that proved void of all content, and the deceitful uses of the word 'peace,' have all taken their toll - an Israeli public that is known for its active participation in elections is responding with indifference, perhaps even with a modicum of despair."

Veteran commentator Yoel Marcus has a diverting analysis of the election campaign. He writes that while prime minister Ehud Barak talked non-stop of his peace plans, his rightwing opponent Ariel Sharon was uncharacteristically taciturn: "With Sharon enjoying such an impressive edge over Barak in public opinion surveys, the Likud leader's campaign consultants were afraid that any exposure of his intentions and plans could hurt his popularity. This kind of advice raises the suspicion that they knew a few things about their candidate, about his opinions and about his plans that they did their utmost to conceal from the public. While the consultants might describe what they've done as brilliant campaign tactics, in point of fact it looks more like a strategy of deceit."

The Jerusalem Post points out in its leader that although both campaigns concentrated on the peace process, the winner will face an equally important priority: addressing the parlous state of the Israeli economy. Unless the state budget is approved by the Knesset (parliament) by the end of March, there will have to be yet another national election.

That presents a classic opportunity for minor factions to step up their demands on the exchequer - opportunism which the paper deplores: "The fact that the outgoing government failed to pass the 2001 budget will expose the new government to strong pressures to increase spending. Such demands should be strongly resisted, as they threaten to worsen the long-term prospects for economic growth and hurt Israel's credibility and ability to compete in the international arena."

Post columnist Larry Derfner makes the interesting point that if Sharon wins with a massive majority, as predicted, he will have a large number of obligations to the sundry factions which elected him.

Derfner points out that any prime minister who gets a landslide also gets a mandate. But a mandate for what? In a fascinating blend of vox-pop interviews and informed sources, Derfner spells out the central dichotomy of the Sharon campaign - some of his supporters believe fervently that he will make peace from a position of strength; others that he will use that strength to make war.

Also in the Post, columnist Leora Eren Frucht argues that the campaign and its probable outcome, have less to do with the looming issues of war and peace, than with the personalities of the two candidates. Barak came over as clever but cold, while Sharon - normally seen as a bull in a china shop - was projected as an affable grandfather-figure.

webTitle: Desmond to sell Westferry stake

fields.headline: Desmond to sell Westferry stake
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Express owner Richard Desmond will today sell his stake in the Westferry printing plant, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Express owner Richard Desmond will today seek to take the pressure off his cash-strapped titles by selling his stake in the Westferry printing plant.

Representatives of his Northern & Shell company are meeting senior managers at Daily Telegraph publisher Hollinger, which owns 50% of the money-spinning plant and has exercised an option to buy out the rest of the operation.

A deal with the Telegraph will ease the cashflow situation at Mr Desmond's publishing empire, which paid £125m for the Express newspapers and the Westferry holding in November last year.

"Once an agreement takes place, there will not be much to be seen to, as the deal has to be done through an arranged formula," said a spokeswoman for Northern & Shell.

Sheadded that the stake should fetch £80m, which would go some way to paying back the £97m loan which Mr Desmond took out to fund the controversial acquisition.

Sources say a more realistic price is between £50m and £60m.

Northern & Shell has only held preliminary discussions with Hollinger over the plant, which prints the southern editions of the Telegraph papers, the Guardian and the Financial Times, as well as the Express which pays £90m a year for its papers to be printed.

"There were preliminary meetings with the Daily Telegraph management, at which Hollinger said it was interested in buying the stake," said the spokeswoman.

The Docklands-based Westferry plant is understood to contribute a substantial amount to the balance sheet at the Daily Express, the Sunday Express and the Daily Star.

Under the terms of the sale, Mr Desmond will still be able to print the Express at Westferry.

Northern & Shell senior executives are also set to make large-scale redundancies at the papers, which employ a total of 580 journalists.

Several high-profile writers have already left the Daily Express in protest at Mr Desmond's background as a publisher of pornographic magazines.

webTitle: The filming of Samuel Beckett's plays

fields.headline: Sam's the man
fields.standfirst: Neil Jordan, Damien Hirst and David Mamet were just some of the big names queueing up to film Beckett's plays.  Peter Lennon witnessed the results
fields.trailText: Neil Jordan, Damien Hirst and David Mamet were just some of the big names queueing up to film Beckett's plays. Peter Lennon witnessed the results
fields.body:
There is gravity, restraint and understated elegance in Dublin Castle. Where better to launch a massive tribute to one of the greatest and most reserved Irish playwrights of the last century, Samuel Beckett? Nineteen directors were let loose on the entire Beckett theatrical canon, from Oscar-winners (Anthony Minghella) to Turner prize-winners (Damien Hirst).

Gravity, restraint . . . well, perhaps not. We stood in our hundreds in the great hall, shoulder to shoulder, glasses in our fists, as the president of Ireland, Mary McAleese, told a joke about Beckett; and then Michael Colgan of the Gate theatre, one of the inspirational figures behind this extraordinary event, delivered his peroration on the triumph of art and Irishmen and women.

Then on we went towards the tom-toms of the city's trendiest nightclub. This is the way the Irish celebrate the Wittgenstein of literature: without inhibition; always referring to him possessively by his first name, no obligation to read or see the work before joining the parade.

Beckett's plays have been filmed before, but the Beckett estate was persuaded by people such as Colgan and Joe Mulholland of RTE (Irish state television) to allow the full canon to go before the cameras. The first game, then, was to detect which of the 19 directors had got away with taking what liberties. Who had used close-ups to chop up a work? Who intruded with nosy zooms?

Before the screenings there were alarmist rumours that the director of The English Patient, Anthony Minghella, who had taken on Play, had sacrilegiously pitched the stage work's three figures, who are stranded up to their necks in urns, into a teeming landscape of endless figures in urns; there was also indignation that Patricia Rozema had transported Happy Days to sunny Tenerife. Had they all been properly briefed on the difference between a Beckettian "stop" and "pause"?

But after I had seen 14 of the 19 works an extraordinary phenomenon became clear: the spectacle of a man from the grave gently taming 19 of the world's most individual directors, among them Neil Jordan, Michael Lindsay-Hogg, David Mamet, Atom Egoyan, Richard Eyre. Damien Hirst was thrown a small bone (virtually openly acknowledged as a necessary publicity stunt); he was prudently only allowed the 45 seconds of Breath. This was the piece written for Oh! Calcutta! - "On a set full of rubbish a person cries out and breathes in again." Kenneth Tynan enraged Beckett by adding "and naked bodies". Beckett withdrew the sketch. Hirst dutifully came up with unpopulated rubbish.

The most poignant work was Catastrophe, the last screen appearance of John Gielgud. He died a few weeks after shooting. Catastrophe was the one politically overt play Beckett ever wrote; it was dedicated to Vaclav Havel in 1982 when Havel was still a persecuted writer. Gielgud, mute throughout, plays the Protagonist, standing on a black box submitting to the Director's callous, humiliating direction.

It was rather touching that the majority of the egos involved quickly acknowledged that no one knew better than Beckett how the works should be performed and made no serious at tempts to impose their will. Many of them were chosen because of a lifelong, if not publicly apparent, admiration for the work. Minghella said that, as an impressionable 20-year-old student, he spent so much time poring over the Master's collection in Reading university that briefly his handwriting began to resemble Beckett's.

Richard Eyre came to do Rockaby (an elderly woman sits in a rocking chair and listens to her own recorded voice) for more personal reasons. Not only has he been working on a film about Iris Murdoch's last years with Alzheimer's, but his mother died with the same condition. "So early dementia," he said, "was a resonant theme for me." Eyre feels that far from being unsuitable for film, "in fact, the very precise directions about light and coming in and out of shadow makes the work much easier to achieve on film. The transition is seamless."

Eyre said he felt no constraints working to Beckett's restrictions. "I wanted to start the film outside the window, and was allowed to open it out that much. You have to suggest the room and window without being too specific. I did want to shoot from the back of the head to emphasise the void but I was not allowed. But it was not necessary. I was allowed to end with a top shot."

Minghella said: "You discover there is a kind of inexorability about the text. There is only one way to do it. Play is as close to being perfectly written as any play can be." There was no difficulty about the final scene in which the figures in urns are repeated ad infinitum. This simply underlines the point that this is not just a particular trio suffering; their banal suffering is repeated across the universe.

The sculptor Charles Garrad (That Time) came by an appro priate route. His work, he said, increasingly began to resemble unpopulated film sets. His elaborate set for Lindsay-Hogg's Waiting for Godot involved filling a shed in Monaghan with 1,000 tons of shale. But when he made That Time - a lank grey-haired man sits in a void and is bombarded by voices - there was no decor. "I would have liked to have had some colours and shapes reflected in his eyes - nothing concrete - but it was not allowed," he said. "I soon realised that the way he put it together is the best way for it to work. It was not that I was forbidden by a higher authority."

It was appropriate that it was the youngest director, Enda Hughes, representing in a way the 21st century, who found the trick for breaking free of the restraints without betraying Beckett's intention. He achieved it with a brilliant, simple leap of the imagination. In the original of Act Without Words II the stage is divided precisely into three squares. Hughes simply transferred it to celluloid. What we see now is not an empty stage but a screen split into three separate frames, making the divisions more plausible, and in these frames the characters cavort in a manner that recalls those old music hall acts on silent film that so fascinated Beckett.

Dublin-born Conor McPherson was given one of the plums, Endgame. With the powerful assistance of two splendid actors, Michael Gambon and David Thewlis, and a good director of photography, Donal Gilligan, the result is quite adequate. But McPherson stumbled out of this experience with this insight: "Beckett thought people were stupid." He also declared that Endgame was full of rubbish. You'd have to stand on your head with your eyes shut to miss the extraordinary compassion Beckett has for us poor unfortunates so pluckily struggling to survive in an absurd life.

webTitle: Children bear brunt of quake trauma

fields.headline: Children bear brunt of quake trauma
fields.standfirst: Last month's devastating tremor in India hit the most vulnerable people the hardest, reports Luke Harding
fields.trailText: Last month's devastating tremor in India hit the most vulnerable people the hardest, reports Luke Harding in New Delhi.
fields.body:
This morning, like every morning, the children of the shattered Indian province of Kutch should be going to school. In better times, boys and girls dressed in blue uniforms would be making their way towards classrooms - for lessons in Hindi, English and numeracy.

But the catastrophic earthquake that hit the western state of Gujarat 11 days ago, killing at least 30,000 people, has also left the region's education system in disarray. No one is going to school anymore in Kutch because there are no schools to go to.

Some 15,000 school buildings were affected by the quake. Some suffered no more than cracks and fissures. But many, close to the quake's vicious and deadly epicentre, were transformed within three minutes into mountains of rubble.

The disaster also saved its especial fury for the elderly and the young, many of whom who were at home at 8.48am during India's Republic Day - a holiday- when the walls fell in.

Two entire schools were also wiped out on the morning of January 26. Three hundred pupils died in the obliterated town of Anjar during a Republic Day parade, and a girls' primary school in Bhachau, just next to the market, crumbled totally, killing at least 78 girls together with their teachers. Their bodies were still being dug out three days later.

Many other teachers were also among the dead elsewhere. In Ahmedabad, for example, a class of 30 small children together with school staff had returned during what should have been a day off for a science project. They were all buried.

As the immediate relief operation to bring power, water, and food to the worst affected areas continues, plans are also now being made to try and get the schools functioning again for those who have survived India's worst earthquake in 50 years.

The Indian government, together with aid agencies such as Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund, have come together to set up a series of makeshift tent schools were pupils can once again be given basic tuition.

"We are talking about 1.8m children who have lost the two safe places in their lives- schools and homes. They have both been reduced to rubble," Maria Calvis, Unicef's representative in India said in New Delhi today.

"Their future is filled with uncertainty and fear. It is very, very important that we act now. The lesson from other earthquakes is that it is imperative to establish some sense of normality. The best way of doing this is by getting children back to school."

It is not clear whether it will take weeks or months before these schools are up and running. Unicef is sending "learning kits" to the region, as well as trained counsellors to help children whose parents and family members have died. But it is likely to be many months before regular lessons resume.

In most of Kutch there is still no electricity, little food and water, and no telephone connections.

Plenty of aid has arrived in Bhuj, the historic town closest to the quake's epicentre. Biscuits, blankets, plastic sheeting, water purification tablets and jumpers have piled up. But not much of it has reached the remote interior in the desert-like Rann of Kutch, or the children who live there.

In the shattered village of Khavda, 50 miles to the north, the entire community has now set up camp in what was once the village school under giant multicoloured awnings. They are unlikely to move out until they have homes to move into: and that will take time.

The children themselves, meanwhile, have their own agonising griefs to bear. In Anjar one boy was plucked from the rubble after spending four days imprisoned. He was in good spirits and chatted with the rescuers as they dug him out. But his leg was trapped under masonry, and in the end the rescue team had to amputate it to free him.

He is, in a sense, lucky: most of his classmates did not survive. While the immediate relief operation is likely to last four months, the scars inflicted by earthquake will take a long time to heal.

webTitle: Rationing of NHS services and drugs is 'inevitable'

fields.headline: Rationing of NHS services and drugs is 'inevitable'
fields.trailText: The debate over NHS funding erupted again today after a British Medical Association report warned that increased public funding alone would never solve the problems of the health service. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
The debate over NHS funding erupted again today after a British Medical Association (BMA) report warned that increased public funding alone would never solve the problems of the health service.

The report says the concept of the NHS as a service that can offer all treatments may have "outlived its usefulness" and that rationing of services and drugs was inevitable.

Both the public and the government would have to accept that new and expensive treatments would in the future be limited to those who could pay for them privately, it said.

The government welcomed the report, pointing out that its endorsement of a tax-funded NHS and its rejection of private health insurance systems reflected the government's own beliefs.

The report comes less than a week after NHS managers warned that health authorities and trusts were struggling to balance their budgets for the next financial year, despite the extra billions earmarked for the service last year.

Last March, chancellor Gordon Brown announced a 6.1% average annual real terms increase for the NHS, worth around £19bn over four years, a move dubbed the biggest ever increase in health service history.

The BMA report says rationing of medicines and therapies in the health service is more attractive than alternative ways of funding the NHS, such as a dedicated health tax or charges for specific services such as GP appointments.

It also warns that patients will continue to suffer unless ministers and voters "faced up" to the idea of NHS rationing.

A BMA steering group spent a year producing its Healthcare Funding Review, based on public opinion polls, written evidence from health experts and surveys of evidence on healthcare policy.

It found that while people distrusted the way healthcare rationing was occurring in a concealed manner in the NHS, there was equal "distaste" for the prospect of an explicit limiting of specified services.

The review gave cautious support to the government's NHS plan, published last July, welcoming the extra investment but warning that improvements could take years to become evident.

BMA chairman Dr Ian Bogle, who headed the steering group, said: "We have looked at other methods of funding healthcare, but these can never resolve the rationing dilemma.

"Whatever funding method we adopt and however much money we spend on healthcare, we always reach a point at which the cost of treatment begins to outweigh the benefits.

"We have to accept the prospect of treatments being excluded from the NHS if we want to maintain a universal service, one which is available to everyone and essentially free at the point of use."

The report concludes: "The concept of the NHS as a comprehensive service may have outlived its usefulness.

"It will be increasingly commonplace to see treatments which are judged to be of limited clinical effectiveness, not cost-effective or an inappropriate use of public funds, excluded from this system."

webTitle: Graham: I won't quit Spurs

fields.headline: Graham: I won't quit Spurs
fields.trailText: George Graham has insisted he won't walk out on Tottenham, despite mounting pressure on him to quit after four successive 0-0 draws.
fields.body:
George Graham has insisted he won't walk out on Tottenham, despite mounting pressure on him to quit after four successive 0-0 draws.

Spurs lie 11th in the Premiership and defeat against Charlton in the FA Cup tomorrow would leave them with little to play for this season. But today Graham told the Sun newspaper: "The buck ultimately stops with me but I won't walk away from Tottenham."

Graham also denied that Spurs needed a good FA Cup run to end their season, claiming: "I can't go along with those who are saying that our season hinges on what happens at Charlton."

"Sure, we need to get the right result at The Valley, get everybody back fit again, and then we can have a good end to the season," he added.

Graham once again blamed a long injury list for the club's recent dip in form, claiming: "If I was in this position with a fully-fit squad I would be the first to hold up my hands."

And the Spurs manager also reminded fans not to have too high expectations for the rest of the season. "There are other clubs as big as Tottenham who can't win the Championship, can't qualify for the Champions League and who are not in either cup," he warned.

webTitle: BBC arts shake-up

fields.headline: Omnibus to air on BBC2 in arts shake-up
fields.trailText: 11am: BBC1 documentary strand Omnibus is being shunted to BBC2 as part of an arts shake-up, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Flagship BBC1 documentary strand Omnibus is being shunted to BBC2 for most of its run, confirming fears that arts would be marginalised in the BBC1 schedules.

Controller of arts commissioning Roly Keating has revealed it will appear more often on BBC2 in future in a shake-up of arts programming.

The current Sunday night BBC2 arts programming block is also to move to Saturday evening and lose its Art Zone branding, as part of the changes planned by Mr Keating.

In addition, cult music show Later with Jools Holland is to move from Saturday to Friday night, where it will be scheduled at 11.30pm after Late Review.

As revealed in November, the Mark Lawson-fronted arts review show is also moving, from the Sunday Art Zone to a new Friday berth following Newsnight.

Mr Keating, in an interview with the Independent, said that from now on Omnibus documentaries "would have to have a sense of the scale and excitement to feel like a national event" to make it onto BBC1.

Otherwise, they will feature in the Saturday night BBC2 arts block, between 7 and 9pm.

Mr Keating said he was scrapping the Art Zone brand because "it may have put off as many people as it brought in".

"Now from 7 to 9 on Saturday nights we can have two long-form arts pieces, maybe an Omnibus documentary followed by a concert performance," he added.

webTitle: Councils shy away from consulting the public

fields.headline: Councils shy away from consulting the public
fields.standfirst: New Labour has urged local councils to involve the public as a matter of policy but, as Phillip Whiteman reports, town halls have greeted the initiative with less than unbridled enthusiasm
fields.trailText: New Labour has urged local councils to involve the public as a matter of policy but, as Phillip Whiteman reports, town halls have greeted the initiative with less than unbridled enthusiasm.
fields.body:
Traditionally, the perception of a citizen's ability to influence the way their council is run has been limited to casting a vote in the May elections. The election of "New Labour" in 1997 saw a change in attitudes, and this government has put councils under a huge amount of pressure to involve the public.

Most authorities in England and Wales will currently be running, or preparing to run, a consultation on whether they should adopt a city mayor or Westminster-style cabinet instead of their century-old committee system.

Best value is another initiative designed to shake up the way local services are delivered. Indeed, ministers have talked of the need to ensure that services "meet the needs of citizens, not the convenience of service providers".

However, question marks still hang over whether local government is consulting effectively, and some councils seem decidedly reluctant to put their future in the hands of the voters.

The government was vague in the original terms it gave councils on how they should consult. That may have been the correct approach, or at least it may have been for those councils willing to try it. The government's attitude was partly designed to encourage innovation. What it overlooked was the fact that some councils might not want to undertake more than a bare minimum of consultation.

For almost three years I have been involved in a research project on how a "middle-England" district council has actually implemented public consultation.

I discovered that, where the controlling political group was ideologically opposed to government policy, the local authority was less enthusiastic to implement the principles of genuine public consultation. In the words of the council leader: "We will do what we have to do and no more." This view was shared by some of the council's officers.

Another form of resistance to public consultation and dialogue was the perception of the councillor's role. A substantial body of research has identified that councillors tend to perceive democracy as a purely representative process and not one of participation. In other words, they are chosen to represent their electors, not to involve them. Ministers will have a hard time reforming this kind of traditional view.

As a result, the consultation undertaken by the council was more about fulfilling a legal requirement, and ensuring the appropriate mark was placed in the auditor's tick box. This culture could hardly be hailed as a mechanism for encouraging councillors genuinely to listen to the public's voice.

This lack of local political will was reflected in the resources allocated to pay for consultation. The two full-time staff employed by the council to manage best value could hardly have coped with genuine public consultation exercises as well. Consultation requires time, money and effort.

Such an environment did not engender a culture of innovation. As a result, the consultation method chosen would usually be one that was cheap, rather than one that was effective and could genuinely influence the policymakers. Newspaper questionnaires and occasional public meetings were the order of the day. Experimentation with such methods as citizen's juries could not be maintained with such low levels of resources and commitment.

It was not only councillors who were unenthusiastic. Among the officer corps there was not always a desire to listen to a counter-view. Interestingly, the most enthusiastic council officers were usually those who had had previous experience of public consultation. This, coupled with the reticence among the politicians, did not enthuse officers to listen to the public.

The government is not free of blame. It may have been vague in defining many consultation methods, but that wasn't the case with best value performance indicators, where user surveys were required. Here, ministers were heavily prescriptive.

Some of the indicators were both incoherent and laden with typographical inaccuracies. The government's response was to issue more guidance, in the form of a 240-page document about data collection. It could hardly be regarded as user-friendly.

Much of the confusion created by the government became apparent last summer, when the DETR faced heavy questioning on technical inaccuracies from confused local authorities.

These problems have not disappeared. Some councils have found themselves unable to resolve the issues, even with the help of equally confused civil servants and government auditors. Authorities have taken to discussing the problems between themselves in order to find a solution. The situation can be summed up by one senior council officer's comment: "I feel that it's being done to us, rather than by us".

Other research has found that there are many positive moves towards greater public consultation, but there must not be an assumption that this has worked across the board. Ministers need to take stock of whether all local councils are heeding the government's desire for greater public consultation. They also need to reflect upon their own policies and how they promote consultation among councils.

For now, the evidence suggests that the government's original expectations of public consultation may not have been achieved.

webTitle: Race hate or just a laugh?

fields.headline: Race hate or just a laugh?
fields.standfirst: A comic's songs have caused South Africa to question issues of racism and freedom of speech, as Chris McGreal explains
fields.trailText: A comic's songs have caused South Africa to question issues of racism and freedom of speech, as Chris McGreal explains.
fields.body:
It is the stuff of the old South Africa. The performer begins gently by his standards. Nelson Mandela and Thabo Mbeki are "kaffirs", he sings in Afrikaans, and kaffirs had better beware because they rape white women and children.

Then he gets to the point. The president should just "fuck off" and Mandela "spyker sy ma" (sleeps with his mother).

There is nothing much unusual about such sentiments in certain sections of South Africa, even today. But it is rare that they are recorded and distributed on a CD.

Now the man who wrote and sang the songs, Shane McCallaghan, finds himself threatened with prosecution and hailed as a defender of free speech when he says it was all a joke.

The CD was recorded three years ago, copied from a tape made at a party, but it only got its first public airing on a Johannesburg radio station last month.

Most who heard it were shocked, if not at the offensiveness of suggesting Nelson Mandela had sex with his mother, then the daring - or stupidity, depending how you look at it - of recording such a thing in modern South Africa.

Amid a barrage of denunciations, the statutory human rights commission asked the director of public prosecutions to charge Mr McCallaghan with promoting racial hatred - a crime in South Africa.

The commission said that the CD "clearly constitutes a violation of the right to dignity of millions of South Africans".

"It remains a matter of deep concern to the commission that, six years after the establishment of a democratic order, there remain people who continue to engage in the business of race hate in the most vile and repugnant form, as some of the material on the CD demonstrates," the commission said.

The ruling African National Congress went so far as to describe the recording as a "threat to the stability of the country", although few others see it as that serious.

Others say it is a matter of free speech, and note that the human rights commission has not demanded the prosecution of a number of black politicians who might be accused of promoting racial hatred - including a member of the KwaZulu-Natal legislature who held his nose and said that white legislators stank.

Mr McCallaghan, who describes himself as a professional comedian, was full of apologies. He says the songs were performed at a drunken party and "not meant to be taken seriously. "This whole thing has just gone haywire. The song was recorded three years ago at a party in Bapsfontein after I had had a few drinks. But I am not a racist, I am a normal person like everyone else," he said.

"I feel very bad about those songs. No one was supposed to hear them. I want to apologise for them."

Mr McCallaghan's claim does not quite gel. He was, presumably, sober when the original recording was transferred to several hundred CDs and sold to clubs and individuals who thought it was great entertainment for their own parties.

But it has forced a broader debate about the impact of aggressive song lyrics so popular among young South Africans.

Mr McCallaghan's deeply offensive, if somewhat ludicrous, CD reached only a few hundred generally like-minded people.

But some of the biggest stars of rap and kwaito - a South African sound modelled on hip-hop - glorify rape in a country where rape is not only common but viewed as a rite of passage by some young men, murder where murder is sadly routine, and racial conflict when racial divisions are still wide.

The deeply controversial American white rap singer, Eninem, who quite freely sings about "niggaz", is hugely popular in South Africa.

Another performer, Nastradamus, sings about the "muthafuckin president". He is, presumably, talking about the man in the White House, but the sentiment is much the same as Mr McCallaghan's.

The human rights commission has no plans to try and ban such music in South Africa. The freedom of speech guarantees in the constitution would probably make it impossible to do so.

But Mr McCallaghan is much closer to home. The sentiments in his lyrics sting so much more because many black South Africans believe that is how whites still express themselves in private.

webTitle: Schwarzenegger may give up movies for politics

fields.headline: Schwarzenegger may give up movies for politics
fields.trailText: The Austrian-born star of the Terminator movies is considering embarking on a career in politics in a bid for the governorship of California
fields.body:
Arnold Schwarzenegger has announced that he is considering quitting the film business and moving into politics in a bid for the governorship of California, according to reports from the BBC today.

Schwarzenegger, a staunch Republican, told the LA Times newspaper that he could run for office in as little as 12 months time. "I've thought about it many times because I love politics," he said.

Claiming he would happily give up his film career, he told the newspaper that California was lacking in leadership at the moment. The current governor Gray Davis has come in for widespread criticism following a state-wide electricity crisis. "I saw in the last 10 years that I'm getting much more pleasure out of (helping people) than making money and making movies," the Terminator star continued. "And it's increasing my desire to do that. It can lead, and will lead, probably, to some political office."

If Schwarzenegger does secure the governorship he will follow in the footsteps of former actor turned politician, Ronald Reagan, who began his political career in California and eventually became president in 1980. The 6th Day star, however, could never hold America's highest office as he was born in Austria.

webTitle: A lament at the passing of the mock exam

fields.headline: Out of practice
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley listens to a lament at the passing of the mock exam
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley listens to a lament at the passing of the mock exam
fields.body:
The days when students sit formal mock A-level examinations under timed supervision in the main hall are, it seems, numbered.

The advent of two sets of public examinations during the sixth-form years - the AS exams at the end of the first-year sixth and A2s the year after - are tolling the death knell for the traditional practice exam in the January of the second-year sixth.

Peter Gacsall, director of music at Haywards Heath College, a sixth-form college, says that in future there will no longer be an appropriate juncture to stage mock examinations.

Staging mock AS exams or A2s in January would be too early because the students would not know enough to test, he says. Stage them much later and the week and a half long mock exams would eat into valuable teaching time.

In the past in his college students sat an internal end-of-year exam at the close of the first-year sixth to sum up their year's learning, to assess their progress and to give teachers some evidence on which to base their A- level grade predictions for university references.

Then, in the January of the second year, students would sit their mocks. These encouraged them to revise and gave them valuable experience of sitting three-hour exams for the first time.

"Exam technique is a huge part of doing well at exams," Mr Gacsall said. "It's not just the learning. It's how much time do you spend planning the essay before you start writing it. The trial exams used to give students the opportunity to practise."

In future, Mr Gacsall believes, individual departments will have to set students practice exam questions for AS- and A2-levels in class time. Given that lessons at his college are just 75 minutes long, a 2 hour 15 minute written music exam will, in future, have to be broken down and fitted into several lessons. These informal exams will also eat into valuable teaching time.

Students, he added, will still need to practise their exam techniques. They cannot be expected to sit down and write for two and a half hours without doing a dry run first.

Today, Mr Gacsall said, students are studying more subjects and taking more examinations than ever before. Whereas in the past most students took three A-levels, today many would be doing four or five AS-levels in the first-year sixth and three or more subjects in the second year.

webTitle: Stone wins appeal over Russells murders

fields.headline: Stone wins appeal over Russells murders
fields.trailText: Michael Stone today won his court of appeal challenge to his convictions for the murders of Lin and Megan Russell.
fields.body:
Michael Stone today won his court of appeal challenge to his convictions for the murders of Lin and Megan Russell.

Three judges in London indicated that they would "allow the appeal" on the basis of the unreliability of key witness Barry Thompson's evidence, given at Stone's trail.

Stone, 40, of Gillingham, Kent, will remain in custody pending deliberation by the court on Thursday on the issue of a possible retrial.

Today's drama unfolded on the second day of Stone's appeal before Lord Justice Kennedy, sitting with Mr Justice Maurice Kay and Mrs Justice Hallett at London's law courts.

Stone was given three life sentences at Maidstone crown court in 1998 for the two murders, and the attempted murder of Megan's sister, Josie, near their home at Chillenden, Kent in 1996. He was in court for the announcement.

Sitting in the dock, flanked by security officers, Stone turned to his sister Barbara and smiled, and she then punched the air in delight.

He could be free later this week if the court does not order a re-trial.

The appeal court's decision followed the revelation that the prosecution could no longer rely on one of its key witness, Mr Thompson, as a "witness of truth".

Stone's counsel, Mr William Clegg QC, told the three judges that just "moments ago" he was handed a document by the crown. Mr Clegg read out from the document.

The prosecution stated in the document that having considered all the material now before the court for the purpose of the appeal, the crown "cannot seek to rely on Barry Thompson as a witness of truth".

Thompson, who told the jury that Stone had confessed to the killings while in prison, reportedly said just days after the conviction that he had told the jury "a pack of lies" when he claimed Stone had threatened him and referred to the murders.

He has claimed in newspaper articles that he and another key witness against Stone at his trial were "paid police informants".

It was shortly after this announcement that Lord Justice Kennedy said the court was "minded" to allow the appeal.

The court has not formally quashed the conviction and Lord Justice Kennedy warned that the proceedings were still "live" and there was a realistic possibility of an order for a re-trial and that therefore nothing to Stone's detriment may be published in the interim.

Yesterday, Mr Clegg said that Mr Thompson had now changed his story. "What he says is completely contrary to the evidence he gave at the trial," Mr Clegg said. He now says Stone made no confession of any kind to him and that his evidence at Maidstone was untruthful."

Another prosecution witness, Damien Daley, also gave evidence that Stone had confessed to the killings in prison.

Stone, who has spent much of his life in prison and institutions and has had addictions to heroin and alcohol, has steadfastly denied any involvement in the killings.

webTitle: Casting news: Rita Hayworth type sought for Banderas thriller

fields.headline: Rita Hayworth type sought for Banderas thriller
fields.standfirst: Plus: Samantha Mumba in line for The Time Machine; Stallone and Bacon team up for Stephen King revenge saga
fields.trailText: Plus: Samantha Mumba in line for The Time Machine; Stallone and Bacon team up for Stephen King revenge saga
fields.body:
 Antonio Banderas (pictured) is set to star as a paparazzi photographer in a new $35m (£23.75m) thriller, Femme Fatale, for Mission Impossible director, Brian De Palma, but the project is still without a leading lady. Producer Marina Gefter told Variety magazine that she was looking for a "sexy Rita Hayworth type" to portray the femme of the title, but concedes: "'There just aren't that many [women] like that around anymore." The search has already taken four months and shooting is due to begin on March 12.

 The Irish pop singer Samantha Mumba may be heading for a role in the latest Steven Spielberg movie according to the BBC. The 18-year-old singer is being considered for a part in Spielberg's film of the HG Wells novel, The Time Machine, which will also star Guy Pearce and Jeremy Irons.

 Sylvester Stallone and Kevin Bacon are set to co-star in a new thriller based on a Stephen King novelette, Dolan's Cadillac, according to the The Hollywood Reporter. Director Paula Wagner, who also wrote the script, is due to start work in May on the story of an innocent woman who is killed to protect a Mafia boss (Stallone) after she witnesses a gangland murder. Her husband (Bacon) sets out to wreak revenge.

webTitle: Why underqualified teachers can lead school ski trips

fields.headline: On slippery ground
fields.standfirst: As thousands of schoolchildren head for the ski slopes,  Phil Revell asks why Britain still allows its teachers to lead school parties after only one week's specialist training
fields.trailText: As thousands of schoolchildren head for the ski slopes, Phil Revell asks why Britain still allows its teachers to lead school parties after only one week's specialist training
fields.body:
New Year's Day 2000 at the Heavenly Valley ski resort in Nevada and the pupils of Hayle Community School were enjoying the first day of the new millennium on the Big Dipper, a ski run graded "blue". At first, 15-year-old Rachel Williams appeared to be doing fine, but seconds later she lost control and careered off the marked slope into a tree. She was killed instantly. It was no one's fault.

"I thought that it must have been a coach crash," said Rachel's mother Helen. "I couldn't believe the accident had happened whilst she was skiing. I thought they would be on the nursery slopes."

Over the next few weeks thousands of children will travel out on a school trip to Europe's ski slopes. The vast majority will have a great time, but skiing is potentially very dangerous and parents sometimes learn too late that the phrase "holiday of a lifetime" can turn out to have far too literal a meaning.

Despite the popularity of the sport, few of the parents sending children on these trips are aware what is involved. Parents who ski are only too aware: "I would never send my children on one of these trips," one parent told the Guardian. "I've seen what happens when they get out there."

Hayle Community School runs a regular ski trip abroad led by geography teacher Phil Allen. He organised the year 2000 trip to Heavenly Valley. The first disappointment was the accommodation. "We were disgusted," said one of Rachel's roommates. "It looked really seedy, a grotty hotel." Students were in pairs with double beds, which they had to share. Rooms opened directly onto verandas open to the public walking by. Rachel and her roommates were disappointed - and a little frightened. Evening activities promised in the brochure failed to materialise and one of the adults with the trip described the organisation as a "real shambles".

This contrasted with the mornings spent skiing with the Heavenly Valley ski school. In groups of eight or nine students were given professional tuition by qualified instructors. The instruction was "very good . . . brilliant".

"It all progressed very quickly," said one student. "Everyone seemed to get much better." Rachel was a natural, who always chose to ski.

In the afternoons, Hayle's teachers would take the students back out onto the slopes to practise their skills. "One afternoon we went right to the top," recalled a student. "It was the third day. He [Allen] took us onto a blue slope: it was very busy and really steep, lots of people were falling over and getting stuck."

Ski runs are graded green, blue, red and black. Green is the easiest. Blue is more difficult, but skiers would expect most beginners to attempt a blue run on this kind of trip. But, for most experts, the caveat would be "under instruction". By the end of the week nearly all the students had covered the skills necessary to attempt a blue slope with the ski school and Phil Allen was leading the group once again when the accident happened.

Allen was operating within Cornwall Education Authority guidelines and an inquest found that he was not responsible for Rachel's death. There was no evidence that she would still be alive if the trip had been organised differently, but the accident highlights areas of concern about the way school skiing trips are run. Ski experts are uncomfortable about a system which allows teachers with minimal skiing qualifications to lead groups.

British ski professionals need a British Association of Snowsport Instructors (BASI) award, which takes between two and four years to achieve. Allen, who had been skiing for more than 30 years, holds the much less stringent Ski Course Organisers (SCO) award. This is an English Ski Council qualification to prepare party leaders to take groups of young people skiing. It is achieved after a one-week course. Cornwall LEA is happy to allow teachers holding this qualification to lead groups.

Freddie Foxon is an ESC coach and the editor of the handbook for the SCO programme. He is worried about the size of the groups that teachers sometimes take out onto the slopes. In this case there were 16 in the party - no problem, according to Cornwall LEA, but double the number the American instructors were taking in the morning. However, as Allen himself told the inquest, it is "normal" to see such large groups in Europe.

There is no suggestion from any of these experts that Phil Allen was responsible for Rachel Williams' death. Students who were with the party that day said his instructions were clear. He told them to ski at a speed they were comfortable with. On ski slopes, accidents will happen. But there are doubts about the system, which allows teachers to take children out onto the slopes without having a ski instructor's qualification.

In the Alps, skiers are used to encountering school parties led by teachers who may have the ESC award or no qualifications whatsoever. Commercial school tour operators routinely offer just two hours of professional ski tuition in the morning, leaving groups to make their own arrangements in the afternoon.

Many schools choose to pay for extra professional instruction. "One of the great dangers with good recreational skiers is that they forget what it was like to be beginners," says Peter Kuwall, BASI's technical development manager.

At Shropshire's William Brookes School, Dave Riley has been organising ski trips for many years. One of his sixth-formers is Arabella Ashfield, currently a member of the English junior ski squad. "My personal view is that there is no way the teacher should be teaching or instructing the group in the afternoon," says Riley. "Teachers should focus on the pastoral management of the group."

Riley books with Interski, a commercial operator which includes morning and afternoon instruction as part of the basic package. Riley buys additional time to allow instructors to stay with their groups throughout the day.

Riley's checklist could be seen as a model for schools and will be of intrest to any parent whose child is clamouring to go on a trip. He tries to get sole occupancy of the hotel and he ensures that parents are fully informed about all aspects of the trip. That includes being clear about the risks children will face. Before they leave he insists that all the children learn basic skills at the local dry ski slope.

"Its very important that the kids are well prepared," he says. "I want them to be able to ski from the top of our local dry ski slope before they go. This isn't a holiday, it's a learning experience." Cornwall LEA does not accept there was anything wrong with the way the Hayle trip was organised. In a statement, a spokesperson for the authority said: "A number of concerns have been raised by Rachel's parents, all of which we have carefully investigated. The coroner's verdict is clear and lays no blame on any adult members of the party . . . Our investigations have not led me to recommend any changes of procedure."

Different LEAs have different policies. But Shropshire LEA would not allow teachers with an SCO award to lead groups and their recommended tutor:pupil ratio is 1:10.

Every death on a school trip sends a chill through parents, who have no way of checking whether the holiday they are paying for is safe.

Outdoor activity trips within the UK are inspected by the Adventurous Activities Licensing Authority (AALA). All centres and individual instructors offering sailing, canoeing, climbing, trekking or skiing are inspected and licensed. AALA has no control over trips abroad and no remit to inspect schools. But there is nothing to stop schools and local authorities requesting their expert assistance. "We would be happy to advise or to be part of an inquiry team," says Marcus Baillie, AALA's chief inspector. "We already assist local authorities, the marine investigation branch and the police."

He makes the point that a common knee-jerk reaction to accidents is to simply ban further activities. Some activities will always involve a certain level of risk, but a proper inquiry system would, he argues, allow lessons to be learned.

Local authority guidelines on how these trips are run are not backed up by clear government advice, despite some excellent general guidance. One way round this problem would be for the government to require LEAs to invite third parties to investigate serious incidents on school trips. But the DfEE has "no plans" to change the current system.

What should parents demand?

 An information evening with a slide/video presentation of the resort.

 Advance tuition at a local dry ski slope (schools may have to organise this).

 Professional tuition by BASI (or European equivalent) qualified instructors at ratios of 1:10 or less.

 Lift passes and ski equipment, though most operators charge extra to hire ski clothing.

 Quality hotel accommodation close to ski lifts. Shared rooms with single beds are normal, but parents should expect no more than three children per room. No additional meal or lunch costs at the resort.

 An evening programme - skating, swimming, pizza evening, prizes - at no extra cost.

 Total financial protection. Fully-bonded ABTA membership and AITO membership should be standard. Comprehensive insurance with no excess clauses.

 School ski operators in Europe should be able to offer the above for less than £500 per child.

webTitle: In brief: Julianne Moore sees therapist over Hannibal

fields.headline: Julianne Moore sees therapist over Hannibal
fields.standfirst: Plus: Quills website censored for too much vice; What Women Want tops UK box office
fields.trailText: Plus: Quills website censored for too much vice; What Women Want tops UK box office
fields.body:
 Hannibal star Julianne Moore (pictured) has told Vanity Fair magazine that she had to talk to her therapist about the more gruesome aspects of her role opposite Anthony Hopkins in the sequel to The Silence of the Lambs. "I actually talked to my shrink about it,'' Moore says in an interview in the March issue of the magazine. "As a parent, as a person, what is this? Hannibal is the dark side that is part of everyone... We are socialised, civilised, but in our fantasy lives we explore those themes. That's okay, but it's a fine line I feel uncomfortable with." Moore was paid a tenth of the reported $20m (£13.57m) which Jodie Foster would have charged to reprise the role of FBI agent Clarice Starling. The film is released here on February 16.

 A website devoted to the film Quills, which depicts the Marquis de Sade 's struggle for freedom of expression, has had to be toned down after complaints over its risqué content, according to Variety. The Quills website shows Geoffrey Rush balancing the words virtue and vice above him. The virtue section takes users to the general information page but the now-defunct vice section offered salacious excerpts from de Sade's writings and links to an XXX-rated site. Alerted by the Motion Picture Association of America about protests from parents over the vice section, 20th Century Fox has now pulled the offending material.

 What Women Want has taken an impressive £3.375 million at the UK box office over its opening weekend, making it the best ever debut in the UK for a romantic comedy. It is also a triumph for Mel Gibson as it has surpassed his previous highest opening weekend for Lethal Weapon 2. The film, which takes a light-hearted look at the battle of the sexes, has proved just as successful in the United States where it has to date grossed over $172m (£116.74m).

webTitle: Thou shalt not pass

fields.headline: Thou shalt not pass
fields.standfirst: A blizzard of dodgy passports has besieged Serie A, followed by a deluge of controversy. But, as Football Italia's head honcho reports, heads are unlikely to roll when every team appears to be as guilty as each other
fields.trailText: A blizzard of dodgy passports has besieged Serie A, followed by a deluge of controversy. But, as Football Italia's head honcho reports, heads are unlikely to roll when every team appears to be as guilty as each other
fields.body:
Football is awash with more dodgy papers than a Wapping printworks, and nowhere are the names involved as big as in Italy's Serie A. To quote Tyler Durden, I am Jack's complete lack of surprise. Lazio's Juan Sebastian Veron is up this week on civil charges of fraud, Inter's Alvaro Recoba is having to leave the country and even the validity of last season's title is now being questioned. Cor.

What is all the fuss about? For years now clubs in Italy have happily 'arranged' dual nationality for players from the four corners of the planet, making them easier to sign and field. There was always a friendly functionary ready to ease the paperwork and no-one thought too much of it - it was just one more way in which footballers enjoyed special treatment.

Naturally, it took a Polish border guard to upset this cosy system. Last September as Udinese arrived in Warsaw for a Uefa Cup tie airport officials barred entry to their two Brazilian players. Their passports were obvious forgeries. The police in Udine began inquiries and, five months on, they are now conducting six different investigations into seven clubs, and 24 players.

The latest name on their list came last week, as police discovered that Alvaro Recoba's recently acquired Italian passport is "a laughable forgery". Recoba has some Spanish ancestry but no Italian blood. Still, his club had been happy to pay an agency to sort out dual citizenship, and no-one had examined the outcome too closely. That is, until police went through the player's Milan apartment. Inter had to swiftly drop the player from Sunday's line -up, and for Alvaro it's meant an express trip back to Uruguay, his real home country, to apply for an Italian visa. In Recoba's case in fact his forged Italian status (removing him from the clubs' 'non-european' quota) had contributed to a new contract with Inter, worth close to £10m a year. Now, with his return date from Montevideo still uncertain, not checking his paperwork is looking a highly costly error. Certainly a decent forger would have been a lot cheaper.

Even more controversial is the Veron case. Lazio fielded the Argentine as an Italian last season, but in April 2000 it emerged that the Calabrian great-grandparents he'd used to acquire citizenship never actually existed (an easy mistake to make, no?). Thus here's the big question right now: if Lazio with Veron used more than the regulation number of non-european players on the way to winning last year's Scudetto, how valid can that Scudetto be? Surprisingly, raising the issue this week is the manager of Roma, Fabio Capello.

"Last year Veron was 'European', this season they've re-registered him as 'non-european," says Fabio. "Ours is the only FA that takes no action. If someone's cheated, they should be penalised. It's the same for Inter, and law-abiding clubs are damaged by this. Let's look at the situation, and re-evaluate the standings." Let's not, say neighbours Lazio, who aren't best pleased with Capello's remarks. Since Veron has yet to be found guilty they're threatening Capello with legal action.

Don't expect to see the scudetto confiscated any time soon though, or even any French-style point deductions. It wasn't until this week, in fact, that the Italian FA finally announced their own inquiry - this a full five months after the incident with the Polish border guard. With the FA currently in the hands of a caretaker president - one who'll soon to be needing the votes of the big clubs over at his day job, running the Italian Sports council - they're hardly likely to go rocking the boat. Plus, way ahead of the passport scandal on their priority list are the allegations of match-rigging in last August's Coppa Italia, and even that case is only inching forward.

Whatever action comes, the irony is that this distinction between 'european' and 'non-european' players should be gone by next season anyway - a recent civil court case declared that anyone granted a permit to work in Italy should be afforded the same rights as a European citizen. But in the meantime it's hard to get too worked up over the great sporting injustice of it all - clubs here are pretty much all as bad as each other, and they've been all been bending whatever rules they could for years.

Investigators have even found dual passports for four players that belong to indignant Mr Capello's Roma. Their Brazilian wing-back Cafu is now a naturalised Italian citizen himself because of his wife's southern Italian ancestry. Don't try that one at your local consulate. Some cheat better than others as the authorities here know full well, and as soon as they get a chance to forget all about it they will, big names or no.
