fields.headline: Straw in bid to toughen asylum rules
fields.standfirst: Home secretary wants Geneva convention rewritten
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw is today expected to urge his European partners to toughen asylum rules.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw is today expected to urge his European partners to toughen asylum rules.

In the latest of a multi-pronged attack by the government on the asylum issue, it was thought he would propose a revamp of the 1951 UN convention on refugees.

His speech at an Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) debate, entitled "modernising asylum", signals the high-profile role the issue will play in the forthcoming general election.

Under his scheme, refugees will be restricted to claiming asylum in the first safe country they reach - meaning they would largely be prohibited from asking for refuge in western European states.

Mr Straw will also urge the international community to devise a more up-to-date definition of asylum and mark out the dividing line between economic migration and asylum.

He is expected to drum up support for the proposals when he attends an informal European summit in Stockholm, Sweden, later this week.

The home secretary's speech follows a joint article by prime minister Tony Blair and Italian premier Guiliano Amato in the Observer at the weekend in which they pledged to target gangs involved in people trafficking.

Labour MEP and former director of the joint council for the welfare of immigrants, Claude Moraes, said: "The 1951 convention was designed for a different age and must be updated. But in doing so, genuine asylum seekers must still enjoy a fair and just hearing, while showing the way for a more comprehensive immigration policy to deal with people fleeing poverty or looking for a better life."

Sarah Spencer, director of the IPPR's citizenship and governance programme, warned that Mr Straw's initiative should balance being tough on smugglers but welcome genuine asylum seekers.

"It's vital we do not end up cherry-picking refugees with job and language skills we need, rather than those most in need of protection. And it is just too risky to make blanket assumptions that applicants from so-called 'safe countries' should not be considered at all."

The conference organised by the leading left-wing think tank also features chairman of the Commission for Racial Equality Gurbux Singh and chief executive of the Children's Society Ian Sparks.

webTitle: Adidas ad campaign

fields.headline: Hingis and Lomu to star in Adidas ads
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Martina Hingis, Jonah Lomu and golfer Sergio Garcia are to star in a new Adidas ad campaign, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Martina Hingis, Jonah Lomu and golfer Sergio Garcia are among the stars being lined up by Adidas for a new advertising campaign based on self-improvement.

The global campaign, dubbed "Makes you better", takes a tongue-in-cheek look at how Adidas gear can help even the world's top sports stars become cooler, more supportive and even lighter.

The first commercial, which has its UK debut on February 14, stars the current number one women's tennis player, Martina Hingis, helping to clear the traffic in Rome by hitting a series of perfect shots wearing her new Adidas Precision polo shirt.

The tagline runs, "Adidas makes you cool".

A second ad, shot in Dublin, features rugby star Jonah Lomu and his All Blacks teammates helpfully loading luggage and passengers from a crowded platform onto a train wearing Adidas Tyranny running shoes.

"Adidas makes you supportive," runs the endline.

A final ad features golfing prodigy Sergio Garcia in Barcelona wearing an Adidas Lite jacket and hitting flowers at passers-by.

"Adidas makes you warm," runs the endline.

The campaign was created by the Amsterdam agency 180 and will also include posters and banner ads.

Adidas yesterday revealed a drop in profits for 2000 due partly to a fall in US sales and partly to a series of costly advertising campaigns to coincide with the Sydney Olympics and the Euro 2000 football championships.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-three, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-three, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Some luck, some bad luck and another win. Blue Square expert Partick Murray has plenty to pore over this week
fields.trailText: Some luck, some bad luck and another win. Blue Square expert Partick Murray has plenty to pore over this week
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £175.80, Sean Ingle = £55.15, Football Unlimited Punters Collective = £29.12, Paul MacInnes = £28.15

Scott Murray: Coventry v Arsenal - No goalscorer £5 @ 8/1

Bet lost

So near and yet so far for Mr M this week, with Dennis Bergkamp finally capping his recent return to form with a 77th minute goal (which the officials for some reason allowed to stand despite Wiltord being as offside as a blue-shirted Inzaghi). And to make matters worse, the inestimable Scott had talked himself out of backing 0 or 1 goals rather than no goalscorer.

But just because he backed a loser doesn't make it a bad bet. Personally I prefer the bet he actually did to the winning bet he could have done. I have nothing against taking the conservative course of action particularly if your bankroll is weak (not a factor in this case), but generally the issue should be which bet is the greater value rather than which one is the more likely to win.

By backing no goalscorer, all Scott gave up was Coventry winning 1-0 or Arsenal winning 1-0, and moreover if either won 1-0 through an own goal he would still collect, and yet he bumped up the price he was taking from 13/8 to 8/1. This implies that the odds for a 1-0 victory to either side was just 11/4 (I won't bore you with the calculations but its all to do with percentages). Even if you were to back these two scores individually at Blue Square's odds (9/1 and 6/1) with proportionate stakes, it would come to over 3/1 and - given the massive margin bookies bet to on the correct score market - even this is unlikely to be value.

So Scott may jokingly put his bet down to greed but I put it down to good judgement. This week's loss will be more than paid for by subsequent winners because in the long run the better the value the bigger the profit. It's that simple (in theory).

Sean Ingle: AZ v Feyenoord: Feyenoord to win £11 @ 10/11

Bet won £11

Our resident Mao obsessive, the Sinophilic Mr Ingle, may just have shaken off his unnatural attachment to multiples. It's early days of course, and one can probably never say one is completely cured, but the simple beauty of singles does finally seem to be working its magic spell upon the boy.

This week, not only has Mr I once again picked a single he's only gone and picked a winner. I'm not too hot on Dutch football so I'll take his word for it that Feyenoord were value - they certainly won convincingly enough (3-0).

Generally speaking, though, I tend to avoid odds-on away teams. Away wins are a lot rarer than one might think even among the top teams - the top four teams in the Premiership, for example, have won only eighteen of their fifty-one away games, barely one in three. And given the tendency of the average betting-shop punter to put the Arsenals, Liverpools, Man Utds, Barcelonas and Feyenoords of this world in their coupon regardless of price, it's pretty unlikely the bookmakers will be foolish enough to offer a lot of value on them.

A winner is a winner though and a single is a single. Progress is being made monetarily as well as mentally - and you've got to like the fact that Mr I is spreading his metaphorical net and trawling Europe's more obscure leagues (albeit not their more obscure teams) for value. Hurrah!

Paul MacInnes: Southampton to beat Newcastle at half-time - £10 @ 4/1

Bet void

First there was the "holiday", then the "illness" and now even the weather seems to be conspiring to protect the last shreds of the MacInnes bankroll. Is there no end to the machinations of the god of football punting in his determination to thwart Mr M's efforts to lose?

Next week, expect a rogue tsunami to hit the Dell hours before the game against Bradford, Paul having backed Robbie Blake as first scorer on the grounds that Robbie Constable, Robbie Turner and Robbie Holman Hunt have all scored there in recent seasons.

Rowan Foggitt of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Walsall to win at Wigan £5 @ 5/2

Bet lost

Alright, so I admit that I'm riddled with prejudice, prey to a million preconceptions, the plaything of Signorina Presumptione if you will. But at the end of the day, surely even Walsall diehards will admit Walsall are not the best team in the Second Division despite occupying top spot for much of the season, and few I think would consider them a much better side than Wigan.

The odds Blue Square offered on Friday's match implied that there is not a lot to choose between the two sides with Wigan slightly the better team (if two equally matched sides meet, the received bookmaking wisdom is that the home side should be about evens and the away team about 9/4), a view I would concur with. Mr Foggitt disagrees however.

For 5/2 to be value, assuming that the received bookmaking wisdom is correct - a big assumption I guess but the bookies seem to be doing alright out of it - then Walsall must be the better team because if the bookies price is 9/4 the true price (after we take off the bookie's margin) is more like 11/4 (and the evens about the home team is more like 6/5). So to me, who for some intangible reason find it impossible to rate Walsall highly this season, 5/2 was never value.

I'm always suspicious of bets on live matches, particularly in lower divisions - it smacks of trying to get round the trebles only rule just for the sake of it and not because you have a strong opinion on the match. Worse than that, it smacks of the "interest bet", a little wager to add some spice to an otherwise uninteresting match. Now, there's nothing wrong with that I would agree, but it doesn't tend to do your bankroll any favours.

But at least it was a single and not one of the far-fetched multiples that did so much damage to the FUPC funds earlier in the season.

Where there's life there's hope. There's still fifteen odd weeks for our struggling punters to turn their season around, all it takes is a lot of concentration and a little bit of luck. But enough, I grow weary, so until next week happy punting.

webTitle: Interview: Sylvia Smith, author

fields.headline: A life more ordinary
fields.standfirst:
Sylvia Smith claims to be a lousy writer, she hates descriptive stories and nothing much happens in her autobiography. So how come a fashionable publisher has snapped up her book? Alex Clark investigates

An extract from Sylvia Smith's memoir
fields.trailText: Sylvia Smith claims to be a lousy writer, she hates descriptive stories and nothing much happens in her autobiography. So how come a fashionable publisher has snapped up her book?  Alex Clark investigates
fields.body:
It's a bold move, and they know it. When the people at the small but studiously trendy Edinburgh publishing house Canongate accepted an anecdotal memoir by an unknown first-time writer, they must have wondered quite what they were letting themselves in for. The Misadventures of Sylvia Smith has nothing of the current bestseller lists to recommend it - no far-flung locations, no life-or-death struggles with illness, abuse or tragic romance, no celebrity, no razzmatazz whatsoever.

Instead, Sylvia Smith has chosen to chronicle the first 50 years of her life; an ordinary woman living an unremarkable life in a resolutely unglamorous location. It is a story of a postwar upbringing in working-class east London, of countless low status administrative and secretarial posts, of a series of cheap rented flats, all told in a collection of affectless vignettes that most resemble a kind of disjointed oral history.

Her life and times are recounted in all their trivial detail. The effect, depending on your taste, is either cumulatively hypnotic or agonisingly anti-climactic. The sheer banality of the episodes that Smith recounts makes Misadventures feel entirely without literary forebears, but it is a strange, unsettling and oddly moving read. If the book succeeds, it will be because it gives voice to one ordinary woman's life, of the kind rarely commemorated in autobiographical writing.

Sylvia Smith herself also cuts an unusual literary figure, not least because she claims to be talentless. She reckons her book appeals not only because it's "hysterically funny" but also because she's used "good English all the way through". She repeatedly asserts: "I'm a lousy writer. I'm sure I am" - and there is no hint that she might be angling for contradiction.

Now 55, Smith has no literary training. She simply started writing at top speed one day, she says,when illness brought a halt to a long succession of temping jobs.

Her writing is evidently more than a hobby, but something less than a vocation - she has to fit it around her daily excursions in an old banger, and time spent caring for her elderly mother.

But while lacking writerly self-regard, Smith is not so disingenuous as to believe her work uninteresting. She has an unshakeable conviction that her material, while not essentially dramatic, is utterly fascinating. Having never come into contact with the literary world, she had no reason to be intimidated by it, but neither was she inclined to preciousness: when the first agent she approached told her she wrote very badly indeed, she could only agree.

Nonetheless, it is her own style, and she is sticking to it. "I don't like the way other people write, they go into great detail and weave a story," she says. "I much prefer to get to the point." And get to the point she does. Apart from a handful of slightly lengthier pieces about her childhood and her family life, very few of Smith's vignettes extend to more than one page. We follow her progress from childhood to middle-age through a variety of bedsits and shared houses, secretarial jobs, friends, acquaintances and numerous partners.

There are a lot of boyfriends, I suggest tentatively. "Don't forget I've been single all my life," she counters, just as she says "Don't forget I'm completely unskilled as a writer," and "Don't forget I was a temp for many years." Smith herself seems to have forgotten nothing, despite claiming not to have kept a diary for most of the period she recounts. She has an especially good memory for her many dates, from 19-year-old Mick, who squired her to the wrestling at Finsbury Park Empire in 1962, to Bob, the rotter who stood her up when she waited for him at a tube station with a pound of sausages.

But as much as we are given a peek into her flings, flirtations and fiascos, we are never invited into her inner life; beyond mild disappointment and good-natured resignation, there is none of the conspiratorial breast-beating of the contemporary memoir, no gush of emotion or articulation of regret. The narrative is singularly and purposefully undynamic.

Instead, Smith has chosen to define her "misadventures" as frozen moments, each of them accompanied by a concise piece of scene-setting. They succeed each other, page on page, with a bravura sense of tedium and pathos, conjuring the world of the uncertainly employed, the happily unachieving. This is the dying fall writ large.

Smith was 43 when, she says, she simply sat down and decided to wrote down all the funny things that had ever happened to her. The only blanks in her memory, she says, were "all the things that went smoothly". Misadventures recalls her 40th birthday, when she took a hard look at her past life: "I felt I hadn't done very much with it. I thought to myself, 'What can I do about this? I don't want to get to 60 and find I still haven't done anything worthwhile.'"

Smith makes no great claims for her life, for the mundane jobs, the inconclusive relationships, the transitory friends and impermanent lodgings. But now she has started writing about it, she has no plans to stop. Her publishers already have a previous manuscript, Appleby House, detailing life in a boarding house run by Mr and Mrs Appleby, and she is currently at work on a book about her holidays, unambiguously entitled My Holidays. It is difficult to think of a less dramatic subject matter, though the author confidently attests: "You should find three-quarters of the book hysterically funny."

Smith is an intriguing woman, a mixture of naivety and narcissism, and her memoir is no less enigmatic. I suspect that there is more fictionalisation in her work than perhaps even Smith is aware of; but her almost aggressively impersonal style does indeed seem the result of an attempt to reject solipsistic navel-gazing.

It is not a work that will appeal to everyone's taste, but there is a certain fascinating banality in these tales of an utterly normal woman, worker, lover and carer. It is a rare glimpse into a life lived quietly and unexceptionally, exactly like millions of others.

webTitle: An extract from Sylvia Smith's memoir

fields.headline: Life after Father
fields.standfirst:
An extract from Sylvia Smith's memoir

Interview: A life more ordinary
fields.trailText: An extract from Sylvia Smith's memoir.
fields.body:
After the death of my father, my 85-year-old mother faced life on her own, running a house and looking after herself unaided for the very first time. She had lived with her family until marrying at the age of 22 and then my father had taken charge. I was her only child and the last of her family as she had outlived her brothers and sisters.

I visited her twice a week and I quickly discovered that old age had set in and she wasn't good at anything. Important letters would drop on her doormat. She would open them, totally misread them, panic, and then telephone me in my furnished flatlet some two towns away, telling me disaster was imminient.

She usually phoned around 7pm when I was cooking my evening meal. As she worried me, I would switch off the oven, remove my partly cooked dinner, jump into my car and drive to her as quickly as I possibly could, only to find there was nothing wrong and the letters did not mention the disaster she had related. After several panic-stricken calls from Mother, resulting in several of my dinners being ruined, I told her she was not to open the post any more but to save it until I came round to see her and I would deal with it.

As I was unemployed but had some savings and was able to run a car, I would collect Mother's pension once a fortnight and then take her shopping in a nearby supermarket. We would have lunch in the cafe, then buy a beautiful bunch of flowers and place them on Father's grave in Chingford cemetery. As the notorious Kray family's graves were only 50 yards away, Mother and I would stop at their tombstones. We frequently saw fresh flowers in their pots beneath their headstones. Mother would say: "What evil men they were," then laugh, and add: "If they could hear me, they'd follow us home, wouldn't they?"

Mother suffered from severe tinnitus which made her very deaf. The telephone was in the hall and Mother could not hear it if it rang while she was watching television in her parlour. She asked me if I would phone British Telecom and arrange for a bell to be fitted within the room.

I phoned BT to discover that Father had rented the same telephone for the previous 32 years, at a cost of over £300. After discussion with BT's executive, I cancelled the rented telephone and purchased a modern one for the small sum of £20, thereby reducing the quarterly bill, and the bell was installed free of charge.

As I didn't possess a washing machine, I would take my weekly wash to Mother and leave her to put it in her automatic machine and get it dry for me. For several months, I wondered why my bath towels and sweaters were rock hard. A friend told me too much detergent was being used.

As Mother's washing was in the same condition, I realised my friend was right. I advised Mother not to put any more soap in the wash. After several weeks of soap-free washes, the bath towels and sweaters became soft again. Mother switched to detergent tablets which she found not so confusing as the concentrated liquid she had been using.

Mother decided she would like new casement curtains for the bathroom. We went down her local high street and chose the material. As I had a brand new sewing machine, it was decided I should be the one to make them. The following day, I found I had mislaid my note telling me the length of the bathroom window. I phoned Mother and asked her to quickly measure it. She returned to the phone and said: "The window measures 3ft 15in." I thanked her and said no more. I measured the window on my next visit.

On one trip to Mother, she told me the electric kettle wasn't working. I filled it up and pushed the plug into the socket on the wall and found she was right. "You're right," I said. "It isn't working." Mother said: "The fridge light is out as well." As we had two old electric kettles stored away, I took them both out of the cupboard and filled them with water, only to discover they didn't work either. I threw all three kettles into the dustbin in the front garden. I said to Mother: "We'd better buy another kettle. Get your coat and we'll choose one from the arcade."

Mother selected a beautiful yellow kettle, which was made in Britain, for the sum of £26. We returned to the house. I filled the kettle with water and plugged it into the socket to find it didn't work either. I suddenly remembered Mother's comment and realised there was a fault within the socket. I retrieved the three kettles from the dustbin and phoned a man friend who changed a faulty fuse. Mother said: "I thought that was odd, dear, but you know best, don't you?"

Mother is older now and has become housebound. Her greatest pleasure is a day out with me in the car.

webTitle: BT's master unbundler takes centre stage

fields.headline: BT's master unbundler takes centre stage
fields.standfirst: New finance director has some clout. He'll need it to eliminate £10bn in debts
fields.trailText: New finance director has some clout. He'll need it to eliminate £10bn in debts.
fields.body:
BT yesterday said it had appointed bankers to prepare BT Wireless for a float, denying weekend rumours that the mobile arm of the former telecommunications monopoly will be merged with Spain's Telefonica Moviles.

The flurry of attention on BT comes as newly appointed finance director Philip Hampton prepares to face investors on Thursday to outline how he will eliminate its £10bn debt by the end of the year.

The third quarter earnings announcement will give Mr Hampton the opportunity to take centre stage - and show, perhaps, that BT's latest recruit knows a thing or two about wringing commercial sweat from former state-owned monopolies. Mr Hampton was part of the team that performed radical surgery on British Gas - spinning off BG, the oil and gas exploration unit, leaving the consumer services company Centrica.

Many are looking for the first signs of how he will revitalise BT.

The company has told the City that there will be no unwelcome surprises in store, and is expected to report pretax profits of about £1bn, compared with £652m for the same period last year.

A spokesman for the company said that only a progress report should be expected on the restructuring plan that was laid out last April - in which the wireless, internet, directories, and fixed line wholesale and retail businesses become separate entities.

BT will, for the first time, provide a limited breakdown of the earnings and debt of its various divisions.

When it launched its plan last year the corporate world was gripped by internet fervour. That sentiment has since evaporated and it is no surprise that BT's plan has been radically changed. The company had hoped to float 25% of Yell, its directories business, and a portion of BT Wireless. With the downward trend of telecoms share prices, investors are worried those floats may be halted.

Without the promise of income from floating those companies, Mr Hampton has had to reassess how BT will reduce its £30bn debt by a third this year - a promise made in November when the last earnings were released.

Debt levels have rocketed from £8.7bn at the time of the March 2000 balance sheet to an expected £31bn by the end of next month.

BT insiders complain that too much is being made of the group's gearing. "We got into debt on purpose," said one. "But we're being treated as though we're students with an overdraft."

When the company had limited borrowings, it was lambasted for not investing in future technologies, the same source said. Now the company has - with money ploughed into the new generation of mobile phones - and the debt is significant, it is being cast as "profligate".

Analysts are curious to see how Mr Hampton will distribute the debt among BT's divisions. Most of the debt was acquired by the mobile arm through the acquisition of the German mobile operator Viag Interkom, along with the purchase of licences to run the new, next generation mobile networks.

Swapping BT's group borrowings among the new businesses is made more difficult by regulator Oftel, which has to give the green light to any debt redistribution.

What might be viewed as prudent by the regulator is often seen as heavyhanded by BT. "It's difficult to be entrepreneurial when you're regulated," said one insider.

Despite the obstacles in BT's way, there is hope among financial institutions that Mr Hampton's experience with British Gas will prove useful for negotiating with the regulator.

Mr Hampton, 48, has a background over which the finance world can enthuse. He came to British Gas from British Steel, where he served as finance director between 1991 and 1996. This followed 15 years of international accountancy work with London-based Coopers & Lybrand and Lazard Brothers.

"He is certainly seen as the magic healer for BT's problems and he does have a good track record," said Hannes Wittig, research analyst with Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein. "But one person cannot change this around. He's not in charge of the company, he's in charge of solving a problem he inherited."

While shareholders are pushing for an answer regarding Yell and BT Wireless's fate, the telecoms industry and Oftel are hammering BT on how slowly it is opening up access to local exchanges - a move seen as essential for allowing rivals to offer high speed internet access.

BT has had weeks of bad publicity as competing operators claim it is stonewalling their attempts to use local exchanges, a process known as "unbundling the local loop". Rivals are rolling back ambitious projects that the government and others had hoped would make Britain a high speed internet mecca.

BT denies any foot-dragging and insists it is being made a scapegoat by companies who, thanks to antipathy in the capital markets, can no longer raise the money to fund those ambitious projects.

The timidity of the markets has also cast a pall of uncertainty over BT's own valuation, particularly as it has not yet separated accounting for its various divisions. While the share price has ranged from £15 to 650p over the last year, most analysts think it should be valued at between 750p and 850p.

"The situation is obscured," said Mr Wittig. "Even people close to the company don't know what it's worth any more. I think this obscurity is to BT's advantage."

Additional reporting by Richard Thurston

webTitle: Letsbuyit escapes liquidation

fields.headline: Letsbuyit escapes liquidation
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Letsbuyit.com has pulled off a miraculous escape from the clutches of administrators, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Struggling online retailer Letsbuyit.com has pulled off a miraculous escape from the clutches of administrators.

The cash-strapped company last night said it had secured £33m from existing and new investors, despite widespread concerns over the strength of Letsbuyit's business model.

It is believed Kim Schmitz, the flamboyant German who was expected to ride to the company's rescue, is not one of the financiers.

Letsbuyit allows consumers to group together and buy goods over the net, but the idea did not generate enough sales and the company was forced to seek court protection from its creditors.

However, the UK-based firm said it expects to make a profit in November 2002 and has enough cash to survive beyond that date.

"The lawyers of the company jointly with management are currently preparing a request for withdrawal of the debt moratorium at the earliest possible date," Letsbuyit said in a statement.

Letsbuyit will attempt to hit its targets by undergoing a radical restructuring of the company, which will include laying off 200 of its 350 staff and shutting down several foreign units.

The revamp will be led by founder John Palmer, who became chief executive following the departure of Letsbuyit's senior management team.

So far, the company's rescuers have been reluctant to come forward, although German venture capital firm Kimvestor admitted it has invested £760,000 and was willing to contribute more.

Letsbuyit's shares, which floated at 223p, rose a staggering 112% to 70p in early trading on the German Neuer Markt index.

webTitle: Giles Smith on the Vauxhall VX220

fields.headline: Hold on for dear life
fields.standfirst: It's one of the least apologetic motors on the road - a hardcore, snarling, frill-free, take-no-prisoners, aluminium racing car. And, believe it or not, it's made by Vauxhall
fields.trailText: Giles Smith: It's one of the least apologetic motors on the road - a hardcore, snarling, frill-free, take-no-prisoners, aluminium racing car. And, believe it or not, it's made by Vauxhall
fields.body:
Vauxhall - renowned purveyor of sensible, plastic-clad saloons and reasonably priced hatchbacks - has loosened its tie and, almost out of nowhere, produced a hardcore, snarling, frill-free, take- no-prisoners, aluminium racing car with two bucket seats and no carpets. On the face of it, this is like the golf commentator Peter Alliss deciding to reinvent himself as a hip-hop artist. "Stranger things have happened," people like to say. But, no, in this case, they haven't.

So, for the first time in history, one can say of a Vauxhall that it looks like a Lotus Elise (in fact, the VX220's chassis was built in collaboration with Lotus). Actually, it looks better: aggressively angled, tough and sharp. Vauxhalls have tended to look as if they were apologising for something. This must be one of the least apologetic cars on the road.

Like the Caterham Seven sports car, it is what they call an enthusiast's or purist's car, enthusiasm and purism being, of course, close cousins of masochism. The VX220 offers standards of comfort that will be familiar to anyone who has ever been thrown around in the back of an army Jeep.

What goes by the name of an interior in these cars is actually mostly an unfinished chassis. In a touching - but ultimately irrelevant - concession to decor, Vauxhall has punched some triangular holes in the aluminium window-winders. That is as pretty as it gets. The car is light on extras, too. A passenger remarked, before getting in, upon the unusually roomy drinks holder. I had to explain that it was the seat.

Actually, there is a cup holder. It is lodged between the two seats and set just far enough back to be entirely useless. I have no idea what it is doing there. It is like finding room for a vase of flowers in a Stealth bomber.

The Caterham Seven's interior is so hilariously narrow that it can oblige drivers with bigger feet to remove at least one shoe in order to avoid depressing two pedals at the same time. A former Caterham owner once told me that the car had cost him a fortune in footwear: he was forever accidentally leaving his shoes on the side of the road.

The VX220 is a little roomier, but that's not saying much. With the roof on, getting in is not so much an act of contortionism as a feat of origami. You don't climb into the car, you post yourself into it, then wrig gle to the bottom, as if it were a metal sleeping bag.

As for getting out, you will have looked more dignified getting out of the deep end in an ill-fitting swimming costume. It is important to perfect a manoeuvre that doesn't leave you on both knees on the pavement. This does not look cool and no amount of active recovery work upon standing (an intent and slightly squinting gaze off into the distance, some distractedly casual use of the remote locking device) is enough to restore the sense of self-possession which the car so loudly demands.

Better, once inside, to stay in for as long as you can. Fantastically, the car comes with a push-button ignition. You press the small aluminium button halfway along the dashboard and the engine abruptly explodes into life. There seems to be absolutely no need for this, except that it puts one in mind of Le Mans and of torpedo launchings in Stingray. A three-year-old who joined me in a number of testings of the VX220 enjoyed this aspect of the car - but not as much as I did.

The mid-mounted engine does its stuff just behind your head and I suppose the nature of that stuff is where the VX220 falls back from its rivals. You will find the same two-litre engine in Vauxhall's Astra Coupe. It is fabulously swift and very smooth but, tragically, it lacks racket.

The Caterham's engine has a bear-like roar and a general ambience which makes conversation impossible at speeds greater than 15mph. In the far more sympathetic VX220, you could still be yakking away at 70. If you're going to own a racing car, then it might as well be one with an engine whose noise terrifies horses and children, and destroys the possibility of human interaction.

But what the heck. The gearstick is a cold lump of aluminium and clatters up and down the gears; the steering wheel is bumper-car small; you are hilariously close to the ground. Racers dream of these things. Obviously, it is the driver who gets all the joy. Passengers who joined me in the VX220 reported only a jarring sensation and a mixed sense of alarm and dismay at my driving. But stuff them; I was having fun.

Clearly there are all sorts of practical drawbacks with a car like this, especially on cold and rainy days. In some of the deeper puddles, I was, to all intents and purposes, underwater. But it's not for a wet winter with the roof clamped on. It's for summer days and open roads. Apparently, there still are some.

webTitle: Israel and Palestine: the past four months

fields.headline: Timeline: how the West Bank and Gaza exploded
fields.trailText:
28 September: Israel's hardline opposition leader Ariel Sharon angers Palestinians by visiting a Jerusalem shrine sacred to Jews and Muslims. Dozens of police and several Palestinians are injured in the riots that follow.
Full story
fields.body:
28 September: Israel's hardline opposition leader Ariel Sharon angers Palestinians by visiting a Jerusalem shrine sacred to Jews and Muslims. Dozens of police and several Palestinians are injured in the riots that follow.
Full story

29 September: Six Palestinians are killed and close to 200 wounded in clashes at the shrine, known as Temple Mount to Jews and Noble Sanctuary to Muslims.

30 September: Clashes erupt in West Bank and Gaza strip. Fourteen Palestinians killed by Israeli fire, including 12-year-old Mohammed al-Durrah, whose death is captured by a television cameraman and broadcast around the world.
Photo gallery: the death of Mohammed

1 October: Ceasefire is agreed but soon collapses. Twelve are killed, including an Israeli border policeman who bleeds to death as Palestinian gunmen keep medics away.

2 October: 19 are killed in the heaviest day of fighting so far. Israeli Arabs protest in solidarity with the Palestinians and Israelis are barred from travel in the Palestinian territories.
Full story

3 October: A ceasefire is reported but the fighting continues. Six are killed.

4 October: Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat fly to France to meet the US secretary of state Madeleine Albright and French President Jacques Chirac. Both sides order military forces away from the flashpoint areas as seven more die.

October 5: The death toll in the first week of the intifada climbs to 67. Three of the dead were Israelis. Israeli tanks roll back from positions in West Bank. Mr Arafat meets US secretary of state Madeline Albright and President Hosni Mubarak in Egypt. Malaysia presents a draft UN resolution condemning the violence committed by Israeli security forces.

6 October: Israel seals the West Bank and Gaza strip. Its troops storm a Jerusalem shrine after Palestinians hoist their flag. One killed in a clash with the police outside the shrine while nine die in the West Bank and Gaza.

October 7: Israeli troops abandon Joseph's tomb, a Jewish holy site in Nablus. Palestinian police promise to defend the site but, hours after the evacuation, a mob storms and burns it. Confrontations erupt on the Lebanese border and Hizbullah abducts three Israeli soldiers. Mr Barak issues 48-hour ultimatum to Mr Arafat - stop the violence or Israeli troops will respond with full force, he warns. Four Palestinians are killed. The UN security council passes a resolution condemning Israel's "excessive use of force." The US abstains.

8 October: The Israeli army blows up two apartment buildings and one factory building in Gaza used as a perch by Palestinian gunmen. Jewish settler Hillel Lieberman is found dead in a cave near a West Bank highway while two Palestinians and one Israeli Arab are killed in the clashes.

9 October: Fighting in Jerusalem, Nazareth and Hebron continues through the Jewish holy day of Yom Kippur. The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, and the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, travel to the region for meetings with Israeli and Palestinian officials. Mr Barak's 48-hour deadline is extended to avoid a prolonged armed conflict, but violence between Israeli Arabs and Jews erupts across the country. Three Palestinians are killed.
Full story

10 October: Mr Barak says it is too early to tell whether a slight fall in level of violence is enough to resume negotiations. A 12-year-old Palestinian boy is shot in the head in Gaza, while rioting continues in the West Bank.

11 October: Violence continues amid a flurry of diplomatic activity. In Hebron, an effigy of Mr Barak is burned at a Palestinian march. Israelis and Palestinians exchange gunfire in cities, villages and along the West Bank's main roads. Three Palestinians are killed.

October 12: Two Israeli soldiers lynched in Ramallah after being arrested by Palestinian police. The bloody murders, televised worldwide, enrage Israeli opinion and provoke massive retaliatory strikes on Ramallah and on Mr Arafat's headquarters in the Gaza Strip.
Full story

October 14: President Clinton announces an emergency peace summit, to be held in Egypt.

October 17: Israeli officials say they have reached agreement with their Palestinian counterparts on scaling back the violence. The deal produces some local, short-term effects, but the intifada goes on.

October 22: Mr Barak announces that Israel is taking a "time out" from the peace process.

November 6: Mr Sharon calls on his Likud party and its allies to topple the Barak government, to prevent the prime minister reaching a peace deal with the Palestinians.

November 8: Mr Arafat sets off to visit President Clinton, and push for an international force to intervene.

November 19: Israeli diplomat shot and wounded near his home in the Jordanian capital, Amman.

November 22: A car bomb explodes in the northern Israeli town of Hadera, killing two people and wounding 35. Mr Barak says that Israel will "settle accounts" with those responsible.

December 26: Israel accepts, with reservations, a so-called 'bridging plan' for peace put forward by President Clinton. He broadly supports Palestinian claims to Jerusalem, but says that, in return, they must drop the demand for a 'right of return' to Israel for all refugees.

January 1, 2001: Israeli soldiers gun down top Palestinian official Thabet Thabet outside his home in Tulkaram on the West Bank - the latest in a spate of officially sanctioned assassinations. Army chiefs say Thabet was a militant, directing armed operations against Israeli forces. Other Israelis point out that he was a peace activist with many Jewish contacts.

January 20: President Clinton steps down, having pursued a Middle East peace settlement until the very last days of his administration.

February 4: Prime minister Barak makes a last desperate plea for Israel's 20% Arab minority to support him in the election. He apologises for the deaths of a dozen Israeli Arabs during rioting in the early stages of the intifada. Community leaders welcome the apology, but say it has come too late. Most are urging Arab voters to boycott the poll.

fields.trailText: Sol Campbell tops Bayern Munich's summer shopping list, reports the Mirror. But the paper warns that Bayern's plans to offer Campbell a £50,000-a-week salary are bound to upset top earner Stefan Effenburg, who is on a mere £40,000 a week. "If someone comes in way above Effenburg in the salary structure then Bayern will have a revolt on their hands," a source close to the club admitted.
fields.body:
Sol Campbell tops Bayern Munich's summer shopping list, reports the Mirror. But the paper warns that Bayern's plans to offer Campbell a £50,000-a-week salary are bound to upset top earner Stefan Effenburg, who is on a mere £40,000 a week. "If someone comes in way above Effenburg in the salary structure then Bayern will have a revolt on their hands," a source close to the club admitted.

Darlington have failed with an audacious bid to sign Nigerian international striker Daniel Amokachi, according to Teamtalk. Apparently, Amokachi is back in England and looking for a club - but he doesn't want to move into the Third Division. "We were 90 per cent certain that he was going to sign for us, but it all went wrong on Sunday," admitted Darlington football director Luke Raine.

Bayer Leverkusen are tracking Arsenal goalkeeper Alex Manninger, reports the Star.

Birmingham City are hoping to resurrect a £1.5m deal for Celtic striker Mark Burchill, following the departure of Peter Ndlovu to Huddersfield. "Now that Peter has gone, we are not overloaded," City's chairman David Gold told Teamtalk. "Fingers are crossed that something can be done for Mark. It was never a dead duck as that is not our style and we never close doors."

Ipswich Town have denied reports that they are planning a £2m bid for Birmingham midfielder Bryan Hughes.

Luton Town are expected to confirm Joe Kinnear as their director of football later today, according to the Mirror. But the paper is undecided as to whether Kinnear's appointment will lead to the departure of current manager Lil Fuccillo.

webTitle: MPs may delay Vaz report until after election

fields.headline: MPs may delay Vaz report until after election
fields.standfirst:
Suggestions of hold-up echo Tory sleaze moves in 1997

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The report of the investigation into whether the embattled minister Keith Vaz has broken parliamentary rules may not be published until after the general election, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The report of the investigation into whether the embattled minister Keith Vaz has broken parliamentary rules may not be published until after the general election, it emerged yesterday.

The Labour dominated Commons standards and privileges committee - which meets today - has decided to re-examine the year-long inquiry by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, into Mr Vaz's conduct. The committee wil re-interview witnesses who have already given evidence to Ms Filkin and talk to Mr Vaz himself before deciding whether to endorse her report.

The situation bears similarities to the committee's position before the last general election. Then it was unable to reach a verdict over Neil Hamilton and Tim Smith, the two Conservative MPs at the centre of the "cash for questions" scandal. At that time the Tory dominated committee was accused of trying to cover up the scandal during the election period.

A delay means Mr Vaz, the Europe minister, could go into the general election with intense speculation about his behaviour continuing during the campaign. The situation is certain to be exploited by the Tories, who are pressing for his resignation. Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, and John Redwood, the for mer shadow trade secretary, have both called for him to step down because of the forthcoming report, and Mr Vaz's involvement in seeking a passport for the billionaire Hinduja brothers, who are facing an inquiry in India over alleged corruption.

"Does Britain want to be represented abroad by this man?" asked Mr Maude. "I would have thought it is now an embarrassment to the government and an embarrassment to Britain and the sooner it is ended the better."

But Gordon Brown, the chancellor, yesterday moved to calm Labour's frayed nerves over the Hindujas affair by issuing a firm "business as usual" message. "People want a stable economy, they want rising standards of living, they want better public services. These are the things that I am concentrating on and will not be diverted from," Mr Brown said.

Downing Street continued to offer robust support for the under-fire minister, insisting that none of the allegations against him had been proved. "The prime minister's view is that Keith Vaz yesterday put out a detailed rebuttal of all the various stories that have appeared. The fact that the papers keep repeating them doesn't make them any truer," Alastair Campbell, the PM's official spokesman, said.

webTitle: Fear spurs voters into the arms of Sharon

fields.headline: Fear spurs voters into the arms of Sharon
fields.standfirst:
Israeli election: Palestinian threats help to seal the prime minister's expected political doom

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinian militants said last night that they were poised to attack targets in Israel on the eve of today's election, which is expected to make Ariel Sharon the country's next prime minister.
fields.body:
Palestinian militants said last night that they were poised to attack targets in Israel on the eve of today's election, which is expected to make Ariel Sharon the country's next prime minister.

The warning came as Israeli soldiers tried to tighten their grip on the West Bank and Gaza Strip before the "day of rage" which leaders of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement say marks the start of an intensification of the four-month uprising.

The army fired rocket-propelled grenades into the Palestinian refugee camp of Rafah, on the border between Gaza and Egypt, after an Israeli soldier on his way to vote in the early ballot staged for the army was killed by a bullet fired from the camp.

Israel also shut down the Palestinian airport in Gaza and the Rafah crossing to Egypt.

Police reinforcements were moved to the northern towns in Galilee, where a call for Israeli Arabs to boycott the election could lead to clashes.

With yesterday's opinion polls showing him leading the incumbent prime minister, Ehud Barak, by as much as 22 points, Mr Sharon could be stepping into a ready-made confrontation.

Yesterday he was challenged not only by the Fatah militias, which have led the protests in the West Bank and Gaza, but also by the militant group Islamic Jihad, which has claimed responsibility for at least two car bombings in Israel in the past four months.

"Our operations will continue and increase. We will carry out powerful blows against the criminal entity within the coming few days," Islamic Jihad said in a statement delivered before yesterday's funeral of a bomber who was shot dead trying to scale the fence sealing off Gaza.

"No barriers, wire fences, or security measures will prevent us from carrying out painful strikes against the enemy."

In the West Bank city of Ramallah, meanwhile, an important Fatah leader declared that the Palestinians would give no quarter to Mr Sharon.

Hussein Sheikh, who commands Fatah's militiamen in the West Bank, said: "The next days and weeks are going to be hard, and the area will witness an escalation in the field.

"We have declared a general state of emergency and we have orders to escalate the intifada."

Mr Barak spent the final moments of his campaign yesterday warning Israelis that the former general Sharon could lead them into a war.

"The Middle East is a powder keg," he wrote in the Yediot Ahronoth, Israel's best-selling paper.

"We are being called to decide whether to give the match to extremists, people who are too extreme for Israel. We are being called to decide whether between us and peace lies another bloody war."

But Israelis seemed to be in no mood to listen. After four months of bloodshed in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, people have lost faith not only in Mr Barak but in the entire seven years of negotiations started by the assassinated prime minister Yitzhak Rabin, according to research published yesterday by the Israel Democracy Institute.

An opinion survey carried out last month found that only 22% of Israelis believed that a peace deal with the Palestinians would end nearly 53 years of violence. Two years ago the figure was 67%.

"Israelis feel that the track Rabin, and especially Barak, took was leading to an agreement having many concessions but no end of conflict, and no solution to problems of personal security," said Ruth Gavison, from the institute.

"Many Israelis feel that what we now have is not a full war, but it is definitely not peace, and the way Barak is leading could lead into a worse war."

In his place Israelis are expected to choose a man who says he has no intention of negotiating with the Palestinians for years, and who last year called on Mr Barak to crush the uprising by assassinating Gaza's security chief.

How big the turnout will be is another question, however.

In Ramallah Mr Sheikh declared: "If the choice is war, it is better for Palestinians to deal with Sharon .Sharon has a clear vision. It is better for us to deal with someone who clearly wants to fight us and have war rather than deal with someone who raises flag of peace and then wages war."

webTitle: Accusations against the minister

fields.headline: Accusations against the minister
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The main allegations against Europe minister Keith Vaz and his response:
fields.body:
The main allegations against Europe minister Keith Vaz and his response:

Donations to his local party

Allegation: Mr Vaz received £15,000 in three separate tranches from businessmen for his 1997 election campaign. The payments were declared in the register of MPs' interests, but the money was not passed onto the local party.

Defence: The current local party treasurer, Piara Singh Clair, who made the allegation in the Sunday Telegraph, did not have access to the local election fund books, adminstered by party agent Keith Bennett. Mr Bennett has insisted all the money has been properly accounted.

Analysis: The election expenses officially returned by the Leicester East local party show that Mr Vaz's party was entitled to spend £7,678.54 and in fact submitted an expenses return of £6,521. This would imply that Mr Vaz should have passed on just under £8,500 to the local party. The party now claims the surplus cash is set aside for use in the coming election, which is why it never appeared to the normal local party accounts. Alternative explanations are that Mr Clair is mistaken about the records, or Mr Vaz overspent, or the money went elsewhere, possibly because it was spent before the election expenses limit came into force.

The proposed £900,000 house purchase

Allegation: Mr Vaz made an offer on a £900,000 London house when he himself could claim very limited funds from his role as an MP and treasurer. Mr Vaz is unlikely to be able to draw on extensive personal funds as he started employment as a humble council solicitor.

Defence: The money for this propery came not just from Mr Vaz, but also from his successful wife who is a solicitor and from his mother and sister. His mother and his wife run Mapesbury Communication Ltd, which made a £48,000 profit in 1998 and a £12,000 profit in 1999. Mr Vaz's own property is worth around £400,000.

Analysis: Three to four people with regular incomes purchasing a house together can raise substantial sums.

The Hindujas

Allegation: Mr Vaz offered to top and tail letters on behalf of the billionaire Hinduja brothers, including lobbying on their behalf for a passport. He met the brothers, who are not his constituents, very soon after they were named as suspects in an illegal arms deal, over which they faced extradition to India.

Defence: He has accepted that he did seek information from the Home Office about the Hindujas' passport applications and knew the brothers well. He says he had a duty to support and represent all Asians, not just his constituents. He says no money was exchanged in return for favours.

Analysis: Some former ministers have claimed that it was normal practice for MPs to lobby for passports on behalf of individuals who were not their constituents. No clear rule exists in the MPs' code of conduct, but senior Labour MPs claim it is legitimate for MPs to seek information on behalf of someone if they are not their constituent, so long as they are not lobbying or financially indebted. Mr Vaz's wife at the very least has received money from the Hindujas and Mr Vaz may not have made this point clear at the relevant times. SP Hinduja said he consulted Mr Vaz as to what protection from extradition British citizenship would provide.

Allegation: Mr Vaz used his premises in the Foreign Office to host a meeting between a Labour supporting Asian restauranteur and an insurance firm over a fire claim.

Defence: Ministerial code of conduct only states that ministers should not "generally" use ministerial offices for party or constituency business

Analysis: The code clearly does allow exemptions in times of necessity. Changes to Mr Vaz's diary required the meeting to be held in his office.

Intimidation of party members

Allegation: Mr Vaz had a hand in seeking to suppress allegations passed by local party members against him to the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin. This is part of a pattern of intimidation in his local party. On May 8 2000 local party chairman Colin Hall wrote to Mustafa Kamal, a local party member, warning him that unless he substantiated or withdrew his allegations, he would be subject to disciplininary action.

Defence: There is no clear evidence that Mr Vaz referred the allegations to the local party. Mr Kamal had erred in that his complaints concerned the local party, and not Mr Vaz's role as an MP.

Analysis: No one making allegations to Ms Filkin should be subjected to such threats since they are covered by parliamentary privilege. Allegations that the local party was improperly run by Mr Vaz were never substantiated in a party report prepared in 1996, but some claim that inquiry ended prematurely.

Undeclared cash payments

Allegation: Lawyer Sarosh Zaiwalla has told the Commons standards and privileges committee that he gave Mr Vaz over £2,000 in cash which was never declared. He insists details of the cash paid to Mr Vaz are in his accounts.

Defence: Mr Vaz has not denied the cash was passed to his associates, but insists that it never went to him personally, but instead to charities.

Analysis: Probably the single biggest issue to be investigated by Ms Filkin and may not be decided for many months.

webTitle: CNN election coverage

fields.headline: CNN election coverage branded 'a debacle'
fields.trailText: 9.15am: CNN's coverage of the US election has been branded 'a debacle' by leading academics, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
CNN's coverage of George Bush's rise to power has been branded "a debacle" by three academics it hired to investigate how it got it so wrong on the election night.

The station has unveiled a major overhaul of its presidential election exit poll procedures following the damning report into the mistaken calls made by the news network and other broadcasters in November.

But CNN was by no means the only US broadcaster to come in for criticism.

"Television interfered with the electoral process and the election result," said the independent report written by three respected academics for CNN.

"In our opinion, that constitutes an abuse of power, if unintentionally so, by CNN and by all the mainstream television news operations," it added.

Voters' News Service, the body set up by ABC, CBS, CNN, NBC and AP to provide exit poll data for projections and analysis, was singled out in for particular criticism.

The report said the decision to set up VNS as a cost-cutting measure that created a single source of exit poll information for all the broadcasters was "questionable".

The academics - Jim Risser, a former director of the Knight Fellowship, Joan Konner, a professor at Columbia University's school of journalism, and Ben Wattenberg, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute - took two months to complete their report.

"It eliminates the possibility of a second source for validating key and possibly conflicting information," they said.

In addition, all the networks were competing to be the first to "call" different states for Republican George Bush or his Democrat opponent Al Gore using VNS data.

In these circumstances, the report concluded that Florida, which the US networks called wrongly twice - first for Mr Gore and then for Mr Bush - when the result was still so close, "was a disaster waiting to happen".

It said: "In sum, the mistaken calls made television in election 2000 look foolish".

The report concluded: "It also threw one state and the nation and the campaigns themselves into confusion and helped lead one candidate into prematurely conceding to the other."

CNN said it would remain in VNS "only if significant changes are made to assure that the errors that plagued election night coverage do not recur".

The news broadcaster has also pledged to fund a second source of exit poll data, to cross-check with VNS statistics.

It will no longer call the presidential winner of a state until all polls have closed in that state and will also avoid making any exit poll projections in states which are statistically - a margin of less than 1% - too close to call.

CNN is also planning to provide more coverage of the mechanics of how exit poll calls are arrived at and be clearer about how it labels unconfirmed projections on air.

"Despite the best intentions and weeks of news department preparations prior to the election, for a variety of reasons, CNN and the other networks fell short in their coverage of election night," CNN said.

"We do not intend to let that happen again."

webTitle: Hello! hires Castaway Ben

fields.headline: Hello! goes 'upmarket' with Castaway Ben
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Former Castaway Ben Fogle is to join Hello! as a roving travel reporter, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former Castaway Ben Fogle is to join Hello! as a roving travel reporter.

The signing of the former Tatler picture editor, who won over viewers' hearts on the BBC's reality show, ends weeks of speculation about his career.

It is the first major coup for former News of the World editor Phil Hall, who has taken the helm as editor-in chief at the magazine.

Mr Fogle, with his blue-blood credentials, is seen as an essential part of the drive to make Hello! more upmarket and hip.

Mr Hall told MediaGuardian.co.uk that Mr Fogle was "popular and glamorous - everything we need".

He added: "He's adventurous, he's done a lot of travelling and he's interested in environmental issues."

Mr Hall said he was discussing sending Mr Fogle to the Galapagos islands.

Bringing his years of experience as a hard-nosed reporter to the sycophantic publication, Mr Hall told a newspaper today he wanted to make Hello! more glamorous and hip: "The suck-up stuff has become too cheesy.

"It is embarrassing to see see questions like, 'Leo, your hair is looking great, where did you get it done?'. What I want to know is why Leo hasn't spoken to his brother in four months. We don't want to turn celebrities over, but we can't keep on asking embarrassing questions like that."

Mr Hall also confirmed the magazine's "special relationship" with the Daily Mail in the wake of OK! publisher Richard Desmond's tie-up with the Express.

"We want to build up relationships with all the national newspapers," he said.

"But the Mail does make a lot of sense, in particular. [Mail owner] Lord Rothermere has met [Hello! owner] Eduardo [Sanchez Junco] in Spain - they went shooting together - and they are meeting again in the next few weeks.

"It's a non-exclusive relationship, but it is very important to us," he said.

Mr Hall added that he would approach the Mail to share the costs of buying certain stories which could then be cross-promoted.

He has also revealed that he is working on plans to develop a television show based on the Hello! brand.

He was unwiling to reveal too much detail about plans for the show, but said he had been approached by one independent producer interested in making a fly-on-the-wall about life inside the celebrity glossy.

But he said there were "contractual" problems with this.

webTitle: The beacon scheme: round two

fields.headline: The beacon scheme: round two
fields.standfirst: Lord Filkin, chairman of the beacon advisory panel, welcomes those involved in the second year of the best practice scheme
fields.trailText: Lord Filkin, chairman of the beacon advisory panel, welcomes those taking part in the second year of the best practice scheme and reports on the successes of last year.
fields.body:
I warmly congratulate those councils that were today named as beacon authorities. After a rigorous process of selection their work is about to begin in earnest. Having been recognised as shining exemplars from which others can learn, they are embarking on a programme of events to share their excellence across local government.

The advisory panel on beacon councils, which I chair, is appointed by ministers to aid them in the selection process for the scheme. In making our recommendations, we were truly impressed by much of the work we came across, and we are very excited by the learning the new beacons have to offer.

The aim of the scheme is to provide learning opportunities, inspiration and support to all councils; to help them make the necessary changes to bring their services level with the best, and to raise standards across local government. So how do we know we are achieving this?

Independent research into the impact of the learning events offered by the beacons during the scheme's first year is being carried out by Warwick University. Early reports are positive. They offer evidence that those who attend beacon events are inspired and informed by what they see, and they take the learning back to their own authorities to improve the services they offer. The research is continuing and will examine how far the learning is applied effectively and how standards in services are raised as a direct result of the beacon scheme.

Spreading best practice is the primary aim of the scheme but the selection process can also be beneficial. The beacon scheme makes participating councils take a good look at the services they offer, what their strengths are and how they can be improved. Authorities have said the internal services review, in deciding which applications to make, has been invaluable.

For shortlisted councils, and particularly those ultimately successful, the recognition comes as a boost to the service's staff. Beacon council status opens the service up to wider scrutiny and enables authorities to make further improvements. Most beacon councils offer a "warts and all" guide to how they have succeeded. This kind of approach, along with the mentoring, workshadowing and secondment opportunities that are offered, leads to open and supportive cooperation between authorities that traditionally may not have worked together. The scheme is offering real opportunities to modernise local government, which will lead to improved services for a modern society.

The panel is determined to ensure continuous improvement in the selection process. The second year of the scheme has seen the application procedure streamlined with electronic submissions and a request for documents that are already prepared, such as best value performance plans. We hope to refine the application process further in the future.

The selection process has become more robust, receiving input from the Audit Commission and other inspectorates. We have reorganised the panel's work to ensure closer scrutiny of the applications and reports. Again, this will be further improved for future years.

For year three, the panel has already responded to requests for more service areas that can be addressed by shire district councils. We have recommended a good selection to ministers, who will shortly be announcing the new themes.

Concrete outcomes - improvements in services for local people - are what we have sought in assessing applications. This criterion is applied to our own work in improving the scheme to ensure it has a real, positive impact on people's lives. The beacon council scheme celebrates the successes of local government, which are too often overlooked. The excellence is out there and this scheme is succeeding in capturing and sharing it.

webTitle: Cruise, Kidman split

fields.headline: Cruise, Kidman split
fields.trailText: A spokeswomen for two of the most bankable actors currently working in film said that the decision had been amicable and was because of the pressures resulting from frequently working apart.
fields.body:
The actors Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman have announced that they are to part. A spokeswomen for two of the most bankable actors currently working in film said that the decision had been amicable and was because of the pressures resulting from frequently working apart.

In a brief statement made yesterday, Pat Kingsley, who represents the actors, said: "Citing the difficulties inherent in divergent careers, which constantly keep them apart, they concluded that an amicable separation seems best for both of them at this time."

Ms Kingsley said the decision was made regretfully. The couple have two adopted children.

The decision comes at a time when both actors have been highly successful and when their careers appeared to be going from strength to strength. In Cruise's case, his role in the latest Mission Impossible film confirmed his status as one of the biggest draws in cinema and Nicole Kidman has recently completed The Others in Spain to add to a successful portfolio of work which included both Hollywood stardom and theatrical success in London.

Both actors have managed to avoid the speculation that usually haunts any high-profile Hollywood couple and are felt to have behaved with dignity in face of the glare of publicity.

They acted together in the late Stanley Kubrick's last film, Eyes Wide 'Shut, and also in Days of Thunder and Far and Away.

Cruise, now 38, is probably best known for his role in the Mission Impossible films but he received most plaudits for his part in Rain Man in which he played the brother of a mentally disturbed Dustin Hoffman.

In an interview in 1998, the Australian Kidman, 33, said of her marriage: "It's been nine years and I'm past the seven-year itch. When you're loved for your flaws, that's when you really feel safe."

In October 1998, the couple sued and won damages from the Express newspaper for having falsely claimed that their marriage was a "hypocritical sham" undertaken either to conceal their homosexuality or as a business arrangement.

webTitle: United looking to brand Beckham

fields.headline: United looking to brand Beckham
fields.trailText: Man United is eager to tie up the rights to the David Beckham brand name, writes Vivek Chaudhary.
fields.body:
David Beckham could shortly become the first footballer to be paid more for his image than his performance under radical contract proposals being considered by his lawyers and Manchester United.

With preliminary talks now under way with a view to a new Beckham deal being in place before the start of next season, United are eager to tie up rights to a brand name whose global marketability they see as crucial to the club's expansion around the world.

Nic Couchman, a London-based sports marketing lawyer specialising in image rights, said: "Beckham is an icon and has a value at United that is way beyond most other players. Footballers like him are increasingly saying to their clubs, if you want to use my name in merchandising then you have to pay me more money."

And Couchman, who has negotiated a number of contracts for Premiership footballers, predicted: "Beckham will receive more money for his image than playing under any new contract."

It is thought that would open the floodgates for more British players to negotiate similar deals, as other leading clubs are also looking to tie up their high-profile players. Image-rights contracts are common among continental footballers, with Arsenal's Dennis Bergkamp and Chelsea's Gianfranco Zola and Marcel Desailly having deals with their English clubs which account for around 30% of annual salary.

Other United players whose contracts are up for renewal along with Beckham's in 18 months' time are Jaap Stam, Ryan Giggs and Gary Neville. But reports suggest Beckham's new contract will make him the highest-paid player in Britain, a distinction currently held by Middlesbrough's Alen Boksic with £63,000 a week.

Beckham's lawyers envisage an image-rights component to reflect use of the Beckham persona in all United merchandising, on the internet and the club channel MUTV. He would also be required to do promotional work around the world, particularly the Far East.

Under the current system, United's players receive a standard and uniform fee within their contract for promotional work related to the club and use of their name in merchandising, as is the case with most other British players.

The Beckham precedent may come too late for some United players, however. There was no such deal for the striker Andy Cole, who signed a new four-year contract last weekend with a flat fee included for promotional work.

Couchman added: "The popularity of image-rights contracts has increased with the arrival of foreign players in England. Clubs are also looking to maximise their commercial activities off the field and believe that players should be helping.

"Clubs want to stop players from doing outside commercial work and get them involved in their own programmes. It's an inevitable part of the commercialisation of football."

webTitle: Popstars winners face the spotlight

fields.headline: Forget rock chic, the result is just pop kid
fields.standfirst: Carefully schooled and rather dismayingly well behaved, the Popstars winners face the spotlight
fields.trailText: Carefully schooled and rather dismayingly well behaved, the Popstars winners face the spotlight, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Breaking all the rules of plastic pop, the latest manufactured band to be launched to a jaded record-buying public got it all wrong yesterday. They sang in tune.

The five young hopefuls propelled into celebrity by ITV's Popstars series revealed their secret weapon at a press conference in London's Heathrow airport, after jetting in from a recording session in Norway.

Instead of the standard "Wait for the single" answer, the five responded to questions about their talent by bursting into a well-rehearsed a cappella version of the Simon and Garfunkel classic, Bridge Over Troubled Water.

But the hair-tingling harmonies clashed somewhat with the yet to be named band's chosen image - scuffed denim and punky hair. The aim might have been rock chic, but the result was just pop kid. If they want to be taken seriously as pop stars, they are going to have to start misbehaving a bit more. The five, it seemed, had been carefully schooled.

Had any of them taken drugs? All five shook their heads solemnly, and Kym Marsh, 24, said: "We do not do drugs and we do not think it is cool for anyone else to do drugs."

But what about those pictures of a scantily clad Myleene Klass, 22, in a fly-on-the-wall documentary? "It was a video diary that got blown out of all proportion. When I found out some of the things that were happening I just left," said Ms Klass.

They must have blown their advances already? "I am going to treat my nan and grandad... maybe a holiday somewhere where they can go and chill out," said Danny Foster, 21.

Even 20-year-old Noel Sullivan, despite emerging as the band's leader, failed in his attempts to shake off his image as a mummy's boy when he revealed he had been on the phone to her constantly. And the greatest crime perpetrated by Suzanne Shaw, 19, was to have spoiled her pop-bob hairdo with some ill-advised extensions.

Still, there is plenty of time for bad behaviour. Popstars, the docu-soap that has followed the formation of a pop band from the cattle-call auditions of 3,000 largely tuneless hopefuls to the selection of the next big thing, is only halfway through its run. Things are looking up: this Saturday we learn of the programme-makers' horror at the discovery of Kym's big secret - her two children.

And while the pop kids may have been smiling in front of the cameras yesterday, the TV executives were guffawing behind them. The latest instalment of the series garnered almost 12m viewers on Saturday night, making it one of the biggest entertainment hits of the year.

The group's first single, understood to be a version of Pure and Simple, already recorded by another manufactured band, Girl Thing, will be released on March 12. Bridge Over Troubled Water will almost certainly feature as the double-A side.

While strict cross-promotion rules prevent Granada from sharing in the single's profits, it stands to make a tidy sum out of merchandising and the inevitable album. Yet the band said they did not feel exploited, as alleged by Spice Girl Melanie C, who knows a thing or two about such matters.

Kym Marsh said: "We are not silly and stupid. We are not dummies." And so she landed her first punch: "Everyone is entitled to their own opinion but this is where she started." Ouch. That's a bit more like it.

webTitle: Popstars: a chart hit waiting to happen

fields.headline: Popstars: a chart hit waiting to happen
fields.trailText: The question on the lips of the music industry is not whether the band will succeed, but why no one thought of the concept before, writes Guy Adams.
fields.body:
The question on the lips of the music industry is not whether the band will succeed, but why no one thought of the concept before.

Pete Waterman, one third of the eighties pop production-line Stock, Aitken and Waterman, has launched his share of manufactured groups but said none had enjoyed such a charmed start to their careers.

"Most artists need to sell 20m albums before they can get this sort of coverage... When I was told about the Popstars concept I had some initial doubts, but in practice it has worked superbly because of the way the series is filmed: viewers have been made to connect with the group and the management team. Everybody's right behind them and that's an incredibly rare thing for a new band."

Mr Waterman expects to produce a couple of tracks for the group's album, including the debut single.

Chris Cowey, the executive producer of Top of the Pops, said the band was certain of a hit with its first single. "I think a hit is guaranteed. There will be a few people around that particular act who will be out of a job if it isn't." The test of the band's talent would come during live performances.

"You can spend your life doing Kids from Fame auditions, but the test is the one you face in front of a live audience."

He added that manufactured music still had an appeal. "I think there is an appetite for plastic pop among teenagers and those who have not escaped the teenage peer pressure to conform."

Nicki Chapman, the manager of teen singer Billie Piper and one of the judges who helped select the Popstars five, said she expected the band to be a hit because of their individual personalities.

"They can stand on their own two feet and they are not boring. At the end of the day, it's the public who will decide if we made the right decisions."

webTitle: Dyke promises rise in programme budget

fields.headline: Dyke promises massive rise in programme budget
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Greg Dyke has told BBC staff he plans to increase the programming budget by 24% by the end of 2002/3, writes Jessica Hodgson.
BBC1 set for budget boost
fields.body:
Greg Dyke has told BBC staff he plans to up the programming budget by 24% by the end of 2002/3.

In an address to staff yesterday, BBC director general reiterated his pledge to boost BBC1 and BBC 2 schedules with an extra £131m for the two stations next year.

But he told staff the extra money could only come from further cost-cutting which will inevitably mean redundancies.

Mr Dyke said he still had to cut a further £28m in running costs by the end of the year 2001/2002 to achieve targets.

In a broad-ranging speech, the director general said the BBC has trimmed £4m more from its operations than was planned when his One BBC strategy was announced last year.

The BBC has to make overall savings of £146m a year by the end of 2003/4.

Cost-cutting under the plan has cut £5m, and an additional £20m has been cut from different parts of the organisation.

Mr Dyke also announced he had cut the amount of money spent on management consultants by 85%.

And he reviewed other changes made over the course of the year, including the BBC's planned new digital services, and new targets for ethnic representation among staff.

But BBC staff were underwhelmed by the director-general's first year anniversary speech.

One insider said most staff, jaded by problems on the London Underground, had been too busy "getting on with their jobs" to pay too much attention to the address.
