webTitle: Lib Dems promise to make elderly care election issue

fields.headline: Lib Dems promise to make elderly care election issue
fields.trailText: Ministers have come under renewed pressure to abandon their policy on long term care for the elderly after the Liberal Democrats pledged to make it an election issue.
fields.body:
Ministers have come under renewed pressure to abandon their policy on long term care for the elderly after the Liberal Democrats pledged to make it an election issue.

The government wants free nursing care for the elderly in residential homes, but has rejected calls to make personal care - help with washing, eating and dressing, for example - available for free.

MPs will today debate the issue at the parliamentary standing committee scrutinising the health and social care bill.

The Liberal Democrats are expected to press for an amendment to the bill to enable free personal care, although it is unlikely to succeed given Labour's inbuilt majority on the committee.

The government's own royal commission on long term care headed by Sir Stewart Sutherland recommended that personal care should be funded by the taxpayer. But ministers refused to support this proposal, arguing that it would not be cost effective.

Yesterday the government defended its stance on long term care in a Commons debate called by the Liberal Democrats. Health minister Gisele Stuart said its policy would lead to better services for old people.

The Conservatives supported the government, saying the cost of free care would be better spent elsewhere in the NHS, even though the Tories in Scotland have backed the Liberal Democrats in campaining for free personal care north of the border

Last month the Scottish executive provoked the wrath of the UK government after it pushed ahead with proposals to accept the Sutherland report recommendations in full, after coming under pressure from the Liberal Democrats and Scottish National party in the Scottish parliament.

The Liberal Democrats said yesterday that free personal care for the elderly would be a central plank of the party's health policy in its manifesto for the general election.

Party leader Charles Kennedy called for a UK wide debate on "delivering a care system fair and fit for all" and warned that Labour's policy would not lift the pressure on elderly people forced to sell their homes to pay for their care.

webTitle: Cussons launches 'lathercam'

fields.headline: Cussons launches 'lathercam'
fields.standfirst: Click here for a doggy bath
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Big Brother producers were the first to introduce a webcam to a shower, capturing Nasty Nick's ablutions from a discreet overhead angle, reports Amy Vickers.
Click here for a doggy bath
fields.body:
Big Brother producers were the first to introduce a webcam to a shower, capturing Nasty Nick's ablutions from a discreet overhead angle.

Now soap manufacturer Cussons is jumping on the bandwagon with a new campaign featuring a cute little dog starring in the world's first "lathercam".

It hopes the promotion, on its website releasethelather.co.uk, will earn a cult following and help transform the image of Imperial Leather from a luxury bar to a family product that children as well as adults can covet.

The move is part of a £9m makeover for the soap, which will extend to a TV campaign in spring, with the "Release the Lather" slogan. The idea is to modernise the brand and position Imperial Leather as synonymous with lather.

The website adds a quirky dimension to the brand with features such as lathercams - fly-on-the-wall webcams placed in showers, advice for keeping fit at work, competitions and games. One of the lathercams even features a dog ambling into a shower.

webTitle: Brown aims children's credit at 4m families to cut poverty

fields.headline: Brown aims children's credit at 4m families to cut poverty
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday intensified the pre-election battle over tax by promising that 4m families in Britain will be better off by £442 a year under Labour thanks to the children's tax credit, which comes into effect in April.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday intensified the pre-election battle over tax by promising that 4m families in Britain will be better off by £442 a year under Labour thanks to the children's tax credit, which comes into effect in April.

Speaking at the launch of an advertising campaign for the credit, the chancellor made a pitch for middle Britain voters when he said that a family on average earnings of £25,000 would receive the equivalent of 2.5p off the basic rate of tax.

The £4.7m TV advertising campaign is designed to raise awareness of the children's tax credit which will benefit 5m families where the main earner brings home up to £40,000. The credit is targeted at the less well off, so that 4m families earning £32,000 or less will receive the full credit of £442 a year. With child benefit payments of £15.50 a week for the first child, this will work out at £1,248 a year.

Mr Brown said that he was determined to overhaul the tax and benefit system inherited from the Tories which neglected the needs of families and children. "We seek to ensure that the tax system actually acknowledges the costs of bringing up children and the tax and benefit system reflects those costs better," the chancellor said. "Under our policy, every family with children should have more support and in this way we improve family prosperity all round and also reduce child poverty."

Under Labour, the number of children living below the poverty line has fallen from 4m to 3m, but Mr Brown believes that further fiscal action is needed to take a further 1m out of poverty in the next parliament. But the chancellor made clear that he would not introduce "indiscriminate" tax cuts in next month's pre-election budget. "We will do nothing that puts economic stability and the improvements we are investing in for our public services at risk," he said.

Mr Brown coupled his tax cuts for families with a warning that the government expected parents to accept their responsibilities. At the same press conference, the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, said that new rules this week would allow the child support agency to crack down on a minority of parents.

Courts will also be able to confiscate driving licences from men who refuse to pay maintenance for their children. "We have to ensure that those absent parents who evade their responsibilities do their best for their children," Mr Darling said.

webTitle: Asylum seekers to be 'sent back'

fields.headline: Asylum seekers to be 'sent back'
fields.trailText: Thousands of asylum seekers could be forced back across the channel to France under a radical scheme with Paris to curb the flow of illegal immigrants to Britain.
fields.body:
Thousands of asylum seekers could be forced back across the channel to France under a radical scheme with Paris to curb the flow of illegal immigrants to Britain.

In a sign of pre-election jitters over asylum, Tony Blair will discuss the idea of summary deportations with the French president Jacques Chirac at an Anglo-French summit on Friday.

The initiative follows an Anglo-Italian scheme, launched over the weekend by the prime minister and his Italian counterpart, to crack down on up to 50,000 illegal immigrants through Bosnia and the western Balkans into Europe.

Mr Blair is now hoping to persuade M Chirac to sign up to a "bilateral repatriation" accord which would see illegal cross-channel immigrants being deported back to France immediately. British officials believe that the plan would end any idea among asylum seekers that Britain is a soft touch, an accusation made forcefully by the Conservatives. A Downing Street spokeswoman confirmed last night that the idea would be on the agenda for the Anglo-French summit in Cahors on Friday. "This will be one of about half a dozen ideas on the agenda," the spokeswoman said. "They will look at issues which effect ports in both countries."

The Tories are likely to seize on the Anglo-French scheme as a sign of panic in Downing Street over asylum, an issue which William Hague has exploited over the past year. Downing Street will be hoping that introducing such a tough measure will take the heat out of the asylum issue ahead of the election.

British officials have drawn up the deportation scheme because of fears that the EU's Dublin convention on asylum, which Britain implemented in 1997, has failed to curb illegal immigrants. Under the convention, asylum seekers can be returned to the country which first cleared them to enter the EU. Asylum seekers who cross the channel usually enter the EU from countries such as Italy which have borders with non-EU states. This makes deportation more difficult.

The French have yet to respond to the British proposal. However, Mr Blair will tell Mr Chirac that the scheme would benefit France by discouraging migrants entering France en route to Britain.

The disclosure of the British plan comes amid cross-channel tensions. It is understood that Britain was irritated last month when officials learnt through the media that the French authorities were reducing border security at smaller channel ports such as Dieppe. There are reports that so called "people-smuggling gangs" are using smaller ports to avoid tighter controls in larger ports such as Calais.

The prime minister underlined his determination over the weekend to stem the flow of illegal entrants when he outlined plans with the Italian prime minister Guiliano Amato to block the "Sarajevo route" from the Balkans.

webTitle: Tube strike gridlocks website

fields.headline: Tube strike gridlocks website
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The London Underground gridlock extends to its recently launched website, thetube.com, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The gridlock caused by yesterday's London Underground strike extended onto the organisation's computer network, crashing the tube's recently launched website, thetube.com.

All day yesterday visitors to the website were greeted with "HTTP/1.1 Server Too Busy" as thetube.com's servers' buckled under the strain of demand.

Project manager for thetube.com Pete Wilson said it had been knocked out with the volume of people coming to the site.

"We reckon we've had more than 3m hits on the site today - a lot more than we anticipated," he said.

He added that they had expected a surge in traffic and, in preparation, took out all the Flash software on the site in order to speed up navigation.

On an average day, thetube.com can cope comfortably with around 200,000 hits, but the strike and demand for service information caught it on the hoof.

"It's been a pretty horrible day all round. Robustness is an issue. We're now rethinking and plan to get the server capacity extended for next week's strike," added Mr Wilson.

Thetube.com is currently working on a rejig and plans to launch a wap and text messaging information service in the next three months.

webTitle: Farr joins Golin Harris

fields.headline: Farr signs for Golin Harris
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Former BBC marketing chief Sue Farr has joined the PR giant responsible for McDonald's, Lloyds bank and Daimler, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Sue Farr, the BBC's former director of public service marketing, has finally signed up for a new job with the PR giant responsible for promoting McDonald's, Lloyds bank and Daimler cars.

Seven months after she quit the BBC, Ms Farr has landed a job as regional managing director for US PR firm Golin Harris.

At Golin Harris she will oversee operations in Europe, the middle east and Africa with effect from tomorrow.

She replaces Mary Bartholomew who retired at the end of last year.

"After seven tremendous years at the BBC, I am delighted to have been offered this fantastic opportunity," said Ms Farr.

Golin Harris is a class act. I look forward to continuing the firm's success and helping to build the Golin Harris brand in London and the rest of the Europe."

Ms Farr left the BBC after Greg Dyke overlooked her for the job of marketing director in charge of the corporation's £73m marketing budget.

Mr Dyke appointed Matthew Bannister instead, but Mr Bannister quit the £180,000 job, and the BBC, in October after only six months in the role.

At the time of Mr Bannister's appointment to the top marketing job, many within the marketing, advertising and media industries expressed surprise that Mr Dyke had not handed the post to Ms Farr, not least because Bannister had no direct experience of marketing.

Ms Farr will preside over offices in London, Frankfurt and Madrid and will be responsible for opening new offices across the region.

Golin Harris' client list includes McDonald's, DaimlerChrysler, pharmaceutical company Bayer Corporation, Lloyds TSB, Bass Brewers and Samsung.

Prior to her tenure with the BBC, Ms Farr held several marketing and communications positions with Thames Television and ad agencies WCRS, Bates Dorland and CDP.

She is chairman of the Marketing Group of Great Britain and is also a member of Forum UK, the Women's Advertising Club of London, the Royal Television Society and the Institute of Directors.

Julia Thorn, chief executive of Golin Harris' London office is to retire on March 31 after more than 25 years in the PR business.

webTitle: Mellor to make movie

fields.headline: Mellor graduates from TV to big screen
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Fat Friends and Playing the Field scriptwriter Kay Mellor is graduating from TV to the big screen, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Fat Friends and Playing the Field scriptwriter Kay Mellor is graduating from TV and moving to the big screen.

She is making a feature-length film of her West End play A Passionate Woman, a romantic comedy about a woman's mid-life crisis.

It is the second feature film by Ms Mellor, who made her name with the ITV drama Band of Gold starring Cathy Tyson and Geraldine James.

And it explains why ITV has not been able to persuade her to do another Fat Friends and why the hit BBC drama Playing the Field is also coming to an end.

She is working on the feature with the Scala Productions, the company which produced her 1999 directorial debut Fanny and Elvis, which starred Ray Winstone and Kerry Fox.

The big-screen version of A Passionate Woman will see Mellor back in Yorkshire, where Fanny and Elvis was shot. Production will begin late this summer and the film is due for a 2002 release.

The story centres on a post-menopausal woman, Betty Stephenson, and her relationship with a man called Craze.

The action opens in 1990s Yorkshire with Betty reminiscing about how she met Craze.

Much of the movie is taken up with a series of flashbacks to the 1950s showing Betty as a young woman and charting her relationship with Craze.

Talks are underway with several British actors about taking the lead parts, but names remain under wraps.

Fanny and Elvis, a classic will-they-won't-they comedy, centred on a romantic novelist in a desperate search for a man to father her child.

Jennifer Saunders and Ms Mellor's youngest daughter Gaynor Faye, better known as Coronation Street's Judy Mallett, also appeared in the film.

Ms Mellor, famed for her gritty but humorous tales of northern folk, wrote A Passionate Woman in 1993 for the West Yorkshire Playhouse inspired by her mother's extramarital affair.

The play transferred to the West End where it ran for more than a year.

The author is also in talks with Tiger Aspect Productions about another feature film project.

webTitle: 'Shame' of former civic deputy

fields.headline: 'Shame' of former civic deputy
fields.trailText: A former deputy leader of Doncaster council was given a two month suspended jail sentence yesterday - the 19th conviction of members of the discredited Labour authority.
fields.body:
A former deputy leader of Doncaster council was given a two month suspended jail sentence yesterday - the 19th conviction of members of the discredited Labour authority.

Michael Farrington, 52, pleaded guilty to an expenses fraud charge which had been expected to go to a three-day trial at Hull crown court.

Farrington, who is still a member of the council, was told by Judge Peter Barker that he had brought disgrace on the public office he held. He is expected to resign although he is not legally barred from serving as a councillor because the sentence is less than three months.

The court heard that Farrington, a civil servant with the Child Support Agency, had claimed expenses for two extra nights at a Blackpool hotel after a conference of the National Society of Clean Air. His solicitor, David Green QC, said that Farrington's wife had been ill and he had wanted two days on his own to reflect on the family's situation.

The councillor, who represents Doncaster's Richmond ward, admitted falsely claiming £137.60 for the two nights, and was ordered to repay the sum and £750 costs. The judge told him: "It is a melancholy day when a man of 52 who is an elected councillor and who became deputy leader of the council has to stand in the dock of a criminal court and plead guilty to an offences of dishonesty."

Judge Barker said that a prison sentence was inevitable for serious dishonesty but he ordered a 12 month suspension because of Farrington's previous good character. The court heard that he might lose his job after 22 years' work with the civil service, pending discussions with his employers.

The number of prosecutions of Doncaster councillors, former councillors and officials is expected to approach 40 after South Yorkshire police's prolonged fraud inquiry, Operation Danum.

webTitle: Jails chief threatens to resign

fields.headline: Jails chief threatens to resign
fields.trailText: Martin Narey, the head of the prison service, last night named six jails as "hellholes" and warned he would quit his job unless conditions throughout prisons in England and Wales improved.
fields.body:
Martin Narey, the head of the prison service, last night named six jails as "hellholes" and warned he would quit his job unless conditions throughout prisons in England and Wales improved.

The director general of the prison service made his scathing criticism of the slow pace of change as the chief inspector of prisons was preparing to publish yet another devastating report, this time into Winson Green, Birmingham, which he is expected to label the worst in Britain.

Mr Narey's threat to quit follows last week's clash between the lord chief justice and the home secretary over the corrosive effects of the ever-rising prison population, and the resignation of Jack Straw's trusted head of the prison service would be a blow to Labour's anti-crime credentials.

Mr Narey told the prison service's annual conference in Nottingham yesterday that he was not prepared to keep on apologising "for failing prison after failing prison". He said he had enough of trying to "explain the very immorality of our treatment of some prisoners and the degradation of some establishments".

He took the unprecedented step of naming Wormwood Scrubs, Leeds, Wandsworth, Portland and Brixton as "hellholes" which had too often been regarded as terrible places which could not be changed. "When pushed to justify intolerable conditions we have found it easier to explain the difficulties than commit to change. We have hidden, eagerly, behind the excuses of overcrowding and behind the pressures of limited resources to defend the indefensible," said Mr Narey.

"Year after year, governor after governor, inspection after inspection, prisons like these have been exposed. Year after year exposure has led to a flurry of hand-wringing, sometimes a change of governor, a dash of capital investment, but no real or sustained improvement."

He added Winson Green's name to his list of the worst prisons and questioned whether things had changed much there since 1982 when "Barry Prosser was kicked to death by staff, none of whom was convicted for his unlawful killing".

Mr Narey said that when he last visited the Birmingham prison in September he found unacceptably dirty conditions in the healthcare centre and did not believe the duty nurse who told him it had been cleaned that morning. The staff were resigned, uncaring or both.

"I recorded that: 'the stench from one cell in which a patient was held pervaded the corridor. As I visited, at 3.45, the evening meal was being served...The board of visitors was adamant that there was no physical abuse at Birmingham. I do not share that confidence'."

He said a report shortly to be published by Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, also reported filthy conditions and appalling hygiene. "He will speak of a mentally ill prisoner denied a change of clothes for several weeks. Yet again Sir David will despair at conditions generally worse than those previously and frankly highlighted in 1995 and 1998."

Mr Narey, who is a career Home Office civil servant and has been in the top job for three years, said he had no wish to be a director general of a service which was going to duck these issues.

"I don't know yet whether I will be offered an extension to my contract when it expires in 11 months. But I tell you now: unless... I believe I have the support, encouragement and determination of all of you in this audience, I'll find an easier way of earning a living."

He said conditions at nearly all the "bastions of all that is inadequate about our service" were changing but the job was not remotely finished. If improvements could be made at the Scrubs, at Leeds and at Wandsworth, why not at Chelmsford, Bedford and Dartmoor, he asked.

Mr Narey's comments follow criticism of his leadership style from prison governors in England and Wales. A letter sent to Mr Narey after a meeting of 67 governors at Sudbury, Middlesex, last month complained that insufficient notice was being taken of their concerns and they were being treated with less respect than before.

Mr Narey held "olive branch" talks with the governors last night but defended his practice of moving them from jobs in which they were "struggling", and announced that some governors would receive "executive coaching".

A letter sent to Mr Narey after a meeting of 67 governors at Sudbury, Middlesex, last month complained that insufficient notice was being taken of their concerns and they were being treated with less respect than before. Mr Narey held "olive branch" talks with the governors last night but defended his practice of moving them from jobs in which they were "struggling", and announced that some governors would receive "executive coaching".

webTitle: Alder Hey hits back at pathologist

fields.headline: Alder Hey hits back at pathologist
fields.standfirst: Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: Alder Hey children's hospital yesterday dismissed claims by a disgraced pathologist that he never knowingly took body parts from babies without their parents' consent.
fields.body:
Alder Hey children's hospital yesterday dismissed claims by a disgraced pathologist that he never knowingly took body parts from babies without their parents' consent.

Dick van Velzen was found by an independent inquiry last week to have illegally stripped body parts from hundreds of children who had died at the Liverpool hospital between 1988 and 1995. He had falsified reports and removed medical records while the organs lay in jars in dusty storerooms.

The Dutch pathologist, who is under police protection in Amsterdam, broke his silence this weekend to tell the BBC that the hospital was to blame for not telling parents what would happen to their children's bodies.

He said he removed organs in postmortems performed with parental consent and followed international protocol. He said problems had only arisen because the hospital had forgotten to explain to parents what a post-mortem was. "It is terrible," he said. "It is not my fault."

Tony Bell, acting chief executive of Alder Hey hospital, responded yesterday: "I do not believe that Professor van Velzen thought that he had consent. He claimed he was adopting international protocols in taking the entire organs system. But if that was the case he should have communicated it to the staff involved in obtaining consent."

Mr Bell brushed aside the pathologist's threats to name 40 members of hospital staff allegedly involved in concealing the organ stockpile.

"There are many names in the Redfern report. There is no secrecy. But if the professor has any new names, we would welcome any new evidence."

James Underwood, vice-president of the Royal College of Pathologists, said he found Prof van Velzen's line of defence "surprising".

He said the pathologist had failed to address the most serious findings of the official inquiry report that he had taken material specifically against parental wishes and falsified autopsy reports.

"What happened at Alder Hey, particularly under the direction of Prof van Velzen, was unacceptable and very different in nature and scale from postmortem practises in the rest of the UK. He had ample time to respond to the report's findings before they were published. If he wishes to challenge the findings now he will have to produce fresh evidence."

Ed Bradley, chairman of the Alder Hey parents support group, said Prof van Velzen's comments were arrogant. "I think in his interview he has been extremely patronising, saying that parents didn't know what taking tissue meant. It goes back to the paternalism in the health service."

But Mr Bradley said that while he rejected Prof van Velzen's defence, others should share the blame.

"They should have had the courage, conscience and professionalism to come forward and say what we are doing here is unethical and unlawful."

webTitle: Is the Musicians' Union failing its members

fields.headline: Playing with fire
fields.standfirst: The Musicians' Union is accused of failing its members.  Adam Sweeting reports
fields.trailText: The Musicians' Union is accused of failing its members. Adam Sweeting reports.
fields.body:
Ask the average pop musician what the Musicians' Union means to them, and you'll probably get a blank stare in return. Although Welsh rockers the Stereophonics are proud to be MU members - they even make an appearance on the union's website - rock and pop performers have long since lost touch with whatever it is the union is supposed to do for its rank and file.

"A long time ago, all the artists that this office represented left the union," says former Dire Straits manager Ed Bicknell. "People used to say to me, 'What does the union do?' I couldn't answer them because I didn't know. Certainly for people working in contemporary music, as opposed to maybe people in dance bands or pit orchestras, there was no perceptible benefit that they could see."

The Musicians' Union has long held a reputation as a left-wing, doctrinaire organisation as secretive and tight-lipped as the KGB. If it's widely known for anything, it's for imposing a labyrinth of infuriating bureaucratic restrictions on the performance or recording of music. Meanwhile, it has tended to miss the bigger picture. Bicknell remembers asking the MU what its line was on artists playing in South Africa's Sun City during the apartheid era, and getting the response that "our members never play there". As it happened, a major British act was playing in Sun City that very week. "I said, 'Your members play in Sun City all the time', and he said, 'No they don't!' It was absurd; it was like they were wearing blinkers."

This week the MU is getting some of the splashiest publicity in its 108-year history, but for all the wrong reasons. Yesterday 72-year-old trumpeter and MU member Freddie Staff took the union to the High Court in a an attempt to find out whether the union has failed to pay out millions of pounds owed to session musicians over a period stretching back 55 years. Staff's action comes in the wake of an EC di rective that stipulated that what used to be ex-gratia payments to musicians have now become legal entitlements.

Bicknell explains: "People like Freddie Staff, and maybe lots of string players who might have played on The Beatles' A Day in the Life or a Walker Brothers record, have stuck their hands in the air and said, 'Where's my money? This money was supposed to come from the MU and I haven't had any.' "

Not everyone agrees that the MU is the last bastion of restrictive practices. According to the London Symphony Orchestra's managing director, Clive Gillinson, "the union is much more flexible and aware of how entrepreneurial everybody has to be now". Pete King, who helped Ronnie Scott found his Soho jazz club in 1959, comments that "many years ago, the club went through a very difficult financial period, and the MU assisted us financially. Generally they tried to look after their members pretty well, I think."

But if the Musicians' Union had adhered to its original rigorous stance, Beatlemania would never have crossed the Atlantic. Until the end of the 1950s the MU prohibited American musicians from performing in Britain, on the grounds that they would be taking work from British musicians. The American Federation of Musicians reciprocated by keeping British artists out of the US. It was largely because of Pete King and Ronnie Scott, who wanted to bring over American jazz musicians to play in their new club, that the Union's diktat was modified.

Bicknell worked as a booking agent in the late 1960s, and remembers how he had to manipulate the exchange system. "Pete and Ronnie worked out an exchange system with the guy who ran the AFM in America - his name was James Petrillo and he was known as Little Caesar - and it meant that if an American musician played one gig in Britain, then a British musician would have to play one gig in America. They were called Man Days. I always used to bring in big bands because they had the most number of Man Days. For instance, if a 16-piece band like Buddy Rich's played 12 nights at Ronnie Scott's, that gave me 192 Man Days. If I had a rock trio going to America, they could play a lot longer over there."

The speed of technological change has helped to leave the MU and its "Spanish practices" behind. It was set up to protect the rights of individual players in an age of big bands and large orchestras, when sampling and electronics hadn't been invented. The union's response to the synthesiser was to try to ban it, because it put string players out of work.

One of the union's most celebrated absurdities was its demand that artists appearing on Top of the Pops had to re-record the backing track of their hit song in an afternoon, when they might have spent weeks in a studio creating the original recording. In practice, artists pretended to re-record the song, then used their original tapes. "It happened to Dire Straits," says Bicknell. "They sat around in the studio and drank tea, didn't do any re-recording at all, then used the studio tapes. The union's attitude was: 'This never happens.' "

webTitle: Sketch, Simon Hoggart: The silent Widdecombe

fields.headline: The curious case of the silent Widdecombe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Home Office questions, and a perfect chance for the Tories to assail Peter Mandelson and Keith Vaz over passport applications.
fields.body:
Home Office questions, and a perfect chance for the Tories to assail Peter Mandelson and Keith Vaz over passport applications.

So of course they didn't do it. Admittedly, questions have to be tabled two business weeks beforehand, before the Mandy business became public. But there's usually a way of working the topic in.

Sadly, this lot couldn't respond in time if you gave them each a bucket of treacle mixed with horse slops and had Mandelson and Vaz run through the chamber clad only in blue woad, chanting the All Blacks' haka. It wouldn't be in their briefing notes, so they wouldn't know what to do.

Instead they talked about crime, asylum seekers and the early release of prisoners. Mike O'Brien, the minister at the centre of the passport allegations, was present but didn't answer any questions. Perhaps that was deliberate. It may have been an unusual example of hiding someone away by putting them on the frontbench.

But something else was going on. There was what Arthur Conan Doyle would have called the curious incident of Ann Widdecombe going bonkers.

Dr Watson: "But Ann Widdecombe did not go bonkers."

Sherlock Holmes: "That was the curious incident."

For Miss Widdecombe has calmed down. The volcano is dormant. Instead of bubbling and squeaking and smoking and fuming and roiling and boiling and sending fiery embers over her colleagues, she was almost silent.

Even her clothes, a smart green jacket and crisp fawn skirt instead of the tartan picnic rug outfit, spoke of a statepersonlike figure.

The reason is simple. She hopes to be leader of the Tory party. It is conceivable that the vote might be as early as May this year. The choice will be made by 300,000 party members from a shortlist of two voted by the MPs. She will be lucky to get on it. But she won't stand a chance if she comes over like a wronged mistress on the Jerry Springer show. Hence the new Widdecombe.

But at the same time that sense of delirious lunacy has to go somewhere. She appears to have recruited Tory MPs to be mad on her behalf.

Take Edward Leigh. He was outraged by the number of criminals who have been let out of jail early. He raced through a list of crimes they had committed after their release: "threats to kill three actual bodily harm twenty-two wounding six assault thirty-five rapes two indecent assault one burglary forty-six robbery seventeen drugs one hundred and eleven" the whole thing delivered in a maniacal gabble, so that the words I've quoted above took him less than seven seconds to deliver.

But he was a model of calm reason compared with John Bercow, the junior home affairs spokesman I think of as Miss Widdecombe's Mini-Me. He too raced through a list of crimes to be blamed on the government, including manslaughter, sex offences, grievous bodily harm, "disorder and. Indeed! Of affray!"

Now and again he glanced up at the press gallery (he is, we are told, an admirer of one of our colleagues, and he was perhaps shyly hoping she had noticed his success.)

As the session continued, Mr Bercow bounced on his seat, wiggled his feet (they seemed to make his head nod in rhythm), and swivelled round to yell at colleagues.

This is what care in the community ought to be about. Instead of dysfunctional people being released early in order to shout at strangers on buses, they can shout at MPs instead.

Through it all Miss Widdecombe sat, grave and pensive, her arms folded under her bosom, possibly forming her first shadow cabinet in her head.

webTitle: Analysis: Tories in Scotland

fields.headline: Northern lows
fields.standfirst:
The Tories are in the doldrums in Scotland and unless they change their image as an English party there is little hope of a recovery

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Tories are in the doldrums in Scotland and unless they change their image as an English party there is little hope of a recovery.
fields.body:
If, despite the Labour party's problems with Peter Mandelson and Keith Vaz, the Tories are still doing badly in the polls in England in advance of a general election, spare a thought for Scottish Conservatism. Its fortunes show very little sign of recovery.

Since the 1997 general election, support for the Tories in opinion polls asking about elections for Westminster peaked at 17% in Mori polls in April 2000 and 22% in ICM polls in September 2000. In surveys of voting intentions for Scotland-only elections, the Tories did even worse, with a peak of 14% in System 3's polls in April and May 2000 and 16% in ICM's poll in September 2000. These are not figures to inspire confidence about the party's electoral prospects, especially when there are now no Scottish Tory MPs at Westminster.

The most worrying thing for the Tory party in Scotland is that the seats it lost as long ago as 1987 were not recovered by the party come 1992, 1997 and 1999. The fear must be that the 11 seats lost in 1997 follow exactly the same pattern - lost for evermore.

Though the elections to the new Scottish parliament in 1999 delivered 18 seats for the Tories, none of these members was elected from first past the post. All succeeded on the back of proportional representation thanks to regional party lists. Also, support for the Tories fell by 2% in 1999 compared with 1997, to a new low of 15.6% - the falling red line on the chart kept going south. The party did regain one of its former Edinburgh parliament seats in Ayr in March 2000 but this was a byelection; it was the first Scottish gain since 1967. It did not indicate a surge in Tory fortunes north of the border.

Of the 11 seats lost by the Scottish Tories in 1997, only two saw a rise in the Tory vote in 1999. Ayr had a rise of 4.2% while Perth recorded an increase of 1.5%. The party's vote fell in all other former Tory-held seats such as Edinburgh West, Galloway and Upper Nithsdale and Stirling. Moreover, in the latter seat, the constituency of the former Scottish secretary Michael Forsyth, the Tory vote collapsed and the party came home in third place behind Labour and the Scottish Nationalists. A similar fate was visited upon the Tories in Aberdeen South, which is now a Labour-Liberal Democrat marginal.

Indeed, overall, the Tory vote rose in only 14 seats from 1997-99, mostly by around 1% and mostly in no-hope seats where the party struggles to hold its deposit - Glasgow Govan, Coatbridge and Chryston and Western Isles were three good examples. On the 1999 figures it would seem that only Ayr and Perth offer the Tories any hope of Scottish representation at Westminster after the forthcoming general election.

Clearly any hopes William Hague entertains of a Tory electoral recovery have not been built on expectations of extensive victories in Scotland. But the Scots Tories are likely to do as badly in 2001 as they did in 1997, with no recovery in sight. A rise from no Westminster seats to between six and eight might be spun as a recovery of sorts, but gaining only one or two would be pretty devastating and not help Scots Tories in the run-up to the next Scottish elections in 2003. Indeed, the party would appear as marginal in Scotland as it did in 1997.

The electoral picture is all the more disturbing for the Tories as they have made some progress in Scotland since 1997. The party was relaunched in 1998 with a more Scottish identity, leadership and policy-making process. They have more autonomy from the English in terms of policy. The party leader, David McLetchie, has performed well in the Edinburgh parliament and some of the party's MSPs have developed a prominent opposition role and strong media presence.

Significantly they have done so on such popular issues as education and health rather than those Mr Hague has focused on such as asylum seekers and policing.

Scots Tories have even raised the prospect of using the parliament's taxation powers to fund public services, effectively increasing income tax - anathema for Labour and the English Conservatives - as well as extending devolution by providing the Scottish parliament with more fiscal powers. However, despite such changes, support for the Tories has remained around or below the level achieved in 1997 and popular perceptions of the party have not radically changed.

Some of the explanation for such stubbornly low support is the legacy of 18 years in power and, in particular, the enduring image of Mrs Thatcher, the poll tax and Tory opposition to a Scottish parliament. Despite their political makeover, the Tories are still perceived as an anti-Scottish party who are representative of southern England. Mr Hague's political focus on Europe, immigration and the "West Lothian question" (why do Scots get to vote on English affairs and not vice versa?) reinforced its English image to some extent.

In addition, the general unpopularity of the Tories across Britain has not helped. If Mr Hague and his shadow cabinet offered a popular alternative to Labour, then support for the Tories in Scotland would rise from the depths and there would be a chance of regaining some seats. The party Mr Hague continues to lead at Westminster looks likely to remain an English party rather than a British one: an ironic situation for the "unionist" party.

Peter Lynch of the University of Stirling is author of Scottish Government and Politics, Edinburgh University Press

However, despite such changes, support for the Tories has remained around or below the level achieved in 1997 and popular perceptions of the party have not radically changed. Some of the explanation for such stubbornly low support is the legacy of 18 years in power and, in particular, the enduring image of Mrs Thatcher, the poll tax and Tory opposition to a Scottish parliament. Despite their political makeover, the Tories are still perceived as an anti-Scottish party who are representative of southern England. Mr Hague's political focus on Europe, immigration and the "West Lothian question" (why do Scots get to vote on English affairs and not vice versa?) reinforced its English image to some extent. In addition, the general unpopularity of the Tories across Britain has not helped. If Mr Hague and his shadow cabinet offered a popular alternative to Labour, then support for the Tories in Scotland would rise from the depths and there would be a chance of regaining some seats. The party Mr Hague continues to lead at Westminster looks likely to remain an English party rather than a British one: an ironic situation for the "unionist" party. webTitle: Family of four found shot dead at home

fields.headline: Family of four found shot dead at home
fields.standfirst:
Police suspect former sergeant major in Coldstream Guards killed wife and two children before turning gun on himself

Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: Police suspect former sergeant major in Coldstream Guards killed wife and two children before turning gun on himself.
fields.body:
A family of four, including two children, were found shot dead at their home in Surrey yesterday when officers broke down the front door following calls from friends who had not seen the parents since before the weekend.

The children, a girl and a boy, were discovered in separate bedrooms upstairs. The mother and father were also found in different rooms.

A shotgun was recovered from the detached house in Heathside Park - a private estate just outside Camberley - and was sent for forensic analysis.

Police suspect the father shot his wife and children while they were asleep before turning the gun on himself, although the officer in charge of the investigation, Detective Superintendent John Beavis, said he would remain "open minded" and admitted he had no idea about motive.

"We have no reason at this stage to believe anyone else was involved," he said.

"It is likely that we are investigating three murders and a suicide. We are not looking for anyone else."

Mr Beavis did not name the family, but neighbours said that the parents were Anthony and Kay Smith, both in their 30s, who moved to the small redbrick estate last summer. They had a son, Adam, and daughter, Gemma.

Mr Smith was until five years ago in the army, where he was a sergeant major in the Coldstream Guards. An army spokesman said last night that Mr Smith would have moved between Windsor Castle and St James' Palace and carried out ceremonial duties for the royal household.

After leaving the forces he worked for a car dealership in Aldershot, Hampshire, before becoming a bodyguard for a firm in London.

Military police went to the gated estate yesterday and have offered to help Surrey with its investigation.

Detectives went to Heathside Park at 9.40am shortly after a friend of the family called at the house. He was concerned because two cars were in the driveway but nobody answered the door.

Neighbours had noticed letters, newspapers and cartons of milk had not been taken into the house for several days.

"They were concerned that there had been no contact or sighting of the family over the weekend," said Mr Beavis.

"They rightly called us and we had to force our way into the house. We found the bodies of four people. All had suffered gunshot wounds. We have had no reports of people hearing shots."

Neighbours said yesterday that they were astonished by the deaths, describing the Smiths as a "lovely family".

"He was a big man in all ways," said Graeme Senior, who knew the family when they lived in Rowledge, near Farnham, Surrey.

"He was stockily built and was also a boisterous character. Kay was very quiet and often stayed at home although she would join him on his overseas trips to motor shows. He was a generous man and would always bring me back a bottle of wine when he went on a foreign trip."

Pat Pearce, mayor of Surrey Heath, said she met the couple when she was canvassing in Camberley last year. "I am deeply shocked that something like this could happen here. It is inconceivable that someone could kill three people and then turn their own hand on themselves."

The bodies were later examined at the house by a Home Office pathologist before being taken to nearby Frimley Park hospital for post mortems.

An inquest into the deaths is to be opened and adjourned by the Surrey coroner, Michael Burgess.

webTitle: The Paulsgrove estate after the paedophile-purges

fields.headline: After the purge
fields.standfirst:
In the wake of Sarah Payne's death, the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth caught the national mood of fear and loathing. As residents routed out suspected paedophiles, innocents were terrorised and riots split the community. But what happened next? Seven months on, Dave Hill pays a visit

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: In the wake of Sarah Payne's death, the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth caught the national mood of fear and loathing. As residents routed out suspected paedophiles, innocents were terrorised and riots split the community. But what happened next? Seven months on,  Dave Hill  pays a visit
fields.body:
It wasn't until he switched on Newsnight that Father Gary Waddington realised he had trouble brewing in his own backyard. Driving home after dining out with friends, he'd seen the burning car surrounded by onlookers, fire fighters and police, but could never have imagined what the scene signified. "I just thought there'd been an accident," he says. "Then I realised I was seeing exactly the same thing on my television screen, with Jeremy Paxman explaining what was really going on - almost literally on my doorstep."

From Father Gary's garden gate you get a view of where the paedophile-purgers of the Paulsgrove estate got into their stride. A municipal green slopes down from the front of St Michael and All Angels church until it meets Allaway Avenue, with its promenade of shops and the local housing office of Portsmouth city council. Facing this stands the second-floor flat where Victor Burnett, 55, used to live, and which he had vacated only hours before a group of his neighbours wanted him out.

There'd been mutterings about Burnett since he'd moved in two years ago. But after he became one of the convicted child sex offenders "named and shamed" by the News of the World following the death of Sarah Payne, and after further coverage in the local press, the mutterings turned into howls of hate. Placards were brandished, missiles thrown and a police officer injured. At one point a woman, thought to have been Burnett's sister, came on the scene. Her car was turned over and torched.

On the same day, August 3, that the News of the World bowed to pressure to stop naming and shaming, the paedophile story got fresh legs. Paulsgrove was the place where it ran. Seven months later it is still running. It took a week for Paulsgrove's dispensers of unofficial justice to extend it to a dozen or so other residents of their own or the adjoining Wymering estate, and, in the process, get the media goggling, the politicians flapping and parents everywhere worrying about predatory "perverts" lurking down their way.

By contrast, the forces of conventional authority have had a lengthier task. The wheels of law and order are still turning. Fifty people were arrested during the period of the protests, 39 of whom were charged. Most of these have come before magistrates in recent weeks: the minor cases have been dealt with, the more serious will go to crown court later in the year. Meanwhile, at ground level, fears have had to be stilled and scars healed.

"It could have happened anywhere," Father Gary says as he takes me on a tour through Paulsgrove. It's not urban unrest country. Paulsgrove does not bloom with affluence, but nor does it reek of decay. Sixty per cent of its properties are owner-occupied and early residents, called "Grovers", maintain a pioneering spirit. Theirs, though, was not the sort of solidarity paraded by the "perv-hunters".

Councillor David Horne, a resident of Paulsgrove for 36 years, describes how "the whole estate was touched by it. If they didn't see it for themselves, they saw it on the news every night. There were lots of terrified people asking each other 'are they going to come down my street next?' Most people look on the protesters with nothing but contempt. You could say the community has united against them. Most of all, they would just like to forget."

The council remains engaged in social fabric surgery. Rob Hutchinson, director of Portsmouth social services, says: "We've got into a closer dialogue with the community; a respectable community which is articulating itself in a way that it hasn't done before. The established local groups like the tenants associations, and more recently the protesters, have been contributing in a responsible and sensible way."

But getting to this stage has not been easy. The problem was establishing a dialogue with the protest organisers - Residents Against Paedophiles, as they are known - with their mobile-phone networks, business cards and mob which trailed in their wake. And once the protests were called off came the long slog of reconstruction. A "Keep Safe" programme has been running in the schools, and last month a Paulsgrove primary hosted the launch of council-funded child protection awareness sessions.

Hutchinson and others have also offered reassurance that the system designed to protect the public against paedophiles works. He stresses that following previous expressions of concern, Burnett had been the subject of two public protection conferences involving social services, probation staff and the police - the standard procedure. The conclusion of both assessments was that, despite his previous record, there was no evidence that Burnett was going back to his old ways. As for the others who attracted Rap's attentions, the authorities are certain that none posed a threat. Up to 20 people were screened by social services, the probation service and the police. Of these, some had no criminal record, no charges pending, nor even any previously recorded allegation of criminal activity. Others did have convictions, of which some were for sexual offences. But these were not against young children and, in one case, had been committed many years ago with no subsequent reoffending.

In short, all the protesters' targets subsequent to Burnett were victims of rumour, gossip and, in some cases, sheer spite. Nor were those besieged and terrorised inside their homes the only victims, according to Superintendent Bob Golding who was in charge of policing: "There are the children who witnessed the demos or took part; some of them were only four or five years old. Then there were others in the area, intimidated by what was happening and too scared to speak out."

The legacy of bloodlust may be hardest to erase. Most of those who had their collars felt were just boy rowdies, out for fun. But it's the images of women and their children marching through the night that stick most in the mind: infants toting cardboard coffins, mothers chanting hate. It may have been triggered by a combination of local circumstances and national news events. But Paulsgrove still came to represent with terrible vividness a mood of fear and loathing in the national psyche.

If the leading lights of Rap are anything to go by, that mood may rise again. Among the most vocal was Katrina Kessell, 33-year-old lone mother of five, and a victim of sexual abuse as a child. Her credentials as a mother took a knock at the height of the protests when her three-year-old son was found wandering alone while she was off venting her ire. Kessell, though, is undaunted. "My mum was looking after him, and she's disabled. He hadn't gone very far; he was looking for the policeman he'd met the night before who'd shown him how to use a camcorder." She regrets the violence, but not being fined £60 last Monday for, as she puts it, "shouting me mouth off in the street".

She sticks by her assertion that only the undeserving got the doorstep treatment: "We checked them all out properly, we had people down the library looking back through the newspapers." She says the longer-term benefits are clear. By Kessell's reckoning, all but two paedophiles now remain to pose a threat to children, and they at least, she says, are being "properly monitored" by the police: "It's a lot better round here now they've gone."

Moreover, she explains, seeing off the paedo-menace has yielded other improvements: the child protection sessions are part of a council drive to assuage community fears that has been careful to take grass-roots sentiment on board. Plus, she says, there's been a healthy growth of public spirit: "A lot of us are closer than we were. Looking out for our kids has helped bring people together."

Not everyone agrees, and not everyone on Paulsgrove is as content to talk to the media: for example, established residents groups have declined to cooperate with a planned Channel 4 Dispatches programme. Yet even some of those with grave misgivings about the protests believe - or, at least, hope - that some good may have come from them.

Father Gary recalls that "the more obvious it became that completely innocent citizens were being driven from their homes, the more people started to think about the problem of paedophiles a bit more deeply. They began to ask well, if we don't have these people here, where else will they go? Or, just because we haven't got them living in our streets, does that mean they stop being a danger to our children?" But as Father Gary also said: "It was a pretty frightening way to start up a debate."

webTitle: Five dead in shooting at US engine plant

fields.headline: Five dead in shooting at US engine plant
fields.standfirst: Special report: Gun violence in America
fields.trailText: A factory worker who was caught stealing from his employers burst into an engine plant in suburban Chicago and opened fire yesterday, the day before he was due to report to prison.
fields.body:
A factory worker who was caught stealing from his employers burst into an engine plant in suburban Chicago and opened fire yesterday, the day before he was due to report to prison.

Five people, including the gunman, were killed and four others were wounded by the shooting at the Navistar plant, which makes lorry engines.

William Baker, 66, was due to surrender today to start serving a five-month federal prison sentence for conspiracy to commit theft from an interstate shipment.

The assistant US attorney, Nancy Needles, confirmed that Baker was the gunman and that he was among the dead. No further information about him and his victims was released.

Martin Reutimann, a 24-year-old engineer, was at his desk when the shooting began.

"I heard somebody yell, 'There's a guy in the centre aisle with a gun!'" The aisle is a hallway where engines are tested.

He saw people running past him and then grabbed his phone and called the police.

Baker, a tool room attendant, had worked at the plantfor 39 years before he was sacked in 1994. He pleaded guilty last June.

webTitle: Quake victims found alive after 10 days

fields.headline: Quake victims found alive after 10 days
fields.standfirst:
Just when all hope was lost India's disaster yields one more miracle

Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: Just when all hope was lost India's disaster yields one more miracle.
fields.body:
The pile of rubble looked like any other: what was once a three-storey building was now a giant mound of debris and a broken front door. But the rescuers sent to search the old quarter of Bhuj - the town flattened by the earthquake in India 10 days ago - were astonished yesterday when they spotted an arm waving at them through a collapsed window frame. Moving closer they heard two feeble voices.

In what must rank as one of the most extraordinary survival stories ever, the rescuers from India's Border Security Force (BSF) dug through the rubble and pulled out a man and woman - a full week and a half after the earthquake entombed them in their first-floor flat.

The brother and sister, who are in their mid 40s, had survived because they had access to water and puffed rice - and were able to crawl around their darkened living-room prison.

"When we pulled them out they could not believe that they were still alive. Both of them had been trying to attract attention but their voices were very feeble. They are emotionally shattered and very weak. But they are not very seriously injured and we expect them to recover," VN Roy, the BSF's inspector general, said last night.

"If we had tried to use bulldozers they would be dead by now," he added.

After spotting the waving arm, BSF paramilitaries spent three hours clearing away masonry with hammers, pickaxes and bare hands.

The residential block had not been noticed previously because it had been buried by an adjoining building that had collapsed totally.

The 12 rescuers formed a human chain, and finally carried the dust-covered woman out on a stretcher at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, followed soon afterwards by her brother.

The pair, who have not been named, were taken to the town's makeshift hospital. Doctors revived them with glucose drips. They were later apparently collected by rela tives, seemingly unscathed by their ordeal.

Before the extraordinary rescue, the authorities had given up hope of finding any more survivors from the earthquake. A teenager was pulled from a well in the obliterated town of Bhachau on Saturday, but since then rescuers had concentrated on retrieving the many bodies of the dead. "Everyone had given up hope," Mr Roy said.

Last night one doctor, who had treated survivors pulled from the rubble after five days, said there still might be others left alive.

"In extreme conditions people can survive for 10 to 12 days," Dr HC Hotchandani, who is working in the hospital of the flattened town of Gandhidham, said. "We were not expecting anybody but five people were brought in last week."

Several of those who survived had been in their kitchens at the time of the earthquake and had been able to retrieve water or soft drinks from their fridges.

Bhuj, the town closest to the epicentre of the catastrophic quake, which measured 7.9 on the Richter scale, was slowly returning to a kind of normality yesterday.

Several shopkeepers went back to work, including a barber who had 50 customers in his first hour. But most of the town is still without electricity and phones. Tonnes of foreign aid pouring into Bhuj's airport have yet to be distributed because there are too few trucks and thousands of people left homeless by the earthquake continue to sleep in the streets.

Some 600,000 people have been left homeless by the quake and more than 17,000 have died, with the toll expected to rise to 30,000 as more bodies are found when rubble is cleared, said Gujarat's home minister, Haren Pandya. The injured numbered 66,758, Gujarat state officials said.

The dead have been cleared from all but three of 400 villages in the region.

"In extreme conditions people can survive for 10 to 12 days," Dr HC Hotchandani, who is working in the hospital of the flattened town of Gandhidham, said. "We were not expecting anybody but five people were brought in last week." Several of those who survived had been in their kitchens at the time of the earthquake and had been able to retrieve water or soft drinks from their fridges. Bhuj, the town closest to the epicentre of the catastrophic quake, which measured 7.9 on the Richter scale, was slowly returning to a kind of normality yesterday. Several shopkeepers went back to work, including a barber who had 50 customers in his first hour. But most of the town is still without electricity and phones. Tonnes of foreign aid pouring into Bhuj's airport have yet to be distributed because there are too few trucks and thousands of people left homeless by the earthquake continue to sleep in the streets. Some 600,000 people have been left homeless by the quake and more than 17,000 have died, with the toll expected to rise to 30,000 as more bodies are found when rubble is cleared, said Gujarat's home minister, Haren Pandya. The injured numbered 66,758, Gujarat state officials said. The dead have been cleared from all but three of 400 villages in the region.

webTitle: TV pick of the day

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: Atlantic City | Live Biathlon | Generation E
fields.byline: Paul Howlett, Simon Burnton and Richard Vine
fields.body:
Films

Atlantic City (Louis Malle, 1980) 11pm, Carlton Cinema Burt Lancaster signed off a long, distinguished career of screen heroes with this moving depiction of a petty crook who finally catches a glimpse of the big time. Fascinated by his young waitress neighbour, Susan Sarandon, he is soon embroiled in husband Robert Joy's drugs racket, and rescues her from gangsters. Superbly acted, Malle's heartfelt study of little people and their big dreams is beautifully shot.

Mimic (Guillermo Del Toro, 1997) 11.30pm, Sky Premier Another superior sci-fi chiller from the Mexican director of Cronos. This has scientists Mira Sorvino and husband Jeremy Northam introducing their genetically modified cockroach-eating bug into New York. Well done. But within years the bug has mutated into a people-eating creature that can take on human shape...

Aguirre: The Wrath Of God (Werner Herzog, 1972) 11.55pm, FilmFour An epic account of Pizarro's conquistadors on a mad quest for the legendary gold of El Dorado. A film of extraordinary power and images, blessed with the elemental presence of "crazy" Klaus Kinski as Don Lope de Aguirre, a megalomaniac who calls down the wrath of his God on the New World. The later revelations about the angst-ridden working relationship of director and star add to the heady mix.

Le Bossu (Philippe de Broca, 1997) 1.20am, Sky Premier De Broca stages one of those breathless, beautiful swashbucklers the French do so well (La Reine Margot, Horseman On The Roof et al): it must be something to do with the Musketeers tradition. The ubiquitous Daniel Auteuil is Lagardère, a 17th-century swordsman. When his friend - the heroic, doltish Duc de Nevers (Vincent Perez) - is betrayed by his scheming cousin, Gonzague (Fabrice Luchini), Lagardère is left to bring up the Duc's daughter, and to seek revenge.
Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Biathlon British Eurosport, 11am It's World Championship time again. Day three of the biathletes' global get-together in Pokljuka, Slovenia, sees the most high-profile individual women's event, the 15km. Look out for Sweden's Magdalena Forsberg, who has dominated this season thanks largely to her reliable shooting. A battle as much of stamina as skill, the biathlon may lack the dizzying speed and instant thrills of alpine skiing but of course they don't get to have guns.
Simon Burnton

Factual

Generation E 11pm, E4 A look at that most peculiar of modern obsessions tonight: the label junkie. The show belongs to the terrifying perspectives of young student Kerry Tier, with her vision of a planet where all the Niketowns have merged into one giant Nikeworld and all other brands have been forcibly phased out. Where's No Logo when you need it?
Richard Vine

webTitle: Mock award for MoD's secrecy

fields.headline: Mock award for MoD's secrecy
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence came under fire at a ceremony to reward upholders of free speech last night. The department was handed a gong "for services to censorship" at the inaugural Index on Censorship awards, held in London.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence came under fire at a ceremony to reward upholders of free speech last night. The department was handed a gong "for services to censorship" at the inaugural Index on Censorship awards, held in London.

Judges said the MoD had made it "virtually impossible for anyone to expose malpractice within the armed or intelligence services" by pursuing a number of prosecutions under the Official Secrets Act.

A jailed Iranian editor, Mashallah Shamsolvaezin, received the award for most courageous defence of free speech. Mr Shamsolvaezin, former editor in chief of a now-banned newspaper, Neshat, was found guilty of "hurting Islam" and placed in solitary confinement.

International whistleblower of the year was Gregory Pasko, a former officer in the Russian navy, who was jailed in November 1997 after revealing how military vessels were dumping radioactive waste into the Sea of Japan.

The awards were announced at a dinner hosted by television presenter Jon Snow.

webTitle: No new evidence from Gadafy

fields.headline: No new evidence from Gadafy
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, yesterday failed to deliver the new evidence which he had claimed would prove the innocence of the man convicted of the Lockerbie bombing.
fields.body:
The Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, yesterday failed to deliver the new evidence which he had claimed would prove the innocence of the man convicted of the Lockerbie bombing.

Although Colonel Gadafy had promised he would unveil evidence so dramatic it would drive the trial judges to suicide, he did not produce anything yesterday to exonerate Abdelbaset Al Megrahi.

In a speech lasting more than two hours, he instead defied calls from Britain and the US for Tripoli to accept responsibility for the bombing and condemned the Lockerbie trial as an injustice and a farce.

From early yesterday morning Libya came to a standstill as the country awaited Col Gadafy's revelations. Libyans aged 18 and over deserted schools, universities, factories and offices to attend meetings where the main theme was the Lockerbie verdict.

There speaker after speaker promised Col Gadafy would reveal the evidence. But he did little more than repeat his denial of Libyan involvement in the mass murder. When asked about the absence of the information, the Libyan leader said what he had read and quoted was the "evidence that was absent in the case. The world didn't know about these facts. I refuted the whole case, destroyed it".

It had been widely speculated that Col Gadafy would produce a document which claimed to show that an extreme Palestinian group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, was responsible for the attack.

Instead Col Gadafy claimed the world had been misled by the judges' verdict. "Abdelbaset can only be viewed in the eyes of international history as a kidnapped hostage," he said. "Keeping him is a terrorist act."

Libya and other Arab nations have called for the lifting of the UN sanctions against Tripoli. But the US and Britain say they must remain until Libya admits its part in the bombing and pays compensation to the families of the victims.

webTitle: Jails chief threatens to resign

fields.headline: Jails chief threatens to resign
fields.trailText: Martin Narey, the head of the prison service, last night named six jails as "hellholes" and warned he would quit his job unless conditions throughout prisons in England and Wales improved.
fields.body:
Martin Narey, the head of the prison service, last night named six jails as "hellholes" and warned he would quit his job unless conditions throughout prisons in England and Wales improved.

The director general of the prison service made his scathing criticism of the slow pace of change as the chief inspector of prisons was preparing to publish yet another devastating report, this time into Winson Green, Birmingham, which he is expected to label the worst in Britain.

Mr Narey's threat to quit follows last week's clash between the lord chief justice and the home secretary over the corrosive effects of the ever-rising prison population, and the resignation of Jack Straw's trusted head of the prison service would be a blow to Labour's anti-crime credentials.

Mr Narey told the prison service's annual conference in Nottingham yesterday that he was not prepared to keep on apologising "for failing prison after failing prison". He said he had enough of trying to "explain the very immorality of our treatment of some prisoners and the degradation of some establishments".

He took the unprecedented step of naming Wormwood Scrubs, Leeds, Wandsworth, Portland and Brixton as "hellholes" which had too often been regarded as terrible places which could not be changed. "When pushed to justify intolerable conditions we have found it easier to explain the difficulties than commit to change. We have hidden, eagerly, behind the excuses of overcrowding and behind the pressures of limited resources to defend the indefensible," said Mr Narey.

"Year after year, governor after governor, inspection after inspection, prisons like these have been exposed. Year after year exposure has led to a flurry of hand-wringing, sometimes a change of governor, a dash of capital investment, but no real or sustained improvement."

He added Winson Green's name to his list of the worst prisons and questioned whether things had changed much there since 1982 when "Barry Prosser was kicked to death by staff, none of whom was convicted for his unlawful killing".

Mr Narey said that when he last visited the Birmingham prison in September he found unacceptably dirty conditions in the healthcare centre and did not believe the duty nurse who told him it had been cleaned that morning. The staff were resigned, uncaring or both.

"I recorded that: 'the stench from one cell in which a patient was held pervaded the corridor. As I visited, at 3.45, the evening meal was being served...The board of visitors was adamant that there was no physical abuse at Birmingham. I do not share that confidence'."

He said a report shortly to be published by Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, also reported filthy conditions and appalling hygiene. "He will speak of a mentally ill prisoner denied a change of clothes for several weeks. Yet again Sir David will despair at conditions generally worse than those previously and frankly highlighted in 1995 and 1998."

Mr Narey, who is a career Home Office civil servant and has been in the top job for three years, said he had no wish to be a director general of a service which was going to duck these issues.

"I don't know yet whether I will be offered an extension to my contract when it expires in 11 months. But I tell you now: unless... I believe I have the support, encouragement and determination of all of you in this audience, I'll find an easier way of earning a living."

He said conditions at nearly all the "bastions of all that is inadequate about our service" were changing but the job was not remotely finished. If improvements could be made at the Scrubs, at Leeds and at Wandsworth, why not at Chelmsford, Bedford and Dartmoor, he asked.

Mr Narey's comments follow criticism of his leadership style from prison governors in England and Wales. A letter sent to Mr Narey after a meeting of 67 governors at Sudbury, Middlesex, last month complained that insufficient notice was being taken of their concerns and they were being treated with less respect than before.

Mr Narey held "olive branch" talks with the governors last night but defended his practice of moving them from jobs in which they were "struggling", and announced that some governors would receive "executive coaching".

webTitle: Curb on sex queries in rape trials challenged

fields.headline: Curb on sex queries in rape trials challenged
fields.standfirst:
Law lords to rule on fairness to defendant

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A law intended to protect women accusers in rape trials from questioning about their sex lives is to be challenged in the House of Lords next month, as being a breach of a defendant's right to a fair trial.
fields.body:
A law intended to protect women accusers in rape trials from questioning about their sex lives is to be challenged in the House of Lords next month, as being a breach of a defendant's right to a fair trial.

Section 41 of the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act, which came into force last December, faces a challenge under the Human Rights Act before it has been applied in a trial.

Three appeal court judges concluded provisionally last month that the provision would "unfairly distort the trial process" if a jury could not be told that the accuser, whom the defendant alleges consented to sex, had willingly had sex with him not long before. Last week they gave leave to take the case to the Lords, which will hold an expedited hearing on March 26. Other pending cases are awaiting the law lords' ruling, which could alter the provision or even hold it incompatible with the European convention on human rights, putting pressure on the government to amend it.

Lawyers for the accused, who was due to stand trial the day after the act came into effect, argued that it prevented him having a fair trial.

The ban was introduced after lobbying by women's groups, who said that past occasions were not relevant in deciding whether a woman consented on the occasion in question. Previous attempts to restrict questioning about sexual history were frustrated because judges were left a discretion, which they freely exercised.

Section 41 removed the discretion, and laid down that, where the issue was consent, questioning would be permitted only in extremely limited circumstances. Evidence of previous sexual encounters with the accused could be given only if they happened "at or about the same time" as the alleged rape. The judge due to preside last December ruled that the law barred him from allowing evidence, but he gave permission "with enthusiasm" to take the case to the court of appeal, adding: "The sooner this is looked at, the better. This problem is likely to arise in many, many cases before crown courts."

No details about the case can be reported because the man is due to stand trial after the judgment.

The court of appeal provisionally concluded that "the trial process would be unfairly distorted if a jury were precluded from knowing that the complainant and the defendant had recently engaged in consensual sexual activity".

The judges confirmed that section 41 barred evidence of previous sexual encounters between the woman and the man where the issue was whether she consented or not, but was admissible where the man's defence was not that the woman consented, but that he believed she was consenting.

It is a defence under English law if the man can convince the jury that he honestly believed the woman was consenting, however unreasonable the belief might seem. If he raises the defence of "mistaken belief", the onus is on the prosecution to disprove it.

This "Morgan defence", named after a case in which a husband invited three men to have sex with his wife, telling them she was "kinky" and was likely to struggle to get "turned on", has been much criticised but mistaken belief in consent remains a defence.

The appeal court judges said the result of the legislation was that the trial judge would have to direct the jury to take account of the evidence that the couple had a previous sexual relationship in assessing the defendant's state of mind, but to disregard it in assessing the woman's.

"It might be thought that a summing up in such terms would owe more to Lewis Carroll than to sensible jurisprudence," said Lord Justice Rose, who headed the panel.

Martin Bowley QC, an experienced criminal barrister, described the law as a shambles. He said: "I think Alice in Wonderland is putting it mildly."

webTitle: Malaria troops may sue MoD

fields.headline: Malaria troops may sue MoD
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Lawyers acting for 14 paratroopers who contracted malaria in Sierra Leone threatened yesterday to take the Ministry of Defence to court over its alleged failure to supply them with drugs in time.
fields.body:
Lawyers acting for 14 paratroopers who contracted malaria in Sierra Leone threatened yesterday to take the Ministry of Defence to court over its alleged failure to supply them with drugs in time.

It is believed to be the first time that soldiers have made a claim against the MoD for not providing the right medicine before sending them on an overseas operation.

Jeremy Woolf, their lawyer, said the anti-malaria drug Mefloquine needed to be in the body for at least 24 hours to be effective.

The paratroopers were given it only 11 hours before they arrived in West Africa last May, yet they were told they were going 36 hours before they left the UK.

The ministry yesterday admitted responsibility for one paratrooper who contracted malaria. He was not provided with drugs until five days after he arrived in Sierra Leone.

However, it rejected claims by the 14 others, who include sergeants, other non-commissioned officers, and privates. They had all received Mefloquine before departure, a spokeswoman said.

"The ministry's medical advice is that if taken within 24 hours of arrival [in malarial regions] you will be protected," she added.

Asked to comment on this disagreement, Mr Woolf said: "My clients were trustworthy and honest men in the eyes of the MoD ... it seems their word is no longer taken."

He described the response to the soldiers' claims as outrageous, saying their careers had been blighted for ever.

Some 200 soldiers arrived in Sierra Leone without anti-malaria tablets because of a shortage of Mefloquine. The issue was first raised last summer by the Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Paul Keetch.

He was told by Geoff Hoon, defence secretary, that "the number of cases confirmed are within medically expected numbers".

Of the personnel who served there, 112 have contracted malaria, and there are three other suspected cases. Yet between 1995 and 2000 only 47 armed forces personnel contracted malaria.

The ministry had "a duty to ensure that our armed forces are given the best protection we can afford", Mr Keetch said.

"The MoD must be prepared to make a full and frank disclosure - this is not a matter of vital national security. A first step would be to publish the full text of the tri-service board of inquiry set up in June 2000."
