fields.headline: Legacy urged to widen bid as dome deadline looms
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Legacy is under government pressure to seek new partners to develop the Millennium Dome ahead of a make-or-break meeting of ministers next week.
fields.body:
Legacy is under government pressure to seek new partners to develop the Millennium Dome ahead of a make-or-break meeting of ministers next week.

Ministers handling the sale have made clear to Legacy that they believe the group's prospects of making a success of the Greenwich complex would be strengthened if other companies joined the bid team.

The pressure on Legacy to widen its share base reflects Whitehall concern about handing the dome to the consortium dominated by Irish-based Treasury Holdings and fronted by the British property developer Robert Bourne.

Doubts have been raised about Legacy's ability to sign up enough tenants to transform the dome into a hi-tech Knowledge City surrounded by pubs, restaurants, shops and houses.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the dome minister, Lord Falconer of Thoroton, are to decide next Monday whether to accept Legacy's offer or throw open the sale and invite fresh bids.

Tony Blair is understood to have privately reassured Legacy that the government hopes to complete the deal next week after Mr Prescott admitted there were "problems" with the negotiations.

A Legacy source said: "If it's off, it's off next week," but insisted that an agreement was close and that the construction giant Sir Robert McAlpine, which declined to join the consortium last month, was now prepared to do so.

Ministers, however, are keen for Legacy to sign up other partners in a move that would inevitably reduce Treasury Holding's 80% stake in the group.

"If there is a situation where the government suggests we bring in a third party, because it might be beneficial, we are not short of offers," said the Legacy source. "That only works if the deal is right for everyone... it still has to be financially worth doing."

Ministers and Legacy had set next Wednesday, St Valentine's Day, as the deadline for the deal to be struck and the government will only extend the period if the agreement is close to completion.

The Legacy source admitted the consortium was "pretty battered" and "battle weary" after growing speculation that it would fail to buy the dome.

Legacy director Richard Barrett, co-owner of Treasury Holdings, insisted at the weekend no "deal breaker" issues were outstanding though the group's spokesmen on both sides of the Irish sea yesterday sounded less optimistic than they did last week.

The Tories have stepped up attacks on the proposed sale, questioning Legacy's ability to handle the project and calling for the sale to be reopened.

Legacy was made "preferred bidder" last autumn when Nomura, the Japanese merchant bank, dropped out. The consortium is likely to seek compensation for the £7m cost of the bid if it is unsuccessful.

Though other potential bidders are waiting in the wings, the government is keen to sell the dome before the election to blunt Conservative attempts to make it a campaign issue.

webTitle: Pass Notes: Coutts

fields.headline: No 1813 Coutts
fields.trailText: Coutts? Oh yes I once had them. Nasty little buggers, lay their eggs in your hair and five minutes later the whole school's scratching its scalp and the nurse comes in with these tweezer things and . . . No, this is Coutts and Co. bankers to the Queen since 1692.
fields.body:
Coutts? Oh yes I once had them. Nasty little buggers, lay their eggs in your hair and five minutes later the whole school's scratching its scalp and the nurse comes in with these tweezer things and . . . No, this is Coutts and Co. bankers to the Queen since 1692.

Oh I see, right yes, sorry, I didn't have my spectacles on. So what's amiss in the hurly-burly world of banking? It seems Coutts's showbiz customers, including Phil Collins, Sir Elton John, Iron Maiden and Britney Spears's record company, are leaving in droves.

Well, they're fickle, aren't they, these showbusiness types. I mean one minute they're wearing cowboy boots, the next they're prancing around in bright red stilettoes. True, but this is a little different. Coutts is owned by NatWest, which was recently bought by the Royal Bank of Scotland, which set about modernising things.

A lot of chrome? Some lime-green paint? No, they closed all of the counter facilities outside the throbbing metropolis of London, ditched 40 managers and set up telephone banking instead.

Good lord, is nothing sacred? Seemingly not. The clients were rather disgruntled to receive an impersonal letter telling them that their branch had changed, and that they had a new bank manager whom they had never even met.

Well I don't know my bank manager either. Come to think of it, I don't have a bank manager. I just keep all my worldly wealth stashed under the mattress. Very wise.

Well, if it's good enough for Sir Elton John, it's good enough for me. Anyway I'd have thought the stars would have relished meeting some new faces - we all know how celebrities love to mingle. Yes, but unfortunately there weren't any mushroom vol-au-vents or glasses of bubbly at this event.

So the glitterati won't be returning to Coutts & Co in a hurry? I wouldn't bank on it.

webTitle: TV review

fields.headline: The man who fell to Earth
fields.trailText: Loving The Alien | The Grimleys | Everyman
fields.body:
Before he was a best-selling author whose pseudo-scientific tomes hypothesised on the involvement of extra terrestrial beings in the evolution of mankind, Erich von Daniken was a hotel manager in Switzerland. A sort of Basil Fawlty-meets-Fox Mulder. His altogether unusual life, from silver-service waiter to what one contributor called "a prominent counter-culture spinner" holding court at the Eclectic Viewpoints Convention in Texas, was charted in Loving The Alien (Channel 4), quite a jolly documentary which seemed to sum up von Daniken rather well.

Damned as a fraud, a heretic and a charlatan, von Daniken's books The Chariots Of The Gods, The Return Of The Gods and The Gold Of The Gods (what the Gods got when they returned their chariots because of the faulty seatbelts, one assumes) sold by the bucketload in the 1960s and 1970s, so he wasn't really bothered about the name-calling. However, it was a bit of a shame for Otto, his TV repairman brother, whose work was made difficult by his sibling's notoriety: he kept getting big Swiss doors slammed in his face. (Erich's sister Leni, meanwhile, cleverly adopted the name Huggenberger, which obviously distracted people enough for her to live her life without such hassle.)

It wasn't until the Swiss authorities began a witchhunt against him - for bringing the good name of watch-making, chocolate-churning, profiting-from-Nazi-persecution-of-the-Jews Switzerland into imagined disrepute - that von Daniken got bothered. After allegations of fraud, tax evasion, premature ejaculation and homosexuality, he was sentenced to three-and-a-half years imprisonment. Relaying this episode in his life, the jolly Erich didn't seem bitter at all.

Of course, being a man used to serving roast beef from a great big silver salver without tipping it into a patron's lap, von Daniken was used to challenges, so he wrote his second book while in prison.

With a historical perspective as well as a personal one, Loving The Alien managed to hint at von Daniken's personality as well as appraise the time when he first became successful. What von Daniken did was create a meta-narrative which connected the implausibly great achievements of ancient civilisations, from Stonehenge to Macchu Picchu, the Great Pyramids to Easter Island, just when folks were tiring of the old meta-narratives like religion and science.

Effectively, he kickstarted the whole New Age, The Truth Is Out There bandwagon, so if you've got a T-shirt saying My Ancient Alien Ancestors Visited Salisbury And All I Got Was This Lousy T-Shirt, you can thank von Daniken for it. Well, maybe "thank" is the wrong word.

"Good" is definitely the wrong word to describe The Grimleys (ITV). Also included in that list of inappropriate adjectives are: funny, well-acted, well-written and interesting. With Amanda Holden's accent wandering almost as far as von Daniken's ancient aliens, Craig Kelly still labouring under the assumption that odd intonation is the equivalent of acting, and the rest of the cast apparently operated by Gerry Anderson, The Grimleys is excruciating twaddle. Thank heavens Spaced is back soon.

Proving that with a little lateral thinking, religious programming need not be totally dull, Everyman (BBC1) continued its impressive run of late with Chained Women. Focusing on Agunots, Jewish women whose husbands won't grant them Jewish divorces or "gets", Everyman got to the heart of the matter (as Joan Bakewell might have said). It exposed the misogyny at the heart of Judaism through the sad stories of women like Doreen, who decided not to have children with her second husband since, not having a get from her first, any children by her new husband would be judged illegitimate and unable to fully celebrate their faith.

With women being blackmailed by intransigent husbands for gets, the words of Chief Rabbi Jonathan Sacks rang hollow when he pointed out that divorce could only be got by mutual consent. This simply wasn't the case, as Everyman recorded: a man could obtain a get, regardless of his wife's consent. It is little wonder that Erich von Daniken's new story of creation is so darn popular when the versions we've got are so archaic and alienating.

webTitle: Blizzards ravage Scotland and north

fields.headline: Blizzards ravage Scotland and north
fields.standfirst:
Weather's icy grip tightens as Tube strike cripples London

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of homes were left in freezing darkness yesterday as blizzards caused chaos in the north of England and Scotland, while in the south the most effective Tube strike in a decade created travel chaos for 3m London commuters.
fields.byline: Angelique Chrisafis, Kirsty Scott, Cynthia Koons  and Seumas Milne
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of homes were left in freezing darkness yesterday as blizzards caused chaos in the north of England and Scotland, while in the south the most effective Tube strike in a decade created travel chaos for 3m London commuters.

Around 20 inches of snow blanketed Northumberland and was quickly blown into impassible drifts by 40 mile an hour winds, cutting power supplies and forcing schools to close. On the A1 in Tyne and Wear, queues stretched five miles. Flights were cancelled at Leeds airport due to low cloud and Yorkshire drivers were advised not to leave the house.

John Barnett, control manager at Northern Electric and Gas, said 20,000 homes were left without power in Yorkshire and Northumberland after a build-up of ice snapped power conductors. Blizzards were so severe, engineers could not see to mend the lines and at least 120 homes were still without power last night.

The Environment Agency said several rivers in the north east were on flood warnings as snow began to thaw.

In Scotland, more than five inches of snow fell at Aberdeen and seven inches fell at Eskdalemuir in Dumfriesshire, leaving more than 4,000 households in darkness. At one point all power to the island of Arran off the west coast was cut, affecting 3,000 homes.

Questions were raised as to why utilities companies could not cope with weather conditions that had been widely forecast and which were described by the Met Office as "normal for this time of year".

A spokeswoman for Scottish Hydro Electric said: "The weather is so atrocious that even the most robust system has to work against gale force winds that can bring a line down. Branches have broken under the weight of snow and that has brought down the lines."

She said repair crews had been forced to stop work be cause of hazardous conditions. By last night, 140 homes were still waiting to be reconnected.

The east coast and northern isles of Scotland were particularly badly affected. In Shetland all schools were closed and public transport services cancelled. In Grampian, more than 100 schools refused to take children. Several main roads in Aberdeenshire and Tayside were blocked, and numerous minor roads were closed by snowdrifts.

Police advised motorists not to travel and Scotrail trains suffered delays because of points failures due to ice.

Near the Glen Shee ski resort workers had to dig a path through 20ft snow drifts on the A93, and in Fife ice blocked the northbound M90.

In County Durham, coastguards and road traffic control were on alert after two deaths from the snow and gales. On Sunday, a teenage boy was swept to his death as he walked along the North Sea coastline at the mouth of the Tees.

He was one of a group of three teenagers washed into icy water by force nine gales. A spokesman for the Tyne Tees coastguard said winds were so strong that the other teenagers were swept back to shore.

In Darlington, a 39-year-old man died when his car collided with a council snow plough and gritter on the A68.

The south was mostly spared the winter onslaught, but the walkout by more than 2,000 members of the train drivers' union Aslef, called over safety fears under the government's plans to part-privatise the underground, all but shut down London's Tube network. With only 40 out of the usual 476 trains in service, the disruption sharply increased traffic congestion and overcrowding on bus and rail services.

City of London police called in extra officers to patrol bus queues after scuffles broke out between stranded passengers.

London Underground, which was accused of provoking the strike by London mayor Ken Livingstone, agreed to meet both main rail unions this morning at the conciliation service, Acas, in an attempt to avoid the next two stoppages planned for Monday and Monday week.

webTitle: Artist's lily pond painting sold for £5.2m

fields.headline: Artist's lily pond painting sold for £5.2m
fields.trailText: A great late Monet, one of the views of the lily pond at his Giverney home which he painted obsessively in his last years, sold for £5,283,500 last night.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A great late Monet, one of the views of the lily pond at his Giverney home which he painted obsessively in his last years, sold for £5,283,500 last night.

The image of sun dappled tranquility was auctioned in just under four minutes, described by Sotheby's as "fairly frantic".

A very different painting, a brooding portrait of a fellow artist by Egon Schiele, went for £7,703,500, a record for the Viennese artist.

Although the auction room was packed, it was a sale only for the serious. Bidding for the Monet opened at £2.8m, and was a battle between two bidders, one dealer in the room and another bidding by telephone on behalf of an anonymous European collector: the picture went to the phone bidder.

The painting, Le Bassin aux Nympheas, was sold by a private collector who had owned it since 1961. It was one of Monet's last works, painted between 1917 and 1920, when he was nearly 80 and had failing eyesight. The large canvas, 39 by 78 inches, is dwarfed by some of the huge paintings of the lily pond, which the artist created in his garden specially in order to paint the effects of light on water.

The Egon Schiele, an early work from 1909 in jewel like colours, was a portrait of his friend and mentor, the painter Anton Peschka, who was to become his brother-in-law. The record price for a Schiele had been set only three months ago, also at Sotheby's, for a portrait of his art dealer which sold for £7,153,500. The painting sold last night went to an unnamed dealer.

webTitle: Leader: Bush's missile plan may explode in his face

fields.headline: Flawed defences
fields.standfirst:
Bush's missile plan may explode in his face

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Bush's missile plan may explode in his face.
fields.body:
The contradictions and paradoxes inherent in US missile defence plans are proliferating faster than the weapons of mass destruction the Americans seek to neutralise. Donald Rumsfeld says the Bush administration has a constitutional and moral duty to build new missile systems. But the American defence secretary, speaking in Munich at the weekend, did not elaborate on the morality (or wisdom) of a superpower tearing up arms control treaties and appearing to intimidate weaker nations with its advanced weaponry.

Mr Rumsfeld asks for European support and assures Russia and China that they are not under threat. But he does not say exactly what is proposed; will it be sea-based, land-based, space based or all three? Nor does he identify the source or scale of the supposedly urgent, emerging threat, other than vague mutterings about "outlaw regimes".

The national missile defence programme developed and then delayed by the Clinton administration is, in the Bush era, becoming something vastly more ambitious and (for public relations purposes) more inclusive: "allied missile defence" or even the grandiose "global missile defence" are the incoming, user-friendly monikers. But nobody in the Pentagon seems to have asked Britain, for example, what it thinks in principle of a missile shield. Therein lies another paradox: Mr Rumsfeld pledges to consult the allies while in the same breath vowing to press ahead come what may.

Much of the proposed technology, especially space weapons, is unproven and in any event, is no defence against one-off terrorist "suitcase" mini-devices. The project is becoming inextricably confused with existing theatre and tactical missile defence systems which, to give one potentially incendiary example, the Taiwanese would like to deploy against China. Nobody, not even the Americans, quite knows how all this will be paid for. Put all these considerations together and the dangerous confusions attending this ill-thought-out scheme are plain.

The political implications are if anything even more complex and disturbing. Russia has heard Washington's justifications yet still adamantly maintains that most variations of its plans would effectively destroy the keystone anti-ballistic missile treaty. China and India fear the US will provoke a new arms race, forcing them to expand their nuclear arsenals. Talks to reduce offensive strategic nuclear weapons and the effectiveness of international anti-proliferation mechanisms, such as the missile technology control regime, may be compromised. The US plans risk exacerbating tensions within Nato and alienating Germany. Clearly they may also widen the transatlantic divisions already exposed by the EU's rapid reaction force.

The government's response has so far been to play for time. It stresses that the US plans are far from finalised; that any deployment would take up to 10 years or more. Evidently, Labour does not want a row before the general election. But when the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, says missile defence is essentially a US debate, he deliberately ignores the fact that America's stated overall intention is clear - and it concerns us all now.

When the defence secretary, Geoffrey Hoon, says Britain should wait and see what the US decides, he looks like a pedestrian standing in the middle of the road waiting to be run over. When Tony Blair goes bridge-building in Washington later this month, he must not let his desire to nurture the "special relationship" lead to further obfuscation of this pressing issue. He should tell George Bush frankly that his missiles could blow up in his face.

webTitle: Comment: underground privatisation doesn't mean efficiency

fields.headline: One strike and we're out
fields.standfirst:
Bob Kiley points out the obvious: privatisation doesn't mean efficiency. Why can't Labour see it?

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Bob Kiley points out the obvious: privatisation doesn't mean efficiency. Why can't Labour see it?
fields.body:
It was unlikely, given the conditions created on the London underground yesterday by the one-day strike, that any passenger lucky enough to get on a train had room to open a newspaper. That was probably a good thing. News of the leaked Railtrack report on the safety of the overground network and the catalogue of Railtrack's "gross inefficiencies" and "negligence" make gloomy reading for passengers crammed into carriages with oxygen levels that feel as though they compare unfavourably with Mars.

Until last Friday, it seemed that the London underground was headed for the same chaos that privatisation has produced in the railway system. Now there is some hope that this grotesque situation might be avoided, but the game is far from over.

Last Friday, John Prescott agreed to hand over the negotiations that will determine the future of London Underground to Ken Livingstone's appointee as transport commissioner, Bob Kiley. The agreement was hailed as a breakthrough and it is certainly a significant step towards reason from a government allergic to Livingstone and all he represents. But it remains to be seen whether Kiley can devise a scheme acceptable to the contractors, Ken Livingstone, John Prescott and, most challenging of all, a Treasury that seems wedded to the mistakes of the past. Kiley will have to accomplish this formidable task against the clock.

Kiley's critique of the terms that the government had set for the initial private-public partnership plan was devastating. The scheme was set to follow the John Major manual on How To Privatise a Railway in all but name. It repeated the folly of separating the wheels from the track - three subterranean Railtracks would have been created; it did nothing to meet the government's aim of developing an integrated transport policy for the capital; the initial targets for service delivery were set to lower standards even further; and the structure of the contracts gave every incentive for the consortia to deliver a poor and expensive service and few levers that the transport authority could pull to ensure a cheap and efficient one.

In his first report to Ken Livingstone on the PPP proposal, Kiley observed, with admirable self-restraint, that it seemed to be based on the idea that privatisation automatically produced efficiency because the profit motive ensured that it did. Not so, he said. It is competition, not privatisation per se that produces efficiency.

There was, of course, no more element of competition in the PPP proposals for the London underground than there had been in the overground railway. Under the original PPP proposals, the contracts would hand over 30-year private monopolies on everything bar the actual operation of the trains and the staffing of the stations. It would have created a system under which, as Kiley put it, the profit motive dictated that contractors offer "the least expensive product or service at the highest price" - a prescription for private profit and public squalor.

Having created the monster, the government would hand it over to Ken Livingstone's transport authority to run. But that authority would have to try, as the railway companies are doing today, to run trains on a system over which it had no control beyond compensatory payments for disruption to services that could be blamed on the infrastructure. Just as in the railway system, such an arrangement risked becoming a disincentive to pre-emptive maintenance, precisely because maintenance disrupts services and would trigger penalties.

It might have been more reassuring had any party to the proposed agreement had a clear idea of what the London underground needed. But beyond the observation, available to passengers on a daily basis, that the system is in deep trouble, there was no inventory of the state of the physical structure, which should have been the starting point of any negotiations. It was, a recipe, Kiley concluded, for worse service at higher public cost.

There were two important concessions last Friday: Kiley, who has an admirable record in salvaging New York's and Boston's underground systems, will have the opportunity to begin negotiations again. The second concession springs from the first - it is fundamental to Kiley's approach that the management of the system remain unified; in other words, that there will be no Railtrack-operator divide. The challenge will be to come up with a scheme that satisfies the Treasury's demand for PPP with a degree of management control of the private operators' activities that Kiley will want.

That is a difficult circle to square. Even if he squares it to his own satisfaction, the prospective bidders - and the Treasury - will be hard to convince. The Treasury position appears to start from a rigid commitment to private finance and go from there to the running of the underground. Kiley, on the other hand, begins with how to achieve the best management of the underground and displays an open mind on how to fund it. As a mere passenger, I know which approach I prefer.

In New York, Kiley largely financed the rescue of the subway system through bonds. Last week, the admirable French railway system, which is most things the British railway system is not - efficient clean, reliable, rapid and reasonably priced - went to the London bond market to raise finance for the next phase of its high speed network. Despite this offence to Treasury orthodoxy, the sun did not freeze in the heavens and Paris still seems to be standing.

The privatisation of the British rail network took one of the most cost-efficient rail networks in the world (although one of the worst funded in Europe) and turned it into a passenger's nightmare. It created a complicated system that is perfect for passing the buck and a nightmare to run. It has cost money and lives. Compared to that, issuing bonds to finance a system that remains in public ownership with democratic accountability seems a rather lesser evil.

Unlike his boss, Kiley is not a man with a track record of populism to whom the government could attribute political motives. He is an expert from an entrepreneurial culture of the kind that the Treasury likes, who is putting forward the modest proposition that a capital city depends on its public infrastructure and that it should be financed in the most cost-efficient way.

Long before Kiley got involved, the companies that were interested in the London Underground PPP warned the government that the price they were willing to pay would come down sharply if Livingstone became mayor. The consortia seemed well able to put a price on the conflict between a politician who wants to win popularity by delivering a better service and their own desire to benefit from the huge contracts.

Labour had hoped, of course, that this would be a done deal long before the election was called. There are a lot of votes to lose in the part-privatisation of the underground. We shall soon know whether Kiley can square the circle, using PPP, but there could be another - perhaps we could call it a third - way. If the benefits of PPP are so great, why not test them against a real alternative? Let Kiley devise a bid for London Underground to run itself, financed with public borrowing and let us compare it with the PPP proposals. And let the judgment be made on the basis of cost and quality of service, not on ideology.

webTitle: Key witnesses in Russell case were police informants, appeal court told

fields.headline: Key witnesses in Russell case were police informants, appeal court told
fields.trailText: Michael Stone, the man found guilty in 1998 of the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan, yesterday began his court of appeal bid to plead his innocence.
fields.body:
Michael Stone, the man found guilty in 1998 of the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan, and the attempted murder of her other daughter Josie, yesterday began his court of appeal bid to plead his innocence.

The 40-year-old only replied to his name as appeal court judge Lord Justice Kennedy, sitting with Mr Justice Maurice Kay and Mrs Justice Hallett, began listening to the evidence.

They were told that one of the key witnesses in the original trial was a perjurer and may even have been a police informant. Stone's counsel, William Clegg QC, said that Barry Thompson had now changed his story. "What he says is completely contrary to the evidence he gave at the trial. He now says Stone made no confession of any kind to him and that his evidence at Maidstone was untruthful," he said. "Secondly he says that he and perhaps he and Daley [another key witness] were both, at the material time, police informants."

Stone, who has spent much of his life in prisons and institutions and has had addictions to heroin and alcohol, has steadfastly denied any involvement in the killings. At his original trial, Mr Clegg said Stone had been "fitted up by a bunch of criminals".

In the lead up to his three-week trial at Maidstone crown court, police were aware that their evidence - mainly based on evidence alleged to have been given to convicted criminals - might not be strong enough. Other grounds in the appeal include issues relating to DNA and non-disclosure of evidence.

Stone was given three life sentences for the murders of Lin Russell and Megan, 6, and the attempted murder of Josie, then 9, near their home at Chillenden, Kent. They were tied up and beaten with a hammer in a ferocious 15-minute attack as they made their way home through cornfields. The family dog was also killed.

Before the appeal began, Stone's sister, Barbara, 38, said: "Michael has always maintained his innocence. We have waited a long time to be able to prove to the courts that this is so. We are very hopeful of the convictions being quashed and that the British legal system proves to be just."

The full opening of the appeal was delayed while the court dealt with moves on Stone's behalf relating to taped telephone conversations between a national newspaper journalist and the witness Barry Thompson.

After the legal argument, the judges ordered that the tapes, transcript and manuscript notes should be disclosed to the defence.

Mr Clegg is expected to begin opening the case proper this morning.

webTitle: 'Death threats' by fan of pop star

fields.headline: 'Death threats' by fan of pop star
fields.trailText: A fan terrorised the teenage pop star Billie Piper by repeatedly threatening to shoot, decapitate and set fire to the singer and her parents, Blackfriars crown court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A fan terrorised the teenage pop star Billie Piper by repeatedly threatening to shoot, decapitate and set fire to the singer and her parents, Blackfriars crown court heard yesterday.

Juliette Peters, 32, from Canning Town, east London, made the threats because she thought the performer had given her a "dirty look" during the recording of a TV show, the jury was told.

It heard that in a letter to Miss Piper's fan club and in messages on the answering machine of her record label, Innocent, Peters called the singer a "stuck-up little shithead" and threatened: "Billie Piper's head needs cutting off... she needs her body to be set on fire."

In one call, Peters allegedly said: "She needs cutting up into little pieces with her head in the north of England and her body in the south."

Other messages, played to the court, included threats to shoot Miss Piper during her next live performance and to send a letter bomb to her fan club and record company, as well as insults directed at her boyfriend at the time, Ritchie Neville of the group Five.

"She needs... petrol poured all over her and just burnt," said another call. "I'll get a gun and shoot her parents' heads off."

Paul Piper, the singer's father, told the court he had been frightened and disgusted by the warnings, and "knocked for six" by one call, which included the words, "Is that all right, Charlie?" - a reference, he believed, to his son aged 10.

Mark Aldred, prosecuting, said the calls came after Peters joined the audience of Channel 5's Pepsi Chart Show, of which Miss Piper was a presenter.

In her letter to the fan club, Peters had written: "Why did you give me such a sly, dirty look out of the corner of your eye?...you are a stuck-up, snooty, bitchy, arrogant spoilt brat."

Peters denies making five threats to kill the singer and four to kill her parents between August 14 and 25 last year.

The case continues today.

webTitle: Poverty pledge fails to deliver

fields.headline: Poverty pledge fails to deliver
fields.trailText: World leaders will not meet their pledge to cut global poverty by half by 2015, because the necessary aid has been diverted from those who need it most, the UN said yesterday.
fields.body:
World leaders will not meet their pledge to cut global poverty by half by 2015, because the necessary aid has been diverted from those who need it most, the UN said yesterday.

Poor people - classified as those living on less than $1 a day - still number 1.2bn, most of them rural dwellers.

At the millennium summit last year 191 countries made the pledge, but only 10m people a year are being helped to escape poverty, compared with the 30m required to meet the target, the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) said.

This is because aid has switched to the big cities in developing countries from the rural areas where 75% of the poor live.

Poverty levels fell dramatically between 1970 and 1990, but the reduction in the countryside has stalled, the IFAD's report, published in New York yesterday, says.

Land reform was needed to create small family farms with access to markets, it said, because this increased up to five times the amount of food produced and the amount of employment.

Water distribution was also a problem, increasing volumes being diverted to cities.

webTitle: Online betting enters the age of aquariums

fields.headline: Online betting enters the age of aquariums
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Plaice your bets now - bookies William Hill are to take bets on goldfish racing on the internet.
fields.body:
Plaice your bets now - bookies William Hill are to take bets on goldfish racing on the internet.

Six fish of different colours will compete in each race. They will line up at one end of a tank, behind a barrier to prevent flying starts, and then swim around the tank until one slips under a bridge at the bottom and becomes the winner.

William Hill hopes to have the first of its fish stable under starter's orders by April 7, Grand National day. A spokesman, Graham Sharpe, said: "It's not a joke. All you need is a spacious tank, a few fish and a few cameras and you're away.

"We will be using fish like the chocolate oranda with red pom-poms, the black and white lion head and the brown telescope eye. We don't want to be accused of cruelty by painting numbers on them.

"The only danger is that it might take them hours to complete the race. We will experiment with different-sized tanks and different-coloured bridges, and we will be taking advice from relevant goldfish experts.

"The goldfish won't realise there are lots of people watching them, so it won't be stressful for them."

In the first race the contestants will all start with the same odds, 5-1; later a form guide and differing odds will be established. But goldfish have notoriously short memories, which could throw the form book out of the window.

And victorious fish may get to bask in their glory in a luxury "winner's bowl".

They will line up at one end of a tank, behind a barrier to prevent flying starts, and then swim around the tank until one slips under a bridge at the bottom and becomes the winner. William Hill hopes to have the first of its fish stable under starter's orders by April 7, Grand National day. A spokesman, Graham Sharpe, said: "It's not a joke. All you need is a spacious tank, a few fish and a few cameras and you're away. "We will be using fish like the chocolate oranda with red pom-poms, the black and white lion head and the brown telescope eye. We don't want to be accused of cruelty by painting numbers on them. "The only danger is that it might take them hours to complete the race. We will experiment with different-sized tanks and different-coloured bridges, and we will be taking advice from relevant goldfish experts. "The goldfish won't realise there are lots of people watching them, so it won't be stressful for them." In the first race the contestants will all start with the same odds, 5-1; later a form guide and differing odds will be established. But goldfish have notoriously short memories, which could throw the form book out of the window. And victorious fish may get to bask in their glory in a luxury "winner's bowl". Press Association

webTitle: Comment:  Labour needs to clean up its image

fields.headline: That whiff of sleaze just won't wash away
fields.standfirst:
Labour needs to clean up its image and Keith Vaz might have to go

Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Labour needs to clean up its image and Keith Vaz might have to go.
fields.body:
There was an unusual photo session at Labour party headquarters last week. One after another, members of the party staff lined up to have their pictures taken alongside the prime minister, all of them no doubt smiling proudly for posterity and their mothers' mantelpieces. Progress towards a general election on May 3 is proceeding almost exactly according to schedule at Millbank Tower and, as it happens, they are getting the souvenirs organised early this time round.

The photo shoot was probably Peter Mandelson's idea. It is the sort of thing he would have planned. He would have seen it as part of the programme to psych up the party staff for the election campaign over which he was, until so recently, in almost complete control. Since the campaign team was put in place last summer, there has been a slow and steady turn of the ratchet to prepare them all for what lies ahead. Now the sense of excited expectancy has already heightened, the tempo is quickening, the number of meetings is increasing and people keep looking at their watches to convey the message that every minute matters.

But it is also as if, isolated as they are, they haven't noticed what is going on in the world and on the front pages of the tabloid newspapers. The eerie reality is that the political turbulence within the government has apparently done little to disrupt this atmosphere. It doesn't even seem to matter much to the "new" Labour apparatchik that the man who was in charge of the campaign to which they are so single-mindedly committed is no longer there. It is one of the dubious, unremarked successes of Tony Blair's new model Labour party that he and his lieutenants have managed to depoliticise the party's staff.

In the past few days, however, the gulf between an efficient party machine and a government in trouble has become only too evident. While the party has been busy preparing for an election that it looks as if it cannot lose, the parliamentary press has been engaged with a political story that could change everything.

In all of this, Mandelson's own role is very odd. The one person who knows how individual politicians should respond to any given crisis has been shown to be supremely incompetent at handling one that involves his own career. Blair is said to have lamented this fact, saying that "what Peter needs is a Peter" - a comment which should rank alongside Thatcher's tribute to the late Lord Whitelaw that "every prime minister needs a Willie". A recognition of the problem does not provide a solution, however.

Some of Mandelson's real friends - a notoriously limited number - have advised the former Northern Ireland Secretary to lower his profile in the wake of his resignation. He has nevertheless appeared determined to do exactly the opposite. It seems as if not a day has gone by without another newspaper claiming an exclusive insight into the man's thought processes, or boasting of a late-night phone call from abroad. All of them have offered increasingly irrelevant analyses of the motivation for a single telephone call to the home office minister, Mike O'Brien, which may or may not have taken place and about which nobody much cares any more anyway.

It seems pitifully evident that a man whose political career was spent attempting to manipulate the newspapers is unable to resist the temptation of trying to continue to do so, despite the fact that every interview he gives, every late-night phone call he makes to yet another journalist is destined to diminish further his standing and that of the government he still purports to serve.

And to what end? Even the man himself, even in his current state, knows that he cannot hope to be restored to the government in any circumstance. He may have a point about being forced to resign as a matter of political expediency which, untypically, did not put the career of Peter Mandelson first - but then that's politics.

He has two further problems. He does not have a political base, either inside parliament or outside it, something which weakens his political standing the moment he is out of office, and at a personal level he is also a curiously vulnerable individual. "There's a flaw in his character," one senior party figure murmured yesterday, unconsciously echoing the now infamous, anonymous description of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, as being "psychologically flawed".

According to this theory, none of Mr Mandelson's current problems need have occurred if he had handled the situation better. And he need not make a difficult situation worse for the government if, as he suggested in his interview in yesterday's Guardian, he confines himself to a low-profile discussion via his lawyers with the inquiry set up into the circumstances of his resignation and the passport applications of the Hinduja brothers.

All might then be well, but for what Mr Mandelson's resignation has brought in its wake. There are two aspects to this. One is specific and relates to the case of his troubled former ministerial colleague, Keith Vaz, whose existing difficulties were dragged into the light of closer public scrutiny by the connecting theme of his friends, the Hindujas. His financial and political affairs have since been subject to an apparently endless series of alarming allegations. The other aspect is the more insidious problem of the attachment of that nasty word "sleaze" to the Labour party.

The opinion polls of the past week have demonstrated that there is still a comfortable lead for Labour, but that the perception of the party has changed. The squeaky-clean image has gone. It may well be gone for good. But it is still a problem that needs serious attention and quickly.

This is what seems to lie behind the suggestion that Mr Vaz, the minister for Europe, has been told to justify himself - or just go. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and the prime minister's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, have both been strident in their defence of Mr Vaz in the past couple of days but that may well not have been enough.

There was a sense at Westminster yesterday that there were too many problems here, that the financial and business complications produced by Mr Vaz amounted to a political embarrassment that was unlikely to go away and that the best thing would be if he were to resign as quickly as possible before anything worse was revealed. The suggestion that Mr Vaz was the subject of a racist vendetta or, even more improbably, the target of Euro-sceptics is not taken seriously.

The committee on standards which is considering a report from the parliamentary commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, on circumstances in Mr Vaz's constituency of Leicester East is due to meet today. That could provide an answer about what Mr Vaz should do next. It might also have an impact on public opinion - if not on the uncritical Labour party staff.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
A dramatic development shocks the Turncoat of Turncoats betting. Peter Hain becomes clear favourite following a revelation in Glasgow MP George Galloway's column on www.orientmagazine.co.uk. This concerns North Korea, a country Britain is so keen to pal up with following its rapprochement with the US, that the Foreign Office recently badgered George into setting up meetings with Korean government friends (of which more below). George ends with news of a newly ex-FO minister. "I now have the 'killer fact' which I believe will secure the [Turncoat] prize for the hapless Hain," he writes. "Mr Hain, 20 years ago, I can exclusively reveal, while still president of the Young Liberals, was an official sponsor of the British Campaign in Solidarity with People's Korea." Good God. From there, almost off the end of the leftwing spectrum to denying Iraqi children cancer drugs ... an astonishing volte-face which propels Peter to 11-8 clear favourite, with Bomber Short and Gus MacDonald out to 4-1 and Robin Cook at 11-2. A full show of betting, and the names of the last two contenders, follows shortly.

As for those recent meetings with North Korean officials, everyone George invited (two FO ministers included) was delighted to talk to the visitors. Well, not quite everyone. Explaining that it would be "quite inappropriate for him to meet with representatives of a communist party", a certain Nick Seigler declined the invitation. As secretary of Labour's international department, I suppose it's unfair to expect him to follow these things closely enough to know that we now want to be friends with North Korea. Still, perhaps someone might fill him in before he makes such an arse of himself again.

There is no news from the kangaroo court of Hinduja whitewash man Sir Anthony "Skippy" Hammond, who has returned to the Home Office, where he worked for 24 years, to size up Mandy Mandelson in a fiercely independent inquiry already pre-empted by his host, the home secretary, and his accusation that Mandy lied. Natural justice at its perfidious Albion best. Old Skippy came over all Greta Garbo at the weekend, saying that all he wants is to be left alone to get on with the job. The job? What, you mean signing whatever Jack, Ali and Mr T put in front of you? Mind you, nothing wrong with a bit of a rest. Put another bar on the fire, help yourself to tea and biscuits (it's Hob-Nobs at the Home Office on Tuesdays), get out the Times crossword. You take it easy, Skippy. You're home now, son.

There is also no news, due to a mixture of the tube strike and sheer indolence, of the fuse crisis at the Times, where person or persons unnamed have been removing fuses from various plugs and even snipping those plugs off the microwave oven. We hope to have further discussions on the matter tomorrow with managing editor George Brock, a living example to us all that it is possible to go about one's business while wearing a tank top and without any semblance of pomposity.

A brief word of acknowledgment to two recent correspondents. To the west London estate agent who sent the "Dear Homeowner" letter that began "This is NOT a circular", you're very kind. Sincere thanks also to Adrian Steele. "I'm sure you will agree," Adrian's missive begins, "that it's the most natural thing in the world to ..." But what can it be? A bodily function? Falling in love? Being born or dying? What, man, what? " ... it's the most natural thing in the world to combine the prestige and status of a Platinum card with some of the lowest rates around." Of course, of course. Well done, MBNA Platinum Plus credit card, for that!

Would the general manager of Rybridge Audi, an "approved" Audi dealership in Stoke-on-Trent, please contact the Diary at once.

webTitle: Ford and GM invest £440m in regions

fields.headline: Ford and GM invest £440m in regions
fields.standfirst:
Hard hit Ellesmere Port and Bridgend win vote of confidence

Britain's car industry
fields.trailText: Hard hit Ellesmere Port and Bridgend win vote of confidence.
fields.body:
The world's two leading car groups, General Motors and Ford, yesterday delivered a much-needed vote of confidence in Britain by committing themselves to £440m investment in plants at Ellesmere Port and Bridgend.

Vauxhall, GM's British arm, which is ending car production at Luton next year with the loss of around 2,000 jobs, said it would invest £200m to build the new Vectra model on Merseyside, guaranteeing 1,200 existing jobs.

Ford, which is ending car assembly at its main Dagenham plant next year, is to put £220m into new engine facilities at Bridgend, south Wales. The move will create an extra 600 jobs in a region reeling from more than 3,000 job losses at the steel group Corus and hundreds more at smaller industrial companies.

Ford's investment has been sweetened by a grant of around £16m from the Welsh assembly whose offer of about £20m in financial aid to keep the bulk of the Llanwern steel works open was spurned by Corus last week.

Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, said the investment decisions were a vote of confidence in Britain and its workforce and showed there were underlying strengths in the country's manufacturing base.

Ford is to raise output at Bridgend by a third to 200,000 units a year by building new Durvec V6 and V8 petrol engines, primarily for the new small Jaguar being produced at Halewood, near Liverpool.

Ian McAllister, Ford UK chairman and managing director, said the grant - which is still to be approved by the European commission - had been an important factor but the Bridgend plant's "world-class" standards of efficiency and productivity had been determinant.

Rhodri Morgan, the Welsh assembly's first minister, said Ford's decision to expand Bridgend was an object lesson to Corus on how to run a business. Ford, he said, had shifted production from Cleveland, Ohio, to Wales but had initially given the American autoworkers' union 90 days to come up with counter-proposals.

"The American unions, which are losing jobs, knew they had an uphill struggle as the engine is destined for Halewood but understand they have had a fair play, compared with that outrageous decision of Corus," he said.

Mr McAllister made it plain that the investment was for the long term and was based on the assumption that Britain would "at some time" be a member of the euro zone.

Union leaders claimed that Vauxhall had timed its announcement to influence the company-wide ballot for industrial action to halt the closure of its Luton plant. The ballot result is due to be announced on Friday.

Tony Woodley, chief motor industry negotiator for the T&G, said the announcement was also timed to have an effect on the growing political support for the Luton workers.

"They [GM] are closing a British plant just to maximise and utilise capacity elsewhere," he said. "They are robbing product from Britain and moving it to other plants in Europe."

Capacity at Ellesmere Port is being increased from 166,000 to 180,000 cars a year. It will make both the current Astra and the new Vectra on the same production line, although main European production of both models will be at GM plants in Germany and Belgium.

webTitle: Marcel Berlins: Instant ministerial promises

fields.headline: Instant ministerial promises
fields.standfirst: After Alder Hey, will hospital officials who fail to give enough information really go to prison?
fields.trailText: After Alder Hey, will hospital officials who fail to give enough information really go to prison?
fields.body:
We've had yet another of those instant ministerial promises to create a wonderful new crime, this time in response to the Alder Hey inquiry. Like all such undertakings reacting to a headline-making scandal (the last was the babies for sale on the internet affair), not much thought has been given to whether or not it could work in practice. Following the Alder Hey report, health secretary Alan Milburn said the new law would ensure that no organs or tissues would be removed without the informed consent of close relatives. Fair enough. But he then said there would be criminal sanctions if such informed consent was not obtained. Does he really envisage that a doctor or hospital official who doesn't provide enough detailed information will be hauled up before the courts and possibly be sent to prison? Are we going to have incessant legal arguments between a doctor in the dock saying he did sufficiently inform and the prosecution saying he didn't? If the doctor misses out a bit of the body in giving relatives a check-list of what's to be removed, can we expect an arrest? I can't see how else to interpret the threat of criminal sanctions.

The House of Lords is soon to rule on the validity under the Human Rights Act of the new law protecting women complainants in rape trials from being asked about their sex lives. I'm not arguing the merits of the issue here, but I wish to point out the following. The judge in the original trial (which has been postponed until the human-rights issue is decided) was a man. The three judges of the appeal court which decided the appeal last month were all men. The five law lords who will finally decide the issue will all be men, because there are no women in the highest court in the land. That means nine men and no women will have been involved in deciding a crucial point which deals fundamentally with a woman's consent to sexual intercourse with a man with whom she'd previously had sex - an issue raising aspects of female psychology not necessarily best understood by a posse of men.

This is the question obsessing the British public - can Peter Mandelson sue the government under the Human Rights Act? webTitle: Surgical skills have their day in court

fields.headline: Surgical skills have their day in court
fields.standfirst: Why would someone qualified in medicine want a different job?  Anita Chaudhuri talks to the doctors who have hung up their stethoscopes and retrained as lawyers
fields.trailText: Why would someone qualified in medicine want a different job?  Anita Chaudhuri talks to the doctors who have hung up their stethoscopes and retrained as lawyers
fields.body:
Let's face it, doctors and lawyers have never enjoyed the most cordial of relationships, particularly in the current post-Shipman, post-Alder Hey climate of mistrust. Doctors are fond of telling the joke about a lawyer who is hoping to win a particularly gruesome medical negligence case. Clutching at straws, the lawyer cross-examines the doctor who signed the death certificate. "Why didn't you make any attempt to revive the patient?" The doctor explains that it had been too late. "Aha, so then the patient might have been alive How do you know he wasn't?" "Well," replies the doctor, "his brain was already in a jar, but I suppose the rest of him could still have gone out and practised law."

Against this backdrop, it is all the more surprising to learn that the legal profession is receiving an unlikely influx of new recruits - disillusioned doctors seeking a more rewarding job. Hilary Barsey, 34, is one. She qualified as a doctor but worked for just a year before deciding to study for the CPE examinations - the conversion course for non-law graduates - and then taking the one-year solicitors' training course.

She says, "It wasn't that I hated being a doctor, I didn't. But London medical schools are very narrow places. I found I was spending all my time with other medics, and the actual job involved going through the same boring procedures over and over. I had always been interested in medical ethics, and I could see that the legal profession was beginning to impact on medicine to a far greater degree."

Barsey now works for Field Fisher Waterhouse, a City firm where she specialises in acting for patients who are suing their doctors. "I use my medical knowledge as a matter of routine. It's very helpful in initial case analysis. As a doctor, I have an immediate grasp of surgical procedures and areas where things can go wrong. I know if a patient is telling me details which sound out of the ordinary, and I'm also better placed to ask difficult questions when the medical specialists are brought into a case."

Not all Barsey's former colleagues in the medical profession support her change of career. "Some have commented about my joining the enemy and going off and suing doctors. If I win a big settlement for a client, there are always some doctors I know who will say 'Oh, bang goes our new incubator', but for the most part it's just light-hearted banter."

To some extent, the two professions are not dissimilar. Both thrive on high levels of adrenalin and drama, surely the reason why they have provided such rich material for TV shows. But in other regards, law seems at odds with the traditional altruistic calling of the professional healer.

Barsey sees things in common. "I work very closely with distressed clients, not so far removed from being a doctor. There's the same satisfaction involved of having made a real difference to someone's life, too. If a family has a brain-damaged child, then it's vitally important that they get the best possible settlement - that's really going to make a difference to them, and as their solicitor I do make a considerable emo tional investment on their behalf."

So what does it feel like to be on the other side of the fence; does she experience the occasional pang of guilt? "Well I do feel a bit sorry for doctors these days. They never used to be the subject of criticism, it simply wasn't done."

Like Barsey, Simon Joyston-Bechal, 37, worked as a doctor for only a year after qualifying. He now works at the big City firm Clifford Chance, where his specialist areas are pharmaceuticals and product liability. "I loved studying medicine, but I did not enjoy working as a doctor," he confides. "When I told my friends at the hospital what I was thinking of doing, none of them was the least bit surprised. Many said they might do the same thing.

"Those who had had a hard slog to get through medical school couldn't understand why I would want to go through all that [studying] again. But I never had a problem with the exams, the problem was with the work.

"I've met several ex-doctors in the law profession. It's worth pointing out that we're not people who couldn't cope with the stress of being a junior doctor and so had to run away and do something else. Rather, we're people who have had the confidence to see that there is more to life than medicine. It takes a considerable amount of independence of thought to walk away from being a doctor, it's a very defining career."

He claims that he works just as hard now as he did as a doctor, although he doesn't have to be on call, but that the working environment is much better: "Medicine is a hostile professional environment; everyone has to make such an effort being nice to the patients that they tend to take their aggression out on their colleagues."

However, he does concede that a medical training can be ideal for becoming a lawyer. "Many of the skills required are the same, such as dealing with distressed people, and also absorbing large amounts of complex information. Medicine gives a good grounding for court; if you've gone on ward rounds with the professor picking apart your words in front of everyone, then you can survive going to trial. When winning or losing a case hangs in the balance, that's stressful, but if you've faced life-and- death situations every day then it puts things into perspective."

For some, the move to law is more empowering than battling with the vagaries of human illness. Ranald Davidson trained as a doctor in Edinburgh and worked as a doctor for a short time before deciding to become a barrister. Now 32, he specialises in medical negligence cases at 3 Serjeants' Inn in London.

"I think part of the excitement about law is that it's adversarial, there really is an element of you against them," he says. "You're pitting your wits against an opponent, which gives a tremendous adrenalin rush. With medicine the adversary is not another barrister or another team, but nature, which is like fighting against fate.

"From the moment you leave medical school you're on a conveyor belt. I realised that I was going to be very unhappy doing the job for the rest of my life so I decided to get out while I was still young enough to take a risk. Now I look at former colleagues who might be tempted to do what I've done, but now they've got children and mortgages the decision will be more difficult."

Some might assume that his move to the Bar was motivated by money, but Davidson laughs at this. "There is this illusion that barristers make fortunes. The reality is that I had to start from scratch and work my way up the ladder again - I've only just about caught up with my colleagues in the medical profession. Obviously longer-term there is money to be made, but consultants who take on private patients can make just as much."

Not all those doctors becoming lawyers are necessarily using their previous backgrounds as a specialism. Patrick Beale, 34, works in the commercial disputes division of Richards Butler. Shortly after qualifying in London, he decided he had had enough. "Something more commercial had always interested me. In the NHS I felt that I wasn't valued by anyone and I didn't like changing jobs every six months during training. You don't get to build up a rapport with a team. So I chose law, but I didn't want to be be pigeonholed by immediately going into medical law."

He finds he still uses his medical training, even in the world of corporate litigation. "You're often dealing with people who find themselves in very stressful situations - if a company director loses a case, for example, it could mean people's jobs are on the line. In medicine I was always very conscious of having to give explanations in lay terms, demystify the jargon. That's also certainly true of being a lawyer."

Beale says he hasn't noticed much shift in his public status since making the job change. "Being a lawyer used to have certain connotations, but you only really notice that when you go to America."

Is being a lawyer easier than being a junior doctor?

"I wouldn't say so. Sometimes I might be in the office from eight in the morning till 10 at night, but at least I go back to my own home and my own bed as opposed to sleeping in hospital."

webTitle: Bertelsmann paves way to flotation

fields.headline: Bertelsmann paves way to flotation
fields.standfirst: RTL share swap lets outsider into family-owned media empire
fields.trailText: Bertelsmann, one of Europe's largest media groups, yesterday laid the foundations for a stock market flotation with a deal to substantially increase its control over television and radio business RTL.
fields.body:
Bertelsmann, one of Europe's largest media groups, yesterday laid the foundations for a stock market flotation with a deal to substantially increase its control over television and radio business RTL.

The family-owned German company agreed to swap 25% of its shares for the 30% in RTL owned by a Belgian investment house, Groupe Bruxelles Lambert. The agreement gives Bertelsmann 67% of RTL, which holds most of Channel 5 in Britain and another 21 TV stations and 18 radio outlets across Europe.

GBL becomes the largest outside shareholder in Bertelsmann but has the right to put all or part of its stake on the stock market in three or four years' time. Bertelsmann said it was acting "to adapt to changing times".

Thomas Middelhoff, Bertelsmann's chief executive, described the deal as a landmark for the company which has assets ranging from Random House publishing to the BMG music business and magazine division Gruner & Jahr.

"From a strategic and a historic point of view, this is a significant step that will lastingly shape the company's future," Mr Middelhoff said.

RTL was formed last year from the merger of CLT-Ufa and the television interests of Pearson, which holds 22% of the group.

The deal also facilitates the sale of further shares in RTL to lift the free float from 11% to the 15% necessary to get the business into the FTSE 100. Bertelsmann tends to seek majority stakes in its interests and was unlikely to make any shares available while it still had only 37% of RTL.

Marjorie Scardino, Pearson chief executive, welcomed the deal. "It simplifies the shareholding structure of RTL and further strengthens our working relationship with Bertelsmann."

The agreement is understood to have been valued at around €10bn which means Bertelsmann paid a 100% premium for the stake. RTL, which has its shares quoted in euros on the London exchange, has a market capitalisation of €14bn (£9bn), implying that the stake was worth less than €5bn.

Insiders said Bertelsmann viewed RTL as undervalued by the market.

Shares in RTL, which is listed in London, Brussels and Luxembourg, yesterday climbed €7 to €100. Pearson shares were marked up 9p to £16.09.

Analysts have long expected Bertelsmann to float. The company has become exposed to the stock market through the formation of RTL last year and is in discussions about the merger of BMG with EMI. "The flotation is not a big surprise," said one media analyst.

webTitle: PizzaExpress rockets up the revenue menu

fields.headline: PizzaExpress rockets up the revenue menu
fields.trailText: A spicing up of the already popular PizzaExpress menu has translated into a 10% increase in like for like sales at the company's 256 restaurants in Britain.
fields.body:
A spicing up of the already popular PizzaExpress menu has translated into a 10% increase in like for like sales at the company's 256 restaurants in Britain.

The rocket and parmesan Soho Pizza and the spiced beef and green pepper-topped Sloppy Giuseppe were among the dishes to have helped raise the average diner's spend to £11.60 - an increase of 7%, chief executive Ian Eldridge said yesterday.

The strong performance at established restaurants was the driving force behind increased profits of £19.5m for the six months to January - 30% higher than the previous year and slightly ahead of analysts' expectations.

Other factors included holding down prices for a period, success in attracting new customers and increasing regular client numbers. Turnover for the same period rose 28% to £89.5m, and average sales per restaurant hit a record high, with half the strongest performances coming from out-of-town PizzaExpresses.

Mr Eldridge said there were still plenty of opportunities to develop PizzaExpress outlets - and that in fact Britain could support twice the number trading today.

Buoyed by the strong results, he said he would consider stepping up the pace of the PizzaExpress roll-out, which has produced more than 120 new company-owned restaurants over the last four years.

Finance director Glen Tomlinson said the company, which pitches itself between the fast food and formal dining markets, would continue to invest in its international operation - particularly in France, Spain and Japan - but would not let this swallow up profits from the UK business.

"It's a question of balance," he said. "And, in our international business, profits from our franchised restaurants will continue to be used to support our [loss-making] company-owned restaurants."

This will reassure PizzaExpress investors in the wake of reports that the company hoped to rapidly replicate the scale of its British business in other European countries.

PizzaExpress's Cafe Pasta chain of 13 restaurants showed a profit for the first time on turnover of £3.4m.

Yesterday's results also revealed £6.3m in cash on the balance sheet that Mr Eldridge said could be spent on acquisitions if the right opportunity arose.

Shares in PizzaExpress closed down 5p at 767.5p.

webTitle: Shoppers shun big ticket items

fields.headline: Shoppers shun big ticket items
fields.trailText: Retailers had a disappointing month in January, according to figures released yesterday, prompting calls by the sector for the Bank of England to cut interest rates this week.
fields.body:
Retailers had a disappointing month in January, according to figures released yesterday, prompting calls by the sector for the Bank of England to cut interest rates this week.

Sales slowed sharply over the month according to the latest snapshot from the British Retail Consortium. Like-for-like sales rose 2.9% in the 12 months to January, compared to a 3.4% rise in December.

"The latest figures serve to further confirm the downtrend in growth," said Bridget Rosewell, the BRC's chief economic adviser. "The slowdown in the economy is now well established and can only be exacerbated by that in the US."

Big-ticket items were particularly hard hit, according to the BRC. "A cut in interest rates is needed to stimulate demand and reverse this worrying trend," said Bill Moyes, director general of the BRC.

Despite the retail slowdown, the service sector as a whole grew robustly in January, according to separate figures released yesterday by the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.

The institute's activity index fell slightly to 57.1 from 57.6 in December but still stands well above the threshold of 50 which indicates an expansion.

"Panel member companies have reported continuous growth of demand for their services for almost two years now as generally buoyant economic conditions have enabled the majority of firms to win new business," the report said.

Trade union leaders are calling on the chancellor to spend some of his estimated £3bn budget surplus on halting job losses in manufacturing.

webTitle: Labour two-faced on Post Office, claims Brussels

fields.headline: Labour two-faced on Post Office, claims Brussels
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The European commission, attacked the government yesterday, questioning its commitment to open up the postal sector to competition and abolish the Post Office's monopoly.
fields.body:
The European commission, attacked the government yesterday, questioning its commitment to open up the postal sector to competition and abolish the Post Office's monopoly.

Frits Bolkestein, the EU commissioner for the internal market, in a speech in London, claimed that the government said one thing in public but did the opposite when it came to negotiating behind closed doors.

The EC wants the Post Office and its European counterparts to lose their monopoly in 2003 on the delivery of all letters weighing more than 50 grams.

It has run into opposition from the European parliament and countries such as Britain which favour a more gradual liberalisation.

Mr Bolkestein, increasingly frustrated at the pace of progress, yesterday cited a recent newspaper interview in which Gordon Brown stated that postal services were an area where the EU should "keep up pressure for reform".

"But, when the commission's proposal for what amounted to not more than a partial opening of the postal markets was discussed in the council of ministers recently, the UK offered little support," the Dutchman told an audience at Mansion House last night. "It was a disappointment to me not to find the UK taking the commission's side."

In a warning to the government not to go its own way on the issue when Graham Corbett, chairman of the UK Postal Services Commission, delivers his recommendations for reform this summer, Mr Bolkestein demanded EU-wide rules for the sector.

"I am aware of the importance the UK government attaches to the views of Mr Corbett, who is due to report shortly on the issue of liberalisation of postal services. I am interested in what Mr Corbett has to say but there cannot be one rule for the UK and another for the rest of the EU."

In private, EU officials claim that Tony Blair is reluctant to act on the matter before the general election for fear of alienating the postal unions. The unions say that the EC's proposals would result in up to 50,000 job losses while the Post Office has warned that it would lose £400m a year in revenues and would no longer be able to provide a nationwide service.

A spokesman last night argued that the government was still committed to liberalisation but "it has to take into account the different circumstances in different countries".

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: S&N beats a flat beer market
fields.body:
S&N beats a flat beer market

Increased sales of Foster's and John Smith's contributed to a strong Christmas for Scottish & Newcastle, which reported a 1.6% rise in beer sales despite a flat overall market. John Smith's was the top performer, with volumes up 4.6%, while Foster's grew by 4%.

Like for like sales for its entire pub estate grew 0.4% for "uninvested" houses and 2.2% for those recently refurbished. The company's shares rose 13p to 470p.

Börse keeps door ajar

Deutsche Börse's chief executive Werner Seifert yesterday revealed that his company has not lost interest in the London Stock Exchange.

"We are very happy that with the appointment of a new chief executive officer Clara Furse LSE has taken a step nearer becoming ready for negotiations again," said Mr Seifert. "We consider ourselves to be good friends, and for that reason we never stopped talking."

Deutsche Börse revived plans for yesterday's flotation only after the collapse of merger talks with the London exchange last year.

The LSE declined to comment on relations with the Frankfurt bourse.

Rio Tinto profit jumps 24%

Rio Tinto, the world's second largest mining group, yesterday reported a 24% increase in annual profits on the back of improved commodity prices and cost savings.

Pretax profits rose to $2.5bn (£1.8bn), while net earnings were up 18% to $1.5b as the highest global economic growth in a decade pushed up demand for metals.

The financial results beat analysts' expectations and Rio Tinto shares rose 9p to end the day at £12.18.

Chairman Robert Wilson predicted a further rise in commodity prices this year, giving an encouraging outlook for the group.

Bridge wins debt reprieve

Bridge Information Systems, the embattled financial news and data company, yesterday won a reprieve by agreeing a restructuring of its debt with its largest shareholders. The US company is applying for chapter 11 protection from creditors while the restructuring takes place.

The agreement will reduce its debt by $700m (£475m) and inject $150m cash into the company.

Under the plan, $340m will be converted into equity while the rest will be reduced with asset sales.

£200m pledge for start-ups

Scottish entrepreneur and multimillionaire Tom Hunter said yesterday he would plough his fortune into a new £200m investment fund to help business start-ups across Britain.

Mr Hunter, who netted £260m from the 1998 sale of Sports Division, a shoe company he founded from the back of a van, said West Coast Capital would be looking at investments in the retail, leisure, property and technology sectors.

It will be one of Britain's biggest personally sponsored equity funds.

A survey released yesterday by accounting firm Grant Thornton showed the number of Scottish businesses going into receivership rose by 67% last year.
