webTitle: Orange is not the lemon it seems

fields.headline: Orange is not the lemon it seems
fields.standfirst: Mobile firm gets its timing right
fields.trailText: Mobile firm gets its timing right
fields.body:
It is a reality in our half-finished digital world, where communication and transportation still take twice as long as promised, that investors or speculators considering whether to play the Orange flotation need to make their mind up within the next day or so.

The "bear" case on this mobile group is obvious enough. Retail punters are being offered a minority stake in a French company, under Gallic management, just when the entire mobile telephony industry's business model is up for debate.

A total of 17 international investment banks are working to corral investors into a company whose future is anything but certain. Orange is billed as a global mobile phone business, but in truth it remains a laggard in one of the prime European markets (Germany) and does not even have a toe-hold in the biggest (America).

As for the numbers, compounded annual earnings growth projections of almost 24% over the next decade are brushed aside by market pessimists. They point out that these blue sky figures are coming from analysts employed by those banks making the scores of millions selling the shares.

Stop and think about the company itself and about the technology.

Orange is, without doubt, the best brand in the world of telephony. Notwithstanding the opacity of French corporate culture, it is a well-managed business, where levels of service and product quality have remained pristine despite explosive rates of growth over recent years.

At the same time, it is clear that the era of talking and swapping data while on-the-move is only just beginning. The wireless application protocol for mobile phones was a disaster because the technology did not work; instead, the simple-to-use short messaging service has become a consumer obsession (and a huge revenue generator for firms such as Orange).

Investing in Orange is a bet that SMS is just a first skip towards mass market use of so-called third-generation mobile services. It carries the assumption that all the big phone firms are investing so much in 3G that the technology will simply be made to work.

Now think about the stock market. Rates have been cut and the markets have broadly travelled sideways since the indicative price range for Orange (valuing the company at a mid-point £38bn) was set last month.

Take into account that retail investors are being offered stock at a 5% discount to the formal sale price, add the expectation that retail demand will be high in both France (if only for patriotic reasons) and Germany (where the public are fast becoming avid punters), and then also remember the parallel bond issue which Orange has launched, whose holders will have the right to swap into Orange shares.

This is what is known as new issue "tension" - pools of competing demand for stock, keeping the big institutions (the natural core holders) on their toes.

It is a fair bet, as things currently stand and assuming something close to mid-point pricing of the issue (800p, say), that shares in Orange will roar away. The stock will be priced to sell. It is an irresistible short-term buy.

Equitable relief

Equitable Life is like a nuclear waste ship constantly rejected entry into ports. Yesterday's news that Halifax is willing to reprocess the company - after it was turned away by Aegon, AMP, Prudential and many others - will bring widespread relief to its lost-at-sea policyholders.

The usual test of a deal is whether someone else jumps in offering more cash. There is one possible alternative - GE Capital - but yesterday Equitable made it clear that GE's £1.2bn offer is no more than a loan at market rates. Most Equitable policyholders will be pitifully grateful that Halifax is willing to pay £500m to take them on and will vote like turkeys for a suspension of Christmas.

Except, that is, for the 90,000 policyholders with lucrative guaranteed annuities. But even they are likely to be tempted by the 20% jam-today bonus backed by Halifax rather than relying on Equitable's somewhat shaky ability to fulfil promises.

Halifax chief executive Mr Crosby said yesterday that Equitable's uncertainty is over. But amid much talk of rescue and salvation at Equitable, and an unusual endorsement from the financial services authority, it is worth remembering that a few years ago a buyer would have had to cough up £3bn-£5bn for the company, paying members huge windfalls.

The Treasury select committee is yet to begin its hearings on Equitable, and reports will follow from the actuarial and accounting professions. An unapologetic Equitable - yesterday it managed a vague statement of regret for the "worrying time" for policyholders - may think its little local difficulty is over, but expect damning appraisals of its management over the next few months.

webTitle: BA hopes Concorde will fly again this summer

fields.headline: BA hopes Concorde will fly again this summer
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: British Airways yesterday confirmed its increasing optimism by announcing that it expects to resume daily Concorde flights to New York by the summer.
fields.body:
British Airways yesterday confirmed its increasing optimism by announcing that it expects to resume daily Concorde flights to New York by the summer.

It revealed its plan as it lodged third quarter profits of £65m, confirming the gradual climb out of the depths of the considerable losses it suffered less than a year ago.

Rod Eddington, BA's chief executive, said that it planned to spend £30m over the next 12 months improving the Concorde service. He added that talks were well advanced to sell Go, its no-frills airline.

Talks have reached a critical stage with six interested parties. While analysts do not believe the price will be much more than £100m, Mr Eddington thought that BA would make a substantial profit on its original £25m investment.

Mr Eddington said that its pretax profits for the third quarter reflected a series of cost-savings and a strategy to reduce unprofitable routes. "They reflect the continuing improvement in our business."

The City reacted sharply to the figures. Shares fell 6% or 27.5p to 430p, largely because analysts felt that investors were taking a profit after a good run on the shares.

Mr Eddington said that BA was in a good position to ride out a slowdown in the US economy, largely due to the policy of his predecessor, Bob Ayling, who cut capacity and concentrated on higher- margin business travellers.

The turnaround had been helped by the move to replace the BA fleet with smaller more efficient Boeing 777 and Airbus 319 aircraft.

Getting rid of unprofitable European routes out of Gatwick and reducing capacity by 9% would help BA cope with an expected softening in demand this year.

Asked about a possible alliance with Swiss Air, Mr Eddington said that he could rule "nothing in or out".

webTitle: Belfast yard on three-day week after £26m loss

fields.headline: Belfast yard on three-day week after £26m loss
fields.trailText: Harland & Wolff put its 500 staff on a three-day week yesterday as work dried up and the Belfast shipbuilder said it lost £26m last year.
fields.body:
Harland & Wolff put its 500 staff on a three-day week yesterday as work dried up and the Belfast shipbuilder said it lost £26m last year.

The yard is waiting for the Ministry of Defence to give a start date for building two roll-on, roll-off ships but the company's main shareholder, Fred Olsen Energy, warned that delays would mean further job cuts.

The bulk of the £26m deficit came from redundancy payments to 1,000 of the 1,500 staff who have been forced to leave the yard, which built the liner Titanic.

Fred Olsen said it had pumped in £90m over the past few years and believed it was time for Harland to become self-sufficient. The Oslo-based group said the Belfast yard's future should be secured by the British government's decision in October to build two of a six-ship fleet in Northern Ireland.

Harland is preparing to go to the Court of Appeal in London in its fight with an American company over a drilling ship contract. Global Marine refused to pay the final £23m instalment for the second vessel claiming it was not finished on time or to order last summer.

A Harland spokesman said it was still chasing other work opportunities and this summer it will seek planning permission to create a £400m science and leisure park on a third of the land it leases and will redevelop it over 10 years under the Titanic Quarter banner.

webTitle: Make or break vote lies with Russians

fields.headline: Make or break vote lies with Russians
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Supporters of Ariel Sharon made a final plea yesterday to the section of the Israeli public which proved decisive in the last three elections: Russian immigrants.
fields.body:
Supporters of Ariel Sharon made a final plea yesterday to the section of the Israeli public which proved decisive in the last three elections: Russian immigrants.

"Don't decide to stay home on February 6. We all like to speak of the behaviour of the victims of the Holocaust who were prepared to go like sheep to the slaughter," said a pamphlet printed in Russian and distributed in cities yesterday.

"Today, as our voting is carried out free from the threat of arms, and from snarling German shepherds, we have no right to passively allow someone else to decide about our lives."

The million Israelis who immigrated from the former Soviet Union in the past decade form 18% of the electorate - a fact recognised by both sides in Russian-subtitled television ads, and in Mr Sharon's fumbling attempts to address rallies in his parents' mother tongue.

"They are a critical mass - over a million people - and they really want to play a greater role," said Lily Galili, who covers the Russian community for the liberal newspaper Ha'aretz. "They want to exercise their power."

In 1999 immigrants were part of the landslide that carried the current Labour prime minister, Ehud Barak, to power: he got 58% of their votes, a shade above his share of the whole vote. But the Russians, who have a reputation for capriciousness and of punishing sitting Israeli leaders, have turned away from him this time.

Opinion polls show that he is trailing among new immigrants, registering 34 points to the hardline Mr Sharon's 47. Ms Galili said that as many as 80% of Russian voters might vote for Mr Sharon, the Likud party's candidate.

Most of the immigrants are staunchly secular - as many as half are not even Jewish - and they cannot forgive Mr Barak for entering a coalition with religious parties. They are also angry at his willingness in talks with the Palestinians to consider giving up part of Jerusalem, which they see as an important symbol of their shaky Jewish identity.

More important, they feel betrayed by his failure to end the Palestinian uprising, in which their community has suffered more than the average Israeli.

The first Israeli civilian killed in this intifada was a Russian, as was one of the army reservists hacked to death by an Arab mob in the West Bank city of Ramallah in October.

Many of the people in Gilo, the settlement on the edges of Jerusalem that has come under Palestinian fire, are Russian, and many Russians have settled in northern Galilee, the scene of October's rioting by Arab Israelis.

"We had trust in this prime minister, but it is unbelievable to have so many Jews murdered here," a Russian voter said at a Barak rally last week. By contrast, the warrior image of Mr Sharon looks reassuring.

webTitle: Sidelines

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Husbands beware. Your marriage may be at risk. Forget work stress or financial pressures or the seven-year itch, if you want to keep your wife, better keep an eye on her girlfriends.
fields.body:
Husbands beware. Your marriage may be at risk. Forget work stress or financial pressures or the seven-year itch, if you want to keep your wife, better keep an eye on her girlfriends. We've got all-round new man Boris Becker to thank for this piece of timely advice, after he revealed to a German magazine why he and his luminous ex-wife Barbara split last year.

It seems the heartless hussy was spending too much time with her female friends - some of whom (whisper it) already had failed marriages under their belt. "They meet once a month and have fantasies," the sensitive ex-tennis player sobbed to Der Spiegel on Sunday. And - as if that wasn't enough - "half of them are either divorced or separated".

And there was silly old Sidelines thinking the split was somehow related to Becker's admission that he had oral sex in a broom cupboard with a Russian model. The fact that he may have fathered her child must also be entirely incidental. Hmm. Someone is clearly living in a fantasy world here, and we're guessing it's not Barbara.

Meanwhile, news reaches Sidelines of a worrying constitutional threat. The women of this once-great nation, according to new research, have fallen out of love with Tony Blair. No longer do his heartfelt utterances and fluffy fringe set female hearts racing. His red-eyed performance as Peter Mandelson resigned left us unmoved. Even mentions of ickle Leo fail to melt stone cold hearts.

Now the Labour party is reportedly starting to panic about the "female vote". In a report entitled "Where is Worcester Woman?", think tank analysts have concluded gravely: "None of the political parties can afford to take the votes of women for granted." Which is nice of them, because the rest of us had assumed that us ladies formed a single, uniform block who could be won over by a few token mutterings about child care and some touchy-feely "real life stories" about courageous single mothers. A tip, Tony: you want Worcester woman? Look in Worcester.

webTitle: Interview: Lars Nittve, the director of Tate Modern

fields.headline: City limits
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones meets the man behind Tate Modern's much-criticised new show
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones meets the man behind Tate Modern's much-criticised new show
fields.body:
Coherence is not the most important thing if you do something that is really wide," says Lars Nittve, the director of Tate Modern. He's talking about Century City, Tate Modern's huge new exhibition about creativity in the 20th-century metropolis - a tour of nine world cities at key artistic moments, the museum's first loan exhibition. "I think that, when you do something that is seemingly coherent, you cover up different possibilities and different voices and different perspectives. I think we were quite keen on keeping curatorial voices visible. I almost have a dream that someone will sit down and actually study, maybe as an academic study, the different curatorial approaches that you find in Century City."

Perhaps one day, but first there are the reviews. Century City has attracted some stinkers. It has been described as an "appalling start to Tate Modern's exhibition programme" and "a joyless stew". The reviews are consistent in what they damn. This is the difference between the sniping Nittve feels is inevitable when an institution has been as successful as Tate Modern, and a really mistaken show. The exhibition does not establish a consistent argument; what does come through is a bizarre mixture of the patronising - unconvincing visits to Lagos and Bombay - and the complacent, with London in the 1990s given pride of place in the Turbine Hall. Other criticisms? The selection of times and places makes no historical sense: for example, New York is represented by conceptual art from the early 1970s, when the city's eminence as art capital stretches from Pollock to Warhol and beyond. It's about fashion rather than curiosity. And the admission price is a shock at £8.50.

Tate Modern has delighted its enemies and disappointed its friends with this show, which stretches from Paris in the age of cubism to London in the age of Gary Hume, and implies they are really quite similar. How was this monster created?

When it came to the museum's first exhibition, the Tate team wanted a curatorial carnival, a state-of-the-art exercise in interpretation. As Nittve explains, it's not simply that the nine sections of Century City have been organised by a curator each. "Then there were the team curators who oversaw three cities each from a Tate perspective. Then above that, Iwona Blazwick oversaw the whole process, and then I oversaw even more." There were seminars to share ideas, but the cities were treated separately and in different styles. You begin to see what went wrong.

Century City takes the same revisionist approach to 20th-century art as Tate Modern's opening displays, with their rejection of "isms" - but this time with more curators and fewer ideas. "We wanted to do something that continued the discussion about curatorial practices that had started with how we install the collection," Nittve explains. The surveys of visitors conducted by Tate Modern have found that around a third are critical of the thematically arranged displays. Nittve believes these people come with a prior understanding of what they think is modern art. People who don't have any assumptions don't mind if Richard Long is next to Monet. He has a Rousseau-esque idea of the perfectly open-minded Tate Modern visitor, and it's this untutored savage that Century City targets.

But doesn't the success of Tate Modern change the nature of its responsibility? The vast visitor figures - expected to hit 5m by the end of the first year - mean that the radical curating by which Nittve sets such store is irrelevant to many people. We might like a rigorous story of modern art, one in which Picasso's Paris is related to our own time historically.

Nittve believes the modern art museum "is about memory and history, and representing history, and at the same time it's an arena for contemporary discourse, for contemporary art. That tension between having a Picasso retrospective and at the same time showing contemporary artists gives the museum its energy. Of course, you also put contemporary artists at risk by comparison with the classics." The danger, as Century City illustrates, is that you simplify the past without helping the present.

Tate Modern's forthcoming attractions include a survey of the Italian 1960s movement Arte Povera, a surrealism show, and a Matisse/Picasso exhibition curated by John Golding, the eminent historian of modernism. All of these sound like substantial shows worthy of this great museum. Century City deserves to be just a blip.

 Century City is at Tate Modern, London SE1 (020-7887 8008), until April 29.

webTitle: Brassai's images of Paris at night

fields.headline: The dark lord
fields.standfirst: There's little chocolate-box prettiness to Brassai's images of Paris at night. Foggy, menacing and empty of human life, they give  Stuart Jeffries the shivers
fields.trailText: There's little chocolate-box prettiness to Brassai's images of Paris at night. Foggy, menacing and empty of human life, they give Stuart Jeffries the shivers
fields.body:
Cliches abound about the photographer Brassaï. He found his profession while wandering through Paris after dark. He sucked the streets into his camera, then rushed home with his haul before dawn. He was a creature of the night . . . There's a marvellous snapshot of Brassaï as a society photographer for a costume ball in the early 1930s. His gaze meets and confounds yours, his dress suit black and white, his shirt overstarched. He looks as if he has stumbled out of a German expressionist film, a sinister dark lord with dark brows and dark rings around his eyes.

And what could be more cliched than Brassaï's stock in trade: photographs of Paris in black and white? We all know Robert Doisneau's Ur-romantic Le Baiser de l'Htel de Ville - he a tousled-haired Tom Waits, she a Celia Johnston with her right arm dangling passively, the gooseberry in beret approaching behind them. Paris is too iconic, too pretty for us to see it afresh in black and white. And we know a little about Henri Cartier-Bresson and his "decisive moment". The photographer must wait and wait until the right moment. And then he must pounce.

So the problem when we look at Brassaï's photographs of Paris in the early 1930s is to really see them. But an exhibition of 250 of his photos (as well as sculptures and drawings) at London's Hayward Gallery will soon give us another chance - and Brassaï is worth the effort.

Occasionally Brassaï seems to have found that photographic holy grail, the decisive moment. His Lovers in a Small Cafe, Near the Place d'Italie (1932) seems just that, a pendant to Doisneau's kissing couple. Here the lovers seated in a booth are poised to embrace. Her head is tilted back, the fingers of her right hand fanned in parallel to her face. Her painted smile, her painted nails are perfect. She is a study in abandon. And what of him? He is pressing her to the back of the booth and we see his hair, slicked back. The photographer has pounced and the moment has been seized.

But this is no decisive moment captured from the flow of reality. The image is too constructed for that. Behind the woman's simulacrum of an ardent face is a reflection of the man's approaching head, the lips cut off, so that we see lazily calculating eyes descending on their quarry. We see what she sees. The romance dissolves in his sleepy predator's advance. Behind them too is a reflection of the woman's profile, which tells another story of what she is feeling. There are other reflections that make us realise that the photographer has sliced up reality and pasted it together in a much more interesting way.

After looking closely at this photograph, it's no surprise to learn that Brassaï would stage-manage his images. Elsewhere, the flower seller's customer was a friend of his, as was at least one of the lovers on a bench. In the sequence at a brothel called Suzy's, the prostitutes look so natural that their client must be real. But no: the client was a stand-in (apparently for legal reasons, but there were also aesthetic imperatives). So, are Kiki, Thérèse Treize and Lilly really dozing prostitutes, with their rhyming eyebrows and Clara Bow lips, or were they stand-ins? It's hard to be certain. Still less, ultimately, to care.

Brassaï (1899-1984) was born in Hungary and arrived in France in 1924. His home town was called Brasso, hence the name Brassaï (his original name was Gyula Halesz). At first he worked as a journalist, then he took up photography so that he could sell German newspapers both the text and pictures. But the photography, as well as being more lucrative, became more interesting. He wanted "to capture the beauty of the streets and gardens in the rain and fog and to capture Paris by night".

He didn't have much enthusiasm for snatching pictures. He preferred composing his im ages, and then retreating to the studio where he would do a great deal of his creative work. "A negative means nothing for my kind of photographer," he wrote. "It's the artist's print that counts."

Unlike his contemporaries, the Englishman Tony Ray-Jones or the American Lee Friedlander, Brassaï never wanted to become what they called a "pickpocket" photographer, nimbly stealing people's images. He couldn't be like them, because he used cumbersome equipment that required lengthy exposure. He used a tripod and a magnesium flash, which were hardly inconspicuous.

One can understand why he didn't want to be a pickpocket photographer. One day in 1944 he leaned out of his window to take a picture of the troops come to liberate Paris. He was mistaken for a sniper and a few bullets whistled over his head.

And he had a higher calling. "The meaning of art is not authenticity, but the expression of authenticity," wrote Brassaï. He also cited Baudelaire, that wanderer of city streets, who, though suspicious of photography, would have seen Brassaï as a painter of modern life "drawing out the eternal from the ordinary". Indeed, Brassaï located himself in a line that started with Rembrandt ("The ancestor of all us reporters of life") and Goya ("He, too, loves the street with its crowded life") before reaching the Paris of Degas and Toulouse-Lautrec.

What eternity can we see in the quotidian that Brassaï photographs? In The Baker (1930-32), Brassaï has photographed a bare-backed baker through the shadows of a barred window. He holds a pole so he can shove the dough into the oven. The light comes from offstage, as does the heat that we can almost feel from the unseen oven. In Paris, there could be nothing more eternal or nocturnal than the baking of bread.

But nothing quite prepares you for Brassaï on the prowl at night. He's so sinister! Very little of his work would find its way on to a chocolate box. That said, my calendar of Parisian photographic scenes does include two by Brassaï. January is the Eiffel Tower shot from the Trocadero in 1931. One huge wrought iron gate is closed, the other open, and through the latter we see the tower with its neon stars. It is too pretty to have much more than documentary value.

For the sinister Brassaï, you should look at his picture of Notre Dame at night as seen from the Isle Saint-Louis. Nobody had really photographed Paris after dark until then; looking at this picture, we sense that he has the city to himself. There isn't a soul in the picture. But beyond that uncanniness is the puffed-up bulk of the cathedral's flying buttresses, huge and upsetting in the dark.

Or consider another soulless photograph, this time of the Luxembourg Gardens. The gates are locked, so Brassaï shoots through them to the virgin snow and the frightening branches of an avenue of trees. At the end of that dark avenue is a tiny but intense burst of light from the palace. There's an extraordinary mood of menace here - a whole code of horror movies in a single image.

The surrealists loved Brassaï. They liked his foggy shots of Paris, particularly his silhouetted statue of Marshall Ney, sword aloft against a sea of fog and neon, particularly. But Brassaï, while producing a lot of work for their reviews and getting a nice poem written about him by Jacques Prévert, didn't dig their philosophy: "I never sought to express anything but reality itself, than which there is nothing more surreal."

In his drawings and sculptures of the 1940s and 1950s he was expressionist. Almost too much so: here his work seems derivative, his drawings borrowing from prevailing trends, his sculptures owing too much to his friend Picasso. His photographs of his art chums are chiefly of historical interest. They aren't the best of Brassaï. For that, let's go back to his Paris of the early 1930s. A magnesium flash of light reaches up the scaffolding around the Tour Saint-Jacques, a spectral stump with underlit gargoyles flying off into the dark. Brassaï is on the prowl once more. I can't wait to see the tower again. Perhaps I'll go tonight.

 Brassaï: The Soul of Paris is at the Hayward Gallery, London SE1, from February 22 to May 13. Details: 020-7960 4242. The exhibition catalogue Brassaï: No Ordinary Eyes is published by Thames and Hudson. Brassaï: Paris By Night is published by Flammarion.

webTitle: Radio pick of the day

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: File On 4 | Harsh Realities
fields.body:
Mark Whitaker tackles some of the financial dilemmas facing Britain's universities in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). There have been several well-publicised rows about research funded by tobacco companies. Birmingham University and Imperial College rejected such grants and MPs became extremely agitated when Nottingham accepted nearly £4 million from British American Tobacco. But are grants from dicey industrial sources the only danger? Whitaker offers examples of government grants which have acquired unacceptable political strings when research findings clashed with official policies.

A different aspect of this theme is tackled by Niall Dickson in Harsh Realities (9.0pm, Radio 4). In the wake of last week's official report on Alder Hey, Dickson asks doctors, managers, and researchers what they understand by "informed consent". Clearly, bereaved parents had no idea what might follow their child's death, yet there is still a constant need for human tissue to be available for clinical research. Where is the line to be drawn?

webTitle: Country Diary:   Somerset

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: As free as a bird
fields.trailText: Somerset
fields.body:
Somerset
If rainwater runs off the hills near Yeovil into the river Yeo's narrow channel at a time when the tide is in, the land at West Mudford can flood to a depth of several feet in a couple of hours. So it was good to know that those who, in 1710, built the farmhouse I was visiting, had set it on a little rise just so high that, even this year, the water never quite crept over the doorstep. I had gone there to visit 12 hens in a paddock out behind the pigsties. They were evidently enjoying the extensive grassy run outside their commodious henhouse and ran to greet us, plumply feathered and clucking, one or two pausing to peck at a trough of layers' pellets. The run is protected by an electric fence to discourage foxes, and the hens showed every sign of being fortunate and well cared for. Only if you looked closely at one individual did you notice that a wing was stunted and bare - a clue to their past. They had been among several thousand battery hens disposed of in the light of new regulations about the minimum space allowable per bird. There was a television appeal for people who might take some. An animal rescue centre at Wincanton gave temporary accommodation to a batch at a time and it was from there that these twelve had come to Mudford; skinny, almost bare of feathers, frightened and thirsty. That was back in July. For two days they cowered inside the henhouse, afraid of the light. After a fortnight they were getting used to a free-range existence, and after eight weeks they were fully feathered. In summer they produced about a dozen eggs every day. The one I poached demonstrated how the corn in their diet produces a rich, red-gold yolk.

Only if you looked closely at one individual did you notice that a wing was stunted and bare - a clue to their past. They had been among several thousand battery hens disposed of in the light of new regulations about the minimum space allowable per bird. There was a television appeal for people who might take some. An animal rescue centre at Wincanton gave temporary accommodation to a batch at a time and it was from there that these twelve had come to Mudford; skinny, almost bare of feathers, frightened and thirsty. That was back in July. For two days they cowered inside the henhouse, afraid of the light. After a fortnight they were getting used to a free-range existence, and after eight weeks they were fully feathered. In summer they produced about a dozen eggs every day. The one I poached demonstrated how the corn in their diet produces a rich, red-gold yolk.

webTitle: Putin puts life into the KGB ghost

fields.headline: Putin puts life into the KGB ghost
fields.standfirst:
The Russian president has put a rejuvenated secret service at the heart of his administration, democrats warn

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: The Russian president has put a rejuvenated secret service at the heart of his administration, democrats warn.
fields.body:
In a courtroom in the town of Kaluga, south-west of Moscow, later this month, a Russian academic and security affairs specialist will stand trial for espionage. Igor Sutyagin, 35, who collates and analyses information from Russian newspapers and periodicals for the prestigious US-Canada Institute in Moscow, is accused of passing state secrets to the old cold war enemy.

Human rights activists denounce the case as the latest evidence of the "spy-mania" gripping Russia under President Vladimir Putin, and point to a series of alarming signals suggesting that the secret police are clawing back power and influence after a decade of disgrace and demoralisation.

"There's a new fear. It's a new situation," a former KGB general now in banking said. "There's a sense of the KGB's return. For 10 years those guys were sitting around silent. Now they see their chance."

Under Mr Putin, who served in the KGB for 16 years, former KGB officers and military men are playing a bigger role in politics than at any time since the break-up of the Soviet Union. Sergei Ivanov, a career KGB officer, heads Mr Putin's security council and is increasingly seen as the unofficial and unelected vice-president. A former KGB colleague, Viktor Ivanov, runs the Kremlin personnel department. Nikolai Patrushev, another former colleague of Mr Putin's and head of the KGB's main successor, the FSB, has just been put in charge of the war in Chechnya.

"It's unprecedented that the army and the interior ministry troops are put under the secret police. That's a new direction for Russia," Sergei Grigoryants, a leading human rights activist and head of the Glasnost Foundation, said.

Outsiders
Of 18 new regional governors elected in the 13 months since Mr Putin became president, four are army or navy officers. Of the seven presidential envoys Mr Putin has appointed to run "super-regions", five are army or ex-KGB officers.

"They're incompetent," the ex-KGB general said. "They don't know economics, they can't pay salaries, and they're outsiders in the regions they're supposed to be running."

Last week the liberals' leader, Grigory Yavlinsky, said that Mr Putin was building a police state. The former prime minister and fellow liberal Yegor Gaidar told a conference in Washington that the jury was still out on whether Mr Putin's government was committed to democracy. He noted "a very serious increase of the role of the secret service", and "selective pressure" on the free media. "All this shows that the Russian leadership at least is not very decided on the issue of democracy being necessary."

The Sutyagin case follows the sentencing in December of Edmund Pope, a retired US naval officer, to 20 years for spying. Mr Pope was the first American to be sentenced for espionage in Russia for 40 years, though Mr Putin promptly displayed magnanimity and pardoned him.

Pollution
That case was preceded by the high-profile trials of environmentalists and ex-military whistleblowers charged with treason for publicising nuclear pollution in Russia's far north and far east. The point, critics say, is to intimidate the independent-minded and discourage opposition.

For example, Mr Sutyagin's employer, the US-Canada Institute, is highly influential with the Moscow foreign policy elite, while being seen as liberal and pro-western.

"The effect of putting Sutyagin on trial is to create a climate of fear," said Valery Borshev, who runs the human rights section of the parliamentary legislation committee. "Yet again, the hunt is on for enemies of the state."

The arrests and trials have prompted a tug-of-war between the security services on the one hand, and civil organisations and the media. Human rights groups have just held the biggest ever conference of its type in Moscow in response to the encroachment on civil liberties. That the conference took place at all is a measure of how Russia's fledgling civil society is developing, indicating resistance to the Kremlin and suggesting that Mr Putin's authoritarian instincts are less than total.

But for the past year reports have been circulating in Moscow that the president is bent on restoring the all-powerful KGB under a new name, and making it answerable to himself. It is thought, however, that he wants it to exercise a selective control, recognising that he cannot restore the sweeping surveillance of the Soviet era.

After the abortive KGB-led putsch against Mikhail Gorbachev in 1991, President Boris Yeltsin set about destroying the KGB. He dissolved its huge bureaucracy and broke down its 16 directorates into five separate agencies, to prevent power being concentrated.

Many of the most able secret policemen left to make money in the new private sector or to run the burgeoning private armies and security services of the big banks and companies. The FSB went through eight chiefs in as many years.

But Mr Putin has ended that disarray and rehabilitated the KGB as the embodiment of the ascetic, incorruptible public service. The Kremlin spin doctors have been assiduously cultivating the image of the secret policeman as modern hero.

In December secret policemen spent the evening carousing with Mr Putin, not at their Lubyanka headquarters in Moscow but in the Kremlin, to celebrate the foundation in December 1917 of the Cheka, the Bolshevik forerunner of the KGB which developed into the key instrument of the Great Terror.

"The history of the Lubyanka in the last century is our history," Mr Patrushev declared. "We should retain and increase everything in that history which worked for the benefit of Russia."

Such remarks chill democrats. Mr Borshev said that during the Yeltsin years he, and various non-governmental organisations, had a dialogue with the Kremlin and were consulted by the security council.

"That's all gone now," he said. "They don't want contact with public bodies. It's closed analysis, closed decisions and closed actions. There's no information and no control. The problem is that the public is now receptive - it is looking to the secret police to solve its problems - while the FSB takes that as a licence to renew the old KGB methods."

Mr Grigoryants said a Russian diplomat had told him that the FSB had installed a "telephone trust-line" at the foreign ministry for staff to denounce colleagues. "They're promised anonymity." Ministry staff had been told to meet foreigners only in pairs, one to keep an eye on the other.

Mr Grigoryants was at a meeting in Brussels with European officials and lobbyists last month to plan a Paris conference. Out of courtesy, he said, he had informed the Russian embassy about the meeting. "Two Russian diplomats showed up. They were very unconstructive and tried to disrupt the meeting."

In an rare interview with a Moscow newspaper in December, Sergei Lebedev, the foreign intelligence chief, waxed sentimental about spies and secret police.

"Being an agent means being reliable," he said. "It means dedication to the homeland, to comrades, it means being noble."

webTitle: Tories plan tax cut to woo grey vote

fields.headline: Tories plan tax cut to woo grey vote
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservatives stepped up the pressure on Gordon Brown to woo the "grey power" electorate in next month's Budget when they announced plans to scrap all income tax on the savings and dividends of 20m mainly older voters.
fields.body:
The Conservatives stepped up the pressure on Gordon Brown to woo the "grey power" electorate in next month's Budget when they announced plans to scrap all income tax on the savings and dividends of 20m mainly older voters.

Labour immediately claimed the Tory plans would give only around £100 a year to most people affected, but would disproportionately benefit the better off, giving an average £1,500 to the top 10%, those with the biggest savings.

William Hague and Michael Portillo joined forces to unveil the £3bn proposal, which went further than expected in exempting not just pensioners' savings and dividends but all such savings for lower and middle income groups.

It would leave only higher rate taxpayers - with incomes above £32,785- paying income tax on savings. The £2.3bn cost (plus £680m to abolish dividend taxes) would be found from £8bn savings on public spending, Mr Portillo said.

Though the Tory proposal would retain the 40% tax rate on savings, the effect of abolishing both the 22% standard rate of tax and the 10% starter rate for all savers would unavoidably mean larger net benefits to those with a high proportion of savings income.

They are typically self-employed people who have retired on capital assets rather than a conventional occupational pension. Around 16m of the likely beneficiaries of the Tory scheme are non-pensioners, mostly on modest incomes. Around 4.7m are re tired, mainly the better off.

The move, which the Conservative leader billed as a blow for "individual independence, institutional freedom and social responsibility", was endorsed as feasible by analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies, who have been critical of both sides' figures during pre-election skirmishes. The plans reflect Tory attempts to win back older voters - who tend to vote in above-average numbers - and to encourage savings which have slipped by two-thirds as a share of national income since 1997.

The Tory plan would also end what Mr Portillo denounced as "one of the greatest injustices of the tax system" - that people who have saved out of taxed income are then taxed a second time on the income generated by their savings, which have also been subjected to corporation tax.

The proposal would create a tax revolution in "a Britain where the overwhelming majority of people who have already paid tax on the income they earn, do not then have to pay tax again when they save that income and earn interest on it", Mr Hague said.

Under the Tory scheme, a pensioner on the basic rate of tax with £10,000 invested in an ordinary building society account would benefit by £120 in the first year, rising to £740 if they kept their money in for five years. For someone with £20,000 in the bank, the gains would be £240 and £1,481 respectively.

webTitle: Tube strike brings chaos for commuters

fields.headline: Tube strike brings chaos for commuters
fields.standfirst:
Blizzards cause travel misery and power cuts in the north

Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Three million London commuters faced a rain-sodden struggle to and from work yesterday as the most effective strike on the London Underground for a decade rammed home the seriousness of the continuing conflict over the future of the tube.
fields.byline: Seumas Milne, Angelique Chrisafis, Kirsty Scott  and  Cynthia Koons
fields.body:
Three million London commuters faced a rain-sodden struggle to and from work yesterday as the most effective strike on the London Underground for a decade rammed home the seriousness of the continuing conflict over the future of the tube.

The chaos was not only confined to the south: transport was disrupted and tens of thousands of homes were left in freezing darkness as blizzards caused havoc in the north of England and Scotland.

In London the walkout by more than 2,000 members of the train drivers' union Aslef, called over fears about safety under the government's plans to part-privatise the underground, all but shut down the network, leaving fewer than 10% of trains running.

With only 40 out of the usual 476 trains in service, the disruption sharply increased traffic congestion and overcrowding on bus and rail services, with City of London police calling in extra officers to patrol bus queues after scuffles broke out between stranded passengers.

London Underground, which was accused of provoking the strike by the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, agreed to meet both main rail unions this morning at the conciliation service Acas in an attempt to avoid the next two stoppages, planned for Monday and Monday week.

Yesterday's strike went ahead despite last Friday's agreement by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, to give Mr Livingstone's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, a free hand to draw up "modifications" to the government's partial selloff plans to avoid the fragmentation of the tube.

The unions have welcomed the move, but all sides concede that there is still no agreed compromise formula and Aslef and the Rail Maritime and Transport union - whose own strike vote was overturned by the High Court last week - are determined to secure safety guarantees from tube managers.

Mr Livingstone laid the blame for yesterday's disruption at the door of "senior London Underground management", who he said had provoked the strike and "been consistently unconvincing about safety on the tube, both to myself and the trade unions".

Mick Rix, general secretary of Aslef, which represents around three-quarters of tube drivers, said the union regretted the inconvenience. "But this is a dispute about safety and we believe most commuters realise that a small inconvenience today is far better than a big accident tomorrow."

Steve Norris, Transport for London board member, described the strike as a "cynical waste of time", and said it had nothing to do with safety and a lot to do with job preservation.

Another board member, Susan Kramer, said: "I'm really sad that the mayor has not had big enough shoulders to accept that he has supported the trade unions to strike and blaming it on London Underground management.

"I do not think that anyone in the real world is convinced that this will make the government more sensitive to the misery of travel in London."

The weather was the cause of further misery in the north as around 20 inches of snow blanketed Northumberland, cutting power supplies and forcing schools to turn children away. The North Yorkshire moors and the Pennines were under eight inches of snow.

In Scotland more than five inches of snow fell at Ab erdeen and seven inches fell at Eskdalemuir in Dumfriesshire, leaving more than 4,000 households in darkness.

In Shetland all schools were closed and public transport services cancelled in whiteout conditions. In Grampian more than 100 schools closed. Several main roads in Aberdeenshire and Tayside were blocked.

In County Durham coastguards and traffic control were on alert after two deaths from the snow. On Sunday a teenage boy was swept to his death as he walked along the North Sea coastline at South Gare. He was one of a group of three teenagers washed into icy water by force nine gales.

In Darlington a 39-year-old man died when his car collided with a council snowplough and gritter on the A68.

webTitle: Asylum seekers to be 'sent back'

fields.headline: Asylum seekers to be 'sent back'
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Thousands of asylum seekers could be forced back across the channel to France under a radical scheme with Paris to curb the flow of illegal immigrants to Britain.
fields.body:
Thousands of asylum seekers could be forced back across the channel to France under a radical scheme with Paris to curb the flow of illegal immigrants to Britain.

In a sign of pre-election jitters over asylum, Tony Blair will discuss the idea of summary deportations with the French president Jacques Chirac at an Anglo-French summit on Friday.

The initiative follows an Anglo-Italian scheme, launched over the weekend by the prime minister and his Italian counterpart, to crack down on up to 50,000 illegal immigrants through Bosnia and the western Balkans into Europe.

Mr Blair is now hoping to persuade M Chirac to sign up to a "bilateral repatriation" accord which would see illegal cross-channel immigrants being deported back to France immediately. British officials believe that the plan would end any idea among asylum seekers that Britain is a soft touch, an accusation made forcefully by the Conservatives. A Downing Street spokeswoman confirmed last night that the idea would be on the agenda for the Anglo-French summit in Cahors on Friday. "This will be one of about half a dozen ideas on the agenda," the spokeswoman said. "They will look at issues which effect ports in both countries."

The Tories are likely to seize on the Anglo-French scheme as a sign of panic in Downing Street over asylum, an issue which William Hague has exploited over the past year. Downing Street will be hoping that introducing such a tough measure will take the heat out of the asylum issue ahead of the election.

British officials have drawn up the deportation scheme because of fears that the EU's Dublin convention on asylum, which Britain implemented in 1997, has failed to curb illegal immigrants. Under the convention, asylum seekers can be returned to the country which first cleared them to enter the EU. Asylum seekers who cross the channel usually enter the EU from countries such as Italy which have borders with non-EU states. This makes deportation more difficult.

The French have yet to respond to the British proposal. However, Mr Blair will tell Mr Chirac that the scheme would benefit France by discouraging migrants entering France en route to Britain.

The disclosure of the British plan comes amid cross-channel tensions. It is understood that Britain was irritated last month when officials learnt through the media that the French authorities were reducing border security at smaller channel ports such as Dieppe. There are reports that so called "people-smuggling gangs" are using smaller ports to avoid tighter controls in larger ports such as Calais.

The prime minister underlined his determination over the weekend to stem the flow of illegal entrants when he outlined plans with the Italian prime minister Guiliano Amato to block the "Sarajevo route" from the Balkans.

webTitle: Nato chief stirs row over missile defence

fields.headline: Nato chief stirs row over missile defence
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, warned Europeans yesterday they must accept that the US president, George Bush, would deploy the controversial national missile defence.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington, Ewen MacAskill  and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
The Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, warned Europeans yesterday they must accept that the US president, George Bush, would deploy the controversial national missile defence.

Lord Robertson's comment will be met with surprise throughout Europe, given that most countries, including Germany and France, have come out publicly against NMD.

Speaking after a defence conference in Munich, Lord Robertson said: "The United States has made it clear that it intends to deploy some effective missile defence system and there has to be an acceptance that that was the decision made in the election campaign and we should treat it seriously and with respect."

He claimed there were no divisions within Nato on NMD: "People wanted to find a split between America and Europe on the issue of missile defence."

The Labour government, eager to maintain good relations with the US, is bending towards support for NMD but is hoping to delay a decision until after the general election.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will play for time today when he meets the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, in Washington.

Mr Cook, who flew into Washington yesterday, will argue that since the US is reviewing the options for NMD there is no pressure on Britain to make up its mind for at least the next few months. A Foreign Office source said Mr Cook did not expect Mr Powell to have NMD "high on his agenda", predicting that their discussions would be dominated instead by Iraq, Libya and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

But the NMD controversy refuses to die away. The Russian defence minister, Igor Sergeyev, further fuelled the row yesterday when he warned that if the US pushed ahead, it would be in breach of the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty, which has acted as a brake on the arms race for three decades. He threatened that Russia would dust down its "star wars" plans.

Mr Cook, the first British minister to meet the new administration, will hold a joint press conference with Mr Powell today. He will follow this tomorrow with a meeting with the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, who strongly favours NMD.

The Foreign Office source said the US had lots of decisions still to make about NMD, such as whether it would be land-based or sea-based. When the US decided to consult its allies, the source said, that would be the time for the British government to take a look at it.

Britain is directly involved because the US wants to use the Fylingdales tracking station in North Yorkshire. This would be needed whether the system is based on land or sea.

Postponing the decision suits the British government. The government, initially sceptical about NMD, has been softening its position over the past few months and any signal of support will create upheaval in the Labour party, which strongly opposed the former US president Ronald Reagan's original "star wars" proposal.

A British official in Washington predicted the introduction of NMD would be "donkey's years" away and would not come in before 2007. But he added: "This thing is coming. It's not a question of whether, it's a question of when."

He said Britain agreed with the US that there was a threat from "rogue states" and that "NMD may well have a role to play in dealing with this issue."

Admiral Eugence Carroll, former director of US operations in Europe and the Middle East and now vice-president of Washington's centre for defence information, yesterday joined the criticism of NMD. He told the Guardian the threat from maverick states did not exist, the cost of NMD would be horrendous, and no one would attack the US knowing it would be pulverised.

The other big issue on the table today is the plan for a European defence force. The British source in Washington said Mr Cook would be "extremely robust" in addressing any US concerns. "The British government would never agree to undertake anything that was Nato-dividing or Nato-weakening," he said.

The US defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, said in Munich at the weekend he was a "little worried" about the Euroforce plan. "It runs the risk of injecting instability into the alliance."

webTitle: Cabinet crisis as fox in brush with the law

fields.headline: Cabinet crisis as fox in brush with the law
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: A fox created a parliamentary diversion at Westminster yesterday.
fields.body:
A fox created a parliamentary diversion at Westminster yesterday.

The fox - nicknamed Basil - sparked a 15-minute alert during which eight security guards and policemen gave chase across three floors after spotting him early yesterday morning.

He was finally cornered in the peers' wing of the Houses of Parliament, sitting on a cabinet next to a division bell, the bell used to summon MPs to vote, in third floor offices where the official Hansard records of parliamentary business are kept.

The police officers named him Basil after a two-hour stand-off during which the urban fox refused to get down from the cabinet.

When RSPCA officers arrived they released Basil back on to the street, unhurt after his brush with the law.

A police spokesman said that Basil had delayed the morning testing of the division bell but had not otherwise disrupted parliamentary business.

"Foxes are sometimes seen in the courtyards because of the closeness of Victoria Gardens, but this is the first occasion one has been seen on the premises," said the police spokesman.

"It is a bit of a debate as to how Basil got in without being spotted, but he was taken away before most of the peers arrived."

It is thought Basil is the same fox that has been seen near the parliament on several other occasions, including the morning of January 17, when MPs voted to ban hunting with dogs.

Basil's latest appearance yesterday could not have been better timed for anti-hunt campaigners who are preparing to lobby peers over the hunting bill.

The bill completes its committee stage this week and will receive a third reading in the Commons later this month before being voted on by the Lords.

The Labour MP Mike Foster, who proposed the private member's bill, said that Basil had been lucky not to run into pro-hunt peers.

webTitle: 'Shame' of former civic deputy

fields.headline: 'Shame' of former civic deputy
fields.trailText: A former deputy leader of Doncaster council was given a two month suspended jail sentence yesterday - the 19th conviction of members of the discredited Labour authority.
fields.body:
A former deputy leader of Doncaster council was given a two month suspended jail sentence yesterday - the 19th conviction of members of the discredited Labour authority.

Michael Farrington, 52, pleaded guilty to an expenses fraud charge which had been expected to go to a three-day trial at Hull crown court.

Farrington, who is still a member of the council, was told by Judge Peter Barker that he had brought disgrace on the public office he held. He is expected to resign although he is not legally barred from serving as a councillor because the sentence is less than three months.

The court heard that Farrington, a civil servant with the Child Support Agency, had claimed expenses for two extra nights at a Blackpool hotel after a conference of the National Society of Clean Air. His solicitor, David Green QC, said that Farrington's wife had been ill and he had wanted two days on his own to reflect on the family's situation.

The councillor, who represents Doncaster's Richmond ward, admitted falsely claiming £137.60 for the two nights, and was ordered to repay the sum and £750 costs. The judge told him: "It is a melancholy day when a man of 52 who is an elected councillor and who became deputy leader of the council has to stand in the dock of a criminal court and plead guilty to an offences of dishonesty."

Judge Barker said that a prison sentence was inevitable for serious dishonesty but he ordered a 12 month suspension because of Farrington's previous good character. The court heard that he might lose his job after 22 years' work with the civil service, pending discussions with his employers.

The number of prosecutions of Doncaster councillors, former councillors and officials is expected to approach 40 after South Yorkshire police's prolonged fraud inquiry, Operation Danum.

webTitle: Fall in some common bird numbers accelerating

fields.headline: Fall in some common bird numbers accelerating
fields.trailText: Populations of 22 of Britain's most common birds have dropped by more than 50% in 25 years, and with some species the decline is accelerating, according to a report published yesterday.
fields.body:
Populations of 22 of Britain's most common birds have dropped by more than 50% in 25 years, and with some species the decline is accelerating, according to a report published yesterday.

Starlings and skylarks are virtually disappearing in some areas as modern farming and forestry methods have removed the food supply they need for breeding and for surviving the winter.

Ten other species have declined by more than a quarter over the same period, while only a dozen have more than doubled in population.

The figures were released by the British Trust for Ornithology (BTO) in a report, Breeding Birds in the Wider Countryside, which monitored the populations of 100 species, excluding sea birds, over the period 1973-1998.

Most startling declines are for the tree sparrow and lesser redpoll, both of whose populations have fallen by 94%. One bird, the little grebe, has for the first time joined the list of birds that have declined by 50%, while two species, the kestrel and the cuckoo, have joined the list of species that have declined by 25%.

Chris Mead, consultant to the BTO said: "It is a curious fact that some of the real rarities are on the increase while the common birds are in decline. The reason is that the RSPB, English Nature and the like buy up the habitats where the rare birds live and provide the perfect surroundings for them to breed and feed.

"Where there are thousands of pairs spread all over the place it is too expensive. These birds have to survive as they can in changing conditions. For example, the skylark used to thrive in summer grown cereal crops. This meant in the winter there was stubble in the fields and loads of food in the form of seeds. Now in the newly growing crops there are too few seeds, and by the summer the crop is too thick for the birds to successfully nest."

He said that recent surveys had shown that the number of seeds per square metre had dropped from 1,000 to fewer than 100. "Not enough to keep a skylark population going," he said.

The same was true for starlings which fed their young on wire worms and leather jackets. Modern pesticides killed these grubs, making it impossible for starlings to find enough food to successfully rear their young.

"We are all to blame. We asked farmers to change their methods, grow more and more and give us cheap food. They obliged and now we realise the birds suffer as a result. Now we are waking up and farmers are being asked to change to more environmentally friendly methods. Let's hope it reverses all these trends before some of these common birds become virtually extinct."

The report said the most worrying aspect was that eight species had declined in monitoring sites by more than 25% in the last five years. They are grey partridge, lesser spotted woodpecker, tree pipit, yellow wagtail, willow tit, starling, tree sparrow. Other "common" birds in heavy decline are spotted flycatcher, pied wagtail, song thrush, mistle thrush and bullfinch. Increasing species collared dove, buzzard, mute swan, sparrowhawk, mallard and tufted duck.

webTitle: Children's safety 'bought at a price'

fields.headline: Children's safety 'bought at a price'
fields.standfirst:
Success in cutting fatal accidents and abuse achieved by restricting freedom to explore

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Success in cutting fatal accidents and abuse achieved by restricting freedom to explore.
fields.body:
The United Kingdom has one of the world's lowest rates of child deaths caused by accident and abuse, according to a UN report published today.

Despite concerns about attacks on children, like the killing of Anna Climbie by her aunt and the abduction and murder of Sarah Payne, such events are rarer than in many other industrialised countries.

But the authors of the first league table of children's deaths by injury in the world's 26 richest countries said that, in some cases, the success of reducing numbers being killed in road accidents, drownings, fires, falls and deliberate injury, might be bought at a price.

On the whole children were no longer being allowed to explore their boundaries and develop their own sense of risk and danger, said the report. The authors, a Florence-based research centre for Unicef, examined the deaths of children aged one to 14.

This revealed that the UK's injury death record, 6.1 per 100,000 children in the age group each year, was better than in any other country except Sweden. The figure is a quarter of that in Korea and less than half that in the United States.

Although the likelihood of children dying from injury had been falling steadily since the 1970s, 20,000 would still die in this group of wealthy nations over the next year. Nearly half that total could be saved if all countries could match Sweden where the death rate was just over five per 100,000 for the years 1991 to 1995.

The report said that although the UK fared well in general, children with parents in unskilled manual jobs were three or four times more likely to die than those whose parents were in skilled non-manual work. The UK also had a bad record on deaths from fires, and boys were more than half as likely to die from injury as girls.

Britain's death rate from intentional injury of 0.8 per 100,000, compared with 2.74 in the US, and 1.58 in France.

In most industrialised nations "parents are increasingly worried about the threats to children, whether from traffic accidents or predatory paedophiles," said the report. "In response to high profile media treatment of selected cases, and more generalised warning from public organisations that have to compete for public attention and public funds, it is natural for parents to increase the level of protection."

It added: "In practice this has meant that millions of parents now drive or accompany their children on journeys, prevent them from playing outside or exploring independently, and feel that every activity has to be supervised."

The report referred to one study in the UK which suggested the proportion of children aged seven and eight who travelled to school without adult supervision fell from 80% to 10% between 1970 and 1990.

Public messages on ensuring the safety of children, said the report, should help parents keep a sense of proportion but there was no point in telling them to change their behaviour because the risks to their children were small.

"The appropriate response to this is not to tell parents that the roads are much safer. It is to make those roads safer so that parents' own assessments of the danger changes."

webTitle: Watchdog could inquire into killing of Ulster lawyer

fields.headline: Watchdog could inquire into killing of Ulster lawyer
fields.standfirst:
New legislation will bring loyalist murder of republican solicitor Pat Finucane within remit of police ombudsman

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: New legislation will bring loyalist murder of republican solicitor Pat Finucane within remit of police ombudsman.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's police ombudsman could start investigating allegations of RUC links to the loyalist paramilitary murder of the Belfast solicitor Pat Finucane next month.

Nuala O'Loan's current powers of retrospective inquiry cover only 12 months, but legislation coming into effect next month extends this to 24 months and gives her authority where there is new evidence or serious public interest.

The killing of Mr Finucane, who had represented several leading republicans and was shot dead in front of his family in their north Belfast home in 1989, would be an obvious choice for her to investigate.

His wife, Geraldine, and nationalist and republican campaigners, who want a full, independent inquiry into the murder, are convinced that army intelligence and RUC special branch knew loyalist gunmen were targeting the high-profile lawyer.

The Ulster Defence Association terrorist Brian Nelson, an agent for the military's force research unit, was jailed for conspiracy to murder him in 1992, and the RUC informer William Stobie, also a UDA member, has been charged in connection with the killing.

The case is political dynamite because of claims that the security forces deflected paramilitaries involved in the Finucane murder from killing a top IRA member who was the army double agent known as "Steak Knife", leading them to kill innocent Catholics instead.

Mrs O'Loan said:"I will be reflecting on which cases to look at, but the Finucane murder is a matter of concern."

The ombudsman's office would probably spend some months reviewing existing information and talking to a police inquiry team, headed by the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, which is looking at allegations of widespread security force collusion with loyalist terrorists in the 1980s and 1990s.

But Mrs O'Loan's investigators could then interrogate RUC officers and seize weapons, documents, vehicles and other relevant material. If this uncovered evidence of wrongdoing she could recommend prosecutions.

Mrs O'Loan is already involved in aspects of the inquiries into the murders of the Lurgan human rights lawyer Rosemary Nelson, blown up by a loyalist car bomb in 1999, and the Portadown Catholic Robert Hamill, kicked to death by a loyalist mob in 1997.

Although these happened before her allotted 12-month time span, she has inherited the police inquiry into claims that RUC officers sat by in a Land Rover a few yards from where Mr Hamill was attacked, and she is examining allegations that RUC officers had threatened Mrs Nelson.

Mrs O'Loan is adamant that her office, which has received 950 complaints against the RUC in 11 weeks, is politically impartial and fully independent from police and government interference.

The origins of the complaints have not yet been analysed, but they are believed to have come from Protestants and Catholics throughout the province, and range from issues such as rudeness to serious physical assault.

Her 33 investigators, recruited from 500 applicants worldwide, hail from as far afield as Australia, Hong Kong and the US, and include lawyers, customs and excise officials and former police.

Taking responsibility for complaints out of police hands is unprecedented in the UK, and Mrs O'Loan insists the new system can work to the benefit of both police and public.

"We don't have an agenda against the police," she said. "Our work is totally factual and can help prove officers innocent as well as guilty. We operate without fear or favour."

 Soldiers went back on to north Belfast streets last night to protect Catholics from loyalist pipe bombs. There have been more than 30 such bombings in the province this year, though none has caused serious injury. An army spokesman said about 80 troops would be deployed in response to an RUC request for back-up.

webTitle: Design gurus comment on Labour's new logo

fields.headline: Design of the times
fields.standfirst:
It's not a new look for Labour - it's a just new logo for their merchandise. Is that clear? Maybe, but that's not the hard part - try working out what it's supposed to represent or why the party needs another symbol. Merope Mills asks seven design gurus to comment

New Labour in power
fields.trailText: It's not a new look for Labour - it's a just new logo for their merchandise. Is that clear? Maybe, but that's not the hard part - try working out what it's supposed to represent or why the party needs another symbol.  Merope Mills asks seven design gurus to comment
fields.body:
Rita Clifton, chief executive of branding consultancy Interbrand

It's a very see-through strategy. There are so many allusions here that it feels a bit like a quiz. The cross is obviously a reference to voting, then the heart suggests voting with your heart, which makes it feel like a campaign device rather than a long-term thing. You also feel like you must have seen it somewhere before. It looks a bit like one of the ribbons you get for breast cancer or Aids. That gives it the feel of a charity, which you may or may not think is appropriate. In style terms, the freehand way it is drawn gives the logo a more human feel. Labour is considered over-slick and over-spun, so it is probably good to go a bit more amateurish. Overall, though, the logo does feel rather undistinguished.

Rupert Howell, chief executive of Chime Communications

Firstly, I do think it's slightly strange to have a separate official logo and then an unofficial motif. I actually think the red rose is a pretty good logo for them, so it's ever so slightly weird to want to add to that. Maybe variations on the rose would have been better, but possibly they can't do that because they don't want to mess around with their main logo.

I thought the logo itself was a bloke parachuting. Parachuting out of the spiralling plane that is the Labour party, perhaps. But I'm not sure that's the image they're going for. It's one of those things that when you read how they got to it, or how they post-rationalised it, it's jolly sensible. But it's not a great design. If they'd come to me I would have certainly tried to see if there was a way of doing a variation of the rose without weakening the main logo itself. But it does classically look like it has been designed by a committee with certain objectives - like voting - in mind. It's not ghastly, it's not dreadful, it's just pretty uninspiring. I've seen worse, but I've sure as hell seen better.

Dan Bobby, senior consultant at brand consultancy Wolff Olins

My first reaction was that this is inappropriate. Not because of the way the logo looks, it's just that this approach seems all wrong at the moment. At a time when Labour is experiencing such great difficulties this logo just doesn't seem significant. It doesn't resonate. As symbols go, the red rose seems like a pretty good one to me. People like it and they know what it means. This feels like it should be for an NGO. I don't know where they're coming from with that, and I suspect not many other people will either.

John Mathers, managing director of Fitch

It's an interesting and bold design move but I'm just not sure everyone is going to get it. I got sent a copy of the logo on fax. It came in on its side and in black and white and it looked the mathematical symbol for greater than and less than three [> < 3]. So I think somebody should have looked a bit more closely at in black and white before they developed the colour version. I can see what they're trying to do but unfortunately the papers at the moment are full of Labour's woes in other directions with Mandelson and Vaz, so I hope this isn't similar to the British Airways relaunch of an identity at the same time the cabin crew go on strike.

Michael Peters, chairman of Identica

It only serves to demonstrate why the Labour party is in such turmoil. It's a joke. It's so reminiscent of so many other things. I'm all for change but why do something that is so derivative of other people. It's got so many different shapes and ideas in it. At the end of the day I think an identity should stand on its own, which this doesn't. It's an indication that people at the communications end of the Labour party are not thinking clearly enough because it's too complicated. And I think that if they're trying to unite people the worst thing to do is have two logos. It makes Labour seem like it's in two minds. I think if one is trying to extend a hand to existing supporters or new supporters of the Labour party they should at least come up with something which is new and innovative and dynamic and futuristic. But the way this has been crafted it looks just like one of a million things. I would have designed a rose with a knot in its stalk - as a way of saying "don't forget us".

Chris Powell, chairman of BMP, New Labour's former ad agency

It's not really a logo because it's not replacing the rose. It's just trying to distinguish their merchandise from one year from the next. But I think whatever it's trying to imply is all in the mind of the person who designed it. I don't think anyone else can perceive those things. I'm constantly amazed by designers who think that the people see designs and read them as if they've got subtitles on. You'd know what it was if someone told you, but you don't naturally see it as a heart or a cross. Only if I see the explanation underneath do I see what it's meant to be.

Michael Wolff, partner at brand consultancy The Fourth Room and creator of Labour's red rose

It's a brutish-looking logo and that is exactly why Labour get criticised as a triumph for style over substance. I know that being English we immediately look for bad things to say about everything, and I wish I could say this is a joy of a design but it's not. It falls into a category where things need to be given an explanation for why they're there because it isn't self-evident. There's a heart there, and a "V" shape and something that looks quite like a fried egg. But people will probably see this as a running man, and they're not going to look at the explanation underneath and and see it as an individual voting with their head and their heart.

Labour is one of the strongest brands around at the moment and you have to ask yourself do they need a second logo as well as the rose? To sign Labour off with something that isn't the rose implies that you're changing something about Labour. But nothing has really changed within the party to warrant a different logo. The rose is real. When we designed it it had some sort of generosity of spirit. Everybody knew what it was. You give somebody a rose because you care for them. It had something both brave and ordinary about it. Whereas this comes from the land of graphic design and has no recognisable meaning. Especially if they're keeping the rose as well. To have two symbols is ridiculous. They should just have refreshed the rose and the typeface instead.

webTitle: 3G cost puts Orange acquisitions on hold

fields.headline: 3G cost puts Orange acquisitions on hold
fields.trailText: A senior executive at France Télécom yesterday indicated that mobile phone subsidiary Orange will have to keep its acquisition plans on hold - at least for a few months.
fields.body:
A senior executive at France Télécom yesterday indicated that mobile phone subsidiary Orange will have to keep its acquisition plans on hold - at least for a few months.

Chief financial officer Jean-Louis Vinciguerra said the group was keen to keep its "single A" credit rating and so would be looking to cut debt.

"We wish to reduce our debt, so we do not envisage any significant acquisitions by Orange in the months to come," Mr Vinciguerra said yesterday.

Orange is in the midst of an initial public offering which will see up to 15% of the shares offered to investors. As well as the proceeds from the float France Télécom is looking to sell non-core assets - from its 10% stake in Sprint to part of its property portfolio, which could raise up to Euro15bn (£9.5bn.)

With other telecoms companies, France Télécom has seen its debt levels soar because of the costof third generation mobile phone networks.

Yesterday it demonstrated that the costs of 3G are not confined to acquiring licences. It said that rolling out 3G networks would cost Orange Euro 8bn over the three years from 2001 - two thirds of the planned capital spending over the period. The Euro 8bn excludes spending on 3G networks in Germany and Italy, where France Télécom is a minority shareholder in the companies which hold the licences.

The group also provided further details of a Euro 3.3bn bond issue which has been launched just ahead of the IPO. The bonds, which will be convertible into Orange shares, are being priced at a premium to the IPO price. "The convertible bond issue will give us access to an investor base complementary to those attracted by the Orange share issue, and will allow us to divest some of our holding at a premium to the issue price," said Mr Vinciguerra.

 One 2 One claimed yesterday to be the first mobile phone company to offer a flat rate phone service. The new Precept Max tariff will offer unlimited, free landline calls and One2One mobiles at any time for £75 a month.

Researchers say the inability to call other networks, such as Vodafone, will make it unappealing to many higher spending users. Precept Max is also out of reach of most consumers, who spend an average of £21 a month on their mobile, according to Market & Opinion Research International, the research company that produces Oftel's consumer use study.
