webTitle: Harry Pearson on players with a conscience

fields.headline: Playmaker seeing the trees for the woodwork
fields.trailText: There is mounting evidence that footballers are rapidly replacing actors and rock stars as the conscience of mankind.
fields.body:
Christian Karembeu told this newspaper on Saturday that at Middlesbrough he talks to the young players and tries to educate them about the environment. "We have destroyed so much," he said, "we have to give something back."

The look of concern etched on the fresh faces of Andy Campbell, Carlos Marinelli and company as they learn about the effect that the draining of Britain's wetlands is having on the corncrake can be imagined.

Refreshing though they were, the France midfielder's comments should not have taken anyone by surprise. For there is mounting evidence that footballers are rapidly replacing actors and rock stars as the conscience of mankind.

At one time when football folk were asked to name the person they would most like to meet they invariably answered "Raquel Welch". (Well, most did. In a Shoot questionnaire Malcolm Allison once controversially opted for Enoch Powell - not, I am sure, for political reasons but more likely because he shared with the bug-eyed Unionist a passion for the limpid verse of A E Housman).

Nowadays they are more likely to plump for the Dalai Lama or Nelson Mandela. No wonder the game was recently nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.

There have, of course, always been politically motivated players. For example, Dominique Rocheteau, who played for France in the World Cup finals in 1982 and 1986, was a Trotskyite, and Paul Breitner juggled defensive duties for Germany with Maoism.

But, if one man could be credited with inspiring the current trend towards really engaging with the important issues of the day, it is surely Jürgen Klinsmann. The former Tottenham striker is very much football's Jane Fonda, albeit with a Terry Griffiths haircut.

A decade ago while playing for Internazionale he told the Italian press that he was considering quitting the game at 26. "How can I think about football," he remarked ruefully, "when such terrible things are happening to the Brazilian rainforests?"

Selflessly, however, the German forward battled on for another eight seasons, missing the occasional open goal or lucrative contract only when his mind was momentarily on the ozone layer.

Klinsmann's words were the catalyst for change. Soon Roberto Baggio was calling on China to withdraw from Tibet and Robbie Fowler demonstrating his support for the sacked Liverpool dockworkers.

Emmanuel Petit, meanwhile, protested about the amount of coverage that was devoted to the question of whether he spat at John Hartson or not by saying, "With the war in Chechnya going on, I think there are better things to do".

To some Petit's complaints about press obsession with trivia may have seemed a trifle rich coming from someone who divided his time between kicking a ball around and running a clothes shop.

But anyone who, as a teenager, ever rebuked his parents with the words "How can you get so worked up about my room being untidy when there are kids living in sewers in Rio de Janeiro?" will have recognised the truth and sincerity of it.

If only those who run our media had heeded the Frenchman's words, people would have been able to lament, "You can see how low down on the West's priorities El Salvador is these days, the BBC have sent Tony Gubba."

And we would have been able to savour the prospect of Alan Green being dispatched to Grozny, a job which would surely have been most suited to a man of his uncompromising views.

"And I'm afraid that is just another terrible, terrible decision by the UN. I don't like to sound like I'm obsessed, folks, but we've seen troops deployed in Kosovo, the Gulf and East Timor and nothing here at all. I mean, are we wrong to expect anything like consistency, Mark Lawrenson?"

"Or even a bit of common sense, Alan. I mean, at the minute it's a case of six or two threes and I'm afraid mad despots, brutal dictators and vengeful terror organisations just have absolutely no idea where they stand."

Around the same time that Klinsmann was voicing his worries about deforestation, British actors were protesting about the erection of a new office block on the site of the original Globe Theatre. After the work put in by the likes of Petit and Karembeu it is clear that, when the demolition crews finally move in on Wembley in a decade or so, something similar will happen.

They will not be met by indifference but by scores of earnest young players linking arms and attempting to turn back the bulldozers with an impassioned reading of Desmond Hackett's report on the 1958 FA Cup final between Bolton Wanderers and Manchester United.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

After the work put in by the likes of Petit and Karembeu it is clear that, when the demolition crews finally move in on Wembley in a decade or so, something similar will happen. webTitle: Technology makes skiving easier

fields.headline: The way we work
fields.standfirst:
We thought technology would enslave us. Actually, it makes skiving much easier

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: We thought technology would enslave us. Actually, it makes skiving much easier
fields.body:
The Roman emperor Vespasian, while rebuilding his fire-ruined capital, was presented with a design for a lifting machine that would replace unskilled labourers. He prohibited its production, explaining: "I must feed my poor."

Technological advances have always threatened jobs: just look at what the combine did to agricultural employment. A Luddite before Ludd, Vespasian put the short-term protection of lower-paid workers before "progress". Today, of course, computers are held responsible for the loss of jobs. Jeremy Rifkin, in his book, The End of Work, warned that information technology could create massive joblessness. While former farm workers could go to the factory, and displaced factory workers could find a home in the office, there is nowhere, Rifkin reckoned, for displaced service-sector workers to go.

With US employment levels at a record high, the inaccuracy of Rifkin's forecast, made just six years ago, seems clear. Capitalism stands accused of many crimes, but its capacity to keep creating demand, which people have to be employed to meet, seems limitless.

The real question is not whether computers will end work - but how they will change it. Do they really make us more efficient? The blistering pace of productivity growth has been attributed to the widespread use of computer technology. Even Alan Greenspan says this, so it must be true. But new analysis of the effect of computers on productivity in 400 large US companies shows that is only half the story.

Firms which introduced computerised systems alongside opportunities for employees to get involved - self-managing teams, devolved decision-making - ended up with a sharp rise in output per head. But the ones which simply stuck computers on desktops, with no change in organisational structure, were, on average, less productive than firms which hadn't installed computers at all. Bosses would have been economically better off standing in the car park, tearing up £50 notes. The study proves the old truth about technology: it's what you do with it that counts.

In one recent global survey, three-quarters of respondents said computers had made their lives better, with just 4% believing they had made them worse. But in the same survey, one in 10 said that advances in computer and internet technology had enabled them "to work more". This is a concern for many people - laptops, the internet and mobile phones have the potential to become the electronic tags of the modern employee. Joanne Ciulla, author of The Working Life, warns that information technology "potentially makes us 24-hours-a-day, 365-days-a-year employees".

Well, yes, it does. But it also makes us, potentially, 24-hours-a-day, 365-days-a-year non-employees, too. It allows us to work as we wish. Perhaps at a steady pace, perhaps in intense bursts followed by long walks in the park. We can use our desktop or laptop computers as much for leisure as for work: the great thing about post-industrial skiving is that it looks exactly the same as post-industrial working.

Smart companies have realised this and stopped trying to control computer use. There is no point banning personal emailing. Staff are increasingly expected to work outside "normal" hours, and they should be allowed to play within them in exchange. When computers are used creatively, they can loosen up rusting systems and allow all of us to work more flexibly and humanely. But it's not up to the computer. It is up to us.

Networks are the production lines of the new economy. Keeping in touch with people is mission-critical. But there are only so many hours in the day, so new forms of meeting are being invented - and the latest is the Lunch That Is Never Eaten.

It works like this: two people agree to have lunch and set a date. They then take it in turns to cancel - by email, of course - and the lunch is indefinitely pushed back. (A fair score on cancellations is vital.) If the two meet at a social function, they can say, honestly: "Don't we have a date for lunch soon? Great." They remain connected without ever needing to break bread together. Result: the ultimate in postmodern, time-efficient schmoozing. Anyone fancy lunch?

Richard Reeves (rreeves@indsoc.co.uk) writes fortnightly. Email Work:work@theguardian.com. For more workplace news and features, visit www.theguardian.com/work.

webTitle: A template for the ideal office

fields.headline: Village people
fields.standfirst:
What have the bustling streets and parks of a 60s New York neighbourhood got to do with the modern workplace? They could be a template for the ideal office, writes Malcolm Gladwell

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: What have the bustling streets and parks of a 60s New York neighbourhood got to do with the modern workplace? They could be a template for the ideal office, writes Malcolm Gladwell.
fields.body:
In her 1961 masterpiece, The Death and Life of Great American Cities, Jane Jacobs described Hudson Street, where she lived in Greenwich Village, New York. She loved it. There was Mr Slube at the cigar store and Mr Lacey, the locksmith, and Bernie, the sweetshop owner, who, during a typical day, supervised the children crossing the street, lent an umbrella or a dollar to a customer and "lectured two youngsters who asked for cigarettes". The street had "bundles and packages, zigzagging from the drug store to the fruit stand and back over to the butcher's," and "teenagers, all dressed up, are pausing to ask if their slips show or their collars look right". It was, she said, an urban ballet.

The miracle of Hudson Street, according to Jacobs, was created by the particular configuration of the streets and buildings. She argued that when a neighbourhood is oriented toward the street, when pavements are used for socialising and play and commerce, the users of that street are transformed by the resulting stimulation: they form relationships and casual contacts they would never have otherwise.

But to reread Death and Life today is to be struck by how the intervening years have given her arguments a new relevance. Who, after all, has a direct interest in creating diverse, vital spaces that foster creativity and serendipity? Employers do. Forty years after its publication, Death and Life has been reborn as a primer on workplace design.

Today, if you visit the technology companies of Silicon Valley, or the media companies of Manhattan, you'll find that secluded private offices have been replaced by busy public spaces, open-plan areas without walls, executives next to the newest arrivals. The hush of the traditional office has been supplanted by something much closer to the noisy, bustling ballet of Hudson Street.

When employees sit chained to their desks, an office is not functioning as it should. As one study after another has demonstrated, the best ideas in any workplace arise out of casual contacts among different groups within the same company. If you are designing widgets for Acme.com, the most useful insights are likely to come from someone in customer service, who hears firsthand what customers have to say about them, or from someone in marketing, who has wrestled with the problem of how to explain widgets to new users.

The catch is that getting people in an office to bump into people from another department is not that easy. As Thomas Allen, a researcher at MIT, concluded after a decade-long study, the likelihood of any two people communicating drops off dramatically as the distance between their desks increases: we are four times as likely to communicate with someone 6ft away as with someone 60ft away. And people seated more than 75ft apart hardly talk at all.

The task of the office, then, is to invite a particular kind of social interaction - the casual, non-threatening encounter that makes it easy for relative strangers to talk to each other: in short, the sort of social milieu Jacobs found in Greenwich Village.

Imagine a classic big-city office tower. The centre part of every floor is given over to the guts of the building: lifts, bathrooms, electrical and plumbing systems. Around the core are cubicles and interior offices, for support staff and lower management. And around the edges, against the windows, are rows of offices for senior staff.

Research into office communication tells us there is almost no worse way to lay out an office. The executives in corner offices will seldom bump into each other. Indeed, stringing the exterior offices out along the windows guarantees very few people are within the critical 60ft radius of those offices. You need to put the most valuable staff members in the centre, or, even better, put all places where people congregate in the centre, so they can draw from as many disparate parts of the company as possible.

Two years ago, the advertising agency TBWA/Chiat/Day moved into new offices in Los Angeles, creating an almost perfect embodiment of Jacobsian principles of community. The agency is in a huge old warehouse, three storeys high and the size of three football fields. It is informally known as Advertising City, and that is what it is: a kind of artfully constructed urban neighbourhood. The floor is bisected by a central corridor called Main Street, and in the centre of the room is an open space, with cafe tables and a stand of ficus trees, called Central Park. There's a basketball court, a games room and a bar. Most of the employees are in snug workstations known as nests, and the nests are grouped together in areas that radiate from Main Street like Paris arrondissements.

The top executives are situated in the middle of the room. The desk of the chairman and creative director of the company looks out on Central Park. Sprinkled throughout the building are meeting rooms and project areas and nooks where employees can closet themselves. Part of the building is elevated above the main floor on a mezzanine, and if you stand there and watch the people wander about with their portable phones, sit and chat in Central Park, and play basketball in the gym, and you feel on your shoulders the sun from the skylights and listen to the gentle buzz of human activity, it is quite possible to forget that you are looking at an office.

A vital community, in Jacobs's view, also needs a certain kind of person who can bind together the varied elements of street life. Offices are no different. In fact, office designers have become increasingly interested in identifying and encouraging public characters. One of the pioneers of this approach is Karen Stephenson, who runs a New York-based consulting company called Netform. She goes into a company - her clients include JP Morgan, the LA police department and IBM - and distributes a questionnaire asking employees about the people they have contact with. Whom do you like to spend time with? Whom do you talk to about new ideas? Every name in the company becomes a dot on a graph, and Stephenson draws lines between all those who have regular contact with each other.

She likens her graphs to x-rays, and her role to that of a radiologist. What she's depicting is the firm's invisible inner mechanisms, the relationships, networks and patterns of trust that arise as people work together over time, and that are hidden beneath the organisation chart.

Once, for example, Stephenson was doing an "x-ray" of an agency that was mostly female, and found that new staffers and male staffers were profoundly isolated, communicating with the rest of the organisation through only a handful of women.

"I couldn't see what tied the women together, and why the men were talking only to these women," Stephenson recalls. "Nor could the president of the organisation. But finally, she asked me to read the names again, and I could hear her stop, and she said, 'My God, I know what it is. All those women are smokers'." The x- ray revealed that the men were trying to gain access and influence by hanging out in the smoking area with some of the more senior women.

What Stephenson's x-rays do best, though, is tell you who the public characters are. In every network there are always one or two people with connections to many more people than anyone else. Stephenson calls them "hubs", and on her charts lines radiate out from them like spokes on a wheel. A few others are what Stephenson calls "gatekeepers": they control access to critical people, and link together a strategic few disparate groups. Finally, there are people with lots of indirect links to other people - who are part of all sorts of networks without necessarily being in the centre of them. Stephenson calls those people "pulsetakers".

"You want to place hubs at the centre," says Joyce Bromberg, the director of space planning at Steelcase, the giant manufacturer of office equipment. Stephenson is helping redesign its headquarters in Michigan. "These are the ones other people go to in order to get information. Give them an environment that allows access. Gatekeepers represent the fit between groups. They transmit ideas. They are brokers, so you might want to put them at the perimeter and give them front porches [areas adjoining the workspace where you might put tables and chairs]. As for pulsetakers, they are the roamers. Rather than give them one fixed work location, give them a series of touchdown spots where you want them to stop and talk, so enabling their meandering."

The point of the new offices is to compel us to behave and socialise in ways that we otherwise would not - to overcome our initial inclination to be office suburbanites. But, in all the studies of the new workplaces, the reservations that employees have about a more social environment tend to diminish once they try it. Jacobs knew the virtues of Greenwich Village because she lived there. What she couldn't know was that her ideas about community would ultimately make more sense in the workplace.

 A longer version of this article appeared in the New Yorker.

webTitle: Pop review: Fingathing

fields.headline: Fingathing
fields.standfirst:
Roadhouse, Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Roadhouse, Manchester

Rating: ****
fields.body:
Fingathing - hip-hop scratch DJ Peter Parker (Dan Baxter) and the classically trained double-bassist Sneaky (Simon Houghton) - started life as part of Rae and Christian's touring band. Their rehearsal improvisations won them showcase slots. Their staccato interludes of dirty, scratch 'n' bass funk were a visceral counter to Rae and Christian's smooth street soul but, people assumed, a limited novelty.

In the last year, however, Manchester's Fingathing have produced a madcap debut album, The Main Event (informed by their love of Worldwide Wrestling Federation, cartoons, computer games and eccentrics from Frank Zappa to Q-Bert) and invented a powerful, and surprisingly musical, live show. With their raw sound augmented by bare looped beats and loopier samples, they have access to all low-end sonics and every sound committed to vinyl. But essentially Fingathing still rock or fold on Parker's razor-sharp scratching and Sneaky's nimble bass runs.

They don't get off to a great start. Late-night club crowds just want to dance. Several grow restless and one or two heckle, in the lengthy silence that follows the in-house MC and Parker's introductory rhetoric. It is testament to Fingathing's instant, addictive sound that moments later even stony-faced hip-hop heads are dancing. Or at least nodding vigorously. The number Ffathead reaches an almost jungle tempo. It is dark, edgy stuff, and perfect for the Roadhouse's low ceiling and high humidity.

Then Fingathing open up. Big Kid is as gloriously naive as Coldcut's early cut'n'paste pieces, while You Fly Me is almost mournful, tropical lounge jazz. Head to Head reconciles their competing influences perfectly: feisty scratching and iron beats create a slammin' foundation for Sneaky's doomy scrapes and strange shards of sound.

There is little in the way of spectacle. Sneaky can hardly start pogoing with his double bass, and working Chris Drury's illustrations (his wrestling freaks decorate Fingathing's sleeves) into the show, as is planned, will sharpen their surreal edge. And a more experienced and ebullient MC would ratchet up excitement between songs, and keep the crowd focused.

As the final tune, Ffling, hits promised "warp speed", such quibbling seems churlish. Its scratch-funk punches are riotous, irresistible and wholly original. Fingathing virgins grin broadly at one another, breathless and a little bemused.

Fingathing play the Atrium, Leeds (0113 242 6116), on Thursday, then tour.

webTitle: Jazz review: Clark Tracey New Quintet

fields.headline: Clark Tracey New Quintet
fields.standfirst:
Sports Club, Wakefield
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Sports Club, Wakefield

Rating: ***
fields.body:
As a drummer, Clark Tracey is total jazz. That whole tedious "less is more" ethos obviously cuts no ice with him. It is possible to pick out one or two funk and maybe even rock motifs in his playing, but they are so deeply entwined inside endless threads of polyrhythmic exploration that you would need laser technology to cut them out.

Once in the performance Tracey actually managed to play an entire half bar using only one groove pattern, but then his roaming technique hijacked his limbs and transported him away into unimagined realms. It was fun to watch, if a little tiring.

The rest of his fresh-faced quintet struggled to keep up. This is a new band and a distinctly low-profile tour, but there was clearly lots of promising talent on display, and a general sense of benevolent pride emanating from behind the master's drum kit.

Each performer had one of their own compositions played by the group. Compared with some of the standards on offer, such as Miles Davis's expansive, other-worldly Eighty One, several of the original works lacked scope and a sense of wonder. Bassist Peter Billington's contribution was like an ode to disappointment and loneliness, while pieces by saxophonist Simon Allen and trumpet player Mark Armstrong evoked images of stubborn knots being picked at, rather than doors being kicked down. Still, these chaps are young - Allen is called "The Foetus" by his benefactor - and for Clarke this new quintet is clearly an exercise in long-term seed nurturing.

On loan from her own quartet, pianist Zoë Rahman maintained an enigmatic, ethereal presence. It is possible to pick out one or two funk and maybe even rock motifs in his playing, but they are so deeply entwined inside endless threads of polyrhythmic exploration that you would need laser technology to cut them out. Once in the performance Tracey actually managed to play an entire half bar using only one groove pattern, but then his roaming technique hijacked his limbs and transported him away into unimagined realms. It was fun to watch, if a little tiring. The rest of his fresh-faced quintet struggled to keep up. webTitle: Classical review: Salonen makes his Mahler mark

fields.headline: Salonen makes his Mahler mark
fields.standfirst:
LPO/Salonen
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
LPO/Salonen
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
Mahler's Third Symphony is arguably classical music's most ambitious philosophical statement. At once pantheistic and optimistic in its approach, it strives to portray both the universe in its entirety and the spiritual forces that drive it.

It opens depicting the emergence of life from raw matter, and it closes in rapt contemplation of the timelessness of divinity. In between come the mutable, stratified phenomena of nature, while at its centre lies Mahler's Nietzschean vision of man as an alienated creature, querulously questioning the meaning of his own existence.

For all its popularity, though, great performances are rare. Capturing the requisite sense of diversity within unity is beyond all but the greatest conductors; all too frequently we are presented with an episodic sprawl. Esa-Pekka Salonen's task was doubly difficult on this occasion. Even though he is well known to London audiences, this was, surprisingly, his London Philharmonic Orchestra debut, undertaken at extremely short notice to replace Bernard Haitink - widely regarded as the work's definitive interpreter - who was indisposed because of a shoulder injury. Salonen made his British debut with the Third in 1983, but he is not an established Mahlerian - though that view may have to be revised after this remarkable performance.

His interpretation is the antithesis of Haitink's, though equally powerful. It is also equally valid. Haitink magisterially asserts spiritual certainty from the beginning, retroactively illuminating the whole score with the vision of God with which it closes. Salonen, in contrast, plunges excitedly into a questioning journey during which the beatific vision only gradually becomes apparent. With the LPO playing as if their lives depended on it, he gleefully unleashes a veritable sonic cyclone in the first movement, relishing its multiplicity of thematic and harmonic clashes. The impression is less of life gradually taking shape than of contrasting patterns of creative convulsion and exhaustion. Just before the movement's close, however, we have an intimation of what is to come; as the storm abates, time stands still and we have a brief glimpse of eternity.

Moments of genuine transcendence intrude with ever increasing frequency upon the swirl of the subsequent sections, until he reaches the famous Nietzsche setting, where we are taken by surprise. Most conductors are meditative at this point; Salonen fills the section with a troubled sensuousness. The undulating phrases have a queasy uncertainty. The string solos, expressing man's longing for joy, curl upwards with a tremulous sensuality. The alto soloist, Anne Larsson, is declamatory rather than contemplative. Salonen allows the finale to unwind slowly out of a vast silence, affirmatively answering the questions that the rest of the performance has posed.

There are doubtless some who might find Salonen's approach idiosyncratic, but it is unquestionably overwhelming. The standing ovation that followed was testament to its impact.

webTitle: Theatre review:  Naked Justice

fields.headline: Court jester Phillips boosts Mortimer's drama
fields.trailText:
Naked Justice
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds

Rating: ***
fields.body:
Who judges the judges? Shakespeare asked the question in Measure for Measure. And the same query lies at the heart of John Mortimer's new play, a pleasantly old-fashioned mixture of moral debate and courtroom drama buoyed up by a star performance from Leslie Phillips.

Mortimer interweaves two apparently disparate stories. Byron, a black 17-year-old, is accused, on the basis of a suspiciously full confession, of murdering his mother's lover. Meanwhile three High Court judges - the staid Keith, the frisky Elspeth and the amiably liberal Fred - are confined together in a safe provincial house while they execute the local law. Byron's case is being tried before the stern, unbending, Angelo-like Keith. But when Elspeth invites an accountant back to dinner one night, it transpires that he has a blackmailing stranglehold over this most upright judge.

Mortimer understands well the nooks and crannies of the law and the gap between its presumed impartiality and the fallibility of its executants. He not only shows Byron's odious prosecutor making a clumsy pass at his female opponent over a chummy, eve-of-case dinner; he also, in the play's best scenes, shows the well-intentioned Fred putting the screws on the supposedly incorruptible Keith in the interests of natural justice. The law, Mortimer implies, will always be an imperfect instrument as long as it is in the hands of flawed, susceptible human beings.

This humane and sympathetic play is also, however, flawed. We never learn enough about the circumstantial details of Byron's alleged crime to make up our minds about his innocence or guilt; you feel Mortimer possibly knows less about black teenagers than he does about High Court judges. His admirable desire to entertain also overcomes his representation of the sometimes wearisome legal process. Revealingly, he remarks in the programme: "You can't afford to have a second of boredom in thetheatre or the whole thing collapses". But Hamlet, Faust, Peer Gynt, all great plays, have their moments of ennui: boredom is the price you pay for excavation of the truth.

No danger of boredom here, however. Certainly not while Leslie Phillips as the bumbling Fred is putting the case for judicial lenience. Phillips fluffs his lines and flirts with the audience but he has the instinctive timing of the born comic and can even get a huge laugh from the word "blimey", which, according to Ackroyd's London, is "fading out of discourse". Nicholas Jones as the hollow pillar of the law, Anna Carteret as the sex-hungry Elspeth and Geraldine Alexander as the harrassed defence counsel for Byron lend firm support in Christopher Morahan's well-drilled production .

And if the play appeals to our own sense of tolerance, it is because Mortimer himself is clearly on the side of the angels and against the judicial Angelos.

Until February 24. Box office: 0113-213 7700.

webTitle: Pop review: The Strokes

fields.headline: The Strokes
fields.standfirst:
Astoria, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Astoria, London

Rating: ****
fields.body:
The Strokes have just one single under their skinny belts, and this appearance - third rung on an NME Brats show ladder - is their first London gig, but they are already commanding a lot of attention. And as they lurch, pose and strut, they look very good indeed.

The five young Italian-Americans, straight outta Manhattan, refuse to be absorbed into the current wave of American bands washing up on our shores, yet remain absolutely US of A. They have looked back to the good old days of bad old CBGBs, when New York City refined punk and gave its sneer a polished cool. Iggy was king, Debbie was queen and excitement was in the air and on the stage. And tonight that excitement is back.

From the first thud of the nagging drum beat of debut single The Modern Age, the Strokes are clearly out to rock. Julian Casablancas, dressed in immaculate new-wave chic with his white shirt, dark tie and red Converse trainers, is a classy geek, the microphone held tightly to his lips as his deep, Jim Morrison-like voice resonates, one arm nonchalantly resting on the mike stand propping him up. Casablancas preens as the squiggly guitar of Albert Hammond Jnr kicks in, his mad mass of curly hair moving to a rhythm of its own as his playing gets speedier.

It's Chuck Berry to a Velvet Underground backing track, a simple and blistering formula that finishes abruptly after all of three minutes.

While never straying from sublime punk-pop territory, each song has something special, one moment that distinguishes it from what has come before. It could be the pulsing guitar solo of the catchy Last Nite, or Casablancas shouting "Alright, stop!" mid-way through New York City Cops, allowing the demented but fluid movements of Fabrizio Moretti on drums to be witnessed without distractions.

Their confidence is overwhelming. Casablancas hardly feels the need to introduce their songs. "I wanna thank everyone who's been so nice to us since we came to England," he drawls. "I have a cold, but it's fine."

It's more than that. It's great. From the joyful toe-bopping of guitarist and Clem Burke lookalike Nick Valensis to the tasteful Television and Stooges overtones, the Strokes are a revelation.

And as Hammond Jnr sinks to his knees, his guitar playing frenetic, it's clear the Strokes won't be supporting anyone for very long.

The Strokes play the Monarch, London NW1 (020-7916 1049), tomorrow.

webTitle: Classical review: The Creation

fields.headline: The Creation
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester

Rating: **
fields.body:
The Creation is heard and recorded less often today than some of Haydn's symphonies, quartets and concertos. But it is the one work of his that has remained consistently in the repertory from the day it was first performed.

Composed by Haydn in the astonishing last decade of his life, when he threw most of his energy into choral music, it glows from end to end with a serene optimism about the beauty of the world and the glory of human life.

Although John Milton's Paradise Lost was among his literary sources, Adam and Eve are portrayed without the slightest hint of the fall that is to come.

None of Haydn's operas has ever made it to the repertory, partly because none of them contains the musically fuelled dramatic tension that opera needs. So The Creation was the perfect medium for him: all narrative, interspersed with stirring choruses that see humanity in the unshadowed positive light of the late 18th century.

The difficulty in a performance is to find some way of giving shape and tension to almost two hours of this optimism. Allow it to become unremitting prettiness and you are sunk.

Harry Christophers conducted a performance that risked that danger in several ways. The choice of the BBC Singers for the chorus was the first risk. Technically they present no risk at all: one feels that nothing can go wrong with such a superb group. But though their 34 voices are so focused that they can produce the volume of a choir twice the size, they still lacked the sheer wall of sound that Haydn's massive choruses demand. Perhaps they would have made a greater impact if Christophers had used a smaller string section.

The BBC Philharmonic were on excellent form and produced some gloriously refined playing. If rather more details went awry than usual, that may have resulted from unclear direction.

In general it was a performance that lacked distinctions between loud and soft: that was the second risk and probably the reason that the warm glow of the music lost its momentum towards the end.

The soloists were led by Nancy Argenta's marvellously life-enhancing soprano: hers is a voice ideally built for Haydn's flowing lines and glittering high notes, her every sound so enticing that one just wallowed in its beauty. William Kendall, replacing an indisposed John Mark Ainsley, presented the tenor solos with an excellent sense of the style and a fine range of colour. But it was, as so often, Michael George who stole the show: his glorious bass voice was complemented by an unmatched clarity of diction and a rare ability to inject dramatic power into music that can so easily become anodyne.

webTitle: When data is unprotected

fields.headline: When data is unprotected
fields.trailText: 6 Februrary: Can a manager keep personal information about an employee and then use it against them?
fields.body:
The problem

If a manager keeps personal information about an employee and then uses it is against that employee in a formal hearing is he breaking any kind of data protection act? (This information is kept as the manager's own personal notes in his home, not on formal headed paper.)

The solution

I doubt it very much. I don't think there is any law that says employment notes should be made on headed paper.

It sounds like you are having problems at work and are undergoing disciplinary proceedings. I suggest that you seek advice on the whole matter from either your union or ACAS. You should also be sure to consult the company handbook that your employer should produce on disciplinary hearings.

In general terms, all workers should assume that anything they say or do at any time in the presence of their boss (or colleagues) could be used against them in the future. So, for example, inappropriate behaviour at the office party, or even at the local pub after work, could be noted and used to build a case against you. Of course, you have the right to query such evidence and question its accuracy - either at a disciplinary hearing, or even at an industrial tribunal. But, you will really need advice on your specific case so the sooner you seek it, the better.


 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

webTitle: Lloyds and Abbey remain at odds

fields.headline: Lloyds and Abbey remain at odds
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: High level talks between executives of Abbey National and Lloyds TSB last night failed to bring the two sides together, sources said.
fields.body:
High level talks between executives of Abbey National and Lloyds TSB last night failed to bring the two sides together, sources said.

The chairman and the chief executives of the banks met to discuss Lloyds approach as the government cleared Abbey's preferred deal - a merger with Bank of Scotland - on competition grounds.

"The decision removes any uncertainty in respect of this merger," Abbey National and BoS said last night.

Competition clearance is yet to be received for Lloyds TSB's takeover bid for Abbey National, regarded as more contentious by some sources as the combined bank would boast a share of the current account market of more than 25%.

A crucial meeting of the panel, which helps form the advice given to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is expected to be held tomorrow to consider the implications of the Lloyds TSB and Abbey National combination. But a decision need not be made public for a further two weeks.

Until the result of the competition authorities' initial investigation is known, little progress is expected in the current three-way stand off.

Yesterday, Lloyds TSB described the meeting with Abbey National chief executive Ian Harley and his chairman Lord Tugendhat as "courteous and amicable".

It is understood that the pair did not immediately reject the Lloyds TSB bid, which was formally tabled last week.

They are now expected to discuss the bid with members of their senior executive team and members of the board but one City source last night predicted that another rebuttal of the approach - first made public more than 90 days ago - was to be expected.

The meeting, at the home of the Lloyds TSB chief executive Peter Ellwood, coincides with a series of top-level meetings between the Lloyds management and institutional shareholders in Abbey to try to win their support for the deal.

webTitle: Classical review: Thomas Hampson

fields.headline: Thomas Hampson
fields.standfirst:
Royal Opera House, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Royal Opera House, London

Rating: ****
fields.body:
Thomas Hampson has been the most high-profile, eloquent exponent of American song in recent times. It's difficult to think of any other singer who could pack out the Royal Opera House with a programme half-full of songs, and in some cases composers, that are little known this side of the Atlantic.

Hampson is a charismatic performer, even if the veneer at times can seem a bit too carefully polished. He is also one of the few singers able to make the vast interior of the Opera House seem an intimate recital venue. His singing came across the auditorium directly and easily, his words clear in both German and English.

The novelties were left for the second half, the first being made up of songs by Schubert and Mahler - staple recital fare, yet well chosen, as the pervading themes of war and nostalgia in these well-worn miniatures revealed something of where the American songs had grown from.

The first six were selected from Schubert's Schwanengesang. After the focused, arresting anger of Der Atlas, pianist Wolfram Rieger changed the mood to one of absolute stillness for Ihr Bild, while in Das Fischermädchen Hampson proved, with his agile and surprisingly delicate ornamentation, that his voice is not too cumbersome an instrument for Schubert's lighter Lieder. That done, the final song of the group, Der Doppelganger, was an apt opportunity to demonstrate the kind of sustained power that he uses so effectively.

It was a more animated Hampson who returned for five songs from Mahler's Das Knaben Wunderhorn, two of them tongue-in-cheek, all but one with a martial theme. Rieger, always a sensitive accompanist, played out the fanfares snappily, his bright piano interludes adding colour to the last song, the epic Revelge.

Hampson is seemingly happiest when charming the audience in their own language, and he relaxed into his native repertoire after the interval. He began with five settings of poetry by Walt Whitman. The martial piano music of Henry T Burleigh's Ethiopia, saluting the colours, took us briefly back to the world of the more substantial Mahler songs. But the most effective setting was not by a native American; Hindemith's version of Sing On There in the Swamp, with its atmospheric, chiming accompaniment and sinuous vocal lines, was written after he emigrated from war-torn Germany.

The art and folk songs that finished the concert were more pared down, with the exception of Stephen White's overblown arrangment of Shenandoah. Hampson's all-American delivery didn't seem entirely sincere when backed by the Opera House's plush velvet curtains - but still, nobody else sings this repertoire quite so persuasively.

webTitle: See you in court

fields.headline: See you in court
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Horrible sense of déjà vu about this week's case. Man has many days off ill for a variety of ailments. Employer issues warning. Man has further days off ill. Further warnings until man is dismissed. In nine cases out of 10, the day starts with the applicant saying to you in baffled tones in the waiting room , "but they were all genuine illnesses", and finishes with the tribuna l chair saying: "The employer was entitled to say enough was enough."
fields.body:
Horrible sense of déjà vu about this week's case. Man has many days off ill for a variety of ailments. Employer issues warning. Man has further days off ill. Further warnings until man is dismissed. In nine cases out of 10, the day starts with the applicant saying to you in baffled tones in the waiting room , "but they were all genuine illnesses", and finishes with the tribuna l chair saying: "The employer was entitled to say enough was enough."

So I suggest gently to Bob that the small offer made by the employer to settle the case might be an attractive one. He shakes his head: "I hear what you are saying. But I have to think what a gladiator would do."

"Eh?"

"I saw it on Richard and Judy. It's a kind of therapy to build self-esteem and confidence. You have to watch the film Gladiator and think how he would act in situations you find in your own life. Russell Crowe would have fought this case."

It crosses my mind to say that watching daytime TV is no path to self-esteem and confidence, but I see Bob is acting in the glow of a self-help epiphany and don't have the heart. In we go to fight the case.

I am cross-examining dutifully when I see something glinting in a blob of sunlight on the table, between my papers and those of my solicitor. At first I fail to recognise it. But no: it is definitely a pubic hair. There is no mistaking it. It is too architectural to be a head hair, articulated and tapering like a spider's leg.

My solicitor is also transfixed by it. Could it have escaped from his papers - perhaps he was reading them in bed and it hitched a lift from his sheets? But his hair is black, and it is not mine for similar reasons. How did it get here?

Chairman: "Um, Ms Counsel - is there a problem?" I realise my cross-examination has slowed to a halt and hastily return to suggesting to the manager in question that he could have sought medical advice about my client's frequent diarrhoea. But every time I turn my head, there is the pube . . .

As predicted, we lose. Bob is forlorn, but not without resources: "What would a gladiator do now? It's hard, as I can't do any of the usual stuff with swords and chariots here."

This might have worried me more if I hadn't been pondering my own small mystery. Perhaps tribunal rooms are bristling with pubes, and I have previously failed to notice them. But why? And how?

 The author is an employment tribunal lawyer.

webTitle: Leader: An inequitable life

fields.headline: An inequitable life
fields.standfirst:
But the Halifax offer may be the answer

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: But the Halifax offer may be the answer.
fields.body:
Never expect courts to provide equitable - or consistent - rulings on social policy. They are neither trained nor structured for such work. They are geared to individual, not collective interests. They are required to focus on petitioners' cases, rather than wider public issues. Hence the excessive damages which the national health service faces - in excess of £2bn annually within a budget of £50bn - to the detriment of patients overall.

Hence the law lords ruling - in contradiction of the high court and appeal court below them - on Equitable Life. In the conflict between 90,000 guaranteed annuity policy holders and 900,0000 "with profits" others, the law lords concluded the former should have their guarantees honoured. In law, a guarantee is a guarantee. In policy terms, it could not be more inequitable. Nine times as many people have had their investment profits frozen for seven months to finance the lucky minority. (We should perhaps add there are Guardian staff in both groups.) Now a belated resolution of the three-year battle looks possible.

Halifax, the UK mortgage bank, announced a £1bn deal to take over the mutual life assurer yesterday. The first half of the deal is firm: £500m to take over Equitable's assets - the fund-management business, its respected 450-strong sales force and highly computerised administrative system. Why is Halifax making such an offer, when 15 companies have looked and walked away? It would double its assets, making buying and selling equities much cheaper, and would mean it was no longer seen as just a mortgage bank.

The other half of the Halifax offer will have to be put to all policyholders - and achieve approval from 70%. It involves "buying out" the promise to the guaranteed policyholders with a one-off payment from the £1.5bn raised last year by freezing the investment growth of other policyholders. The idea is to limit current liabilities by raising the value of guaranteed annuity policies by 20% and then capping them. The dealers hope the guaranteed policyholders will prefer an assured 20% rise in the value of their policies, rather than keep their guarantees that will reduce in value should interest rates and inflation rise. If only Equitable Life had admitted liability of £1.5bn earlier- rather than a mere £50m - perhaps even the law lords would have ruled differently.

webTitle: Equitable deal under fire

fields.headline: Equitable deal under fire
fields.standfirst:
£1bn Halifax rescue offer divides policyholders

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Equitable Life's 1m policy holders were bitterly divided last night over whether to accept Halifax's £1bn offer for the beleaguered mutual insurance group.
fields.body:
Equitable Life's 1m policy holders were bitterly divided last night over whether to accept Halifax's £1bn offer for the beleaguered mutual insurance group.

Two groups of the policyholders, whose agreement is crucial for the full £1bn to be paid, described the agreed deal with Halifax as "derisorily low" while GE Capital of the United States was on the sidelines with the threat of a spoiling offer.

Chris Headdon, chief executive of Equitable, issued a strongly worded rejection of GE's offer, which was received late on Friday, shortly after the Halifax declared its hand.

Insisting that one part of GE's approach - which he refused to describe as an offer - comprised a loan, Mr Headdon said he saw little point in meeting GE Capital.

"This is a binding commitment," Mr Headdon said of the Halifax deal.

GE Capital was understood last night to be reviewing the terms of its offer.

The two-pronged deal with the Halifax, clinched over the weekend, was supported by the financial services authority, the City regulator, which was closely involved in the negotiations. It will allow Equitable to remain mutual and a new president is expected to be appointed in the next few days.

"The transaction offers the prospect of a significant strengthening of the with-profits fund, improving its investment and the likely future returns for policy holders generally," said Sir Howard Davies, the FSA's chairman.

After a series of failed talks with a num ber of potential bidders, including Prudential, Aegon of the Netherlands and AMP of Australia, Halifax was able to reach an agreement with Equitable as a result of the insurer's proposals to buy out the future rights of guaranteed annuity policyholders.

The law lords ruled last summer that this group - 90,000 out of Equitable's 1m policyholders - had been treated unfairly when Equitable cut the bonuses paid to them. Equitable is offering to put £1.5bn in one-off payments into the policies to boost their value by as much as 20%.

Stuart Bayliss, head of the Equitable Life Guaranteed Annuity Rate Action Group, which put forward proposals aimed at capping the insurer's liabilities, described the Halifax deal as good news. Provided it was properly communicated by the insurer, he believed the compromise deal would be backed by "a very substantial majority" of policyholders.

Two other groups, the Equitable Members Action Group and the Equitable Life Members Help Group, accused the insurer of "indecent haste" in agreeing to the deal with Halifax.

James Crosby, chief executive of Halifax, insisted it was a "good deal for everyone involved".

Halifax is paying £500m for the fund management operation, the IT and administration business, and its 400-strong sales force. Another £250m will be paid once policyholders approve the scheme to cap the liabilities for the guaranteed annuities, with the remaining £250m only paid once the Equitable sales force achieves turnover and profitability targets in 2003 and 2004.

The sales force will be rebranded Halifax Equitable and over the coming days will be locked in to Halifax with performance-linked options deals.

As a result of the deal, Halifax's fund management arm, Clerical Medical, will double in size to £60bn and allow Halifax to claim that 50% of its revenues are derived outside its core mortgage and savings business. Halifax hopes this claim will help boost its shares, which yesterday rose 2p to 647p, still below the 774p at which they were given to members when it converted from a building society four years ago.

Mr Crosby estimated that, with Equitable on board, Halifax's profits would be boosted by £120m.

The former Equitable sales force will be selling a new Halifax Equitable brand from the Halifax stable, which also includes Clerical Medical, Halifax Financial Services and St James's Place Capital.

Richard Coleman, banking analyst at ABN Amro, said the deal was "smart" and would work for Halifax even if the new Halifax Equitable brand did not take off.


 How will this deal work?

Halifax is paying up to £1bn into Equitable's with profits fund - £500m immediately, and then up to another £500m, providing a compromise deal involving payments to those people with so-called guaranteed annuities is approved by a majority of policyholders. Halifax will have all the insurer's operations except for its £26bn with profits fund, which will remain independent and member owned but managed by Clerical Medical, the Halifax's pension and fund management arm.

 Will policyholders have to approve the takeover?

No, but policyholders will have to approve a payment of £1.5bn to 90,000 policyholders with guaranteed annuities.

 I have a guaranteed annuity - tell me more.

Equitable set aside £1.5bn last year by cutting its investment growth. The details of how the money will be dis pensed are still being finalised, but probably will be put to the vote this summer. Payments would typically see the value of these policies boosted by 20%.

 What if I don't have a guaranteed annuity?

Equitable's troubles meant it adopted a low risk investment strategy - producing low returns. The Halifax's £1bn payment, combined with a successful compromise deal will mean Equitable's fund managers have more investment freedom, which should eventually mean better investment returns and higher bonuses.

Many experts also point out that the Halifax' Clerical Medical has outperformed Equitable Life in recent years and is top of a short list of alternative pension providers.

 Is Equitable abolishing the 10% penalty on those wishing to transfer funds?

No, this stays "for the moment".
